title: Youngblood v. QualServe Corporation
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John Youngblood, Appellant,
v.
QualServe Corporation f/k/a Food Service Holdings, Inc.,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-140Â Â Â 
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Gary White, III of Columbia, for Appellant.
Mark W. Bakker, J. Theodore Gentry and Alice W.W. Parham, all of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â John Youngblood appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Qualserve Corporation on his breach of employment contract action.Â  We affirm.1
FACTS
Qualserve Corporation2 employed John Youngblood as a warehouse supervisor.Â  Youngblood did not have a written employment contract with Qualserve.Â  In early 2000, Qualserve published an employee manual.Â  
On May 9, 2002, Qualserve terminated Youngblood from his position as warehouse supervisor for failure to follow company procedures.Â  Youngblood then instituted this action, claiming the employee manual created a contract of employment.Â  Qualserve filed a motion for summary judgment, which the trial court granted.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and the inferences which can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. and Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  Where a verdict is not â€œreasonably possible under the facts presented, summary judgment is proper.â€Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Youngblood argues the trial court erred in granting Qualserveâ€™s motion for summary judgment because the language in the employee manual transformed his at-will employment to a contractual employment relationship.Â  We disagree. 
South Carolina recognizes the doctrine of employment at-will.Â  Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).Â  â€œAt-will employment is generally terminable by either party at any time, for any reason or no reason at all.â€Â  Id.Â  Although some exceptions have been recognized, the doctrine of employment at-will remains in South Carolina as a longstanding economic incentive that provides the marketplace its necessary flexibility.Â  Id. at 335, 516 S.E.2d at 925.Â  
Nevertheless, â€œan employer and employee may contractually alter the general rule of employment at-will, thereby restricting the freedom of either party to terminate the employment relationship without incurring liability.â€Â  Baril v. Aiken Regional Med. Ctr., 352 S.C. 271, 281, 573 S.E.2d 830, 836 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  An employee handbook may create such a contract.Â  Small v. Springs, 292 S.C. 481, 485, 357 S.E.2d 452, 455 (1987).Â  The court in Small explained, â€œIt is patently unjust to allow an employer to couch a handbook, bulletin, or other similar material in mandatory terms and then allow him to ignore these very policies as â€˜a gratuitous, nonbinding statement of general policyâ€™ whenever it works to his disadvantage.â€ Id.  
Although the Small court instructed that an employer may continue at-will employment by inserting a conspicuous disclaimer into the handbook, the supreme court subsequently ruled a disclaimer is merely one factor to consider in ascertaining whether the handbook as a whole conveys credible promises that should be enforced.Â  Id.; Fleming v. Borden, 316 S.C. 452, 463, 450 S.E.2d 589, 596 (1994).Â  The entire handbook, including any disclaimer, should be considered in determining whether the handbook gives rise â€œto a promise, an expectation and a benefit.â€Â  Fleming, 316 S.C. at 463, 450 S.E.2d at 596.Â  â€œAn employee manual that contains promissory language and a disclaimer is â€˜inherently ambiguousâ€™ and a jury should interpret whether the manual creates or alters an existing contractual relationship.â€Â  Horton v. Darby Elec. Co.,360 S.C. 58, 67, 599 S.E.2d 456, 460 (2004).Â  
The first page of the employee manual contained the following language written in bold capital letters:

The contents of this handbook do not constitute the terms of an employment contract, express or implied, between Food Service Supplies, Inc. (FSSI) and the employee.Â  The contents of this employee handbook are not all inclusive in that they summarize current company policies and procedures and are intended as guidelines Only.Â  the company retains the right to change, modify, suspend, interpret or cancel in whole or in part any of the published or unpublished policies or practices of the company, without advance notice, in its sole discretion, and without Having to give cause or justification to any employee.Â  
Nothing contained in this handbook should be construed as a guarantee of continued employment, but rather, employment with the company is on an at-will basis.Â  This means that the employment relationship may be terminated at any time by either the employee or the company for any reason not expressly prohibited by law, or for no reason.
Any written or oral statements by a supervisor, corporate officer or other agent of the company that is contrary to the foregoing, or that purports to change, add to, or delete anything in this handbook is invalid and should not be relied upon by any prospective or existing employee unless such a statement and/or agreement is in writing and signed by the president of FSSI.

The Qualserve disclaimer is written in bold, highlighted in all capital letters, and contained in its entirety on the first page of the employee manual provided to Youngblood.Â  Moreover, Youngblood does not argue the employee manual lacks a disclaimer.Â  Therefore, the issue to resolve is whether other provisions in the employee manual give rise to â€œa promise, an expectation, and a benefitâ€ upon which Youngblood relied and which altered his at-will status.Â  
Youngblood argues the provisions of the manual, specifically the disciplinary policy contained therein, create sufficient mandatory and promissory language to alter his at-will employment status to a contractual relationship.Â  Specifically, Youngblood alleges the disciplinary policy contained promises of a progressive disciplinary policy and Qualserve failed to provide him the required warnings before terminating his employment.Â  

The disciplinary policy provides, in part:
  
The Companyâ€™s normal practice is to help the employee identify problems and to improve performance and behavior.Â  The specific disciplinary action will normally be based on an assessment of the offense, the circumstances, and previous record.Â  The company reserves the right to take whatever disciplinary measures it feels are appropriate, including discharge, if in the judgment of management the employeeâ€™s conduct and/or performance cannot be corrected or it seriously threatens the well being of the Company or other employees, or if other circumstances indicate that termination is appropriate.
  

The manual lists examples of offenses for which an employee will be disciplined, but notes behavior subject to discipline is not limited to the listed acts.Â  The manual details a progressive discipline procedure that may be used.Â  However, it cautions:Â  

The decision of whether to use progressive discipline and what type of discipline to use will be based on the judgment of management. . . .Â  Some types of conduct or performance may result in immediate termination of employment with no prior discipline. . . .
Any employee who believes they have been treated unfairly with respect to discipline, counseling, or termination of employment should pursue a complaint under the Problem Resolution Plan in the handbook.
Employment with FSSI is at the mutual consent of FSSI and the employee, and either party may terminate that relationship at any time, with or without cause, and with or without advance notice.

In Conner v. City of Forest Acres, the South Carolina Supreme Court found that an employee manual containing mandatory or promissory language in a disciplinary policy provision may create a contractual employment relationship.Â  348 S.C. 454, 464, 560 S.E.2d 606, 611 (2002).Â  Examples of mandatory language from Conner include:Â  â€œ(1) violations of the Code of Conduct â€˜will be disciplined,â€™ (2) â€˜discipline shall be of an increasingly progressive nature,â€™ and (3) â€˜all employees shall be treated fairly and consistently in all matters related to their employment.â€™â€Â  Conner, 348 S.C. at 464 n.4, 560 S.E.2d at 611 n.4.Â  
In contrast, the supreme court recently held an employerâ€™s manual exemplified â€œthe appropriate manner in which to give employees a guide regarding their employment without altering the at-will employment relationship.â€Â  Horton, 360 S.C. at 67, 599 S.E.2d at 460.Â  The court found the manual contained conspicuous disclaimers, which the employee understood.Â  Id. at 67, 599 S.E.2d at 460-61.Â  It further found the disciplinary procedures contained permissive language and did not provide for mandatory progressive discipline.3Â  Id.
Â at 67, 599 S.E.2d at 461.
Unlike the manual in Conner, Qualserveâ€™s employee manual contained no mandatory or promissory language in the disciplinary policy.Â  To the contrary, the disciplinary policy clearly contains disclaimers and is couched in permissive language, as was the manual in Horton.Â  This language clearly notified the employee that the disciplinary provisions did not create a mandatory progressive discipline policy.Â  Rather the disciplinary provisions only created a scheme of discretionary discipline available to the company.Â  
Furthermore, Youngbloodâ€™s own testimony demonstrates his understanding that the disciplinary policy allowed Qualserve the discretion to terminate or discipline its at-will employees:

Q: So the company retained the discretion to discipline or terminate in its own discretion, is that correct?
A: Say that again.
Q: The company retained the right to terminate or discipline employees in its own discretion?
A: Through that book [the employee manual], yes, they did.

Accordingly, we hold no reasonable jury could find the disciplinary policy created â€œa promise, an expectation and a benefitâ€ that would alter Youngboodâ€™s at-will employment.Â  
Youngblood also asserts other sections of the employee manual are â€œreplete with mandatory and representative language.â€Â  He lists 34 page numbers that he asserts contain mandatory language.Â  However, he fails to argue how any of these provisions contain promissory language that would alter the at-will nature of his employment. Â 
Youngblood next argues a memorandum from Human Resources Director Jennifer Gutierrez reinforced his interpretation of the employee manual that the progressive discipline policy was mandatory.Â  In this memorandum, Gutierrez instructed:

In order to ensure we consistently apply corporate policies and procedures, and comply with all federal and state legal requirements I will need to be notified of all situations which may ultimately require termination prior to any actual terminations take place.Â  If this is an employee whom you feel is not contributing to your team, proper steps must be taken in advance in order to protect yourself and the company.Â  Under no circumstances should an employee be terminated â€œon the spotâ€ with out any prior discussions with myself.Â  You should always allow a â€œcooling offâ€ period to ensure proper handling of an issue.Â  

Youngblood acknowledged that this memorandum was not disseminated to rank-and-file employees but only to supervisors.Â  He also admitted that its purpose was for protecting the company rather than giving legal rights to the employees.Â  We find nothing in the memorandum could be interpreted as â€œa promise, an expectation and a benefitâ€ that would alter the at-will nature of Youngbloodâ€™s employment.Â  The memorandum simply directed Youngblood and other supervisors to contact the Human Resources department before terminating an employee.Â  It in no way limited Qualserveâ€™s authority to terminate employees.Â  
Youngblood also argues the oral representations of Melanie Mead, a member of Qualserveâ€™s human resources staff, created sufficient mandatory and promissory language to alter his at-will employment status to a contractual relationship.Â  Youngblood alleges Meadâ€™s oral representations contained promises of a progressive disciplinary policy and Qualserve failed to provide him the required warnings before terminating his employment.Â  Youngblood testified that when Mead distributed the employee manuals, she explained the disciplinary policy to him.Â  He acknowledged that her explanation was reflected in the employee manual.Â  Youngblood also testified that as a supervisor, he followed the progressive discipline guidelines at Meadâ€™s instruction.Â  He stated she told him to follow the guidelines â€œto help the company as far as legal suitsâ€ and instructed him to take no action against employees without consulting her.
Even when viewing Youngbloodâ€™s testimony in the light most favorable to him, we find it does not create a genuine issue of material fact as to whether his status as an at-will employee was altered.Â  He admitted Meadâ€™s explanations were reflected in the employee manual, which as stated above, contained clear disclaimers and was couched in permissive language.Â  He did not testify that Mead instructed him to ignore those disclaimers.Â  Youngblood stated that as Mead explained to him, the disclaimers were in effect to allow for immediate termination of employees who committed serious violations of company policy, such as carrying a weapon on the job site or selling drugs on the job site.Â  He claimed the disclaimers should not apply to him as â€œa 21 year employee thatâ€™s done an outstanding job.â€Â  However, he subsequently acknowledged that the disclaimer applied to â€œall employees.â€Â  
In addition, the disclaimer on page one of the employee manual establishes that an employee cannot rely on any type of oral representation received from a supervisor, corporate officer, or other agent of the corporation.Â  Youngblood acknowledged the disclaimer contained this language.Â  By the terms of the employee manual, Youngblood was warned against relying on conversations he had with Mead that purported to alter his at-will status.Â  Therefore, the oral representations of Mead do not create a material issue of fact to be resolved by the jury.Â  
Finally, Youngblood refers to the handbookâ€™s problem resolution plan.Â  Although in his brief he claims the plan was not made available to him, he admitted in his deposition that he never pursued the problem resolution plan.Â  Accordingly, we find Youngblood cannot rely on this provision in his action for breach of contract.Â  
Youngblood also asserts his termination breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  As we find Youngblood has failed to establish the existence of a contract of employment altering his at-will status, his claim for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing must also fail.Â  See Keiger v. Citgo, Coastal Petroleum, 326 S.C. 369, 374, 482 S.E.2d 792, 794 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding where plaintiff failed to allege that her at-will employment status was altered by a handbook or other agreement, her claim for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing must fail).Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment is hereby
AFFIRMED.Â  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL,
JJ., concur.Â Â Â  

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
2 Qualserve Corporation was formerly known as Food Service Supplies, Inc. and is referred to by that name throughout the employee manual.
3 The supreme court listed as examples of the permissive language used:Â  

(1) the disciplinary procedure â€œis to be viewed as the guiding policy insofar as taking disciplinary action . . .;â€ (2) â€œsupervisors are not required to go through the entire three steps involved in the disciplinary procedure;â€ (3) â€œ[d]iscipline may begin at any step in the procedure depending on the seriousness of the offense committed;â€ and (4) â€œsupervisor may repeat any of the first two steps of this procedure when he feels it is necessary, so long as the discipline is commensurate with the offense committed.â€

Horton, 360 S.C. at 67 n.7, 599 S.E.2d at 461 n.7 (emphasis in Horton opinion).

title: Byrd v. Byrd
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James Byrd, Respondent,
v.
Delores B. Byrd, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-141
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Delores B. Byrd, pro se, of Spartanburg.
Fletcher N. Smith, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Delores B. Byrd, the wife, appeals a family court order denying her motion to restore the case to the active docket.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The parties divorced in 1994.Â  Among other things, the divorce decree required James Byrd, the husband, to pay alimony to the wife in the amount of $115 per week, with the proviso that he could petition for a reduction in alimony if the wife returned to work or received an award of disability through a then-pending claim.Â  The family court also ordered that the marital residence be sold and allowed the wife to remain in the home until the time of the sale.
In 1997, the husband filed a new action in the case in which he requested a temporary hearing to address several issues, including the sale of the marital home and termination of spousal support.Â  Pursuant to this request, the family court held a hearing on August 12, 1997, and issued a temporary order finding the wife was receiving social security disability benefits and terminating further alimony payments from the husband to the wife.Â  The family court also ordered the marital home to â€œbe placed immediately up for sale by a reputable real estate concern.â€Â  Neither party requested a final hearing in the case, prompting the family court to issue an administrative order striking the case from the docket with leave to restore for good cause.Â  No motion to restore was ever made until 2002.Â  
The marital home was finally sold in December 2001.Â  In February 2002, the wife filed her own action in which she requested reinstatement of alimony based on the financial circumstances of the parties, reimbursement of one half of the costs she incurred in preparing the marital home for sale, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The husband answered and counterclaimed on April 15, 2002. 
The family court held a hearing in the wifeâ€™s action on September 12, 2002.Â  On October 16, 2002, the family court filed a final order in the case dismissing with prejudice both the wifeâ€™s complaint and the husbandâ€™s counterclaim.Â  In declining to rule on the issue of alimony, the family court found â€œthat neither party filed a timely motion to restore [the 1997 action] and as such the issue of alimony is barred from further consideration by this Court and thus the issue of alimony is not a proper issue[ ] before this Court.â€Â  In the same order, the family court found that, although the wife had expended money in preparing for the sale of the marital home, any reimbursement to which she was entitled was offset by her refusal to obey certain provisions in the divorce decree concerning the impending sale and the fact that she had beneficial use of the home for the seven years preceding the sale.Â  
After the final hearing in the 2002 proceeding but before the filing of the final order, the wife petitioned to restore the 1997 case to the docket and have a hearing set on the issue of alimony.Â  In her petition, the wife alleged the sale of the marital home in 2001 amounted to a substantial change in circumstances entitling her to alimony.Â  As additional support for her claim, she also alleged the husbandâ€™s income had increased from $1,880 to $3,077 per month.Â  As evidence of good cause to restore the case, the record also included a proposed order to restore prepared and signed by the wifeâ€™s attorney.Â  This proposed order stated (1) alimony was terminated on a temporary basis, (2) a final merits hearing was never held in the matter, (3) the wife was informed that the marital home had to be sold before a final hearing could take place, and (4) the parties only recently closed on the sale of the marital home.
On November 4, 2002, the family court held a hearing on the wifeâ€™s motion to restore the 1997 action.Â  By order dated November 25, 2002, the family court issued an order denying the motion.Â  It is from this order that the wife appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œWhenever a domestic relations . . . case has been filed and entered in the File Book for more than two hundred seventy (270) days without having been continued, tried or otherwise disposed of, the clerk of court shall strike the case from the File Book with leave to restore.â€[2]Â  â€œAny case stricken from the File Book . . . shall be restored only upon the written order of the Chief Administrative Judge, obtained after written application is made and good cause shown why the case should be continued as a pending case . . . .â€[3]

The family court explained its refusal to restore the case as follows:Â  
The case was initially filed five and a half years ago, . . . and was stricken from the active docket almost five years ago.Â  Both parties simply allowed the case to die from inaction.Â  It would be unjust to revive it after such an extended period of lack of prosecution. 

In our view, the family court placed unwarranted emphasis on the amount of time that had elapsed between the striking of the case and the wifeâ€™s attempt to have it restored to the docket.Â  When the supreme court ordered that lawsuits pending in the family courts more than two hundred seventy days without a final hearing or other disposition be struck from the docket, it required only a showing of â€œgood causeâ€ in a written application to have a case restored as a pending matter.[4]Â  No mention is made as to how much time a litigant has to request this relief, let alone that an extended lapse of time before moving to restore, without more, is tantamount to a lack of good cause.Â  Moreover, the family court made no specific findings as to why it would be â€œunjustâ€ to hold a hearing on the merits.Â  We therefore hold the family courtâ€™s refusal to restore the 1997 case to the docket under these circumstances amounted to an error of law.[5]
We further disagree with the husbandâ€™s argument that the wifeâ€™s appeal must fail because she did not appeal the family courtâ€™s dismissal of her 2002 action.Â  It appears from the order dismissing that case and comments from the wifeâ€™s counsel that the family court indicated it would rule on the wifeâ€™s request to have her alimony reinstated when a motion to restore the prior action was made.Â  As such, contrary to what the husband argued in his brief, we hold the order dismissing the wifeâ€™s 2002 lawsuit was not a final judgment on the merits of her alimony claim and therefore should not bar her from pursuing on appeal her right to a hearing on this issue.
Finally, we hold that the wife has demonstrated good cause to support her petition to have the case restored to the docket.Â  It appears the wife was informed that no final hearing in the matter could be held until the marital home was sold.Â  As noted in her petition, this event did not occur until late 2001, thus accounting for all but less than ten months of the extended delay before the filing of the petition.Â  Because it appears the cessation of alimony payments at the temporary hearing was not intended to be a final adjudication of the wifeâ€™s entitlement to future support, we hold it would be manifestly unjust to prevent a final hearing on this issue.
CONCLUSION
We therefore reverse the order denying the wifeâ€™s petition to restore the 1997 action and remand the case to the family court for a final hearing in the matter.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Administrative Order for the Family Courts (S. Ct., filed June 5, 1992).
[3]Â  Id.
[4]Â  Cf. Maxwell v. Genez, 356 S.C. 617, 591 S.E.2d 26 (2003) (stating that Rule 40(j), SCRCP, in preventing a plaintiff who failed to moved to restore a case removed by consent from the docket within one year after the matter was stricken from taking advantage of the tolling provision stated in the rule, did not require a party to move to restore the case to the docket within one year after it was stricken and holding that â€œ[a] party can move to restore a case to the docket more than one year after the claim was stricken without running afoul of Rule 40(j)â€).
[5]Â  See Williams v. Vanvolkenberg, 312 S.C. 373, 375, 440 S.E.2d 408, 409 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating that an appellate court reviews an evidentiary record under the â€œgood causeâ€ standard by determining whether the trial courtâ€™s determination is supportable by the evidence and not controlled by an error of law).

title: State v. Bellamy
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Antrea Labert Bellamy, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-142
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Antrea Labert Bellamy was indicted and convicted of armed robbery and murder.Â  He received concurrent sentences of thirty years imprisonment on each charge.Â  Bellamy appeals his conviction for armed robbery.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Bellamy was indicted for the murder of Richard Hanson and the armed robbery of Hanson, Keri Newton, and Ashley Bushner.Â  The indictment for armed robbery stated: 

That ANTREA LABERT BELLAMY, aka Antrea Labult Bellamy did in Horry County on or about the 2nd of June 2001, while armed with a deadly weapon, to wit:Â  a handgun, take and carry away personal property from or in the immediate presence of Richard Hanson, Keri Newton and/or Ashley Bushner with intent to deprive him of possession by use of force, threats or intimidation, in violation of Section 16-11-330(A), S. C. Code of Laws, 1976, as amended.Â  

Bellamy was tried before a jury on these charges.Â  At trial, the State presented testimony of Bushner, Newton, and Matthew Williams.Â  Williams, who was Newtonâ€™s fiancÃ©, was present at the time of the alleged robbery and murder.Â  Bushner and Newton testified to the events that occurred on the night in question upon returning to Williamsâ€™ home after a trip to a convenience store.Â  
Newton testified when she attempted to get out of the car one of the men pulled her out and to the ground.Â  â€œ[W]ith a gun to my head, tells me to keep my head down, asking if nobody gives up any money, my brains are getting blown out; and he just asked me if I had money and that time thatâ€™s when Matthew [Williams] and Ricky [Hanson] came outside.â€Â  The prosecutor then asked Newton if anything was stolen from anybody that night, to which she responded, â€œNot to my knowledge.â€Â  Newton stated she recalled three assailants, but only two having guns.Â  
Bushner provided testimony similar to Newtonâ€™s and confirmed there were three assailants, but recalled all three having guns.Â  Bushner also testified, â€œNobody talked to me or messed with me at all.â€Â  
Williams also testified to the presence of three men, all of whom were armed with guns, at his home that night.Â  Williams, however, stated he and Hanson, who was shot and killed during the incident, were told by an assailant, â€œOne of you are going to die tonight if you donâ€™t give us the money.â€Â  Williams testified another assailant said, â€œGive me your jewelry, take your rings off, take your necklace off, give me your money . . . .â€Â  Williams responded by giving the men money and a ring.Â  
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Bellamyâ€™s attorney moved for a directed verdict on both the murder and the armed robbery charges.Â  As to the armed robbery charge, Bellamy argued the case lacked sufficient evidence to go to the jury because none of the witnesses could identify him as one of the assailants.Â  In addition, Bellamyâ€™s attorney asserted the evidence suggested Bellamy was attempting to collect money Hanson owed him, rather than committing a robbery.Â  The trial court denied these motions and submitted the case to the jury.Â  The jury convicted Bellamy of both murder and armed robbery.Â  Bellamy appeals his conviction on the armed robbery charge.[2]  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Bellamy argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to try him on the armed robbery charge.Â  We disagree. 
 Issues involving the subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.[3]Â  â€œA circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction if:Â  (1) there has been an indictment, which sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser included charge of the crime charged in the indictment.â€[4]Â  â€œAn indictment is sufficient to convey jurisdiction if it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense intended to be charged and informs the defendant of the circumstances he must be prepared to defend.â€[5]
 The supreme court has defined robbery as â€œthe felonious or unlawful taking of money, goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€[6]Â  â€œArmed robbery occurs when a person commits robbery while armed with a deadly weapon.â€[7]
 We hold the indictment is sufficient on its face to confer subject matter jurisdiction on the trial court to try Bellamy for the offense of armed robbery.Â  It contains all the required elements of an armed robbery offense and sufficiently places Bellamy on notice that he was to be tried on the offense of armed robbery against Hanson, Newton, and Bushner.[8]  
 Although Bellamy frames his issue on appeal as that of lack of subject matter jurisdiction by the trial court, he argues a material variance existed between the allegations in the indictment for armed robbery and the proof provided at trial.Â  Specifically, he contends the State did not provide sufficient proof to convict him of the armed robbery of Hanson, Newton, and Bushner.Â  Rather, the only evidence of armed robbery provided at trial supports the armed robbery of Williams, who was not included in the indictment.Â  We hold this argument does not address Bellamyâ€™s contention that subject matter jurisdiction was lacking; therefore, it is not properly preserved for our review.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 â€œA material variance between the charge and the proof entitles the defendant to a directed verdict.â€[9]Â  Although Bellamy moved for a directed verdict, his motion did not include the argument that a material variance existed between the indictment and the evidence presented by the State.Â  Issues not raised to the trial court in support of a directed verdict motion are not preserved for appellate review.[10]Â  We therefore cannot address this issue on appeal. 
  AFFIRMED. 
  GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Bellamyâ€™s appellate counsel filed an appeal and a petition to be relieved as counsel, arguing the trial court failed to instruct the jury on the law of accident.Â  Bellamy also submitted a pro se brief.Â  This court denied counselâ€™s petition to be relieved and ordered the parties to brief the issue of whether a material variance existed between the allegations of Bellamyâ€™s armed robbery indictment and the proof at trial, thus defeating subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The rebriefing order noted this issue was the only point of arguable merit in Bellamyâ€™s appeal.
[3]Â  Mathis v. State, 355 S.C. 87, 90, 584 S.E.2d 366, 368 (2003).
[4]Â  Locke v. State, 341 S.C. 54, 56, 533 S.E.2d 324, 325 (2000). 
[5]Â  Id.
[6]Â  Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 556, 571 S.E.2d 280, 282 (2002).
[7]Â  Id.
[8]Â  See State v. Bryson, 357 S.C. 106, 114 n.6, 591 S.E.2d 637, 641 n.6 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting an amendment to an indictment that changes the identity of the victim does not necessarily divest a trial court of subject matter jurisdiction and explaining that the critical point in Bryson was the fact that this case involved two counts of assaulting an officer while resisting arrest that could be distinguished only by knowing the identity of the victim involved).
[9]Â  State v. Evans, 322 S.C. 78, 81, 470 S.E.2d 97, 99 (1996).Â  
[10] Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Res. Depâ€™t,
328 S.C. 24, 34, 491 S.E.2d 571, 576 (1997).Â

title: City of Columbia v. Assaad-Faltas
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        City of Columbia,
        Respondent,
v.
Marie Therese Assaad-Faltas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-143
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Marie Therese Assaad-Faltas, of Columbia, pro se, for Appellant. 
Dana M. Thye, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Marie Therese Assaad-Faltas appeals from her conviction in municipal court for shoplifting.Â  The circuit court, in its appellate capacity, affirmed.Â  We now affirm. 
FACTS
Faltas was arrested after two Wal-Mart employees witnessed her swap the labels of two less expensive folders for two more expensive binders.Â  The arrest warrant charged her with shoplifting less than $1000 worth of merchandise in violation of section 16-13-110 of the South Carolina Code (2003).
At trial, E.J. Lipscomb, an employee of Wal-Mart, testified he witnessed Faltas exchange the labels on the binders for other labels.Â  He testified that she then attempted to purchase the binders with the different labels.Â  Faltas was subsequently stopped and questioned by Lipscomb and another employee, Frederick Stevens.Â  
Lipscomb identified a Polaroid photograph taken the date of the incident and testified it properly depicted the binders and folders that Faltas attempted to purchase with swapped labels. Finally, he testified the actual binders were returned to the store shelves and the labels, which were removed, were not kept.Â  
Stevens also testified regarding the incident.Â  He observed Faltas removing the labels from binders and from colored folders.Â  Stevens confirmed with the cashier that Faltas purchased binders, not folders.Â  Faltas was stopped and had only the clear binders in her possession.Â  
Faltas fired her counsel midway through trial.Â  After being appropriately warned of the dangers of self-representation by the trial court, Faltas was allowed to proceed at trial pro se.Â  She was allowed to recall several of the Cityâ€™s witnesses to reexamine them.Â  
Faltas testified that she neither shoplifted nor had the intent to shoplift.Â  She explained she switched the labels to correct an initial mislabeling by Wal-Mart.Â Â  Faltas asserted that she purchased binders at the appropriate price.Â  Finally, Faltas challenged the Polaroid photograph and indicated the binders and folders depicted were not those she attempted to purchase, nor were they the ones on which she tried to correct the labels.Â  
Faltas was convicted of shoplifting and fined $500.Â  The circuit court affirmed her conviction and sentence.Â  The court subsequently denied her Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion and a motion to â€œperpetuate testimony.â€Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.Â  In reviewing criminal cases, this court may review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2001) (internal citations omitted); see also, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-25-105 (Supp. 2004) (â€œThere shall be no trial de novo on any appeal from a municipal courtâ€).
DISCUSSION
Faltas raises a multitude of issues related to the conduct and outcome of her trial in municipal court.Â  The issues will be considered as they are presented in Faltasâ€™s Statement of Issues on Appeal in her brief.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Dismiss
Faltas alleges the municipal court erred in failing to dismiss her case.Â  She claims the warrant failed to state a crime and did not provide her adequate notice; the evidence was not properly maintained and presented at trial; and the City â€œaggravated the unfairness by inexcusably refusing to show the Defense any remaining evidence until the morning of trial.â€Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Warrant
Faltas contends the warrant â€œfailed to state a crime and did not give Appellant notice of the charges against her.â€Â  We disagree.
First, this issue was not sufficiently raised to the trial court.Â  As such, it is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
However, as the arrest warrant serves the function of an indictment in magistrate and municipal courts, the sufficiency of the indictment may impact the subject matter jurisdiction of the court.Â  Faltasâ€™s argument also fails on the merits.Â  â€œAll proceedings before magistrates in criminal cases shall be commenced on information under oath, plainly and substantially setting forth the offense charged, upon which, and only which, shall a warrant of arrest issue.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-710 (Supp. 2004).Â  This section requires the offense with which a party is charged should be set forth â€œplainly and substantially,â€ so as to enable the party accused to understand the nature of the offense charged, in order that the party may be prepared to meet the charge at the proper time.Â  See State v. Randolph, 239 S.C. 79, 84, 121 S.E.2d 349, 351 (1961).Â Â  
The affidavit as part of the arrest warrant clearly sets forth the location of the crime and the facts underlying the crime.Â  It explains Faltas was observed â€œswapping price tags on merchandise for tags that were less expensive.â€Â  The arrest warrant then lists the offense and the applicable section of the South Carolina Code:Â  â€œShoplifting under $1000Â  16-13-110.â€Â  Accordingly, we find Faltas was properly advised of the nature of the offense for which she has been charged.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Preservation of Evidence
Faltasâ€™s main contention throughout her brief appears to be the failure of either Wal-Mart or the City to maintain the actual folders and labels she allegedly shoplifted.Â  She asserts that because they failed to present the actual folders at trial, the charges should have been dismissed.Â  We disagree.
In State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 538-39, 552 S.E.2d 300, 307 (2001), the South Carolina Supreme Court explained:

The State does not have an absolute duty to preserve potentially useful evidence that might exonerate a defendant.Â  Arizona v. Youngblood, 488 U.S. 51, 109 S.Ct. 333, 102 L.Ed.2d 281 (1988); State v. Mabe, 306 S.C. 355, 412 S.E.2d 386 (1991); State v. Jackson, 302 S.C. 313, 396 S.E.2d 101 (1990).Â  To establish a due process violation, a defendant must demonstrate (1) that the State destroyed the evidence in bad faith, or (2) that the evidence possessed an exculpatory value apparent before the evidence was destroyed and the defendant cannot obtain other evidence of comparable value by other means.Â  State v. Mabe, supra; State v. Jackson, supra.

In both Cheeseboro and Mabe, evidence was destroyed without bad faith and the appellant in each case was unable to prove the evidence had exculpatory value.Â  In Jackson, however, the evidence was found to be material and the destruction was done even though the State knew the evidence was material.Â  The court concluded:Â  â€œIn the case at bar, the videotape was clearly â€˜materialâ€™.Â  The exculpatory value was apparent before its destruction because one assistant solicitor was willing to drop the charges because of it.Â  In addition, Jackson had no other evidence and could not obtain evidence of comparable value.â€Â  Jackson, 302 S.C. at 316, 396 S.E.2d at 102.
In the instant case, testimony indicated the evidence was returned to Wal-Mart after being photographed, pursuant to Wal-Martâ€™s standard procedure.Â  Witnesses testified the photographs accurately represented the evidence.Â  Faltas has been unable to demonstrate the return of the evidence to Wal-Mart for re-labeling and sale was done in bad faith.Â  Nor has Faltas, in the judgment of the circuit court and this court, explained the exculpatory value of the folders.Â  Finally, Faltas was able to bring like folders and binders to the trial for use in cross-examination and demonstrative purposes.Â  She was not prevented from being able to make her defense by the return of the folders and binders to the general merchandise of the store.Â  We further adopt the reasoning and analysis of the circuit court in its well-reasoned opinion.Â  We join the circuit court in finding that the trial court properly denied Faltasâ€™s motion to dismiss on this ground.
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Refusal to Provide Evidence Ahead of Trial
Faltas contends the trial court erred in allowing the trial to proceed when she was not presented the evidence prior to the date of trial.Â  We disagree.
Faltas attempts to use this issue to expand on her discussion of the previous issue regarding whether the trial court improperly refused to dismiss the case because the actual folders and binders were not maintained.Â  At trial, she did not seek to challenge the authenticity of the photograph when it was entered into evidence.Â  Therefore, her current issue is not preserved for review on appeal as it was not specifically raised to or ruled on by the trial court.Â  See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Admission of the Polaroid Photograph
Faltas contends the trial court erred in admitting the photograph â€œover Defense objection because it was not independently corroborated.â€Â  She also maintains it was error for the court to rely on the photograph in finding her guilty of shoplifting.Â  We disagree.
Faltas attempts to use this issue to expand on her discussion of the previous issue regarding whether the trial court improperly refused to dismiss the case because the actual folders and binders were not maintained.Â  At trial, she did not seek to challenge the authenticity of the photograph when it was entered into evidence.Â  She sought to challenge the lack of the physical evidence and the chain of custody.Â  Therefore, her current issue is not preserved for review on appeal as it was not specifically raised to or ruled on by the trial court.Â  See id.
On the merits, â€œ[t]he admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed in the absence of a manifest abuse of discretion accompanied by probable prejudice.â€Â  State v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 21, 596 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Id.  
Two witnesses testified at trial that the photographs properly showed the folders and binders at issue.Â  Both witnesses testified regarding the contents of the photographs and had no difficulty identifying the contents. It was not error for the court to admit the evidence.Â  As to the courtâ€™s reliance on the evidence, that goes to the weight of the evidence and is not reviewable on appeal.Â  See State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous. . . . This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the â€¦ evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€).Â  The decision of the trial court to admit the photograph and any reliance placed on the photograph in making its ultimate determination is affirmed.
III.Â Â Â  Directed
Verdict
Faltas contends the trial court erred in failing to grant her motion for a directed verdict.Â  We disagree.
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 633, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 274, 584 S.E.2d 138, 140 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003).

Section 16-13-110(A)(2) of the South Carolina Code (2003) states:
  
(A) A person is guilty of shoplifting if he:
â€¦.
(2) alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag marking, indicia of value, or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any merchandise displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale in a store or other retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase the merchandise personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise. . . .
  

The directed verdict motion here concerned the failure of the City to provide the court with the actual labels removed from the folders and placed on the binders.Â  Faltas asserted the City failed to provide evidence of her â€œintent to buy an item for less than it was priced.â€Â  Any contentions beyond that specifically raised in the motion to the trial court are not preserved for review on appeal.Â  See State v. Newton, 274 S.C. 287, 293, 262 S.E.2d 906, 910 (1980) (stating matters not passed upon by the trial court will not be reviewed).
Two Wal-Mart employees testified to observing Faltas switch labels from less expensive items to more expensive ones.Â  The witnessesâ€™ testimony indicated Faltas then purchased the more expensive binders, although she only paid the cost of the less expensive folders.Â  Additionally, a receipt was produced indicating the cost of the items purchased was $0.97, which was the cost of the less expensive folders and not the cost of the binders the witnesses testified Faltas had in her possession when she was stopped.Â  We find there is evidence in the record indicating Faltas swapped the labels with the intent to deprive Wal-Mart of the full value of the merchandise.
IV.Â Â Â  Wal-Mart Manifest and Motion for Continuance
Faltas contends the trial court erred in refusing to grant her a mid-trial continuance in order to obtain a routing manifest in Wal-Martâ€™s possession.Â  Additionally, she argues the court erred in not finding the failure of the City to provide the manifest prior to trial was a violation of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194, 10 L. Ed. 2d 215 (1963).Â  We disagree, and again crave reference to the order of the circuit court.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Continuance
A trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for continuance will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  State v. McMillian, 349 S.C. 17, 21, 561 S.E.2d 602, 604 (2002).Â  During trial, Faltasâ€™s counselâ€”shortly before his discharge by Faltasâ€”began questioning Lipscomb regarding any internal documents or manifest produced by Wal-Mart involving this incident.Â  Lipscomb indicated there was and he believed it was brought to trial.Â  However, the document was not located.Â  Lipscomb testified the manifest contained only information that had already been testified to by Wal-Mart employees.Â  No motion for a continuance was made at the time of the initial testimony regarding the manifest.
Faltas then dismissed her counsel and proceeded pro se.Â  The court properly questioned Faltas regarding her understanding of the dangers of representing herself and instructed her that there would be no continuance on the grounds of her dismissing counsel.Â  After beginning her questioning of Stevens, Faltas moved for a continuance to examine the manifest. Â The trial court denied this motion.Â  This motion was not contemporaneous with the introduction of the testimony regarding the manifest.Â  
Faltasâ€™s counsel, prior to being fired, questioned Lipscomb regarding the manifest and its content.Â  Faltas did not immediately move for a continuance after assuming her representation and was warned no continuances would be granted.Â  As the motion was not contemporaneous with the testimony regarding the manifest and there is no indication the continuance would have provided any additional information, it was not an abuse of discretion for the court to deny the motion.
 B.Â Â Â Â Â  Brady Violation
Faltas also appears to argue there was a Brady violation by the City for failing to provide the manifest prior to trial.Â  We disagree.
First, it is doubtful this issue was preserved for review.Â  Second, Faltas provides no basis beyond speculation as to the exculpatory value of the document.Â  In any event, the manifest was never in the possession of the City.Â  It was an internal document created by Wal-Mart and was at all times in the possession of Wal-Mart or its employees.Â  See State v. Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 452, 503 S.E.2d 214, 220 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding Brady requires the prosecution to disclose evidence that is:Â  1) in its possession; 2) favorable to the accused; and 3) material to guilt or punishment).
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Ineffective Assistance of Counsel and Confrontation of Witnesses
In her brief, Faltas asserts:Â  â€œDefendants must not be forced to choose only one of her several Sixth Amendment rights.Â  Trial judge had her choose between effective assistance of counsel and effective confrontation of her accusers and effectively deprived her of both.â€Â  
In her arguments in her brief, she does not seem to raise the effective assistance of counsel argument again.Â  As such, it is deemed abandoned.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (finding appellant was deemed to have abandoned issue for which he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority).Â  Additionally, there is no claim for ineffective assistance of counsel on direct appeal.Â  See State v. Felder, 290 S.C. 521, 522, 351 S.E.2d 852, 852 (1986) (holding post-conviction relief, rather than direct appeal, was proper avenue of relief for defendant claiming ineffective assistance of counsel).
As to her argument on the trial judgeâ€™s restriction on her confrontation of witnesses, she seems to claim in her brief the limitation was caused by the failure of Wal-Mart and the City to preserve the binders and labels.Â  This issue has been appropriately addressed above. Â 
To the extent that she is critical of the trial judgeâ€™s handling of her examination and cross-examination of witnesses, we find the claim to be without merit.Â  Normally, we will not disturb on appeal a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning the scope of cross-examination of a witness to test his credibility absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Lynn, 277 S.C. 222, 225, 284 S.E.2d 786, 788 (1981).Â  However, the right to meaningful cross-examination of an adverse witness is included in the defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront his accuser.Â  State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 385, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994).Â  In Delaware v. Van Arsdall, the United States Supreme Court held that the Confrontation Clause does not prevent:

a trial judge from imposing any limits on defense counselâ€™s inquiry into the potential bias of a prosecution witness.Â  On the contrary, trial judges retain wide latitude insofar as the Confrontation Clause is concerned to impose reasonable limits on such cross-examination based on concerns about, among other things, . . . or interrogation that is repetitive or only marginally relevant.

Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 679, 106 S.Ct. 1431, 89 L.Ed.2d 674 (1986).
After electing to proceed pro se, Faltas was allowed wide latitude in recalling the Cityâ€™s witnesses and in questioning witnesses.Â  The trial court prohibited her from asking repetitive questions and from rehashing all the testimony previously elicited by her counsel.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the limitations placed upon Faltasâ€™s examination and confrontation of witnesses.
VI.Â Â Â  Reasonable Doubt and Circumstantial Evidence
Faltas contends the trial court applied an incorrect standard in determining whether the City had proven its case beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Additionally, she maintains the trial court improperly weighed the circumstantial evidence in the case.Â  We disagree.
First, it appears the claims may not be preserved for review on appeal.Â  She raises the issues in her brief as what she terms the â€œJudgeâ€™s Instructions to Himself.â€Â  She asserts the trial courtâ€™s statement of her guilt indicates he utilized the incorrect standard.Â  The court stated:Â  â€œI just find Mr. Lipscombâ€™s testimony credible, and then when I go over the physical evidence, I donâ€™t, Iâ€™m not shaken, so I think the evidence is there, and Iâ€™m going to find her guilty.â€Â  However, she failed to preserve any error because she did not raise any objection to the statement or to the application of an allegedly incorrect standard.Â  A contemporaneous objection would be required to raise the issue before the trial court and preserve it for appellate review.Â  State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996).Â  Accordingly, neither claim is preserved for review on appeal.
On her claim regarding the circumstantial evidence, Faltas additionally did not raise the issue to the circuit court nor obtain a ruling on the issue from the circuit court on appeal.Â  For this additional reason, the specific claim is not preserved for our review.Â  See City of Columbia v. Ervin, 330 S.C. 516, 519-20, 500 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1998) (stating an issue not raised to an intermediate appellate court cannot be considered in a subsequent appeal to the court of appeals or supreme court).
The circuit court did address the merits of her claim regarding reasonable doubt.Â  This claim also fails on the merits for the reasons expressed in the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  Pursuant to section 14-25-45 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), municipal courts have jurisdiction in criminal cases and are explicitly restricted from having jurisdiction in civil cases.Â  The only standard of review utilized by the court is the â€œbeyond a reasonable doubtâ€ standard established for criminal matters.Â  The use of the phrase â€œIâ€™m not shakenâ€ is not evidence the trial court utilized an incorrect standard as Faltas claims.Â  Nothing in the record indicates the judge utilized an incorrect standard or gave himself improper instruction regarding the appropriate standard.Â  We find no error in the judgeâ€™s verdict or the explanation of his verdict.
VII.Â Â  Motion to Supplement Record and Perpetuate Testimony
Faltas contends the trial court erred in failing to allow her to supplement the record with additional evidence, and the circuit court erred in refusing to allow her to perpetuate testimony.Â  
Neither of these contentions appears to be argued in Faltasâ€™s brief.Â  The issues are deemed abandoned.Â  See, e.g., Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 344, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003) (holding the court will not consider issues raised on appeal but not argued in the body of the brief); Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship., 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) (finding issue is deemed abandoned where appellants raise alternative holding in their statement of the issues on appeal, but they fail to argue it in their brief).Â  We reject these contentions as meritless in any event.Â  The circuit court and this court serve only in an appellate capacity in this matter.
CONCLUSION
The shoplifting conviction of Faltas is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Gates
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.Â  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
        Harlan Gates, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-144
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Christopher A. Wellborn, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Harlan Gates appeals his conviction for driving under the influence (DUI), alleging the trial court erred in not suppressing the evidence derived from the checkpoint in which he was stopped.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Gates approached a checkpoint established in the city of York and was asked to stop.Â  While speaking with Gates, Deputy Lonnie Vinesett smelled the odor of alcohol and asked Gates to pull off to the side of the road.Â  Deputy Vinesett asked whether Gates had been drinking and he indicated he had three or four beers.Â  After failing three field sobriety tests, Gates was arrested for DUI.Â  His Datamaster test indicated Gates had a blood alcohol concentration of .10.Â  
At trial, Gates moved to suppress the results of the stop, arguing it was unconstitutional.Â  York Police Lieutenant Thomas Jenkins testified in camera regarding the checkpointâ€™s establishment, purpose, and procedures.Â  Lt. Jenkins testified there were â€œa number of DUIâ€™s and speeding cases in that particular area,â€ and they established the checkpoint, utilizing officers from several different departments.Â  He testified the checkpoint was established and operated pursuant to York County policies, but each officer was operating under the policy of their particular agency when conducting the stop and any subsequent tests.Â  
The trial court allowed the evidence into the record, indicating the checkpoint was established for a legitimate purpose, officers stopped all approaching cars, and officers investigated matters typically associated with a traffic checkpoint.Â  Gates was convicted of DUI (second offense) and sentenced to one year imprisonment and a $5,000 fine, suspended to two days in jail and payment of a $1,000 fine with three years probation. Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (internal citations omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gates contends the checkpoint violated his Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures because: (1) the primary purpose was general crime control; and (2) the officers participating retained more discretion than is allowed.Â  As a result, he maintains the trial court erred in failing to suppress the results of the stop.Â  We disagree.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Primary Purpose
Gates asserts the primary purpose of the checkpoint was general crime control, which violates the Fourth Amendment.Â  We disagree and find the checkpoint was established for a legitimate reason.
The Fourth Amendment requires searches and seizures be reasonable. A search or seizure is ordinarily unreasonable in the absence of individualized suspicion of wrongdoing.Â  Chandler v. Miller, 520 U.S. 305, 308 (1997).Â  The United States Supreme Court has upheld brief, suspicionless seizures of motorists at a sobriety checkpoint aimed at removing drunk drivers from the road.Â  See Michigan Depâ€™t of State Police v. Sitz, 496 U.S. 444, 455 (1990) (finding the Stateâ€™s interest in preventing drunken driving through sobriety checkpoints at which all drivers are briefly stopped advanced public safety and did not violate motoristsâ€™ Fourth Amendment protections).Â  In Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. 648, 663 (1979), the Court found that random, suspicionless stops to check license and registration of drivers violated the Fourth Amendment, but that in certain circumstances, such as where all cars are stopped, it would be permissible.Â  However, the Court in Prouse indicated stops for the purpose of the general interest of crime control would not be valid.Â  Prouse, 440 U.S. at 659 n.18. 
In City of Indianapolis v. Edmond, 531 U.S. 32 (2000), the United States Supreme Court was asked to determine whether a checkpoint for the purpose of detecting illegal narcotics violated the Fourth Amendment.Â  The Court found the stop for the detection of illegal narcotics was a search for â€œordinary criminal wrongdoingâ€ and, therefore, did not conform to the requirements of the Fourth Amendment.Â  Edmond, 531 U.S. at 41-42. Â The Court held:Â  

We decline to suspend the usual requirement of individualized suspicion where the police seek to employ a checkpoint primarily for the ordinary enterprise of investigating crimes.Â  We cannot sanction stops justified only by the generalized and ever-present possibility that interrogation and inspection may reveal that any given motorist has committed some crime. 

Id. at 44.Â  Thus, while brief suspicionless stops of all vehicles and aimed at public safety do not violate the Fourth Amendment, suspicionless stops aimed at trying to catch a motorist committing some general crime are in direct contravention of the Fourth Amendment guarantees.Â  
During the in camera hearing in the present case, Lt. Jenkins testified specifically regarding the reasons for the checkpoint and its location.Â  He stated: 

Public safety.Â  We keep a record of all the DUIâ€™s and all the traffic, you know, among the shifts, that they enter everything into the computer and periodically weâ€™ll go into the computer and see where the most areas where we have a lot of speeding, DUI, reckless driving and that type of stuff and pick out the checkpoints from there.Â  

Additionally, he testified:Â  â€œThere was a number of DUIâ€™s and speeding cases in that particular area.â€Â  
Gatesâ€™ counsel questioned Lt. Jenkins regarding the purpose of the checkpoints and the following colloquy occurred:

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  So, road blocks are kind of an important crime control measure, arenâ€™t they?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Correct.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  So when youâ€™re setting up these road blocks, when youâ€™re looking at it, the reason youâ€™re setting them up is for crime control, isnâ€™t it?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Yes sir.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  I mean, you donâ€™t do it because you donâ€™t have anything else in your life going on; youâ€™re doing it because you want to control crime?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Right.Â  

Gates asserts the above colloquy indicates the checkpoints were established for unconstitutional reasons.Â  However, Lt. Jenkins had specifically detailed how the site was chosen using the computer statistics regarding DUIâ€™s and speeding in a particular area.Â  Gatesâ€™ counselâ€™s questions were very general, and the responses given by Lt. Jenkins are not in conflict with the prior reasons given for the checkpoints.Â  
Protecting the public, though reducing crime, is a goal of checkpoints established based on the number of DUI and speeding cases in an area.Â  However, the checkpoint, which stopped Gates, was not established for the purpose of finding ordinary criminal wrongdoing or for general crime control.Â  It was established specifically because of the number of DUI and speeding cases in the particular area.Â  
As in Sitz, the intent of the checkpoint in this case did not violate the Fourth Amendment.Â  Sitz, 496 U.S. at 455 (â€œIn sum, the balance of the Stateâ€™s interest in preventing drunken driving, the extent to which this system can reasonably be said to advance that interest, and the degree of intrusion upon individual motorists who are briefly stopped, weighs in favor of the state program. We therefore hold that it is consistent with the Fourth Amendment.â€).Â  Accordingly, we must look to whether the checkpoint violated the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution because it allowed too much discretion in the stops and tests performed.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Discretion by Officers
Gates maintains the checkpoint violated the Fourth Amendment because it allowed the officers to retain too much discretion in the implementation of the stops.Â  We disagree and find the checkpoint was operated pursuant to the procedures approved by the United States Supreme Court.
Because stopping an automobile and detaining its occupants constitutes a â€œseizure,â€ the Fourth Amendment is implicated in this case, even though the purpose of the stop is limited and the resulting detention quite brief.Â  United States v. Martinez-Fuerte, 428 U.S. 543, 556-558 (1976).Â  â€œThe essential purpose of the proscriptions in the Fourth Amendment is to impose a standard of â€˜reasonablenessâ€™ upon the exercise of discretion by government officials, including law enforcement agents, in order â€˜to safeguard the privacy and security of individuals against arbitrary invasions.â€™â€Â  Prouse, 440 U.S. at 653-54 (quoting Marshall v. Barlowâ€™s Inc., 436 U.S. 307 (1978)).
In Prouse, the United States Supreme Court invalidated a discretionary, suspicionless stop for a spot check of a motoristâ€™s driverâ€™s license and vehicle registration.Â  The officerâ€™s conduct in that case was unconstitutional primarily on account of his exercise of â€œstandardless and unconstrained discretion.â€ Prouse, 440 U.S. at 661.Â  The Courtâ€™s primary consideration was that the officers were not stopping all vehicles, but were randomly choosing vehicles to stop and detain.Â  The Court explicated:

When there is not probable cause to believe that a driver is violating any one of the multitude of applicable traffic and equipment regulations--or other articulable basis amounting to reasonable suspicion that the driver is unlicensed or his vehicle unregistered--we cannot conceive of any legitimate basis upon which a patrolman could decide that stopping a particular driver for a spot check would be more productive than stopping any other driver. This kind of standardless and unconstrained discretion is the evil the Court has discerned when in previous cases it has insisted that the discretion of the official in the field be circumscribed, at least to some extent.

Id.Â 
The Court in Prouse was expressly concerned with the extent of the intrusion into the privacy of the driver or other occupants.Â  The Court found there was â€œsubstantial anxietyâ€ created through the use of random stops and the required show of authority to the particular driver.Â  Prouse, 440 U.S. at 657.Â  The Court explained:Â  â€œâ€˜At traffic checkpoints the motorist can see that other vehicles are being stopped, he can see visible signs of the officersâ€™ authority, and he is much less likely to be frightened or annoyed by the intrusion.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting United States v. Oritz, 422 U.S. 891, 894-95 (1975)).Â  The Court then detailed one possible solution was to question â€œall oncoming traffic at roadblock-type stopsâ€ and then, with only brief periods of detainment.Â  Prouse, 440 U.S. at 663.Â  The United States Supreme Court was not as concerned by the actions after the stop as it was the reasons for the stop.Â  
In the instant case, Lt. Jenkins explicitly testified every vehicle was stopped as it passed though the checkpoint.Â  Whether the officers were under Lt. Jenkinâ€™s command from York County or were from another agency, he announced that the plan established for the checkpoints required every vehicle be detained briefly.Â  He also described the checkpoint in detail; including the fact it was more than a sufficient distance from several possible turn-around locations.Â  The officerâ€™s vehicles were stationary with lights flashing.Â  Finally, officers placed warning signs along the road allowing more than sufficient warning to alert drivers of the upcoming checkpoint.Â  
While the questions asked of the drivers may have varied based upon which officer was conducting the stop, Lt. Jenkins testified all stops were â€œreasonably briefâ€ pursuant to the plan established.Â  Additionally, each officer conducted their own tests if they felt a driver might be intoxicated.Â  Deputy Vinesett conducted Gatesâ€™ test and detailed his process.Â  He explained Gatesâ€™ failure of each of the tests.Â  The stop was neither unreasonable, nor left to the â€œunbridled discretionâ€ of the officers as in Prouse.Â  Prouse, 440 U.S. at 663.Â  Neither Sitz, Prouse, nor Edmond require the specific questions or actions performed by the officers after the stop to be pursuant to written guidelines or be in complete concert with one another. 
CONCLUSION
We find the checkpoint was established for the legitimate purpose of decreasing DUI and speeding in an area specifically targeted because of prior incidents.Â  The checkpoint was operated pursuant to guidelines, which took into consideration all of the concerns expressed by the United States Supreme Court in Prouse and Sitz.Â  The checkpoint did not entail random stops, nor were drivers detained for an unreasonable amount of time.Â  Drivers were warned of the approaching checkpoint and afforded the opportunity to turn around.Â  
We do not find the differences among the officers as to their questions or specific actions after the stop to be an unreasonable intrusion into the occupantâ€™s privacy.Â  Additionally, we find the officers did not have â€œunbridled discretion,â€ nor did they have â€œstandardless and unconstrained discretionâ€ in making the stops.Â  Accordingly, we find the checkpoint utilized to stop and detain Gates was appropriate and did not violate the Fourth Amendment.Â  Gates conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.
