title: Dept. of Health and Human Service v. Miller
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Dept. of Health and Human Service, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Moses L. Miller, as PR of the estate of Genobia Washington, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-154
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed March 1, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Zack E. Townsend, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
        George R. Burnett, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The probate court appointed Moses Miller as the personal representative for the estate of his mother, Genobia Washington.Â  The South Carolina Department of Heath and Human Services (DHHS) filed a rule to show cause for Millerâ€™s failure to pay a claim filed by DHHS against Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  After two hearings on the matter, the probate court issued an order finding DHHSâ€™s claim valid and ordering the estate to pay DHHS.Â  Miller appealed the probate courtâ€™s order to the circuit court, which affirmed the probate courtâ€™s order.Â  We also affirm.1 
FACTS

Before her death, Genobia Washington brought a tort action against a third party for injuries she suffered when the van she was riding in came to an abrupt stop causing her to fall out of her wheelchair.Â  After Washingtonâ€™s death, Miller proceeded with the action.Â  DHHS informed Miller it had a right to an assignment from Washington for amounts paid on her behalf by Medicaid as a result of the accident.Â  Miller settled the tort action before trial for $57,500.Â  The trial judge, in his order, specified the terms of the settlement agreement and described how the $57,500 would be allocated.Â  In relation to the amount paid to DHHS, the order states: 

  It further appears that out of the settlement proceeds, the total sum of Seven Thousand Two Hundred Forty-Four and 07/100 ($7,244.07) Dollars is being paid to the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services as full and final settlement of any liens held by the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services.Â  
  . . . 
  Moses Miller, as personal representative of the estate of Genobia Washington, is authorized and directed to pay the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (SCDHHS) the sum of Seven Thousand Two Hundred Forty-Four and 07/100 ($7,244.07) Dollars as full and final satisfaction of any lien held by SCDHHS and that such payment is an accord and satisfaction of the said lien . . . 

After Washingtonâ€™s death, DHHS notified the probate court and Miller of an $81,903.08 claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  Miller did not pay the claim, and DHHS filed a rule to show cause with the probate court seeking payment.Â  The probate court conducted a hearing, during which the parties stipulated that the amount of the claim in dispute was $74,659.01.Â  
Prior to the initial hearing, Miller filed a Corrected Amended Inventory and Appraisement of Washingtonâ€™s estate with the probate court.Â  This filing reflected assets owned by Washington at her death, including her home and property upon which it sits.Â  Under the description of the property, the following notation was made: â€œThis property was condemned by the State of South Carolina D.O.T. for Interstate Right-of-Way.Â  No money was exchanged.â€Â  In addition, neither this filing, nor the Final Accounting filed by Miller, reflected the receipt of any money with regard to the condemnation.Â  
During the hearing, Miller called Donna Crosby, the Director of Right-of-Way for the CRM West Program, which acts as a consultant performing right-of-way acquisitions for the South Carolina Department of Transportation (DOT).Â  While Millerâ€™s attorney examined Crosby, he questioned her about a release executed by DHHS.Â  DHHS executed a claim release releasing its $81,903 creditor claim filed against Washingtonâ€™s estate solely to allow a right-of-way on Washingtonâ€™s property to be conveyed to the DOT.Â  Pursuant to the claim release, DHHS retained its claim against the remainder of Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  When Millerâ€™s attorney asked Crosby if any cash payments were made to Miller in connection with the conveyance to the DOT, the following dialog between Millerâ€™s attorney and Crosby occurred.

  [Crosby].Â  We issued a check for $18,200.
  [Millerâ€™s Attorney].Â  $18,200?
  A.      Yes
  Q.     For payment of the actual piece of property?
  A.   Yes.
  Q.     And who was that paid to?
  A.     Mr. Miller - - I believe it was made payable to Mr. Miller, if I remember correctly.Â  

After cross-examination by the attorney for DHHS, who confirmed the payment outright to Miller, the probate court then questioned Crosby as to the nature of the property rights the DOT received.Â  Crosby informed the court that the purchase of the property was a fee simple conveyance, and the DOT now owned the property outright.Â  In light of Crosbyâ€™s testimony, the probate court issued a Sua Sponte Interim Order requesting a copy of the check for $18,200 payable to Miller.Â  In addition, the court noted a discrepancy in the release signed by Melinda Clark, a representative from DHHS.Â  â€œThe claim release is dated December 18, 2000 but it refers to a Deed, dated December 26, 2000.â€Â  Therefore, the court requested Clarkâ€™s testimony as to the facts and circumstances concerning the release.Â  
Miller also called Doris Pope as a witness during the initial hearing before the probate court.Â  He initially questioned her about her knowledge of the settlement with DHHS relating to the tort action, but proceeded to ask her about her claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  On cross-examination, Pope revealed she was Millerâ€™s fiancÃ© and she did not have a written contract for the services she provided to Washington.Â  The probate court further inquired about Popeâ€™s services and her lack of records as to those services.Â  During the probate courtâ€™s examination of Pope, she admitted she lived with Miller and Washington for the past two years and did not pay rent.Â  
The information requested by the probate judge was provided at a subsequent hearing.Â  The probate court then issued a final order declaring DHHSâ€™s claim valid.Â  In addition, the probate court ordered Miller to pay the $18,200 he received from SCDOT and $2,500 reflecting the value of the household furnishings he received, plus interest, to Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  The probate court also determined the claim presented by Doris Pope was a â€œsham,â€ and ordered her to repay the $5,000 she received from Washingtonâ€™s estate, plus interest.Â  Miller appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the order of the probate court.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

Proceedings in the probate court regarding claims for money due are actions at law.Â  Matter of Estate of Tollison, 320 S.C. 132, 135, 463 S.E.2d 611, 613 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  A probate courtâ€™s findings of fact in an action at law will not be disturbed on appeal unless the record reveals no evidence to support the courtâ€™s findings or the probate court was controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Â Jurisdiction Over DHHSâ€™s Claim for Reimbursement
Miller argues the probate court erred in determining the circuit court did not have jurisdiction to issue an order satisfying both of DHHSâ€™s claims.Â  Essentially, Miller asserts the circuit courtâ€™s order stating the $7,244.07 payment from the settlement â€œas full and final settlement of any liens held by the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services,â€ acted as a full settlement of all claims by DHHS against Washington and her estate.Â  Therefore, he maintains the probate court does not have jurisdiction to review the claim by DHHS against Washingtonâ€™s estate.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
DHHS brought its claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate pursuant to section 43-7-460 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  This section pertains to DHHSâ€™s ability to recover amounts paid for nursing facility care from a recipientâ€™s estate.Â  This section provides, in pertinent part: 

  (A) The State Department of Health and Human Services shall seek recovery of medical assistance paid under the Title XIX State Plan for Medical Assistance from the estate of an individual who:
   . . . 
  
    (2) was fifty-five years of age or older when the individual received medical assistance, but only for medical assistance consisting of nursing facility services, home and community-based services, and hospital and prescription drug services provided to individuals in nursing facilities or receiving home and community-based services.
  

Â§ 43-7-460 (emphasis added).Â  Section 62-1-302 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), states the subject matter jurisdiction of the probate court and provides: 

  (a) To the full extent permitted by the Constitution, and except as otherwise specifically provided, the probate court has exclusive original jurisdiction over all subject matter related to:
  
    (1)  estates of decedents, including the contest of wills, construction of wills, and determination of heirs and successors of decedents and estates of protected persons . . .
  

Section 62-3-104 of the South Carolina Code (1987) describes the procedure under which claims against a decedentâ€™s estate will be administered.Â  This section states:Â  â€œAfter the appointment and until distribution, all proceedings and actions to enforce a claim against the estate are governed by the procedure prescribed by this article [Â§Â§62-3-101 et seq.].â€Â  Â§ 62-3-104.Â  
DHHS brought a claim seeking reimbursement for Medicaid payment made on Washingtonâ€™s behalf for long-term care services provided to her in her home pursuant to section 43-7-460.Â  Section 43-7-460, as cited above, states claims under this section must be brought against the recipientâ€™s estate.Â  Because the Probate Code gives the probate court exclusive original jurisdiction over all matters relating to a decedentâ€™s estate, including claims against that estate, the probate court in this case clearly had exclusive original jurisdiction to determine the validity of DHHSâ€™s claim.Â  Therefore, the probate court did not err in determining the circuit court did not have jurisdiction over this claim and could not have declared it satisfied in its order.Â  
II.Â  Two Separate Claims
Miller argues the probate court erred in determining DHHS had two separate claims.Â  He maintains the claim filed by DHHS, pursuant to section 43-7-440 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) and asserting its right to seek subrogation for medical expenses paid on behalf of Washington, is the same claim brought against her estate in this action.Â  He asserts the only difference in that claim and the claim presented in this action is DHHS brought the former claim against Washington, and DHHS brought the later claim against her estate.Â  We disagree.Â  
In order to address this issue, we must compare the two statutes governing the claims brought by DHHS.Â  First, DHHS brought a claim for subrogation and assignment of rights pursuant to sections 43-7-410 to 450 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), seeking recovery for payments made by Medicaid as a result of the accident in which Washington was injured.Â  Section 43-7-420(a), pertaining to DHHSâ€™s right of assignment of amounts recovered from third parties states:Â  â€œEvery applicant or recipient, only to the extent of the amount of the medical assistance paid by Medicaid, shall be deemed to have assigned his rights to recover such amounts so paid by Medicaid from any third party or private insurer to the State Health and Human Services Finance Commission.â€Â  Section 43-7-430(a), pertaining to DHHSâ€™s right to subrogation, states:Â  â€œThe State Health and Human Services Finance Commission shall be automatically subrogated, only to the extent of the amount of medical assistance paid by Medicaid, to the rights an applicant or recipient may have to recover such amounts so paid by Medicaid from any third party or private insurer.â€
Second, as stated previously, DHHS filed this claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate seeking reimbursement for long-term care services paid by Medicaid.Â  DHHS brought this claim pursuant to section 43-7-460 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004).Â  This section states:

  (A) The State Department of Health and Human Services shall seek recovery of medical assistance paid under the Title XIX State Plan for Medical Assistance from the estate of an individual who:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . 

  
    (2) was fifty-five years of age or older when the individual received medical assistance, but only for medical assistance consisting of nursing facility services, home and community-based services, and hospital and prescription drug services provided to individuals in nursing facilities or receiving home and community-based services.
  

In comparing the nature of these two claims and the statutes under which DHHS brought these claims, we find these claims are two separate and distinct claims and were brought under separate and unrelated sections of the South Carolina Code.Â  The prior claim was against Washington for payments made by Medicaid as a result of an accident for which she recovered from a third party; whereas, this claim is a claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate for reimbursement for payments made by Medicaid for long-term care services.Â  DHHS brought the prior claim pursuant to a statute allowing recovery from a third party tortfeasor.Â  Contrarily, DHHS brought this claim pursuant to a statute allowing for recovery from a recipientâ€™s estate.Â  
The letter from DHHS satisfying the earlier claim based on the tort recovery and settling for the $7,244.07 payment specifically included a release from the Casualty Recovery Department of DHHS only.Â  â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions according to the terms the parties used; understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€ Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  Therefore, we find the probate court did not err in its determination that two claims existed. 
III.Â  Probate Courtâ€™s Sua Sponte Interim Order
Miller argues the probate court erred in conducting its own investigation pursuant to its Sua Sponte Interim Order.Â  Miller argues the probate courtâ€™s actions were improper and in violation of the Code of Judicial Conduct citing to Rule 501, SCACR.Â  We disagree.
Rule 614, SCRE, governing the calling and interrogation of witnesses by the court, provides: 

  (a) Calling by Court.Â  In extraordinary circumstances, the court may, on its own motion or at the suggestion of a party, call witnesses, and all parties are entitled to cross-examine witnesses thus called.Â  Before calling a courtâ€™s witness, the court shall afford the parties a hearing on the matter outside the presence of the jury.
  (b) Interrogation by Court.Â  When required by the interests of justice only, the court may interrogate witnesses.

The testimony provided by Crosby, as compared with Millerâ€™s prior filings with the probate court, indicates a discrepancy in his representations to the probate court.Â  We find these circumstances are extraordinary and meet the requirements pursuant to Rule 614, SCRE, allowing the probate court to call an additional witness.Â  In addition, the probate court afforded both parties notice of Clarkâ€™s testimony and the opportunity to cross-examine her, and therefore, neither was prejudiced by her testimony.Â  
IV.Â  Invalidation of the Claim Release 
Miller asserts the probate court erred in finding the claim release executed by DHHSâ€™s in favor of the South Carolina Department of Transportation invalid.Â  Miller contends DHHS did not make a claim against the real property purchased by the DOT.Â  Therefore, the probate court improperly raised the issue on its own.Â  
In our review of the record, we find this issue was not properly preserved for appellate review.Â  â€œIn order to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 399, 570 S.E.2d 176, 180 (2002).Â  Miller did not object on the record to the judgeâ€™s raising of this issue.Â  Accordingly, we are unable to consider it on appeal.Â  
V.Â  Invalidation of Doris Popeâ€™s Claim
Miller also argues the probate court erred in invalidating Doris Popeâ€™s claim in its final order.Â  His argument is similar to the argument made with regard to the probate courtâ€™s invalidation of the claim release.Â  Miller asserts DHHS did not contest this claim, and therefore, the probate court improperly invalidated her claim.Â  
Again, we find this issue was not properly preserved for appellate review because Miller failed to make an objection on the record.Â  Mizell, 351 S.C. at 399, 570 S.E.2d at 180.Â  Therefore, we find the probate court did not err in addressing the validity of Popeâ€™s claim.Â  
CONCLUSION
The probate court did not err in determining the circuit court did not have jurisdiction over this claim brought by DHHS and in determining this claim is a separate and distinct claim from DHHSâ€™s prior claim relating to Washingtonâ€™s tort claim against a third party.Â  In addition, the probate court did not act improperly in issuing its Sua Sponte Interim Order requesting additional testimony and evidence.Â  Finally, Millerâ€™s claims that the probate court erred in addressing the validity of the claim release executed by DHHS and the validity of Popeâ€™s claim against Washingtonâ€™s estate were not properly preserved for appellate review.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit court affirming the probate court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Kimbrell v. Kimbrell
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dorothy Ann Hamilton Kimbrell, Appellant,
v.
William Calvin Kimbrell, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-145
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed March 3, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
O.W. Bannister, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, and Kim R. Varner, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This is an appeal of a family courtâ€™s equitable distribution of marital assets.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
Dorothy Ann Hammond Kimbrell (Wife) and William Calvin Kimbrell, Jr. (Husband) married on February 27, 1982 and had three children together.Â  On February 16, 2000,Wife filed an action for divorce on the ground of physical cruelty and prayed for custody of the minor children, equitable division of the marital property, alimony, child support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Following a hearing, the family court issued a temporary order requiring, among other things, Husband to pay the guardian ad litemâ€™s initial fee of $1,000.Â  It ordered Husband to â€œmaintain use of the marital home and . . . be responsible for any insurance, taxes, costs, maintenance, or upkeep associated therewith.â€Â  The court also ordered Husband to pay Wife $4000 a month in unallocated support.Â  
By consent of the parties, Wife subsequently moved back into the marital home.Â  When Husband refused to continue paying the utilities and mortgage, Wife brought a rule to show cause action against him to enforce compliance with the temporary order.Â  The family court held that Husband was not in contempt because he was not required to pay $4000 in support as well as be responsible for the mortgage and the utilities of the marital residence.Â  
The parties entered into an agreement, approved by the family court, that placed custody of the children with Wife and equally divided the proceeds from the sale of the marital home, a 401K Plan, and the remainder of the marital estate, leaving the determination of which assets and debts constituted the marital estate for the family court.Â  The family court issued the order of divorce on the ground of continuous and uninterrupted separation for more than one year.Â  The family court subsequently issued a final order on the equitable division of the assets and debts in May of 2002.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court, nor does it relieve the appellant of the burden of convincing us that the family court committed error.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.                   Deferred Cash Bonus Program

Wife claims the trial court erred in excluding the post-separation portion of the incentive deferred cash bonus program from the marital estate.Â  She also claims it erred in estimating this income to be taxable to Husband at 40%.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe term â€˜marital propertyâ€™ means all real and personal property, which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  Husbandâ€™s employerâ€™s deferred cash bonus program rewarded employees who were â€œproductive employee[s] of [the] companyâ€ and in good standing with the company for four years.Â  As the Wife acknowledges in her brief, the Husband received the bonuses â€œas an incentive to continue his employment.â€Â  The amount of the bonus was based on Husbandâ€™s earnings for a particular year.Â  However, he was not entitled to the funds unless he worked for the company for four more years and did not report those monies on his taxes until distribution at the end of the fourth year.Â  The trial court awarded Wife, after the subtraction of 40% to pay Husbandâ€™s taxes on each bonus, 75% of the 1997 deferred bonus, 50% of the 1998 deferred bonus, and 25% of the 1999 deferred bonus, if they ever vested.Â  
We find that the family courtâ€™s calculation of the marital portion of the deferred bonus program is not unreasonable.Â  Although the amount Husband earned for the bonuses was based on the market each year he was employed, he earned them by staying with the company for four more years.Â  The bonuses did not actually vest until they matured four years later, and he would not have received the monies if he left the company before the four years expired.Â  Thus, Husband had not earned the entire amount of the bonuses at the time of the filing of marital litigation.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the family court prorating the bonuses.
We also find no error in the family courtâ€™s deduction of 40% of the bonuses prior to division to allow for taxes.Â  The family court must consider the tax consequences to each party as a result of equitable apportionment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(11) (Supp. 2004).Â  Husband testified that the distribution flows to him as taxable income at the tax rate of 40%.Â  We find the family courtâ€™s estimation of the Husbandâ€™s tax consequences was not unreasonable.Â  

II.                Wachovia stock

Wife claims the family court erred in finding one account included the Wachovia stock from Husbandâ€™s incentive program.Â  We disagree.
Husband testified that the Wachovia ILJ account encompassed the incentive program stocks.Â  Though Wife claims Husband did not produce some of the accounts in his property disclosure, she offers no evidence to the contrary.Â  Furthermore, Husband testified on cross-examination that Wife confused the accounts and double counted stock.Â  The family court, which was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of Husband and Wife in regard to the confusion in documentation, found Husband disclosed all the accounts.Â  The family court treated the account as marital property and divided it equitably.Â  Therefore, there was sufficient evidence for the family court to conclude that the incentive program stock was part and parcel of the Wachovia stock.Â  

III.             IRA

Wife argues the family court erred in finding an IRA was non-marital.Â  Husband testified that the IRA, which he had held for seven years, was a rollover from his pre-marital employment with the exception of a percentage earned during two years of the marriage.Â  Though Wife testified that the entire IRA was marital property, she offered no evidence otherwise.Â  Husband admits the family court erred in holding the entire IRA was non-marital.Â  Therefore, we modify the order of the family court and hold 2/7 of the IRA is marital property and should be divided equally between the parties.Â  

IV.            Marital fund withdrawals

Wife argues the family court erred in finding certain payments made from the marital fund to be marital debt.Â  We disagree.Â  Husband paid numerous marital debts from the marital fund.Â  The family court then ordered half of the debts to be deducted from Wifeâ€™s portion of the marital assets.Â  
A. Guardian ad litem fees
In the temporary order, the family court ordered Husband to make the initial $1,000 payment to the guardian ad litem based on his available cash flow.Â  In the final order, the family court ordered Wife to be responsible for $1000 of the remaining $1500 balance owed to the guardian, finding that â€œthe expenditure of time by the guardian was necessitated by [Wifeâ€™s] actions and the fact that even after the expiration of two (2) years [Husband] still has not had a visitation with his daughters.â€Â  It held that the $1000 Husband withdrew from a marital account to pay the initial fee was an expense to be shared equally between the parties.Â  â€œAn award of guardian ad litem fees lies within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Nash v. Byrd, 298 S.C. 530, 537, 381 S.E.2d 913, 917 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  As the family court found the fees were incurred due to the wifeâ€™s conduct, we find no abuse of discretion in the court ordering the wife to be responsible for a majority of the fees.Â  Furthermore, the wife failed to cite any authority prohibiting the family court from reallocating the payment of the guardian fees ordered in the temporary order.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s allocation of the guardianâ€™s fees.Â  
B. BellSouth phone bill 
Wife claims a bill from Bell South for $206.73 should be entirely Husbandâ€™s responsibility.Â  However, Wife admitted the bill was due before she moved out of the marital home.Â  Husband testified he gave Wife money for the bill at the time it was due.Â  Although Wife claimed she had paid the bill, Husband testified that he paid the bill in April because it had not been paid.Â  The family court, in finding the bill was a marital debt, â€œreceived ample testimony that the said bills were incurred prior to the separation and were for the benefit of the family.â€Â  As the family court was in the best position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses, we find no error in its holding that the bill was a marital debt.Â  See Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
C. Pharmacy bill
Based on the testimony of the parties, the family court also found the pharmacy bill to be marital debt.Â  Wife admitted the bill, which was for prescriptions for Wife and the partiesâ€™ son, became due before the parties separated.Â  Her only argument against being responsible for part of the bill was that she thought because Husband did not send her the bill, it was his personal bill.Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s determination that this bill was in fact a marital debt.Â  
D. Cable bill and mortgage payment
Husband testified he paid the mortgage payment for February in June of 2000.Â  In addition, Husband claimed that in July of 2000 he had to pay two months of cable bills because the bills had not been paid at the time Wife left the marital home.Â  The family court found Husbandâ€™s testimony credible and declared this to be marital debt.Â  As the family court was in the best position to observe and evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and their conflicting testimony, we find no error in this determination.Â  See Bowers, 349 S.C. at 91, 561 S.E.2d at 613.Â  
E. Furniture
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Finally, the wife challenges the family courtâ€™s holding that bedding Husband purchased constituted marital debt.Â  The family court determined the parties had agreed during mediation to use money from the marital funds to purchase bedroom furniture for the children to use when they visited Husband because Wife retained all of the original furniture.Â  The record reflects evidence of this agreement.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not err in deducting half of the costs of the furniture from Wifeâ€™s share of the marital assets.Â  

V.               Jewelry

Wife argues the trial court erred in finding her jewelry had increased in value.Â  We disagree.
Wife listed all of her jewelry as valued at $7,450.00.Â  The family court noted Husband valued the jewelry at a retail price of $35,000.Â  The court rejected both of these valuations.Â  Considering all of the evidence, the family court valued the marital portion of all jewelry to be $12,500.00.Â  This amount included the marital portion of the engagement ring and all of the wifeâ€™s other jewelry.Â  The original engagement ring was stolen and replaced with a more expensive ring after the parties had been married some years.Â  The court recognized Husband had documentation to support a valuation of Wifeâ€™s engagement ring of almost $9000 â€œbased on 1995 prices and that the $5000.00 Dollar wholesale increase in the engagement ring was not considered in the said coverage.â€Â  Husband valued the remaining jewelry as $7,500.Â  As the family courtâ€™s valuation of the jewelry was within the range of evidence, we find no error.Â  See Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating the family courtâ€™s valuation of property will be affirmed if it is within the range of the evidence).

VI.            Mortgage payments

Wife claims the family court erred in deducting five months of mortgage payments from her one half share of the marital property.Â  We disagree.Â  
Â Â Â Â  The temporary order required Husband to pay the mortgage for the months now being attributed to Wife.Â  However, in the same order, the family court awarded Wife $4000 a month in unallocated support.Â  In its order refusing to hold Husband in contempt for failure to pay the mortgage the family court clarified the temporary order by finding Husband was not responsible for making the mortgage and utility payments in a house in which he no longer resided because the temporary order â€œwas . . . predicated on [Husband] having possession of the marital residence at his costs.â€Â  Husband continued to pay wife $4000 a month in support during this time.Â  Based on the courtâ€™s finding, Wife was responsible for the mortgage payments on the home beginning with the month she moved back into the house.Â  Therefore, we find the family court correctly ordered the five months of mortgage payments be deducted from Wifeâ€™s share of the marital assets.Â  Â  
CONCLUSION
As Husband admitted that 2/7 of the IRA at issue was marital, we modify the family courtâ€™s decision finding the entire IRA was non-marital and hold 2/7 of the IRA is marital property for purposes of equitable distribution.Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s decisions as to the remainder of property at issue on appeal.Â  The family courtâ€™s order is hereby
 Affirmed AS MODIFIED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lou Lindsey, Iris Hill and Emma Cade, formerly known as Emma Ferguson,
Appellants,
v.
David H. Alexander and Golden Creek Baptist Church, Julius C.
Hydrick, Jr., Individually and as Trustee of the Corinne E. Hydrick Residuary Trust,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-150
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed March 3, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
R. Murray Hughes, of Pickens, for Appellants.Â  
Harry I. Rivers, Jr., of Easley; Herman E. Cox, of Greenville; and Kenneth D. Acker, of Pickens, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lou Lindsey, Iris Hill, and Emma Cade (Appellants) appeal the trial courtâ€™s determination that a road joining the partiesâ€™ property with neighboring landowners is not a public road or easement and that any private easement interest was abandoned or lost by adverse possession. We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Lindsey and Hill purchased 59.5 acres of property in 1990.Â  A river bisects their property, dividing it into a 20-acre eastern tract and a 39.5-acre western tract upon which the couple built their home.Â  There is no longer a bridge over the river, and it cannot be crossed by a vehicle at any point that it passes through their property.[2]Â  
Plats of the property show the location of an old road running from the river on the eastern tract, the opposite side of the river from where the home is located, across the property of Emma Cade, a landlocked 20 acre tract situated between the Lindsey/Hill parcel and the property belonging to David Alexander and Golden Creek Baptist Church (Respondents).Â  The plats indicate the road continues eastward forming the southern and northern boundary of the Alexander and Golden Creek properties respectively.Â  The old road terminates at a gate placed there by Alexander.Â  
Alexander blocked access to the road sometime around 1990 or 1991 by placing a metal cable and later a gate at the point where the road intersects the main highway between his property and the churchâ€™s property.Â  The road has remained unused since Alexander erected the gate. Â It has been in serious disrepair for decades and is impassable by vehicular traffic.Â  
Appellants brought a declaratory judgment action against Alexander, Golden Creek Baptist Church, and a Trustee of the Hydrick Residuary Trust arguing the road was, or at one time had been, a public road or easement entitling them to access.Â  They requested injunctive relief requiring Alexander to remove the gate.Â  The trial court ruled in favor of Alexander, finding the road was not a public road or an easement and that if it â€œhad ever been at one time in the distant past, some type of public or private road, easement or highway, clearly and unquestionably it has been abandoned as such and has been extinguished as either a public or private easement.â€[3]Â  
DISCUSSION
A suit for declaratory relief may be legal or equitable, and is characterized as such by the nature of the underlying issue outlined in the complaint.Â  Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 86, 473 S.E.2d 474, 476 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law action.Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed unless there is no evidence to support them.Â  Townes Assoc., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
First, Appellants contend the trial court erred by determining the road was not a public easement, road, or highway.Â  We disagree.
In Outlaw v. Moise, 222 S.C. 24, 71 S.E.2d 509 (1952), our supreme court established the rule for proving the existence of a public easement.Â  The court stated:

[W]here lands are platted and sales are made with reference to the plat, the acts of the owner in themselves merely create private rights in the grantees to the use of the streets and ways laid down on the plat or referred to in the conveyance.Â  But these rights are purely in the nature of private rights founded upon a grant or covenant, and no public rights attach to such streets or lands until there has been an express or implied acceptance of the dedication, evidenced either by general public use or by the acts of the public authorities.

Id, at 31, 71 S.E.2d at 512 (emphasis added).
Troy Porter, Director of Roads and Bridges for Pickens County for over 20 years, testified the road in question had never been dedicated to the public or maintained by Pickens County.Â  Porter also testified he was personally familiar with the area and considered the road an â€œold trail or private road.â€Â  The parties all agree the road has been impassable for decades and remains blocked by trees and deep gullies prohibiting general public use. Accordingly, we find there was sufficient evidence contained in the record to support the special refereeâ€™s finding the road failed to qualify as a public easement or roadway. 
Next, Appellants argue the trial court erred by finding any private easement they, or their predecessors in title, may have had in the road was abandoned.Â  We disagree.
The primary elements of abandonment are the ownerâ€™s intention to abandon and either his express declaration or the external act by which his intention is carried into effect.Â  Immanuel Baptist Church of N. Augusta v. Barnes, 274 S.C. 125, 131, 264 S.E.2d 142, 144-45 (1980).Â  Hill testified that when she and her husband bought their land, the road required a four-wheel drive vehicle to traverse it, and that she had seen no vehicles on the road since they purchased the property.Â  There was no evidence in the record Appellants attempted to use the road or clear the overgrowth to make it passable.Â  Alexander testified no one had objected to his actions blocking the entrance to the road or sought access since he erected the metal cable and later a gate.Â  He further testified that from the time his father acquired his property in the mid-1960s, the road has never been used, and since he moved onto the property in 1979, he has never seen a vehicle on the road.Â  Finally, aerial photographs introduced into evidence show the road diminishing in clarity between 1965 and 1987.Â  Moreover, it is undisputed the road is now impassable.Â  Accordingly, we find sufficient evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that any private easement that may have existed has been abandoned.
The trial court found that even if any private easement had not been abandoned, Appellants lost any right they may have had to the use of the road because Alexander extinguished them by adverse possession.Â  Although Appellants challenge this finding, we need not address the issue because the ruling that any private easement has been abandoned disposes of the case.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is
dispositive).  
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  A bridge that once connected the two tracts washed away during a flood in the 1930s and was never rebuilt.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court noted that counsel for Golden Creek made a brief appearance stating the church â€œdid not and would not take an active part in the litigation.â€Â  The court also noted the Hydrick trust failed to appear.Â  Alexander was the only defendant to file a response.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Timothy Darrell Davis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-152
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 4, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Timothy Darrell Davis appeals his murder conviction, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to clarify its voluntary manslaughter jury instruction, specifically its explanation of sufficient legal provocation.Â  We affirm.[1]
BACKGROUND

This case arises from the September 2001 stabbing death of Heath Barnette.Â  Barnette was having a relationship with Davisâ€™ estranged wife, Lorinda, and was her co-worker at Miracle Hill Ministries.Â  Davis and Lorinda separated in January or February of 2001.Â  Davis wanted to reconcile with Lorinda and saw Barnette as an obstacle to that goal.Â  Beginning in June, Davis began contacting Lorindaâ€™s family as well as supervisors and clergy at her workplace to discuss the situation.Â  He asked questions about Barnette and his relationship with Lorinda, asked others to intervene, and asked for a meeting where he could confront Barnette.Â  He also asked Lorinda to stop seeing Barnette and told her he would not let her have a divorce.Â  
Additionally, in separate conversations with both Lorinda and her mother, Davis threatened to take the coupleâ€™s two children away and keep them from Lorinda.Â  Because of these threats, Lorinda moved the children to an undisclosed out-of-state location until she could handle the matter in court.Â  
The stabbing occurred on September 3, approximately four to six weeks after Lorinda relocated the children.Â  Eyewitnesses saw two men leave Lorindaâ€™s apartment.Â  The first man, bleeding from a wound, was being chased by the other, who was wielding a knife.[2]Â  Some of the witnesses reported seeing the man with the knife repeatedly stabbing or attempting to stab the injured man.Â  When Barnette eventually fell to the ground, Davis ran back to his truck.Â  
In a written statement to police, Davis offered the following version of events.Â  He entered Lorindaâ€™s apartment through a window, reportedly to find information about his children.Â  Inside he encountered Barnette, who was already in the apartment.Â  Barnette asked Davis to leave and threatened to call the police. Â Davis actually encouraged Barnette to call because he did not think Barnette should be in the apartment.Â  Davis offered to leave if Barnette would go outside with him so other people could see they had both been in Lorindaâ€™s apartment.Â  Barnette said one of them was leaving and started making threatening advances, came at Davis to grab him, and then came at Davis swinging.Â  Davis grabbed a knife from the block on the kitchen counter and told Barnette he did not want to hurt him but did not want to get hurt.Â  Davis suggested they go outside, but Barnette continued to move toward him.Â  Davis explained he was wielding the knife to keep Barnette away.Â  He said, â€œI jabbed the knife outward away from me.Â  And it stuck him in his right side/abdomen.Â  I wanted to only cut him at worst, but wound up stabbing him partly due to our momentum while moving toward each other.â€ Â After the stabbing, Davis followed Barnette outside and got in his truck, still holding the knife.Â  He then left, stopping to throw the knife in the river.Â  In earlier oral statements to police as well as conversations with Lorindaâ€™s mother and a pastor, Davis told basically the same story except that in those conversations he claimed Barnette lunged at him, running into the knife.Â  In his conversation with a pastor, Davis admitted that once outside the apartment, he â€œyelled something after [Barnette] to the effect of this will teach you to mess around with another guyâ€™s wife,â€ before realizing what he had done and fleeing the scene.Â  
The State asked the court â€œto charge number one, adultery as provocation, adultery, and manslaughter charge.â€Â  The trial court agreed, and confirmed it would charge on murder, voluntary manslaughter, self-defense, and accident.Â  Davisâ€™ counsel told the trial court, â€œI think the facts -- the four charges that youâ€™re going to charge are sufficient.â€Â  The trial court instructed the jury as indicated and included the following explanation of voluntary manslaughter:

  Now manslaughter is defined as the taking of a human being -- the life of a human being without malice, but in sudden heat of passion when the heat of passion is caused or brought about by a sufficient legal provocation.Â  If a person flies into a sudden heat of passion upon a sufficient legal provocation and it results in the death of another, the law says that the act having been done under those circumstances, it would be manslaughter and not murder.
  To illustrate, if I were to go up to one of you and commit an unwarranted attack upon you say by striking you in the face and you acting under the heat of passion aroused by my act of hitting you were to kill me then you would not be guilty of murder but of manslaughter because you killed me in sudden heat of passion caused by my unwarranted attack.
  Now, ladies and gentlemen, I charge you that murder may be reduced to manslaughter if the act was committed in the heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.Â  I just explained that to you.
  And I further charge you that adultery may in some instances serve as a sufficient legal provocation.Â  However, spousal adultery is not a license to kill.Â  The killing of a paramour may be reduced from murder to manslaughter where -- only where they are -- where the couple or paramour and the spouse are found engaged in sexual intercourse or some close embrace because this could constitute sufficient legal provocation.
  Therefore the stabbing of a paramour may be reduced from murder to manslaughter where a couple, a paramour and a spouse are found engaged in sexual intercourse or some other close contact because this could constitute a sufficient legal provocation.
  However, ladies and gentlemen, I charge you that where there has been a cooling off time sufficient for a person of ordinary reason and control to rid himself of the overpowering passion caused by the act and the stabbing, the law would say that thatâ€™s murder and not manslaughter.Â  

Davisâ€™ counsel asked the trial court to clarify the jury instruction by explaining a paramour can also â€œbe a slapper,â€ but the court found it had adequately covered the definition of sufficient legal provocation.Â  The jury found Davis guilty of murder and the trial court sentenced him to life in prison.Â  
DISCUSSION

Davis argues the trial courtâ€™s instruction was confusing and did not fit the facts of the case, because it failed to sufficiently define legal provocation as it relates to adultery.Â  Davis suggests the trial court should have explained more clearly that although a person must find his spouse engaged in a close embrace for adultery to constitute sufficient legal provocation, if the spouseâ€™s paramour attacks the person, that may constitute sufficient legal provocation to reduce the murder to manslaughter.Â  Read as a whole, the charge did not constitute reversible error.
A trial court must determine the law to be charged based on the evidence at trial.Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d. 110, 112 (2003).Â  The trial court should charge only the law applicable to the case, because the purpose of jury instructions is to enlighten the jury.Â  State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 836 (1989).Â  Jury instructions that do not fit the facts of the case may confuse the jury.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, a jury charge must be reviewed in its entirety and if the charge as a whole is free from error, isolated portions that may be misleading do not constitute reversible error. Â State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 554, 446 S.E.2d 411, 415 (1994).Â  â€œThe substance of the law must be charged to the jury, not particular verbiage.â€Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 303 (2002). 
â€œVoluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.â€Â  State v. Cooley, 342 S.C. 63, 67, 536 S.E.2d 666, 668 (2000).Â  Spousal adultery may serve as sufficient legal provocation, but is not a license to kill.Â  State v. Gadsden, 314 S.C. 229, 233, 442 S.E.2d, 594, 597 (1994).Â  For example, the case of a killer lying in wait or searching for the guilty embrace is not one involving sufficient legal provocation.Â  Id. 
As part of its jury charge, the trial court enumerated the elements of voluntary manslaughter.Â  It further defined sufficient legal provocation, providing examples of an unwarranted attack as well as provocation resulting from a person finding his spouse in a guilty embrace with a paramour.Â  The trial court also explained why not all situations involving an adulterous spouse serve to reduce murder to manslaughter.Â  Even if somewhat confusing, the trial court sufficiently explained the law of voluntary manslaughter.Â  In fact, the evidence focused heavily on the relationship between Lorinda and Barnette, and Davisâ€™s near obsession with it, thereby raising the adulterous spouse issue to the trial court.Â  The trial court instructed the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter, including situations involving adultery but also including provocation from an unwarranted attack.Â  The jury charge was based on the evidence presented and the relevant law.Â  The charge was without reversible error.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  One witness testified he had also seen the same man walk up to Lorindaâ€™s apartment the day before the stabbing.Â

title: Blassingame v. Mount Vernon Mills, Inc.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        James Blassingame, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Mount Vernon Mills, Inc. and Claim Management Services, Defendants,
        Of Whom Mount Vernon Mills, Inc. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-153
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 4, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Tracy Welsh Tiddy, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Michael Smith, Logan, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mt. Vernon Mills, Inc., the Employer, appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the decision of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the Panel held Claimant James Blassingame had failed to timely give notice to the Employer that he had sustained an injury at work.Â  We reverse. [1] Â Â Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Blassingame worked in the shipping department of the Employer.Â  He alleged that on October 9, 2001, he injured his back while pulling a roll of cloth.Â  Blassingame stated that he immediately told his co-worker, Clarence Thomason that he had hurt his back.Â  Thomason confirmed that Blassingame had told him about the injury and that he advised him to report it to their supervisor, Lee Pruett.Â  Blassingame approached Pruett and told her his back was hurting.Â  Pruett went to her supervisor, Brian Pilgrim, because Blassingame had numerous â€œoccurrencesâ€ on his work record from leaving work early.Â  Pilgrim and Pruett explained to Blassingame that because of the prior occurrences, he was possibly facing termination under company policy if he garnered additional occurrences.Â  Blassingame stated that when he was told that if he left work, he may be fired, he returned to work.Â  About thirty minutes later, he returned to Pruett to tell her that he had to leave because of his back pain.Â  Although Pruett acknowledged that Blassingame spoke to her about the back pain he was experiencing and asked to be allowed to leave and see a doctor, she denied that he told her he had been injured while working.Â  
Blassingame saw his family doctor, Dr. Winston Floyd, that day.Â  A week later, he presented an excuse from Dr. Floyd to Pruett.Â  In this excuse Dr. Floyd wrote:

  Mr. Blassingame was seen in this office on October 9, 2001, complaining of severe low back pain.Â  Examination at that time was suggestive of the possibility of disk disease.Â  He was started on Vioxx, 50 mg a day and placed on warm compresses and given a work excuse until the following Friday.Â  X-rays of the lumbar sacral spine were taken.
  When he returned for follow-up evaluation he had excellent response with Vioxx without complete resolution of the pain.Â  X-Ray exam showed extensive mild degenerative changes of the vertebral disk.Â  

By the time Blassingame presented the doctorâ€™s excuse, the Employer had terminated his employment due to his absences.
Blassingame filed a Form 50 on February 5, 2002.Â  The Employer denied the claim, asserting in part that it was not given notice of the injury.Â  The Single Commissioner held Blassingame had properly notified the Employer of his work related accident and back injury.Â  She further held Blassingame had sustained a compensable work related injury and was entitled to medical treatment and temporary total compensation until he reached maximum medical improvement.Â  The Employer appealed this decision to the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  The Appellate Panel reversed the decision of the Single Commissioner.Â  It held Blassingame failed to meet his burden of proof to establish he had given notice of his injury within 90 days as required by law.Â  It further held Blassingame had failed to give a reasonable excuse for not providing adequate notice and that the Employer was prejudiced by his failure to give notice.Â  Blassingame appealed to the circuit court, which reversed the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions does not prevent the Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusions from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).
The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  â€œAlthough it is logical for the [Appellate Panel], which did not have the benefit of observing the witnesses, to give weight to the Single Commissionerâ€™s opinion, the [Appellate Panel] is empowered to make its own findings of fact and to reach its own conclusions of law consistent or inconsistent with those of the Single Commissioner.â€Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 454-55, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the [Appellate Panel].Â  It is not the task of this Court to weigh the evidence as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442 (citations omitted). 
DISCUSSION

The Employer argues the circuit court erred in reversing the decision of the Appellate Panel of the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission.Â  We agree.
The statutory notice requirements provide:

  Every injured employee or his representative shall immediately on the occurrence of an accident, or as soon thereafter as practicable, give or cause to be given to the employer a notice of the accident and the employee shall not be entitled to physicianâ€™s fees nor to any compensation which may have accrued under the terms of this Title prior to the giving of such notice, unless it can be shown that the employer, his agent or representative, had knowledge of the accident or that the party required to give such notice had been prevented from doing so by reason of physical or mental incapacity or the fraud or deceit of some third person.Â  No compensation shall be payable unless such notice is given within ninety days after the occurrence of the accident or death, unless reasonable excuse is made to the satisfaction of the Commission for not giving such notice and the Commission is satisfied that the employer has not been prejudiced thereby.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).
This section does not provide a specific method of giving notice.Â  Hanks v. Blair Mills, 286 S.C. 378, 381, 335 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The purpose of the notice provision is to actually put the employer on notice of the injury so it can investigate it immediately after its occurrence and can furnish medical care for the employee in order to minimize the disability and its own liability.Â  Id.Â  â€œFor adequate notice, there must be â€˜some knowledge of accompanying facts connecting the injury or illness with the employment, and indicating to a reasonably conscientious manager that the case might involve a potential compensation claim.â€™â€ Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 457, 562 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 126.03[1][b] (2001)).Â  Although the provision for notice should be liberally construed in favor of claimants, â€œthere are limitations upon that rule and the statutory requirement cannot be disregarded altogether.â€Â  Mintz v. Fiske-Carter Constr. Co., 218 S.C. 409, 414, 63 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1951).
In Hanks, this court found the employer was put on notice based on the claimantâ€™s medical and work history and by a letter from the company doctor, in which the doctor stated the claimant was suffering from chronic lung disease and recommended a transfer to an area having a dust level at or below the permissible exposure limits.Â  Similarly, in Etheredge, this court found a doctorâ€™s letter, in which the doctor stated the claimant had acute muscle spasms and strains that were aggravated by overhead lifting, in addition to the claimantâ€™s known work history as a draw/wind operator, which required her to lift heavy spools above her head, provided the employer with adequate notice.Â  In both Hanks and Etheredge, this court found the Commissionâ€™s findings of adequate notice were supported by substantial evidence.Â  
Blassingame testified that he told Pruett that he had hurt his back pulling a roll of cloth.Â  His co-worker, Clarence Thomason, confirmed that Blassingame told him about his back injury.Â  He also stated he saw Blassingame speaking with Pruett, but did not hear what he said.Â  Blassingame presented medical notes from his orthopedist and physical therapist in which it is noted he stated he experienced an onset of back pain while pulling a roll and that he had reported this to his supervisor.Â  
Pruett and Pilgrim, however, denied Blassingame had blamed the pain of which he complained on a work-related injury.Â  Pruett testified, â€œHe had told me that he was, that he had hurt his back, that his back, actually he said that his back was hurting and that he wanted to go to the doctor.â€Â  She stated he never mentioned hurting his back while pulling the roll.Â  Pruett explained that it did not strike her as unusual that Blassingame requested to leave in order to see a doctor because he â€œwas always going somewhere.â€Â  She stated he had many occurrences on his record for leaving work for one reason or the other.Â  She explained that when she was talking to him on the day of the alleged accident, her main concern was whether he would be fired because of all of the occurrences.Â  She did not conduct any type of investigation into the cause of Blassingameâ€™s back pain.Â  
Pruett stated that when Blassingame brought her the doctorâ€™s excuse a week after his last day at work, he did not say anything to her about it.Â  Rather, he walked in, gave her the note, and walked out.Â  This doctorâ€™s excuse does not specify that Blassingame injured his back at work.Â  
In addition, Blassingame had sustained a back injury in the past.Â  Pilgrim testified he was aware of Blassingameâ€™s back problems and that he knew Blassingame was taking Vioxx before his termination.Â  He also stated that Blassingame had requested a medication called Back Well in the past.Â  
The circuit court held:Â  

  [T]he contradictory testimony of [Blassingameâ€™s] supervisor is not sufficient to overcome the direct testimony of [Blassingame] that he advised his supervisor of his work related injury, the corroborating testimony of Clarence Thomason, medical evidence from the same day of the accident and later which shows that the Claimant reported a work related injury, and Dr. Floydâ€™s note and work excuse provided to the employer a few days after the accident.Â  

In making this finding, the circuit court improperly weighed the evidence.Â  The question in reviewing an appeal from the Appellate Panel is not whether there is substantial evidence to support the appealing partyâ€™s position, but whether there is substantial evidence to support the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â  See Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc. 336 S.C. 154, 161, 519 S.E.2d 102, 106 (1999) (finding that although there was evidence from which the Commission could have found the other way, there was also clearly evidence which would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion it reached, and thus the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the Commissionâ€™s decision).Â  We find substantial evidence does exist in this case to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision that Blassingame failed to properly notify the Employer of his injury.Â  
Pruett and Pilgrim both testified that while Blassingame complained of back pain, he did not inform them that he had been injured while working.Â  They stated his request to leave was not unusual given his history of leaving work early.Â  Furthermore, they were aware that in the past Blassingame had some back problems for which he had taken Vioxx and requested additional medication from the Employer.Â  Considering these facts, the Appellate Panel could reasonably conclude that the doctorâ€™s excuse, which did not specify Blassingame had sustained a work-related injury, was not enough to put the Employer on notice of a potential workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
In addition, we find the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination that the Employer was prejudiced by the lack of notice is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Pruett and Pilgrim both testified that if Blassingame had reported a work-related injury, the Employer would have conducted an investigation.Â  Because of Blassingameâ€™s failure to provide adequate notice of his injury, the Employer was not able to conduct this investigation.Â  We furthermore find substantial evidence to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision that Blassingame failed to provide a reasonable excuse for not providing notice.Â  
As substantial evidence exists in the record to support the findings of the Appellate Panel, the circuit court erred in reversing the Panelâ€™s decision.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
REVERSED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â 

 [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
