title: Charleston County Department of Social Services v. King
text:
On October 15, 1999, Casey Ashlee, Ashley King, and Cody King were placed in emergency protective custody



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Charleston County Department of Social Services, Plaintiff, and John Roe and Mary Roe, Intervenors, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Pamela King, Kenneth King, Jr., and Cody King, a child, D/O/B- 03/24/97, Defendants,
        of whom Pamela King is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-155
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed March 4, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Robert V. DeMarco, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        FramptonÂ  Durban, Jr., Chief Counsel Charleston Cnty. DSS, of N. Charleston and R. Glenn Lister, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
        Ellen Babb, of N. Charleston, and Ruth F. Buck, of Sullivans Island, for Guardian Ad Litem
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Pamela King appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights to her son Cody.Â  We reverse.
FACTS

In October of 1999, Pamela, her husband Kenneth King, and their three children, Casey, Ashley, and Cody, were traveling through South Carolina in route from Pennsylvania to make a new home in Texas near Pamelaâ€™s family. At the time Casey was age 9, Ashley was almost 5, and Cody was approximately two and a half.[1]Â  On October 15, 1999, the children were taken into emergency protective custody by Charleston County Department of Social Services (DSS) after the parents were arrested for attempting to pass a fraudulent check at a Wal-Mart and what was identified as a â€œcrack pipeâ€ was found in Pamelaâ€™s purse.Â  
In a March 20, 2000 order, the family court adopted a treatment plan agreed upon by DSS and the parents.Â  The court required the children to remain in DSS custody until the parents successfully completed a placement plan.Â  Among other things, this plan required substance abuse counseling, parental counseling, and counseling addressing anger management and criminal domestic violence.Â Â  
In February of 2000, Kenneth and Pamela moved to Hardeeville, South Carolina.Â  Pamela began working toward the completion of her treatment plan.Â  She completed her parenting classes in September of 2000.Â  In February of 2001, she completed a class on relationship issues sponsored by a family violence treatment center.Â  During this time, Pamela paid the child support obligation for approximately six months before beginning to pay it only sporadically.Â  Pamela testified that she paid the child support to the best of her ability.Â  
In October of 2000, the foster care review board recommended termination of the parental rights of Kenneth and Pamela.Â  Pamela testified that it was at this time she began using cocaine from October of 2000 until June of 2001 due to her despondency over losing her children and at Kennethâ€™s prompting.Â  She acknowledged that she continued using it until June of 2001.Â  In April of 2001, the family court issued a permanence planning order adopting a plan for all three children of termination of parental rights and adoption.Â  In the order, the court noted that there had been some compliance by Pamela but not enough to remedy the situation.Â  It allowed Pamela to continue visitation with the children.
Pamela had left Kenneth in February of 2001 and moved to Smoaks, South Carolina to live with her mother and stepfather.Â  She explained, â€œI did a lot of soul searching.Â  I wasnâ€™t happy.Â  I was missing my kids.Â  I realized that I had a loser for a husband who was not helping me to get them back in any way. . . .Â  I just decided to turn my life around.Â  Things just fell into place after I left him.â€Â  In the time since she left Kenneth and moved to Smoaks, her life has greatly improved.Â  She found stable employment and lives with her mother and stepfather.Â  She testified she had not used drugs since June of 2001.Â  In September of 2002, she completed a year-long substance abuse program through drug court.[2]Â  In April of 2002, the guardian ad litem and foster care review board changed their recommendations from termination of parental rights to reunification.Â  Importantly, DSS accepted those recommendations as to Codyâ€™s brother and sister and returned them to Pamela in November of 2002.Â  Casey, one of the children returned to Pamela, is autistic.Â  
While Pamela was working toward completion of her treatment plan, the children were living in separate foster homes.Â  Cody was eventually placed with the Shanklin family.Â  He stayed with this foster family for approximately two years, but was removed sometime prior to September of 2001.Â  While Cody was with the Shanklins, his pediatric endocrinologist, Dr. Steven Willi, diagnosed Cody as having psychosocial dwarfism or psychosocial failure to thrive.Â  Dr. Willi explained this condition occurs when a child is not being met with the appropriate nurturing behaviors from some parent or parent surrogate.Â  Mrs. Shanklin testified that when Cody was in their foster care, he initially would become sick after his visitation with Kenneth, Pamela, and his siblings, but this changed after Kenneth no longer participated in the visitations.Â  After that point, Cody â€œlooked forward to going,â€ acted â€œvery lovinglyâ€ toward Pamela, and would play with his mother, siblings, and grandparents.Â  Mrs. Shanklin also testified that during this time she made sure Cody understood that Pamela was his biological mother by placing a picture of his biological family near his bed and allowing him to have letters and cards from them.Â  Cody was removed from the Shanklin household by DSS when Mr. and Mrs. Shanklin temporarily separated, despite Mrs. Shanklinâ€™s desire to continue taking care of him.Â  
When Cody was removed from the Shanklinâ€™s foster care, he was temporarily placed in two households before being pre-adoptively placed with Kurtis Kendle and Gayle Kendall (hereinafter the Kendles[3]) in October of 2001.Â  A pre-adoptive placement means the family is being recommended as an adoption home for Cody by DSS.Â  Cody has by all accounts thrived in the Kendle household.
During the entire time Cody has been in foster care, Pamela has exercised every visitation offered her.Â Â  Initially visitation was twice a month, but DSS cut the visitation in half.Â  Thus, DSS limited Codyâ€™s visitations with his mother to one hour a month. 
This action for termination of parental rights was filed in May of 2001.Â  DSS originally sought the termination of Pamela and Kennethâ€™s rights to all three children.Â  The Kendles were joined as intervenors in October of 2002.Â  At the hearing, DSS presented the testimony of two expert witnesses to demonstrate that it was in Codyâ€™s best interests to stay with the Kendles.Â  
Dr. Elizabeth Ralston, a Ph.D. in clinical psychology and qualified as an expert in family reunification, testified that Cody does not identify Pamela as his natural mother or Casey and Ashley as his natural siblings.Â  However, she testified that based on observation, Pamela is a nurturing and loving mother to her children.Â  Dr. Ralston stated Cody is doing well with the Kendles, but admitted she is unsure if Cody has bonded with the Kendles or whether he is just employing a survival mechanism.Â  Dr. Ralston also testified that Cody is comfortable with Pamela, his siblings, and his grandfather.Â  Her opinion that Cody should remain with the Kendles was rooted in her belief that Cody is thriving with the Kendles and to remove him would be traumatic.Â  However, she acknowledged that when Cody was older and learned that that he had a brother and sister who were returned to their mother when he was not may also be traumatic, but she stated she could not predict the impact such knowledge would have on Cody.Â  
Dr. Charles Saylor, a forensic psychologist, testified Cody had resolved his earlier confusion at being placed with the Kendles.Â  He also testified that while Cody knew neither the Shanklins nor the Kendles were his biological parents, he could not identify Pamela as his biological mother.Â  However, Cody could identify Casey and Ashley as his siblings.Â  Dr. Saylor found Cody was â€œin a good home where he is well cared for by . . . parents who are very capable and very devoted to him.â€Â  He concluded it would be in Codyâ€™s best interest to be allowed to continue living with the Kendles and have closure. 
On cross-examination, Dr. Saylor admitted his evaluation did not include the overarching question of whether it is in the best interest of Cody to stay with the Kendles or be reunited with Pamela but was limited to determining whether â€œCody [has] adjusted to life with the Kendles.â€Â  He also admitted that if Pamela could present a nurturing, caring, loving home that would be â€œokayâ€ for Cody.Â  Finally, Dr. Saylor testified Pamelaâ€™s restricted visitation of one hour a month was not enough to create a bond with Cody.Â  
Ruth Buck, the guardian ad litem, testified that although she initially recommended termination of parental rights to the court in March of 2001 because she was dissatisfied with the parentsâ€™ progress with their treatment plans, she changed her position to reunification with Pamela in April of 2002.Â  She stated she changed her opinion because (1) Pamela was making progress, (2) Codyâ€™s brother stated he wanted to be returned to Pamela, and (3) Pamela no longer had contact with Kenneth.Â  Buck testified that Pamela â€œnever missed a visit nor did the grandparents.Â  And I continued to see an improvement in the children in their relationship with the mother on the visits over the time.â€Â  Importantly, she testified Pamela was a fit mother and Cody has a good relationship with his brother and sister.Â  Most alarmingly, Buck accused DSS of having reserved Cody for adoption because he was very adoptable.Â  She testified that when she questioned Jacqueline Adams, a DSS adoption specialist, about the Kendlesâ€™ pre-adoptive status, Adams responded, â€œWe donâ€™t get many blue eyed blond children very often, and these people want Cody.â€Â  During her testimony, Adams denied making this statement.Â  
Gayle Kendall testified she baby-sits a friendâ€™s twins one day a week at her own house but other than that does not have outside employment.Â  Kurtis Kendle is a homebuilder with an office in their home.Â  They live on the Isle of Palms walking distance from the beach.Â  Gayle Kendall stated they only applied to be pre-adoptive parents and absolutely did not apply to be foster parents.Â  Melissa Turner, a DSS adoption specialist, acknowledged that when Cody was placed with the Kendles, she told them that they could represent themselves as his parents and gave them a Medicaid card with the name Cody Kendle on it.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In its order, the family court found Buck was biased in favor of Pamela.Â  The family court found grounds for termination had been established in that (1) Pamela had failed to complete her placement plan within six months and was still not in compliance with the placement plan, (2) Pamela had failed to contribute to the support of Cody, and (3) that Cody had been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  In addition, the court found it was in Codyâ€™s best interests to terminate Pamela and Kennethâ€™s parental rights.Â  Pamela appealed the order of the family court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW

When reviewing a case involving the termination of parental rights, the best interests of the children are always the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Any ground serving as the basis for the termination of parental rights must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998).Â  In reviewing a termination of parental rights, the appellate court has the authority to review the record and make its own findings of whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Ledford, 357 S.C. 371, 375, 593 S.E.2d 175, 176-177 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Under South Carolinaâ€™s termination of parental rights (TPR) statute, â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2004).Â  The family court found three grounds supported termination of Pamelaâ€™s rights.Â  We will address each ground in turn.Â  
1.     Failure to contribute support
Pamela argues the family court erred when it found her failure to contribute child support as a ground for termination.Â  We agree.
A ground for termination of parental rights occurs when the â€œchild has lived outside the home . . . for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2004).Â  The statute explains:Â  

  Failure to support means the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has willfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.

Id.Â  Wilfulness is â€œconduct of the parent which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties . . .Â  because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 336, 543 S.E.2d 580, 582 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. V. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 839 (1992)). â€œWhether a parentâ€™s failure to visit or support a child is wilful is a question of intent to be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case.â€Â  Id.
Pamela paid her child support obligation consistently until November of 2000, at which time the payments became sporadic.Â  She explained that at that time she was paying all of the bills for herself and Kenneth, who was not contributing at all.Â  As the family court noted in its order, Pamela also failed to make any payments from June of 2001 to December of 2001.Â  She began making payments again in January of 2002.Â  Pamela stated she made her child support payments the best that she could.Â  
Pamela admitted she did not make any payments after June of 2002, but stated it was not a wilful failure to support and that she simply believed she was in compliance with a court order.Â  On June 21, 2002, at DSSâ€™s request, the family court issued an order striking Pamelaâ€™s child support arrearage and closing the case.Â  An October of 2002 consent order vacated the June court order, addressed the future need to recalculate the obligation, and did not require payment until December of 2002.Â  In a further order, dated January 6, 2003, the family court held enforcement of the child support obligation in abeyance until the parental rights hearing.Â  As Casey and Ashley were returned to Pamela in November 2002, revision of the amount of support being paid was needed.Â Â  
Pamela made child support payments as she was able and her most recent and substantial failure is explained by her understanding of a court order holding them in abeyance until a final hearing on her parental rights.Â  We find this misunderstanding as to her continued requirement to pay mitigates her failure to provide support and hold it was not wilful.Â  Therefore, we find the family court erred in terminating her rights based on a wilful failure to provide support.
2.     Failure to complete placement plan within six months
Pamela argues the court erred in finding her parental rights should be terminated for her failure to complete her placement plan within six months.Â  We agree.
â€œ[F]ailure to comply with DSS treatment plans is not one of the statutory grounds for termination of parental rights in this state.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Lail, 335 S.C. 284, 294, 516 S.E.2d 463, 468 (Ct. App. 1999) overruled on other grounds by Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 109, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (overruling prior cases calling for strict construction of the TPR statutes).Â  Instead, the TPR statute allows for termination if the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal within six months following the adoption of a placement plan.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2) (Supp. 2004).
The family court found Cody was removed from Pamelaâ€™s custody because he faced a substantial risk of harm.Â  The court found this substantial risk was a â€œcomplete lack of stability existing in the King family at the time of removal.â€Â  The court specifically commented on the transient nature of the King family.Â  However, at the time of the hearing, Pamela had stable living arrangements in her mother and stepfatherâ€™s home and stable employment.Â  Thus, we find the conditions that caused the removal have changed for the better.
Furthermore, the guardian ad litem testified that Pamela had completed the requirements of the placement plan.Â  Pamelaâ€™s actions demonstrate substantial compliance with her placement plan.Â  A final order dated March 17, 2000, required Pamela to complete substance abuse counseling, counseling with the Lowcountry Childrenâ€™s Center, and other counseling that is not specifically defined.Â  A May 17, 2000 order required Pamela to complete substance abuse counseling, undergo a psychological evaluation, and anger management or criminal domestic abuse violence intervention.Â  A September 1, 2000 order required parental effectiveness training, substance abuse counseling, and undefined counseling.Â  
Pamela completed substance abuse counseling on April 10, 2002 and Systematic Training for Effective Parenting on September 13, 2000, and received a Diploma in Relationship Issues from the Family Violence Treatment Center on February 20, 2001.Â  In April of 2000 she went to Coastal Empire Mental Health for counseling, but she told her counselor that everything was fine in her life and she did not want mental health services.Â  Her counselor interpreted this as a refusal of services.Â  However, Pamela later returned in February of 2001 to Coastal Empire Mental Health and continued in some sort of counseling until June 2001.Â  We find Pamela did substantially complete all of the requirements ordered by the court.
This finding is supported by the very actions and testimony of DSS.Â  DSS returned Codyâ€™s brother and sisterÂ  to Pamela, even though one is autistic.Â  This would suggest that DSS considered her as having completed the requirements of the placement plan and having remedied the instability that had caused the childrenâ€™s removal.Â  It is also supported by the actual testimony of her DSS caseworker.Â  Louvette Green testified that Pamela was in compliance.Â  However, Green then proceeded to recant and say Pamela did not finish her counseling.Â  While Mr. Kavolanchik from Coastal Empire Mental Counseling stated Pamela dropped out of counseling after six months, the actual duration of counseling ordered by the court was unspecified and we cannot find that Pamela was not in substantial compliance.Â  See generally Lail, 335 S.C. at 294, 516 S.E.2d at 468 (â€œThus, while the motherâ€™s efforts to comply fully with DSS treatment plans were less than whole-hearted, the motherâ€™s attitude toward DSS is understandable given the chain of events that precipitated the dissolution of the Lail family. Such an attitude, without more, does not mandate the solution sought by DSS in this case.â€).Â  Thus we find termination on the grounds of non-compliance was in error.Â  
3.     Foster care of fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months
In a fairly recent amendment, the TPR statute provides as a ground for termination:Â  â€œThe child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2004).Â  There is no question Cody has been in foster care under the responsibility of the state since October of 1999.Â  Thus, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s finding that this ground has been established.Â  However, we reiterate that this is the only ground DSS established by clear and convincing evidence to support termination of Pamelaâ€™s rights to Cody.Â  
4.     Â Best interests of the child
Although we find one ground for termination does exist, we must also determine whether termination would be in Codyâ€™s best interests.Â  We find it is not.Â  
Our legislature has provided, â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2004).Â  However it is still â€œ[t]he public policy of this state in child custody matters is to reunite parents and children.â€ Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 296, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-20 (1985).Â  The supreme court has recognized a childâ€™s shared interest in preventing an erroneous termination of her familial bond with her natural parent.Â  Greenville County Depâ€™t Soc. Servs. v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 196, 437 S.E.2d 107, 111 (1993).Â  Furthermore, while there is a presumption that it is in the best interest of a child to be in the custody of its biological parent, such a presumption is rebuttable.Â  Shake v. Darlington County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 306 S.C. 216, 222, 410 S.E.2d 923, 926 (Ct. App. 1991) (citingÂ  Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C. 75, 79, 386 S.E.2d 456, 458 (1989)). 
The family court found it would be in the best interests of Cody for Pamelaâ€™s parental rights to be terminated.Â  This was partially based on the fact it was â€œundisputed that the child is safe and well cared-for by the [Kendles] and is emotionally attached to [them].â€Â  The court refused to apply the factors set forth in Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C. 75, 386 S.E.2d 456 (1989). 
The Moore factors are to be used â€œwhen a natural parent seeks to reclaim custody of [her] child.â€Â  Id. at 79, 386 S.E.2d at 458.Â  These factors require the court to consider the following:Â  (1) whether the parent can prove he or she is a fit parent, able to properly care for the child and provide a good home; (2) the amount of contact, in the form of visits, financial support or both, which the parent had with the child while in the care of a third party; (3) the circumstances under which temporary relinquishment occurred; and (4) the degree of attachment between the child and the temporary custodian.Â  Id.Â  at 79-80, 386 S.E.2d at 458.Â  
The family court refused to consider these criteria because Moore involved a private custody action, voluntary relinquishment, and the application of a rebuttable presumption that it is in the best interest of a child to be in the custody of its biological parent.Â  However, we find application of the Moore factors is not limited to voluntary relinquishment cases.Â  This court applied the Moore factors in Shake v. Darlington County Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv., 306 S.C. 216, 410 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  In Shake, the natural parents voluntarily relinquished custody of the child when he was a month old due to the childâ€™s failure to thrive.Â Â  At that time he was placed in the care of the foster mother.Â  When the child was five months old, he was returned to his natural parents, but a month later, DSS sought and procured an emergency protective custody order at which time he was placed back in the care of the foster mother.Â  Up until the time of the hearing on this matter four years later, the child had remained in the continuous care of the foster mother.Â  The foster mother brought the action seeking termination of natural parentsâ€™ rights to the child.Â  The family court denied the termination and granted custody to the natural mother.Â  On appeal, this court affirmed the denial of termination of parental rights, but applied the Moore factors to hold custody should be returned to the foster mother.Â  Similarly, the supreme court applied the Moore factors in an action to terminate a fatherâ€™s parental rights brought by a childâ€™s guardian ad litem following removal of the child from the natural mother and placement of the child with foster parents who wanted to adopt him.Â  Hopkins v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv., 313 S.C. 322, 437 S.E.2d 542 (1993) overruled on other grounds by Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 109, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (overruling prior cases calling for strict construction of the TPR statutes).Â  Thus, the appellate courts have applied the Moore factors in cases involving DSS removal of children.Â  Furthermore, the Kendle family has intervened in this case as the pre-adoptive foster family, similar to the foster motherâ€™s initiation of the action in Shake.Â  Accordingly, we will consider the Moore factors as guidance in determining whether termination of Pamelaâ€™s parental rights is in Codyâ€™s best interest.Â Â Â  
Â  Pamelaâ€™s fitness as a parent cannot be questioned.Â  She has improved her life and provided a stable family environment for Codyâ€™s brother and sister.Â  For DSS to argue Pamela is an unfit parent would require it to argue that it improperly returned the two children to her.Â  Furthermore, Louvette Green agreed that â€œ[w]hat [this case] boils down to is Cody, himself, and only Cody, has become attached to the Kendles and that is the issue DSS is having before the court today.â€Â  
Second, Pamela has had continuous contact with Cody.Â  Although DSS limited her to one hour a month with her son, Pamela took advantage of every visitation offered and begged for more time with him.Â Â Â  See generally Greenville County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 195, 437 S.E.2d 107, 111 (1993) (noting that the â€œState marshals an array of public resources and has the power to shape the historical events that from the basis of terminationâ€ and that DSS â€œhad contributed to the lack of bonding between Mother and her child.â€).Â  Furthermore, Pamela has provided some financial support.Â  
For the third factor, custody was relinquished because the instability in Pamelaâ€™s life posed a threat of harm to the children.Â  However, she has altered her lifestyle and it no longer presents an obstacle in this case.Â  
As to the final factor, there is no question that Cody is thriving in the Kendlesâ€™ home.Â  However, Dr. Ralston could not state if Cody had bonded or was simply employing a survival technique.Â  
Furthermore, testimony demonstrates Cody is a resilient child who has a relationship with Pamela, his brother and sister, and grandparents.Â  If returned to Pamela, Cody would not only have the love, support, and care of his natural mother, but also of these other family members.Â  Pamela testified that Codyâ€™s brother and sister miss him and write him letters, which they cannot send.Â  Buck testified that during visitations Cody and his brother and sister played together and were very close.
In this case, our focus centers on what is in the best interests for Cody.Â  We are concerned by the length of time Pamela took in completing her treatment plan while her children remained in DSS custody.Â  However, it was after Pamela had turned her life around and rededicated herself to completing her treatment plan that DSS took action to place Cody with preadoptive parents.Â  Although Pamela had not had a positive drug test since June of 2001 and was enrolled in a substance abuse and counseling program that would fulfill the requirements of her plan, DSS placed Cody with the Kendles in October of 2001.Â  Only six months after Cody was placed with the Kendles, the Foster Care Review Board changed its recommendation from termination of parental rights to reunification with Pamela within six months.Â  Despite this recommendation, DSS continued to pursue termination while Cody remained with the Kendles in a preadoptive placement.Â  There is no question that, at the very latest, when Codyâ€™s brother and sister were returned to her, Pamela was a fit parent capable of caring for Cody.Â  

  Keeping the best interest of Cody as our paramount concern, we conclude that Codyâ€™s interests would be served best by denying termination of parental rights. 
  CONCLUSION
    

For the reasons discussed above, we find the family court erred in terminating the parental rights of Pamela King to her son Cody King. 
REVERSED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â 

[1] Casey was born June 17, 1990, Ashley was born November 17, 1994, and Cody was born March 24, 1997.Â  
[2] In September 2001, Pamela entered drug court as a result of criminal charges that arose from her employment when she lived in Hardeeville.
[3] Although the Kendles filed their motion to intervene under the pseudonyms John Roe and Mary Roe, they used their real names at the hearing.Â

title: In the Interest Of:  S. Damion
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Interest Of:Â  S., Damion, A Juvenile under the Age of Seventeen,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Marion D. Myers, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-156
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 4, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART,
AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe; all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Damion S. pled guilty in family court to first-degree burglary, safecracking, grand larceny, and two counts of second-degree burglary.Â  On appeal, he argues the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to accept his pleas because the juvenile petitions were insufficient.Â  We affirm in part, vacate in part, and remand.
BACKGROUND
The juvenile petitions against Damion alleged he was involved in break-ins at three separate homes.Â  The first-degree burglary petition involved an incident at the home of Matt Ragen.Â  The safecracking, grand larceny, and one of the second-degree burglary allegations arose from a break-in at the home of Jimmie Coward.Â  The remaining second-degree burglary charge and a nol prossed petit larceny charge concerned a break-in at the home of June Williford.Â  
The family court accepted Damionâ€™s guilty pleas, adjudicated him delinquent, and later sentenced him to an indeterminate period not to exceed his twenty-first birthday.Â  
DISCUSSION
The court of general sessions has jurisdiction over a criminal case where there is an indictment sufficiently stating the offense, the offense is a lesser-included offense of the indicted offense, or the defendant waives presentment of the indictment.Â  Cohen v. State, 354 S.C. 563, 565-66, 582 S.E.2d 403, 404 (2003).Â  An indictment is sufficient for jurisdictional purposes where it â€œapprises the defendant of the elements of the offense intended to be charged and informs [him] of the circumstances he must be prepared to defend.â€Â  Koon v. State, 358 S.C. 359, 365, 595 S.E.2d 456, 459 (2004).Â  This court has previously applied the rules governing indictments to a juvenile petition, citing due process rights applicable in both arenas.Â  In the Interest of Jason T., 340 S.C. 455, 458-59, 531 S.E.2d 544, 545-46 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œBased on the due process protections governing juvenile proceedings and the exemplary procedure employed in courts of general sessions to preserve adultsâ€™ due process rights, we now hold that a family court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to adjudicate a juvenile delinquent for a charge not alleged in the juvenile petition unless the adjudication is for a lesser included offense or there has been a written waiver of notice.â€).
I.Â  First-Degree Burglary Petition
A person commits first-degree burglary where he enters a dwelling without consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein, and one of the statutorily defined aggravating circumstances is present.[1]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A) (2003).Â  In State v. Lynch, the State moved at the outset of a murder and first-degree burglary trial to amend the burglary indictment by deleting one aggravating circumstance and replacing it with another.Â  State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 638, 545 S.E.2d 511, 513 (2001).Â  Following his conviction on both charges, our supreme court reversed his burglary conviction, concluding the amendment impermissibly changed the nature of the offense charged.Â  Id. at 640-41, 545 S.E.2d at 514.Â  The court noted without the aggravating circumstance, the crime would be second-degree burglary and thus although it is but one element of the crime, â€œthe aggravating circumstance is â€˜the essenceâ€™ of first degree burglary.â€Â  Id. at 640, 545 S.E.2d at 514 (quoting State v. Sowell, 85 S.C. 278, 67 S.E. 316 (1910).Â  Because the aggravating circumstances involved were distinct and required materially different proof, the court held the amendment struck the charged offense and replaced it with an entirely different one and thus deprived the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 640-41, 545 S.E.2d at 514.Â  
Citing Lynch, our supreme court has since held the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant of first-degree burglary where the indictment failed to allege any one of the several aggravating circumstances set forth in the statute.Â  Mathis v. State, 355 S.C. 87, 92, 584 S.E.2d 366, 368-69 (2003); see also Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 369, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995) (holding circuit court lacked jurisdiction to accept second-degree burglary guilty plea where the indictment failed to allege any circumstance of aggravation).
In this case, the purported first-degree burglary petition fails to allege any circumstance of aggravation.Â  The State, however, points out the petition alleges that after waiving his rights, Damion confessed to the crime of first-degree burglary.Â  We need not decide whether such an incorporation would suffice for jurisdictional purposes because the confession referenced also contains no hint of any aggravating circumstance.Â  The State also notes Damion did not challenge the Stateâ€™s factual recitation, in which the prosecutor asserted the offense occurred during the hours of darkness, thus asserting an aggravating circumstance was present.Â  This argument fails to recognize the charging document itself serves as the focus of our jurisdictional analysis.Â  Although the sufficiency of an indictment is to be viewed with a practical eye considering all surrounding circumstances, this evaluation is to be based on pre-trial surrounding circumstances, not information related during a guilty plea hearing.Â  See State v. Wade, 306 S.C. 79, 86, 409 S.E.2d 780, 784 (1991) (rejecting dissentâ€™s attempt to include evidence presented at trial as surrounding circumstances available for consideration in evaluating sufficiency of an indictment).Â  Because the petition fails to allege any aggravating circumstance, we vacate Damionâ€™s delinquency adjudication for first-degree burglary.
II.Â  Remaining Petitions
We affirm Damionâ€™s remaining issues pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Browning, 320 S.C. at 368, 465 S.E.2d at 359 (â€œAn indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon.â€); Id. (â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€); State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1993) (holding question of sufficiency of an indictment must be viewed â€œwith a practical eye in view of the surrounding circumstancesâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312 (2003) (defining second-degree burglary); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-390 (2003) (defining safecracking); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30(B) (2003) (defining grand larceny). 
CONCLUSION
We vacate Damionâ€™s adjudication on the offense of first-degree burglary and affirm his adjudication on the remaining charges.Â  Because we have vacated his adjudication as to the most serious offense, we remand to the family court for any reconsideration of his sentence deemed appropriate as a consequence of this opinion. 
 AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â  
 HUFF, J., concurs.
 GOOLSBY, J., dissents in part and concurs in part in a separate opinion.
GOOLSBY, J. (dissenting in part and concurring in part): I dissent to the extent the majority vacates on the ground of lack of subject matter jurisdiction the appellantâ€™s adjudication of delinquency for having committed the offense of first-degree burglary and remands appellant to the family court for resentencing.Â  I otherwise concur.
Viewing, as we must, the allegations of first-degree burglary set forth in the petition with a â€œpractical eyeâ€ and taking note of all surrounding circumstances that existed pre-trial, I would hold the petition was sufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction upon the family court to adjudicate those allegations.Â  See State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. McCloud, 354 S.C. 40, 579 S.E.2d 534 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The petition says the juvenile along with another â€œforced entry into the residenceâ€ in question, they searched for money once inside, and the juvenile confessed â€œto the crime of burglary 1st,â€ which is no different than had the petition expressly referenced the burglary statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (A) (2003).Â  His confessionÂ  states he and another person â€œgot a lot of change and some jewelryâ€ after they got inside the house. 
If the appellant had a question about which aggravating circumstance the State intended to rely upon, he should have raised this issue earlier by motion.Â  See Rule 12(e), SCRCP; Rule 2(b), SCRFC; cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (Rev. 2003).Â  This he did not do.Â  He should not now be heard to complain.
I would affirm.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Section 16-11-311(A) provides:

  
    
    
      
        (A) 
         A person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and either:
      
      
        (1) 
         when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
      
      
        (a) 
         is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive; or
      
      
        (b) 
        causes physical injury to a person who is not a participant in the crime; or
      
      
        (c)
         uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument; or
      
      
        (d) 
         displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm; or
      
      
        (2) 
         the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of both; or
      
      
        (3)Â Â Â Â 
         the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.

California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), counsel for Lykes attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating he had reviewed the record and concluded that Lykesâ€™ appeal is without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial.Â  Lykes filed a separate pro se response.Â

title: Jenkins Produce v. Central Carolina Christian Academy
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Charles Jenkins, d/b/a Jenkins Produce, Respondent,
v.
Central Carolina Christian Academy,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-159
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 4, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Dalhi N. Myers, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Harry Clayton DePew, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Central Carolina Christian Academy (â€œthe Academyâ€) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying its motion to set aside the default judgment entered in favor of Charles Jenkins d/b/a Jenkins Produce (Jenkins).Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On October 30, 1996, Jenkins and the Academy entered into a contract whereby Jenkins agreed to sell produce to the Academy for an agreed upon price of $51,468.75, which was payable on December 13, 1996.Â  Because the Academy failed to pay for the produce, Jenkins filed an action for breach of contract on April 1, 1997.Â  An affidavit of service indicates the action was served upon â€œMs. Jamesâ€ on April 7, 1997.Â  The affidavit does not list an address or Ms. Jamesâ€™s position at the Academy.Â  Instead, one line on the affidavit is marked that Ms. James is â€œ[a] person of suitable age and discretion residing with the Plaintiffs (Â  ) / Defendants (Â  ).â€Â  Receiving no response from the Academy, Jenkins filed an affidavit of default on September 2, 1997.Â  Â Â  
On July 7, 1998, the circuit court entered a default judgment in the amount of $51,528.75 against the Academy.Â  Jenkinsâ€™s attorney mailed a copy of the judgment to the Academy on July 15, 1998.Â  Because the Academy failed to respond, Jenkinsâ€™s attorney again informed the Academy, via certified mail dated September 28, 2001, about the outstanding judgment.Â  Although Mr. Theodore Myers, the Headmaster of the Academy, signed the certified letter there was no response to the judgment. 
In December 2001, Jenkins filed an execution against the property of the Academy to satisfy the judgment.Â  By letter dated December 31, 2001, the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department indicated that it had complied with the required regulations in terms of checking property records and attempting to contact the Academy.
On April 22, 2002, Jenkins filed a rule to show cause and an order of reference.Â  The circuit court judge signed the order of reference and a hearing was set before the master for August 26, 2002.Â  This document was filed on July 16, 2002. 
In response, the Academy filed a motion to set aside the default judgment on August 22, 2002.Â  In its motion, the Academy alleged that Jenkins had failed to properly serve the Academy pursuant to Rule 4(d)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.[2]Â  Specifically, the Academy asserted that service upon â€œMs. Jamesâ€ was insufficient to provide it with notice of the suit because the Academy had never employed an agent by the name of Ms. James.Â  Although the Academy admitted that it â€œbecame aware of the existence of the default judgment in either 2000 or 2001,â€ it contended that it was never â€œafforded an opportunity to defend this suit on the meritsâ€ and was â€œnever notified of a hearing to ascertain damages as required by South Carolina law.â€
As a result of the Academyâ€™s motion, the master continued the case until the circuit court could rule on the jurisdictional issue raised by the Academy.Â  On January 9, 2003, the circuit court judge held a hearing on the Academyâ€™s motion to set aside the default judgment.Â  By order dated March 12, 2003, the judge denied the Academyâ€™s motion, finding:Â  (1). service of process was sufficient because Jenkins properly served the Academy, which was the name listed on the contract at issue, and Jenkins was, thus, not required to serve the parent corporation of South Richland Ministries, Incorporated; (2). the Academy was not entitled to notice prior to the damages hearing given the requested relief was a sum certain; and (3). the Academy failed to avail itself of the relief outlined under Rule 60(b)(4) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure since it did not move to set aside the default judgment within a â€œreasonable timeâ€ after it was notified of the entry of the judgment.[3]Â  In his order denying the Academyâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the judge reaffirmed his ruling that the Academy had failed to move to set aside the entry of the default judgment within a â€œreasonable timeâ€ as required by Rule 60(b)(4).Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
The Academy argues the circuit court judge erred in finding the jurisdictional requirement of service of process was satisfied.Â  In support of its argument, the Academy asserts that even if the summons and complaint had been served on Ms. James, she was not a proper party because she was not an agent.Â  Additionally, the Academy claims that Jenkins could not cure the insufficient service of process by notifying the Academy after the default judgment had been entered.Â  We disagree.
â€œA party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested relief.â€Â  Perry v. Heirs at law of Gadsen, 357 S.C. 42, 46-47, 590 S.E.2d 502, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The decision of whether to grant or deny a Rule 60(b) motion is within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Id. at 47, 590 S.E.2d at 504.Â  â€œOn review, we are limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion in granting or denying such a motion.â€Â  Id.
Because the Academyâ€™s motion to set aside the default judgment was based on Jenkinsâ€™s alleged failure to properly effectuate service as required by Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, the Academyâ€™s requested relief was governed by Rule 60(b)(4).Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 209, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995) (â€œRule 4, SCRCP serves at least two purposes.Â  It confers personal jurisdiction on the court and assures the defendant of reasonable notice of the action.â€); Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583-84, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating in order for service upon a corporation to be effective, it must be made on an actual agent).Â  
Rule 60(b)(4) permits relief from judgment if the judgment is void.Â  Smith Cos. of Greenville v. Hayes, 311 S.C. 358, 360, 428 S.E.2d 900, 902 (Ct. App. 1993); Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP (â€œOn motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons: . . . (4) the judgment is void.â€).Â  â€œThe definition of â€˜voidâ€™ under the rule only encompasses judgments from courts which failed to provide due process, or judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction or personal jurisdiction.â€Â  McDaniel v. United States Fidelity & Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996).
Under Rule 60(b)(4), â€œthe court may grant a party relief from judgment if the party makes a motion seeking relief within a reasonable time.â€ Smith Cos. of Greenville, 311 S.C. at 359, 428 S.E.2d at 902; see McDaniel, 324 S.C. at 642-44, 478 S.E.2d at 870-71 (applying â€œreasonable timeâ€ requirement to motion pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), but recognizing inconsistency among the decisions of South Carolina appellate courts, other state courts, and federal courts as to whether requirement should be imposed to challenge a judgment as void). 
Based on the evidence presented in the record, we find the circuit court judge did not abuse his discretion in denying the Academyâ€™s motion to set aside the entry of the default judgment.Â  The default judgment was entered on July 7, 1998, and copy mailed to the Academy on July 15, 1998.Â  On September 28, 2001, Jenkins notified the Academy about the judgment by certified mail.Â  Mr. Theodore Myers, the Headmaster of the Academy, signed that he received this letter.Â  Furthermore, the Academy admitted in its motion that its â€œprincipals became aware of the existence of the default judgment either in 2000 or 2001,â€ yet it did not file its motion to set aside the default judgment until August 22, 2002, four days before the hearing scheduled on Jenkinsâ€™s motion for a rule to show cause.Â  Based on the foregoing, we find there is evidence to support the judgeâ€™s ruling that the Academy failed to make its motion within a â€œreasonable time.â€Â  See McDaniel, 324 S.C. at 644, 478 S.E.2d at 871 (finding Rule 60(b)(4) motion untimely where party filed it nearly four years after order enforcing settlement agreement was filed).Â  Therefore, even assuming arguendo that the judgment was void for insufficient service of process, the Academyâ€™s delay in moving to set aside the default judgment precluded it from receiving any relief under Rule 60(b)(4).
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court judge is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  Rule 4(d)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides:

The summons and complaint must be served together. The plaintiff shall furnish the person making service with such copies as are necessary. Voluntary appearance by defendant is equivalent to personal service; and written notice of appearance by a party or his attorney shall be effective upon mailing, or may be served as provided in this rule. Service shall be made as follows:
. . . 
Upon a corporation or upon a partnership or other unincorporated association which is subject to suit under a common name, by delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process and if the agent is one authorized by statute to receive service and the statute so requires, by also mailing a copy to the defendant.

[3]Â Â  Although the Academy moved to set aside the default judgment pursuant to Rule 55(c), the circuit court judge properly analyzed the motion pursuant to Rule 60(b) on the ground the default judgment had already been entered. See Rule 55(c), SCRCP (â€œFor good cause shown the court may set aside an entry of default and, if a judgment by default has been entered, may likewise set it aside in accordance with Rule 60(b).â€).

title: Smiley v. SCDHEC
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James W. Smiley, Appellant,
v.
S.C. Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management and Wild Dunes Community Association,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-160Â Â Â 
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Amy Elizabeth Armstrong and James S. Chandler, Jr., both of Pawleyâ€™s Island, for Appellant.
Kenneth Krawcheck and Leslie West Stidham, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Smiley appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s judicial review of the Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel, which affirmed the Appellate Panel, finding that Smiley lacked standing to appeal a permit issued by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (â€œDHEC/OCRMâ€).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
    In February 2001, DHEC/OCRM issued a critical area permit authorizing the Wild Dunes Community Association to excavate 25,000 cubic yards of sand each month from the intertidal beach of Isle of Palms and to transport it to private property owned by Wild Dunes.Â  The permit provided that the depth of the excavation would not exceed 18 inches and imposed other special conditions.
    Smiley lives on the Isle of Palms and has been actively involved in the conservation and protection of the beach and dune system on the island.Â  Also, Smiley uses the beach for recreational and rehabilitative purposes.Â  Smiley sought to have the Administrative Law Judge set aside the permit because he alleged the excavation would interfere with his use of the beach.Â  
    Before the hearing on the merits, DHEC/OCRM filed a motion to dismiss for lack of standing, asserting Smiley could not demonstrate the requisite injury.Â  The Administrative Law Judge determined Smiley lacked standing and dismissed the case.Â  The Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel affirmed the dismissal and the circuit court affirmed the administrative rulings.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF
REVIEW
        In reviewing the final decision of an administrative agency, the circuit court essentially sits as an appellate court to review alleged errors committed by the agency.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 519, 560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002).Â  â€œOur scope of review is the same as that established for the circuit court.â€Â  Id. at 512, 560 S.E.2d at 413.
        â€œWe must affirm if the decision of the agency is supported by substantial evidence, and we may not substitute our judgment for that of the agency upon questions as to which there is room for a difference of intelligent opinion.â€Â  Byerly Hosp. v. South Carolina State Health & Human Serv. Fin. Commâ€™n, 319 S.C. 225, 229, 460 S.E.2d 383, 385-86 (1995).Â  Substantial evidence is â€œevidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached.â€Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).
        LAW/ANALYSIS
        I.      Standing

Smiley argues the
circuit court erred in finding he lacked standing to contest the permit issued
to Wild Dunes.We disagree.
 

        To have standing, a plaintiff must satisfy a three-part test consisting of the following elements: (1) the plaintiff must have suffered an injury in fact; (2) there must be a causal connection between the injury and the conduct complained of; and (3) a favorable decision must be likely to redress the injury.Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n for Prot. of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Dept. of Natural Res., 345 S.C. 594, 601, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001).Â  The injury in fact must be concrete and particularized, as well as actual or imminent.Â  Id.Â  The â€œimminent prejudice must be of a personal nature to the party laying claim to standing and not merely of general interest common to all members of the public.â€Â  Citizens for Lee County, Inc. v. Lee County, 308 S.C. 23, 29, 416 S.E.2d 641, 645 (1992).Â  A plaintiff must allege facts that demonstrate how he or she personally will be prevented from enjoying the land or wildlife in question to have standing to maintain an action.Â  Sea Pines, 345 S.C. at 602, 550 S.E.2d at 292.Â  A mere interest in a problem, rather than a real injury, does not give rise to standing.Â  Beaufort Realty Co. v. Beaufort County, 346 S.C. 298, 301, 551 S.E.2d 588, 589 (Ct. App. 2001).
          This case focuses on the first element of the three-part testâ€”the injury in fact.Â  Although Smiley alleges the excavation will harm his use and enjoyment of the beach, he has failed to demonstrate the injury is actual or imminent because the permit simply authorizes the excavation, which has not occurred.Â 
       
            In Beaufort Realty, 346 S.C. at 302, 551 S.E.2d at 590, we held the filing of plats was not an actionable injury because the injury had not yet occurred and was purely conjectural and hypothetical.Â  Cf. Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 204 F.3d 149, 156 (4th Cir. 2000) (finding standing when the plaintiffs had already suffered damage); Am. Canoe Assâ€™n v. Murphy Farms, Inc., 326 F.3d 505, 520 (4th Cir. 2003) (finding standing where the particularized injury had already occurred).Â  
            Furthermore, Smiley has failed to demonstrate how the proposed project will prevent his enjoyment of the beach.Â  The permit allows for only a limited removal of sand on a portion of the beach.Â  Thus, if the excavation occurs, Smileyâ€™s use and enjoyment of the beach will only be temporarily altered.Â  His injury, at best, will be a temporary detour in his jogging route and does not compare to the permanent injury in South Carolina Wildlife Fedâ€™n v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 296 S.C. 187, 190, 371 S.E.2d 521, 523 (1988), where the plaintiffs were found to have standing because the parties alleged the decision of the Coastal Council would permanently change the fish and wildlife resources in the wetlands.Â  However, even a permanent injury does not assure a plaintiff will have standing.Â  In Sea Pines, the complained-of activity would permanently destroy wildlife, yet our Supreme Court found the plaintiffs lacked standing.Â  Certainly, if the permanent injury in Sea Pines did not warrant standing, Smileyâ€™s temporary inconvenience does not give rise to standing.
            Smiley also seems to assert he has standing because he has a legally protected right that will be violated by the removal of sand.Â  Section 48-39-260(1) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) provides the State has a responsibility to â€œprotect, preserve, restore, and enhance the beach/dune system.â€Â  Thus, the State cannot allow activity that â€œsubstantially impairs the public interest in marine life, water quality, or public access.â€Â  McQueen v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 354 S.C. 142, 149, 580 S.E.2d 116, 120 (2003).Â  Furthermore, the Public Trust Doctrine is based on the premise that â€œsome things are too important in society to be owned by one personâ€ and â€œeveryone has the inalienable right to breathe clean air; to drink safe water; to fish and sail, and recreate upon the high seas, territorial seas and navigable waters; as well as to land on the seashores and riverbanks.â€Â  Sierra Club v. Kiawah Resort Assoc., 318 S.C. 119, 127-28, 456 S.E.2d 397, 402 (1995).Â Â Â  However, Section 48-39-260(4) and (5) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) also provides the State policy is to â€œencourage the use of erosion-inhabiting techniques which do not adversely impact the long-term well-being of the beach/dune systemâ€ and â€œpromote carefully planned nourishment as a means of beach preservation and restoration where economically feasible.â€Â  The excavation of sand does not substantially impair the public interest and is within the Stateâ€™s policy of preserving and restoring its beaches, thus Smiley has failed to demonstrate how the permit would violate these protections. 
            II.        Administrative Law Judge
            Smiley argues the preceding tribunals applied the incorrect standard in deciding the motion to dismiss.[1]Â  Smiley asserts the ALJ should have viewed the facts and inferences in a light most favorable to him; however, the Administrative Procedures Act determines the standard the ALJ is to apply to this case.Â  In a contested case, a hearing before the ALJ is in the nature of a de novo hearing as mandated by the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Reliance Ins. Co. v. Smith, 327 S.C. 528, 534, 489 S.E.2d 674, 677 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Cf.Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 376-77, 527 S.E.2d 742, 754 (2000) (finding the ALJ sits in an appellate capacity to review non-collateral or administrative final decisions).Â  Following the mandates of the APA, the ALJ did not commit reversible error in the standard applied to the facts of the case.
            Smiley also contends the ALJ did not properly address the merits of his appeal.Â  Smiley suggests the ALJ mischaracterized the project and determined it would benefit him, and, thus, decided he lacked standing.Â  However, Smiley misconstrues the ALJâ€™s analysis, which explained Smileyâ€™s aesthetic concerns about a temporary interference did not present evidence of a concrete or particularized injury.
            AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, BEATTY, SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1] Smileyâ€™s arguments are limited to a discussion of the ALJ, thus we limit our analysis accordingly.

title: Tench v. SCDOE
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gary P. Tench, as Conservator for Jason Shawn
Tench, and individually, Appellant,
v.
The South Carolina Department of Education, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-161Â Â Â 
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Douglas A. Churdar, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gary Tench (Appellant), as Conservator for Jason Tench, appeals from an order finding the accrual of post-judgment interest ceased when the South Carolina Department of Education (Respondent) paid its judgment obligation.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS 
    This action arose from a motor vehicle accident on October 6, 1994, in which eighteen-year-old Jason Tench was seriously and permanently injured when a school bus operated by the Respondent pulled in front of his vehicle.Â  Jasonâ€™s father, Appellant, brought suit against Respondent for Jasonâ€™s bodily injuries and medical expenses.Â  In addition to a $250,000 payment to Jason, on September 20, 1996, Respondent was ordered to pay $250,000 to Appellant.[2]Â  After a complex procedural stage, our Supreme Court reinstated the September 20, 1996 judgment by order filed October 1, 2001.[3]Â  After remand, a dispute arose as to whether post-judgment interest commenced on September 20, 1996 or October 1, 2001, when the original order was reinstated.Â  An order filed on December 4, 2001 determined that the accrual of post-judgment interest commenced on September 20, 1996.[4]Â  On that same date, Respondent delivered a check for $250,000 to Appellantâ€™s counsel, which was accepted.Â  As of December 4, 2001, the post-judgment interest that had accrued since September 20, 1996 totaled $182,191.75.Â  In 2003, Respondent paid Appellant $182,191.75.Â  Appellant maintains that he is entitled to additional post-judgment interest from December 4, 2001 through the date the $182,191.75 was tendered.Â  Appellant filed a motion requesting the lower court â€œdeclare the legal rights between the parties with respect to the issue of post-judgment interest.â€Â  An order filed on January 19, 2004 determined Appellant was entitled only to post-judgment interest in the amount of $182,191.75, which had already been tendered by Respondent.Â  Appellant now appeals.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
     STANDARD OF REVIEW
        The interpretation of a statute is a matter of law.Â  Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In an action at law, our scope of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep,
        L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In an action at law, the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless the findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an erroneous application of the law.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â Â  
            LAW/ANALYSIS
            Appellant argues the trial court erred by determining the accrual of post-judgment interest ceased when the Respondent paid a portion of its â€œcombined judgment/post-judgment interest obligation.â€Â  We disagree.
            Section 34-31-20(b) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), which governs the award of post-judgment interest, provides that â€œ[a]ll money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered shall draw interest according to law.â€Â  The parties agreed that this statute has been interpreted as providing for simple interest, not compound interest.Â  
            Our Supreme Court has defined compound interest as â€œinterest on interest; that is, accrued interest is added periodically to the principle and interest is computed upon the new principle thus formed.â€Â  In the Matter of Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 362, 434 S.E.2d 254, 258 (1993).Â  By arguing that he is entitled to additional post-judgment interest, the Appellant is making a claim for compound rather than simple interest.Â  According to simple interest, post-judgment interest accrued only on the $250,000 judgment and once Respondent paid that judgment, which occurred on December 4, 2001, no additional interest accrued.[5]Â  Thus, because section 34-31-20(b) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) does not specifically provide for compound interest, the trial judge was correct in concluding that additional interest does not accrue on interest.[6]  
            AFFIRMED.
            ANDERSON, BEATTY, AND SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215], SCACR.
[2] At the time of the accident, the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, under which these claims were brought, included monetary caps of $250,000 per person and $500,000 per occurrence.
[3] Tench v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Educ., 347 S.C. 117, 553 S.E.2d 451 (2001).
[4] The order stated that â€œ[t]he Defendant must satisfy the Plaintiffâ€™s judgment with post-judgment interest at the statutory rate of 14% from September 20, 1996 through the date of satisfaction.â€Â  The order did not provide for the payment of additional post-judgment interest after December 4, 2001, nor did it provide for the payment of interest on interest.
[5] Although Appellant describes Respondentâ€™s post-judgment interest as a component of a â€œjudgment/post-judgment interest obligation,â€ he acknowledges in his brief that that â€œpost-judgment interest is not part of the judgment itself.â€
[6]  Judge Few correctly stated in his order that â€œ[i]f interest in interest is due in a situation such as this, it is the role of the General Assembly to provide for an award of compound interest by statute.â€Â

text:

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Marcus Duran Smith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-162Â Â Â 
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005 

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marcus Smith pled guilty to breaking into a motor vehicle; assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature; assault and battery with intent to kill; two counts of kidnapping; and three counts of armed robbery.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent sentences of five years for breaking into a motor vehicle; ten years for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature; fifteen years for assault and battery with intent to kill; fifteen years for both counts of kidnapping; and fifteen years for all three counts of armed robbery.Â  Smith appeals, arguing his plea did not comply with the mandates set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  On appeal, counsel for Smith has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), asserting that there are no meritorious grounds for appeal and requesting permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Smith has not filed a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
 ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Staten
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
        Lucius Staten, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Henry L. McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-163
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â Lucius Staten appeals his conviction for lynching in the first degree.Â  He argues the trial court erred in (1) admitting a prior statement by the decedent; (2) barring evidence regarding an alleged confession; and (3) refusing to charge the jury on the law of mere association and mere suspicion.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 15, 2001, Phillip Lee, Jr., a student of Benedict College and a reputed gang member of the Crips, was gunned down on Benedictâ€™s campus.Â  Brothers Lucius and Dushun Staten were indicted for the offenses of murder and lynching in the first degree for this crime.Â  They were tried together in 2002.Â  The jury found Dushun and Lucius guilty of lynching in the first degree, but only Dushun guilty of murder.[1]Â  The trial court sentenced Lucius to fifteen years, suspended upon the service of eight years for lynching.Â  The court sentenced Dushun to thirty years for murder and ten years for lynching, to run concurrently.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, Op. No. 3900 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 6, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 47 at 74).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct.
