Allen, 370 F.3d 75 (1st Cir. 2004); United States v. Lee, 374 F.3d 637 (8th Cir. 2004); People v. Cook, 815 N.E.2d 879 (Ill. App. Ct. 2004); Thomas J. Reed, Crawford v. Washington and the Irretrievable Breakdown of a Union: Separating the Confrontation Clause from the Hearsay Rule, 56 S.C. L. Rev. 185 (2004); see also Williams v. SCI-Huntingdon, No. Civ.A. 02-CV-7693, 2004 WL 2203734, at *11 n.7 (E.D.Pa. Sept. 30, 2004) (â€œâ€˜an off-hand, overheard remarkâ€™ to an acquaintance, such as . . . one made by [a] co-conspirator . . ., is outside the scope of Crawford and thus does not violate the Confrontation Clause.â€).
Some courts have examined what encompasses â€œinterrogationâ€ within the meaning of Crawford.Â  In Fowler v. State, 809 N.E.2d 960 (Ind. Ct. App. 2004), transfer granted (Dec. 9, 2004), the Court of Appeals of Indiana ruled that when police arrive at the scene of an incident in response to a request for assistance and begin informally questioning those nearby immediately thereafter in order to determine what has happened, statements given in response thereto are not testimonial.Â  The court observed that what constitutes a testimonial statement is the official and formal quality of such a statement.Â  The court noted that Crawford chose not to say that any police questioning of a witness would make a statement in response thereto testimonial.Â  Rather, Crawford expressly limited its holding to police â€œinterrogation.â€Â  The court stated: â€œWhatever else police â€˜interrogationâ€™ might be, we do not believe that word applies to preliminary investigatory questions asked at the scene of a crime shortly after it has occurred.â€Â  Id. at 964.
In People v. Corella, 18 Cal. Rptr. 3d 770, 776 (Cal. Ct. App. 2004), the California Court of Appeal illuminated:

Preliminary questions asked at the scene of a crime shortly after it has occurred do not rise to the level of an â€œinterrogation.â€Â  Such an unstructured interaction between officer and witness bears no resemblance to a formal or informal police inquiry that is required for a police interrogation [that results in inadmissible testimonial hearsay].

The Supreme Judicial Court of Maine, in State v. Barnes, 854 A.2d 208 (Me. 2004), found to be nontestimonial statements that were made by the murder defendantâ€™s mother (the victim) to police officers at the station house where she went after an earlier assault by her son.Â  The interaction did not involve structured police interrogation triggering the cross-examination requirement of the Confrontation Clause in admitting the officerâ€™s testimony regarding the motherâ€™s statements.Â  The mother went to the police station on her own, her statements to the officers were made when she was still under the stress of the alleged assault by the defendant, and officers were not questioning her regarding known criminal activity.
In State v. Forrest, 596 S.E.2d 22 (N.C. Ct. App. 2004), the Court of Appeals of North Carolina concluded a crime victimâ€™s statements to an officer made shortly after she was rescued from a kidnapping and assault by the police were not testimonial.Â  The statements were made immediately after the rescue and with no time for reflection or thought on the victimâ€™s part and were initiated spontaneously by the victim.Â  The victim was not (1) providing a formal statement, deposition, or affidavit; (2) aware she was bearing witness; or (3) aware her utterances might impact further legal proceedings.Â  Id. at 27; see also People v. Newland, 775 N.Y.S.2d 308, 309 (N.Y. App. Div. 2004) (â€œ[A] brief, informal remark to an officer conducting a field investigation, not made in response to â€˜structured police questioningâ€™ should not be considered testimonial.â€); People v. Mackey, 785 N.Y.S.2d 870 (N.Y. Crim. Ct. 2004) (stating responses to police officers during a preliminary field investigation are not barred as testimonial statements under Crawford if the statements and the circumstances in which they were made lack the requisite formality to constitute a police interrogation).
Various jurisdictions have addressed the status of excited utterances as nontestimonial.Â  In People v. King, No. 02CA0201, 2005 WL 170727, at *5 (Colo. Ct. App., Jan 27, 2005), the Colorado Court of Appeals elucidated:

[C]lassification of a statement as an excited utterance, while not dispositive, supports a conclusion that a statement is nontestimonial.Â  An excited utterance by definition is one made before the declarant has had an opportunity to reflect on the event.Â  Therefore, it is consistent with the definition of an excited utterance to conclude that it is not a statement which a declarant would reasonably believe at the time it was made might later be used at trial.

In Hammon v. State, 809 N.E.2d 945 (Ind. Ct. App. 2004), transfer granted (Dec. 9, 2004), the victim made a number of excited utterances to police officers at the scene of the crime, in response to preliminary police questions.Â  In concluding these excited utterances did not constitute testimonial statements, the Court of Appeals of Indiana declared:

[T]he very concept of an â€œexcited utteranceâ€ is such that it is difficult to perceive how such a statement could ever be â€œtestimonial.â€Â  The underlying rationale of the excited utterance exception is that such a declaration from one who has recently suffered an overpowering experience is likely to be truthful. . . . An unrehearsed statement made without time for reflection or deliberation, as required to be an excited utterance, is not â€œtestimonialâ€ in that such a statement, by definition, has not been made in contemplation of its use in a future trial.

Id. at 952-53 (citations omitted).
A number of courts dealing with excited utterances have taken the approach of analyzing the intent of the declarant and determining whether the recipient of the excited utterance questions the declarant.Â  See Allie Phillips, A Flurry of Court Interpretations: Weathering the Storm after Crawford v. Washington, 38-Dec Prosecutor 37 (Nov/Dec 2004).Â  For example, if a declarant provides an excited utterance that is simply a cry for help or for medical treatment, and if the witness would not reasonably expect the statement to be used in a prosecutorial manner at the time the utterance is made, then those utterances are being declared nontestimonial and are subject to a traditional hearsay analysis.Â  See, e.g., People v. Moscat, 777 N.Y.S.2d 875 (N.Y. Crim. Ct. 2004); State v. Forrest, 596 S.E.2d 22 (N.C. Ct. App. 2004); State v. Orndorff, 95 P.3d 406 (Wash. Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, if a declarant provides an excited utterance that could reasonably be expected to be used at a later trial (such as reporting a crime), or if a statement is made in response to questioning by a 911 operator, those utterances are being declared testimonial and will require the witness to testify.Â  Phillips, 38-Dec Prosecutor at 41.
D.Â  Status of Leeâ€™s Statements under Crawford
The analysis of whether the admission of Leeâ€™s statements violated the Confrontation Clause begins with the question of whether the statements are testimonial, triggering Crawfordâ€™s per se rule against their admission.Â  In this case, Leeâ€™s statements were not: (1) ex parte in-court testimony or its functional equivalent; (2) extrajudicial statements contained in formalized testimonial materials, such as affidavits, depositions, prior testimony transcripts, or confessions; or (3) taken by police officers in the course of an interrogation.Â  Rather, Leeâ€™s statements were made during a private conversation with his cousin and roommate, Britt.Â  See Crawford, 541 U.S. at ___, 124 S.Ct. at 1364 (â€œAn accuser who makes a formal statement to government officers bears testimony in a sense that a person who makes a casual remark to an acquaintance does not.â€).Â  Significantly, the decedent did not make the statements â€œâ€˜under circumstances which would lead an objective witness reasonably to believe that the statement would be available for use at a later trial.â€™â€Â  Id.Â  Concomitantly, Leeâ€™s statements do not qualify as testimonial.
Leeâ€™s statements are nontestimonial.Â  Consequently, their admission is outside of Crawfordâ€™s scope.Â  See Crawford, 541 U.S. at ___, 124 S.Ct. at 1364.
E.Â  Applicability of Ohio v. Roberts
â€œJustice Scaliaâ€™s opinion [in Crawford] hints, but does not decide, that the Confrontation Clause no longer applies to non-testimonial hearsay, and that its admission is governed by a jurisdictionâ€™s hearsay rulesâ€ and Robertsâ€™ â€œindicia of reliabilityâ€ approach.Â  David F. Binder, Hearsay Handbook Â§ 7:2 (4th ed. 2004).Â  Most jurisdictions are leaning toward the idea that â€œCrawford [left] the Roberts approach untouched with respect to nontestimonial statements.â€Â  United States v. Saget, 377 F.3d 223, 227 (2d Cir. 2004); see also Horton v. Allen, 370 F.3d 75, 84 (1st Cir. 2004) (â€œThus, unless Christianâ€™s statements qualify as â€˜testimonial,â€™ Crawford is inapplicable and Roberts continues to apply.â€); State v. Manuel, 685 N.W.2d 525, 533 (Wis. Ct. App. 2004), review granted, 689 N.W.2d 55 (Wis. 2004) (â€œ[W]e proceed, in an abundance of caution, to analyze Manuelâ€™s confrontation clause claim under the Roberts analysisâ€).
Because nontestimonial hearsay is at issue here, we apply the reliability test of Roberts to determine whether the admission of Leeâ€™s hearsay statements violated Luciusâ€™s Confrontation Clause rights.
Under Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56 (1980), for the statement to be admissible, the declarant must be unavailable, and the statement must fall within a firmly rooted hearsay exception or bear particularized guarantees of trustworthiness.Â  Obviously, Leeâ€™s death rendered him unavailable to testify.Â  Therefore, we examine whether Leeâ€™s statements fall within a firmly rooted hearsay exception.
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE; see also State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 558, 575 S.E.2d 77, 81 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œEvidence is not hearsay unless it is an out of court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€).Â  The rule against hearsay prohibits the admission of evidence of an out-of-court statement to prove the truth of the matter asserted unless an exception to the rule applies.Â  See Huggler v. State, 360 S.C. 627, 602 S.E.2d 753 (2004); State v. Weaver, 361 S.C. 73, 602 S.E.2d 786 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Rule 802, SCRE (â€œHearsay is not admissible except as provided by these rules or by other rules prescribed by the Supreme Court of this State or by statute.â€); Rule 803, SCRE (setting out exceptions to the hearsay rule).
One exception to the hearsay rule is an excited utterance.Â  Rule 803(2), SCRE.Â  An excited utterance is a â€œstatement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition.â€Â  Id.Â  A statement that is admissible because it falls within an exception in Rule 803, such as the excited utterance exception, may be used substantively, that is, to prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 558 S.E.2d 518 (2002); State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999).
â€œThe rationale behind the excited utterance exception is that the startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication.â€Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 20, 558 S.E.2d at 521; see also State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 S.E.2d 30 (2001) (stating the basis for the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule is that the perceived event produces nervous excitement, making fabrication of the statements about the event unlikely).Â  An excited utterance expresses the real belief of the speaker because the utterance is made under the immediate and uncontrolled domination of the senses, rather than under reason and reflection.Â  McHoney, 344 S.C. at 94, 544 S.E.2d at 34.Â  In deciding whether a statement falls within the excited utterance exception, a court must consider the totality of the circumstances.Â  Id.Â  Such a determination is left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521; State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 515 S.E.2d 525 (1999).
â€œThree elements must be met to find the statement [is] an excited utterance.â€Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  First, the statement must relate to a startling event or condition.Â  Id.Â  Second, the statement must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement.Â  Id.Â  Third, the stress of excitement must be caused by the startling event or condition.Â  Id. (citing Rule 803(2), SCRE).Â  Other factors useful in determining whether a statement qualifies as an excited utterance include the declarantâ€™s demeanor, the declarantâ€™s age, and the severity of the startling event.Â  Id. at 22, 558 S.E.2d at 521.
The statements here clearly meet the first element because they relate to the startling event of Lee having a gun â€œpulledâ€ on him.Â  As for whether Lee was â€œunder the stress of excitementâ€ when he made the statements, we note that the amount of time that passed between the startling event and the time the statement was made is one of several factors to consider when deciding whether a statement is an excited utterance.Â  Id. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  While the passage of time between the startling event and the statement is one factor to consider, it is not the dispositive factor.Â  Id.Â  Even statements after extended periods of time can be considered an excited utterance as long as they were made under continuing stress.Â  Id. at 22, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  Lee, normally a â€œcalm, humble, laid back kind of person,â€ was described by Britt as being â€œstorm, angry, storm, angry, just temper-high kind of person when he came in the roomâ€ on the Sunday evening before the shooting.Â  Britt testified that Lee â€œjust kept walking back, walking back and forth in the room.Â  Just like . . . banging on stuff.â€Â  When asked what had happened, Lee replied: â€œThey just pulled a . . . gun on me.â€ (emphasis added).Â  Leeâ€™s demeanor and the severity of the startling event are factors that weigh in favor of finding his statements to be excited utterances.Â  Finally, the third element is satisfied.Â  The â€œstress of excitementâ€ was caused by the â€œstartling eventâ€ of Lee having a gun â€œpulledâ€ on him.
Moreover, the fact that the statements were made in regard to questioning by Britt does not preclude their admissibility.Â  See United States v. Iron Shell, 633 F.2d 77 (8th Cir. 1980) (noting the single question, â€œwhat happened,â€ has been held not to destroy the excitement necessary to qualify under excited utterance exception to hearsay rule); United States v. Glenn, 473 F.2d 191 (D.C. Cir. 1972) (stating fact that excited utterance is made in response to inquiry is not decisive on issue of admissibility).
Given the totality of the circumstances, we find Lee was under the continuing stress of excitement when he told Britt â€œthey just pulled a . . . gun on me.â€Â  When Britt asked who â€œpulledâ€ the gun on him, Lee declared: â€œThe niggers we had a[n] argument with on Saturday.â€Â  On cross-examination by Luciusâ€™s attorney, Britt stated that Lee actually said, â€œThe small kid pulled out a gun and asked . . . whatâ€™s up now.â€Â  Britt believed Lee was specifically referring to the â€œlittle brother,â€ Dushun.Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting Leeâ€™s statements to Britt because the statements fall under the excited utterance hearsay exception.
We are not required to find any other guarantees of trustworthiness because the court will only look to this prong if a statement does not fall within a firmly rooted hearsay exception.Â  See State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999).Â  Leeâ€™s statements constitute excited utterances.Â  The United States Supreme Court has held that an excited utterance is a firmly rooted exception to the hearsay rule.Â  See White v. Illinois, 502 U.S. 346 (1992); see also State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 45, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999) (â€œexcited utterance exception is firmly rooted in South Carolina law and satisfies the requirements of the Confrontation Clauseâ€).
The admission of Leeâ€™s statements satisfies Roberts.Â  The trial court correctly admitted the hearsay statements.Â  Luciusâ€™s Confrontation Clause rights were not violated.[4]
II.Â  Statement Against Penal Interest by Unavailable Witness
Lucius maintains the trial court erred in excluding Michelle Buffâ€™s testimony that Maurice Sanders told her he shot the decedent.Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Relevance
For evidence to be admissible, it must be relevant.Â  Rules 401 & 402, SCRE; State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 606 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Relevant evidence is defined as â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE; State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 142, 591 S.E.2d 646, 651 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Under Rule 401, evidence is relevant if it has a direct bearing upon and tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in controversy.Â  In re Care and Treatment of Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 577 S.E.2d 451 (2003); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 551 S.E.2d 240 (2001).
Prior to the Statensâ€™ joint trial, the State stipulated that neither Lucius nor Dushun actually shot Lee.Â  The State declared: â€œ[W]e are proceeding on the theory of accomplice liability . . . . Whoever the shooter is is not relevant.â€Â  Buff, the girlfriend of Limel Sims, would testify that she took Maurice Sanders to the Benedict College area to look for the gun.Â  In her statement to police, she revealed that, when she took him to the bus station, Sanders confessed to shooting a man at Benedict College because â€œthe guy he shot and some of his friends had jumped him at the mall.â€Â  She added that Sims confirmed Sanders shot Lee.Â  The trial court ruled the test for trustworthiness of the statement was not met, and the identity of the shooter was unimportant for the State to prove its case for aiding and abetting murder.
Buffâ€™s testimony was not relevant.Â  The trial judge did not abuse his discretion in excluding the evidence.
B.Â  Analysis under Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE
Nontestimonial statements against the interest of the declarant at the time when made are admissible as an exception to the hearsay rule if the declarant is unavailable and the circumstances show that a reasonable person would not have made the statement unless believing it to be true.Â  See Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004).Â  Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE, provides in pertinent part:

The following are not excluded by the hearsay rule if the declarant is unavailable as a witness:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

  
(3) Statement against interest.Â  A statement which was at the time of its making so far contrary to the declarantâ€™s pecuniary or proprietary interest, or so far tended to subject the declarant to civil or criminal liability, or to render invalid a claim by the declarant against another, that a reasonable person in the declarantâ€™s position would not have made the statement unless believing it to be true. . . . .
  

The declaration against penal interest exception has been applied to the determination of whether a third party committed the crime charged instead of the defendant in a criminal case.Â  See State v. Doctor, 306 S.C. 527, 413 S.E.2d 36 (1992).Â  An abuse of discretion standard is applied to a trial judgeâ€™s ruling on the issue of whether a statement is admissible as a declaration against penal interest.Â  State v. Forney, 321 S.C. 353, 468 S.E.2d 641 (1996).
However, â€œ[a] statement tending to expose the declarant to criminal liability and offered to exculpate the accused is not admissible unless corroborating circumstances clearly indicate the trustworthiness of the statement.â€Â  Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE; see also McClain v. Anderson Free Press, 232 S.C. 448, 468, 102 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1958) (Oxner, J., concurring).Â  A defendant seeking to offer a hearsay statement against interest bears the formidable burden of establishing that corroborating circumstances clearly indicate the trustworthiness of the statement.Â  State v. Wannamaker, 346 S.C. 495, 552 S.E.2d 284 (2001).Â  Exculpatory evidence that is not corroborated with other evidence that clearly shows its trustworthiness is excluded.Â  Forney, 321 S.C. at 359-60, 468 S.E.2d at 645; State v. McKnight, 321 S.C. 230, 234, 467 S.E.2d 919, 921-22 (1996).Â  Whether a statement has been sufficiently corroborated is a question left to the discretion of the trial judge after considering the totality of the circumstances under which a declaration against penal interest was made.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Kinloch, 338 S.C. 385, 526 S.E.2d 705 (2000).
Rule 804(b)(3) does not require that the information within the statement be clearly corroborated, it means only that there be corroborating circumstances which clearly indicate the trustworthiness of the statement itself, i.e., that the statement was actually made.Â  Kinloch, 338 S.C. at 389, 526 S.E.2d at 707.Â  The corroboration requirement â€œgoes not to the truth of the statementâ€™s contents, but rather to the making of the statement.â€Â  McDonald, 343 S.C. at 323, 540 S.E.2d at 466.Â  The corroboration requirement is a preliminary determination as to the statementâ€™s admissibility, not an ultimate determination about the statementâ€™s truth.Â  Kinloch, 338 S.C. at 389, 526 SE.2d at 707.
In State v. McKnight, evidence offered by a witness with a motive to testify against the alleged declarant was held not sufficiently trustworthy:

First, the declarant in this case, Willie, was available to testify. . . . Moreover, Willie did not exercise any fifth amendment privilege against self-incrimination.
Second, no corroborating evidence existed which clearly indicated the trustworthiness of Willieâ€™s statement against penal interest.Â  On the contrary, the evidence presented during the in camera hearing severely undermined that statementâ€™s trustworthiness.Â  Belser admitted that he felt Willie had wrongly put the blame on him for crimes actually committed by Willie. This statement suggested that Belser had a possible motive for attributing Chandlerâ€™s murder to Willie.Â  Belser also stated that when Willie confessed to the murder, he felt Willie was only joking.Â  Indeed, Willie himself admitted telling at least three different versions of his story at one time or another.

Id. at 234-35, 467 S.E.2d at 922.
Sanders was unavailable to testify due to the exercise of his Fifth Amendment rights.Â  Buff would testify that Sanders confessed to the murder, thereby exposing him to possible further criminal charges.Â  The only corroboration was from the eyewitness testimony of Brandon McCants, who testified that he saw Sanders shoot Lee, and Dushunâ€™s statement that he and Lucius withdrew.Â  However, McCants did not come forward with his information until two months after the incident, even though he was questioned by police much earlier; Dushun obviously had motive to lie; and, when arrested shortly after the shooting, Sanders tested negative for gunshot residue.Â  Lastly, but most importantly, Sims, Buffâ€™s boyfriend, was charged with the murder as well, and Buffâ€™s statement would exculpate him.Â  Therefore, she had motive to make up the story about Sandersâ€™ confession.
Based on the totality of the circumstances, and because of the lack of corroboration and Buffâ€™s possible motivation to be untruthful, the trial court correctly excluded her testimony.Â  Lucius did not carry his burden of showing circumstances clearly corroborating the making of the statement.Â  See United States v. Salvador, 820 F.2d 558 (2d Cir. 1987) (stating inference of trustworthiness from proffered corroborating circumstances must be strong, not merely allowable, not an insignificant hurdle).Â  Moreover, the circumstances do not indicate that the statement was not fabricated.Â  See United States v. Bagley, 537 F.2d 162 (5th Cir. 1976) (excluding statement on basis of doubt as to whether it was made).Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s reasoning that, because the State conceded neither Staten brother was the shooter, showing Sanders as opposed to Sims was the shooter did nothing to aid the jury in its decision.Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to admit the testimony.
III.Â  Jury Charge
Lucius contends the trial court erred in refusing to charge mere association and mere suspicion.Â  We disagree.
The law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 555 S.E.2d 391 (2001); State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 525 S.E.2d 511 (2000).Â  The judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721 (2000).Â  In reviewing jury charges for error, we must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 577 S.E.2d 460 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A jury charge is correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately covers the law.Â  Id. at 318, 577 S.E.2d at 464.Â  To warrant reversal, a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Reese, 359 S.C. 260, 597 S.E.2d 169 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œFailure to give requested jury instructions is not prejudicial error where the instructions given afford the proper test for determining the issues.â€Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 263, 565 S.E.2d 298, 304 (2002).
Lucius requested a charge on mere suspicion before the charge was given, and then objected to the charge when he believed the trial court insufficiently presented the law on mere suspicion to the jury.Â  Though the trial court did not specifically address mere suspicion, its charge on the whole, combined with the law on reasonable doubt and mere presence and knowledge, conveyed to the jury the notion that mere suspicion is insufficient for finding a defendant guilty.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s refusal to specifically charge mere suspicion was neither erroneous nor prejudicial to Lucius, as required by Burkhart.Â  See Burkhart, 350 S.C. at 263, 565 S.E.2d at 304.
Lucius never requested a charge on mere association before the trial court actually administered the charge.Â  Furthermore, he did not request such an instruction after the trial court had charged the jury with the law.Â  The trial court did not have an opportunity to rule upon the objection.Â  See State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 444, 513 S.E.2d 385 (Ct. App. 1999) (to preserve objection to jury charge, defendant must raise the issue at trial).Â  In addition, Rule 20(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure provides:

Notwithstanding any request for legal instructions, the parties shall be given the opportunity to object to the giving or failure to give an instruction before the jury retires, but out of the hearing of the jury.Â  Any objection shall state distinctly the matter objected to and the grounds for objection.Â  Failure to object in accordance with this rule shall constitute a waiver of objection.

Therefore, the issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  Furthermore, although Dushun objected to the trial courtâ€™s alleged failure to include a charge on mere association, an appellant may not preserve an issue for appeal by way of a co-defendantâ€™s objection.Â  See State v. Carriker, 269 S.C. 553, 555, 238 S.E.2d 678, 678 (1977) (â€œWhile appellantâ€™s co-defendant did object, the appellant may not utilize the objection of another defendant to gain review.â€).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, Luciusâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] The trial court declared a mistrial on Luciusâ€™s charge for murder.
[2] Britt stated he was present when Lee and the Statens had a confrontation on the Saturday before the shooting.
[3] 541 U.S. 36, 124 S.Ct. 1354 (2004).
[4] Lucius further claims the trial court erred in admitting the hearsay statements because they actually relate to a prior bad act, not an excited utterance involving â€œthe event.â€Â  However, this objection was not made at trial, and the trial court did not have an opportunity to rule upon the objection.Â  See State v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 599 S.E.2d 448 (2004) (noting that, to be preserved for appellate review, issue must be raised and ruled upon in the trial court).Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for appeal.

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Delores D. Leonard, Appellant,
v.
Kershaw County, State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-164
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gerald F. Smith, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Kennedy DuBose, Jr., of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Delores Leonard, a former part-time magistrate for Kershaw County, appeals the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of her action for unpaid wages.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Delores Leonard became a part-time magistrate for Kershaw County in 1996 and served in that capacity until she resigned in April 2003.Â  During that time, Leonard requested on several occasions for the county to compensate her for the hours she spent â€œon-callâ€ in addition to her scheduled twenty hours per week.Â  In February 2003, Leonard filed an action for unpaid wages, alleging that the county only paid her for twenty hours a week, when in fact she worked additional hours for which the county had failed to compensate her.Â  At trial, Kershaw County filed a motion to dismiss based on the lack of subject matter jurisdiction and for failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, which the trial court granted.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial judge in a civil matter may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed â€œto state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of actionâ€ in the pleadings filed with the court.Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The question to be considered on a motion to dismiss on the pleadings is whether, in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, the pleadings articulate any valid claim for relief.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 232-233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Upon review of a grant of a motion to dismiss, the appellate court applies the same standard of review that was implemented by the trial court.Â  Oâ€™Laughlin v. Windham, 330 S.C. 379, 382, 498 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Leonard argues that the trial court erred in finding the language of the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act is mandatory rather than discretionary and therefore not her only available remedy.Â  We disagree.
The complaint cited the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act for Leonardâ€™s entitlement to compensation for all hours worked, but requested relief under S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10â€”110 (Supp. 2004), the Payment of Wages Act, which entitles employees to relief against an employer for failure to pay wages.Â  The trial court found that the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act governs magistrate payment and therefore provides the exclusive remedy to Leonard.Â  The act reads:

A magistrate aggrieved by a ruling or action taken by a county or the governing body of the county concerning classification, reclassification, or compensation of magistrates based upon this chapter, or with respect to the operation of the magistratesâ€™ court system within the county, may petition the county governing body, in writing, for redress.

S.C. Code Â§ Ann. 22-8-50(A) (1989).Â  
Leonard contends that the term â€œmayâ€ in the language of the statute renders it permissive and that since it is optional, she can therefore chose to seek her remedy under the Wage Payment Act.Â  The general rule of statutory construction is that a specific statute prevails over a more general one. Mims v. Alston, 312 S.C. 311, 313, 440 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1994).Â  The Payment of Wages Act is a general statute that applies to all employers in South Carolina, while the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act specifically addresses wage disputes between magistrates and counties.Â  Legislative intent is the supreme rule of statutory construction if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  It is clear that the legislature intended for the Magistrates Compensation Act to cover everything its name implies.Â  It is only logical for Leonard, who based her right to compensation on the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act, to achieve her relief from that statute as well, particularly since the statute expressly provides cure for conflicts emerging between magistrates and their employers.Â  The term â€œmayâ€ merely demonstrates the legislatureâ€™s intent to give magistrates the option of redress.Â  
We hold that the Magistrateâ€™s Compensation Act provides an exclusive remedy for magistrates with disputes over wages and Leonard should have filed her claim pursuant to that act.Â  Therefore, the trial court correctly dismissed the case.
AFFIRMED
      
  ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Long v. Long
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Suzannah Force Long,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        James Neel Long,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-165
  Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph M. Ramseur, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Robert M. Rosenfeld, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Neel Long (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order denying his request to terminate or modify his obligation to pay alimony to his former wife, Suzannah Force Long (Wife), refusing to terminate his obligation to maintain a life insurance policy naming Wife as beneficiary, and refusing to award attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife divorced in 1998 and entered into a voluntary agreement that the family court incorporated into its divorce order.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, Husband deeded all rights to the marital residence to Wife, and Wife assumed sole responsibility for payment of the first mortgage.Â  Husband agreed to pay Wife periodic alimony in the amount of $1,100 per month.Â  The agreement stated the alimony was payable directly to Wife, was not considered income to Wife, and if Husband was late, Wife could compel payment through the family court without a hearing. Â The parties also agreed that: 

  [T]he completion of the formal education of both of the partiesâ€™ children and/or the satisfaction of the first mortgage on the marital residence referenced above, shall be considered a â€œchange of circumstanceâ€ for the parties; however, there is no agreement as to any type of specific monetary relief which will be afforded Husband upon the happening of these events.

Husband also agreed to maintain $200,000 in life insurance with Wife and children as alternate beneficiaries as long as he was obligated to pay alimony.Â  
In August 2002, Wife initiated this action and sought to hold Husband in contempt for failure to pay alimony and requested an increase in alimony.Â  Husband counterclaimed seeking termination or modification of alimony based upon a change in circumstances. Both parties requested costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
The family court issued an order denying both partiesâ€™ requests for modification of alimony.Â  The court found neither party had met the burden to warrant an increase or decrease in alimony.Â  Although the family court terminated Husbandâ€™s obligation to maintain a life insurance policy for the benefit of his children, the family court left intact Husbandâ€™s obligation to maintain life insurance for the benefit of his Wife because his alimony obligation was not terminated.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered each party to bear his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Questions regarding alimony lie within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by some error of law or is based on findings of fact that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                  Alimony
Husband argues the family court erred in failing to terminate or modify his alimony obligation.Â  We disagree.
An award of periodic alimony may be modified pursuant to section 20-3-170 of the South Carolina Code (1985). That statute provides:

  Whenever [a spouse] . . . has been required to make his or her spouse any periodic payments of alimony and the circumstances of the parties or the financial ability of the spouse making the periodic payments shall have changed since the rendition of such judgment, either party may apply to the court which rendered the judgment for an order and judgment decreasing or increasing the amount of such alimony payments or terminating such payments . . . .

To justify modification or termination of an alimony award, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material. Eubank v. Eubank, 347 S.C. 367, 372, 555 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 2001).
Husband argues that a change has occurred because Wife satisfied the mortgage on the marital residence and voluntarily retired early at age fifty-three, thereby diminishing her income.Â  However, Wife asserted that during the marriage the parties had planned for her to retire from her job as a full-time teacher when she reached retirement age.Â  At the time of the divorce, Wife earned a gross monthly income of $2,859, and her monthly expenses totaled $3,023.50.Â  At the time of the hearing, she received a monthly retirement benefit of $1,802.47, and her monthly expenses had increased to $3,235.67.Â  At the time of the divorce, Husband earned a gross monthly income of $7,500, subject to monthly withholding for income taxes, Social Security, and insurance.Â  His gross monthly expenses were $4,452, including $2,000 he paid in alimony and child support.Â  At the time of the final hearing, Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income had increased to $9,083.Â  His monthly gross expenses included a $2,293.97 monthly mortgage payment on the house he shares with his current wife.Â  
Pursuant to the partiesâ€™ agreement, completion of the childrenâ€™s education or the mortgage satisfaction only indicates a circumstance when alimony may be reviewed, specifically leaving the ultimate decision to the discretion of the family court.Â  The agreement did not provide for a conclusive change upon the mere occurrence of one of these stipulations.Â  The family court found Husband did not meet his burden to warrant a reduction in alimony.Â  Although Wife no longer has a mortgage payment, she still pays taxes and insurance and her overall expenses have increased slightly.Â  These factors, coupled with the fact that Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income has increased substantially, indicate no abuse of discretion by the family court in refusing modification.Â  
II.               Life Insurance
Husband also argues the family court erred by failing to terminate his obligation to maintain life insurance naming Wife as the beneficiary.Â  We disagree.
In the original divorce action, the parties reached an agreement resolving contested issues that the family court incorporated into its order.Â  The family court found the parties entered into the agreement freely and voluntarily, had ample time to consider every provision of the agreement, and fully understood the agreement.Â  Husband agreed, pursuant to the agreement, that he would maintain a life insurance policy naming Wife as beneficiary for so long as his obligation to pay alimony remained.Â  Since we hold the family court did not err in refusing to modify alimony, the family court correctly ordered Husband to maintain the life insurance policy as previously ordered.
III.           Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the family court erred by refusing to award him attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
â€œOrdinarily, the award of attorney fees lies within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€ McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 601, 506 S.E.2d 1, 10 (Ct. App. 1998). The factors to be considered in awarding reasonable attorney fees and costs include: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services. Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, the beneficial results obtained by counsel, the respective financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).
We find the family court properly considered the factors in declining to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree with Husbandâ€™s contention the family court erred in finding both he and Wife achieved beneficial results.Â  Wife obtained beneficial results in regard to both alimony and the life insurance policy. Therefore, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision regarding the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â  
AFFIRMED.Â  
 ANDERSON, BEATTY, SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
James E. Johnson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
John  L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-166
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: James Johnson appeals the lower courtâ€™s denial of his directed verdict motion.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On the night of July 3 and the early morning of July 4, 2002, James Johnson, Gregory Ray, and Anthony Johnson were in Myrtle Beach when they met Jason Ernst, who attempted to sell them ecstasy pills.Â  James, Gregory, and Anthony then proceeded to abduct Ernst, steal his pills and wallet, and force him to give them his Personal Identification Number to his debit card.Â  The men then drove to several Automatic Teller Machines (ATM) and withdrew cash, then claimed they dropped Ernst off on an isolated highway.Â  Ernstâ€™s dead body was found underneath a Highway 22 ramp, precisely where James stated they had let Ernst out of their vehicle.Â  The death occurred as a result of a fall from a bridge.Â  In September and November of 2002, the Horry County grand jury indicted James Johnson on four counts: murder, kidnapping, strong armed robbery, and financial card fraud.Â  After the State presented its case at trial, Johnson made a motion for directed verdict on all charges, which the trial court denied. Â The jury found James guilty and the trial judge sentenced him to life imprisonment for the murder.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight. State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this Court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the State. State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury. State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
James argues the trial court erred by refusing to direct a verdict of acquittal on the charge of murder because the State did not introduce any direct or circumstantial evidence that reasonably tended to prove guilt.Â  We disagree.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, sufficient evidence exists to demonstrate the trial judge correctly sent the case to the jury.Â  The trial judge relied upon the defendantâ€™s voluntary statement to police when deciding to deny the directed verdict motion.Â  We also feel this piece of evidence provided an evidentiary trail indicating at the very least, that James participated in the crimes immediately preceding the death of Ernst.Â  James admitted to driving the car after Ernst was abducted and robbed of cash and his ATM card.Â  James also stated that he took the ecstasy pills from Ernst and later dropped him off on a bridge in an area that that by his description, was identical to the location where the victimâ€™s body was found.Â  Furthermore, James claimed that the three men let Ernst out of the vehicle and the vehicle then struck Ernst in a manner James described as a â€œloud thumpâ€ and not a mere â€œtap.â€Â  Authorities also found Anthonyâ€™s wallet in Ernstâ€™s pocket.Â  
A forensic pathologist testified that the victimâ€™s injuries were consistent with a fall from a high object, but in his opinion, inconsistent with suicide.Â  A senior examiner with the Department of Latent Prints of the State Law Enforcement Division testified that the victimâ€™s wounds were consistent with a struggle and with being dragged across the pavement on the bridge and he also ruled out a possible fall as a result of an automobile collision.Â  
James concedes that the stateâ€™s evidence proves his involvement in the kidnapping and robbery but that no evidence places him at the scene of the murder and cites State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000), where the supreme court reversed a denial of a directed verdict when the Stateâ€™s evidence failed to place the defendant at the scene. See also State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 322 S.E.2d 450 (1984).Â  These cases however, create a much more tenuous link between the respective defendants and the scenes of the crime.Â Â  In the case at bar, James admitted to the officer who took his statement to being at the scene and went so far as to describe the location where Ernst plunged to his death.[2]Â  Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, we find substantial evidence exists for the trial judge to have denied the directed verdict motion.Â  â€œ[T]he trial judge must submit the case to the jury if there is any substantial circumstantial evidence . . . from which his guilt may be fairly or logically deduced.â€Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 322, 555 S.E.2d 402, 405 (2001). 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Sergeant Richard Bonneyâ€™s testimony: 

Q.    And in your description and your understanding of the conversation was the place that the defendant says he left the victim out of the car the same place the body was found?
A.Â Â Â Â  Yes, it is.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Reginald A. McLemore,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mary Dreher,       
Respondent
        
      
    
  

Appeal From Richland County
Donna S. Strom, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-167
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John S. Nichols and Melvin Dean Bannister, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Mary Dreher, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Reginald McLemore appeals the family courtâ€™s order denying his request for reimbursement for child support paid to Mary Dreher. 
We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
After many years of knowing each another, Dreher and McLemore engaged in a sexual relationship.Â  In 1991, Dreher gave birth to a daughter, Brianna.Â  Following Briannaâ€™s birth, Dreher accepted money from McLemore on multiple occasions over an approximate eight-year period.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In 2002, McLemore petitioned the family court asserting he was Briannaâ€™s father and requesting visitation.Â  McLemore subsequently amended his complaint requesting a paternity test, and alternatively, if the paternity test indicated he was not Briannaâ€™s father, requesting reimbursement for child support paid.Â  After finding that Dreher had for some time acknowledged McLemore was the childâ€™s father and McLemore had paid child support to Dreher, the family court issued a temporary order granting McLemoreâ€™s request for visitation.Â  Dreher then filed an answer and counterclaim stating she informed McLemore on numerous occasions that another man, not McLemore, was Briannaâ€™s father.Â  Dreher also requested attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The family court conducted a hearing, at which Dreher requested the family court reconsider its temporary order.Â  As a result of that hearing, the family court issued an order requiring McLemore to submit to a paternity test and suspending his right to visitation pending a further order of the court.Â  Subsequently, the family court issued a final order denying McLemoreâ€™s request for visitation after finding he was not Briannaâ€™s father, and denying McLemoreâ€™s request for reimbursement after finding the payments he made to Dreher were not child support.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered McLemore to pay eight hundred dollars in attorneyâ€™s fees payable in monthly installments of one hundred dollars.Â  McLemore filed a motion to reconsider.Â  After a hearing on this motion, the family court issued an order reducing McLemoreâ€™s payment of attorneyâ€™s fees to fifty dollars per month.Â  McLemore appeals from the family courtâ€™s order. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a decision by the family court, this court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 21, 553 S.E.2d 251, 254 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, we are not required to disregard the findings of the family court or ignore the fact that the family court saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate the credibility and weigh their testimony.Â  Id. at 21-22, 553 S.E.2d at 254.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Paternity 
McLemore argues the family court erred by refusing to grant him reimbursement for child support paid to Dreher.Â  We disagree.
McLemore asserts Dreher misled him into thinking Brianna was his child and the payments he made to Dreher were child support for Brianna.Â  Furthermore, McLemore contends the only explanation for his continued payments to Dreher was his belief that he was Briannaâ€™s father.Â  In addition, he argues the decision to abandon his claim for visitation after he discovered he was not Briannaâ€™s father supports his position.Â Â  Dreher, however, testified she told McLemore several times he was not Briannaâ€™s father.Â  Barbara Richardson, a friend of Dreherâ€™s, confirmed she visited with Dreher shortly after Briannaâ€™s birth and witnessed Dreher inform McLemore that he was not the father.Â  Giving weight to the family court, we find the courtâ€™s determination that McLemore knew prior to the filing of his cause of action that Brianna was not his child was reasonable based on the evidence.Â  
II.Â  Child Support
McLemore contends because Dreher did not challenge the nature of the payments as child support, as determined by the family court in its temporary order, the status of the payments as child support is the law of the case.Â  We disagree. 
Contrary to McLemoreâ€™s assertion, the family courtâ€™s findings of facts in a temporary order do not become the law of the case.Â  Temporary orders are issued without prejudice to the rights of the parties at the final hearing.Â 
Rimer v. Rimer, Â­361 S.C. 521, 527 n.6, 605 S.E.2d 572, 575 n.6 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not err in making a determination that the payments by McLemore to Dreher were not child support in its final order.Â Â  
III. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
McLemore argues the family court erred in awarding Dreher eight hundred dollars in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Specifically, McLemore complains the family court did not consider the necessary factors in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Section 20-7-420(38) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), provides that attorneyâ€™s fees may be awarded in an action brought in family court.Â  â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless there is an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay, whether beneficial results were obtained by the attorney, the financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each party.Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 645, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In determining what amount of attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider â€œthe nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; the professional standing of counsel; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Id.Â  
Our review of the record indicates the family court considered the necessary factors in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Dreher.Â  At the hearing on McLemoreâ€™s motion to reconsider and in response to McLemoreâ€™s argument that he did not have the ability to pay the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded to Dreher, the family court judge stated he considered all factors, not just the ability to pay.Â  Furthermore, after determining McLemoreâ€™s monthly income, the judge reduced his monthly payments by half.Â  In addition, the record contains an affidavit supplied by Dreherâ€™s attorney specifying her experience and expertise, her hourly rate, and the time she spent working on this case.Â  We find the family court considered all of the appropriate factors and did not abuse its discretion.Â  
 AFFRIMED.  
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  On September 9 and 10, 2003, Donald Lyles was tried and convicted of criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated nature.Â  He was sentenced to ten years in prison.Â  Lyles appeals, arguing the judge erred in allowing the State to introduce evidence that he had two pending charges for criminal domestic violence.Â  On appeal, counsel for Lyles has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), asserting that there are no meritorious grounds for appeal and requesting permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Lyles has not filed a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.

In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ralph L. Jones,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-169
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 7, 2005

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ralph Jones pled guilty to assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct in the first degree, indecent exposure, and possession of crack cocaine.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent sentences of twenty-three years for assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct; three years for indecent exposure; and five years for possession of crack cocaine.Â  Jones appeals, arguing his plea did not comply with the mandates set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  On appeal, counsel for Jones has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), asserting that there are no meritorious grounds for appeal and requesting permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Jones has not filed a pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED.[1]
 ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
GB&S Corporation,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
County of Florence, Karl Gene Smith, and HS, Inc.,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-171
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed March 9, 2005Â Â 

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Brown W. Johnson, of Florence, for Appellant HS, Inc.
Charlie J. Blake, Jr., of Florence, for Appellants Florence County and Karl Gene Smith.
Kermit S. King, and David C. Shea, both of Columbia, for Respondent GB&S Corporation.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The County of Florence through its treasurer, Karl Gene Smith (collectively, the County) sold GB&S Corporation property at a tax sale, after the propertyâ€™s former owner, HS, Inc., became delinquent in taxes owed on the property.Â  GB&S brought this declaratory judgment action seeking to require the County to execute and deliver a tax deed for the property.Â  The County alone defended the matter in pre-trial proceedings, with HSâ€™s informal assistance, until the circuit court granted summary judgment to GB&S.Â  HS intervened during the pendency of the Countyâ€™s motion for reconsideration, which was denied.Â  HSâ€”and presumably the Countyâ€”now appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment against the County.Â  We dismiss this appeal, finding: (1) the County abandoned its defense of this action in the circuit court; and (2) HS, which has never filed a pleading, failed to properly raise any of the issues on appeal before the circuit court.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
GB&S purchased property in Florence County through a tax sale in October 1996.Â Â  The property had been subject to the tax sale because its former owner, HS, owed delinquent taxes from the years 1994 and 1995.Â  However, the County later found the tax sale invalid and set it aside.
In June 1998, GB&S brought the present action against the County seeking declaratory judgment that the sale was valid.Â  The action also sought an order requiring that the County execute and deliver to GB&S a tax deed for the property.
The County answered in July 1998.Â  Its sole argument was the tax sale was invalid because the County failed to comply with South Carolina Code section 12-45-410, which requires â€œ[a]ny taxes paid by a delinquent taxpayer to a county treasurer or tax collector must be applied to the oldest chronological delinquency on the property for which payment was intended.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-45-410 (2000) (the statute).Â  Specifically, the County argued it erroneously applied money paid by HS in 1996 to taxes due for the 1995 tax year rather than the older debt from the 1994 tax year, and that its non-compliance with the statute rendered the tax sale invalid.Â  Additionally, it admitted paragraph twelve of GB&Sâ€™s complaint that asserted HS received notice of the levy.Â  
In May 1999, GB&S moved for summary judgment, arguing the tax sale was valid as a matter of law because the undisputed facts indicated that even if the County had properly applied HSâ€™s delinquent tax payments pursuant to the statute, a deficiency would have remained.Â  The County responded, arguing its failure to strictly comply with the statute precluded a finding that GB&S was entitled to summary judgment as a matter of law.Â  HS elected not to intervene at this time, opting instead to monitor the litigation and lend assistance to the County.Â  
At the summary judgment hearing in January 2000, only attorneys representing GB&S and the County appeared.Â  The arguments before the able circuit judge were confined to those matters arising from the Countyâ€™s failure to strictly comply with section 12-45-410.Â  Although the issue of notice was conceded in the Countyâ€™s answer, a memorandum submitted to the circuit court contained a general challenge to the issue of proper notice.Â  Contrary to the admission in the Countyâ€™s answer, the County furnished an affidavitâ€”prepared by an owner of HSâ€”contending that service on â€œDonice Majorsâ€ was insufficient, for she â€œhas never been an agent or in any way connected with HS, Inc.â€Â  The Countyâ€™s memorandum conversely referred to Donice Majors as an â€œagent for HS, Inc.â€Â  The issue of noticeâ€”with the Countyâ€™s conflicting submissionsâ€”was not pursued at the hearing and the circuit court addressed only the issue argued at the hearing, that is, the Countyâ€™s failure to strictly comply with section 12-45-410.Â  
The circuit court granted summary judgment to GB&S in March 2000, finding that even if the County had properly applied section 12-45-410, â€œthere would still have been due and owing an amount in excess of $406 for the tax year 1994â€ and $1,437.61 in taxes for 1995.Â  The court also found that â€œ[a]t no time prior to the tax sale were the property taxes paid in full.â€Â  The court declared the sale valid and ordered the County to issue a tax deed to GB&S.
The County made a motion to amend in March 2000.Â  Over three years later, HS filed a memorandum in support of the Countyâ€™s motion.
During the pendency of the courtâ€™s decision on the Countyâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the County informed counsel for HS that it did not wish to continue participating in the litigation and the County â€œwas not particularly interested in seeing this decision overturned.â€Â  In response, HS made a motion to intervene in April 2000.Â  In an affidavit accompanying the motion, counsel for HS stated, among other things:

4.     [GB&Sâ€™s] suit did not include as a party HS, Inc., the former owner of the property and the delinquent taxpayer.
â€¦
6.Â Â Â Â Â Â  HS, Inc. assisted [the County] in this action to the extent of providing information and an affidavit from the owner of HS, Inc. with the assurance from the [the County]Â  that the interest of HS, Inc. would be protected and the [the County] would vigorously defend the suit.
7.Â Â Â Â Â Â  After the Court issued a summary judgment in favor ofÂ  [GB&S], counsel for [the County] for the first time informed me that [the County] was not interested in seeing this decision overturned. Â Therefore, in order to protect its interest, HS, Inc. should be allowed to intervene pursuant to Rule 24(a)(2) since HS, Inc. has an interest in the property and its interest will not be adequately represented by the existing party.Â  In fact, it appears the suit may be a friendly suit between the existing parties.

Judge Casey Manning granted HSâ€™s motion to intervene in October 2002.Â  
In June 2003, the circuit court held a hearing on the Countyâ€™s motion for reconsideration, at which counsel for GB&S and HS were present.Â  However, â€œno representative of, or attorney for, County of Florence appearedâ€ in spite of having received proper notice.Â  The court denied the motion for reconsideration.
HS appealed, and the County, at the behest of HS, executed the notice of appeal.Â  
DISCUSSION
This appeal presents a procedural morass.Â  HS seeks to posture itself as a proper party on appeal by claiming to represent not only its interests but also the interests of the County.Â  We reject the suggestion by counsel for HS at oral argument that he is also counsel of record for the County.Â  During the preliminary stages of the appeal process, GB&S sought dismissal of this appeal.[1]Â  Because the County had not filed an initial brief, this court sought to determine if the County claimed an interest in the appeal.Â  The court was informed that the Appellants had filed a joint initial brief.Â  Counsel for the Countyâ€”as listed in the caption of this opinionâ€”wrote the following letter to this courtâ€™s docketing clerk:

I represent the County of Florence and Karl Gene Smith â€¦ My clients and HS, Inc. have filed a joint Brief, and I did not intend to file a separate brief. Please advise if you need any additional information.

Our review of the file further reveals the absence of a motion seeking substitution of counsel.Â  See Rule 235, SCACR (â€œThe attorneys â€¦ of the respective parties in the court below shall be deemed the attorneys â€¦ of the same parties in the appellate court until withdrawal is approvedâ€).Â  There is no support for the position that counsel for HS is counsel of record for the County.
We address the Appellants separately.
The County
The record leaves no doubt that the County abandoned its opposition to the grant of summary judgment to GB&S.Â  Following the grant of summary judgment and the filing of its reconsideration motion, the County, through counsel, made it perfectly clear that it was â€œnot interestedâ€ in seeking reversal of the circuit courtâ€™s summary judgment decision.Â  Counsel for the County failed to appear at the hearing on its reconsideration motion.Â  Counsel for the County even failed to appear at oral argument in this court.Â  A party may not abandon its position in the trial court and then resurrect it on appeal. Â Â See State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 156-57, 526 S.E.2d 228, 231 (2000), cert. denied 530 U.S. 1209 (2000) (An issue conceded in the trial court cannot be argued on appeal); Ex parte McMillan, 319 S.C. 331, 335, 461 S.E.2d 43, 45 (1995) (A party cannot acquiesce to an issue at trial and then complain on appeal).
HS
At the outset, HS sought to protect its interest by monitoring the litigation.Â  HS thus elected to allow the County to protect its interest.Â  Only when the County decided to throw the towel in did HS seek to intervene as a party pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.[2]Â  HS was granted leave to intervene and responded by filing a â€œmemorandum in support of motion to amend findings and judgmentâ€ in support of GB&Sâ€™s reconsideration motion.Â  The circuit court, at the hearing on the Countyâ€™s reconsideration motion, noted that HS had filed no â€œpleadingâ€ as mandated by Rule 24(c), SCRCP.[3]Â  The circuit court further found:

HS, Inc.[] has filed no pleading and therefore neither has raised nor joined any issue with [GB&S]; and HS, Inc.[] has filed no motion for reconsideration; and in the view of this Court, HS, Inc.[] has nothing pending before this Court as to which counsel for HS, Inc.[] should be permitted to argue or as to which the undersigned needs to render a decision.

We concur with the finding of the circuit court in this regard.Â  We do, however, accept HSâ€™s argument that its interest in the underlying property gave it standing to intervene.Â  Yet standing, by itself, does not a lawsuit make, nor does it satisfy all the requirements of intervention.Â  A party must take all proper steps to properly avail itself of the courts of this state.Â  HS has failed to do so and acknowledged at oral argument its noncompliance with Rule 24.
We further reject for two reasons the attempt of HS to borrow the appellate rights of the County.Â  First, an appellant may not preserve an issue for appeal by way of a co-defendantâ€™s objection.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 487 S.E.2d 187 (1997).Â  Secondly, the Countyâ€”having abandoned in the circuit court its right to challenge the grant of summary judgmentâ€”has no appellate rights from which to borrow. 
This appeal is 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Judge Cureton, on behalf of this court, denied the motion of GB&S â€œto quash HS, Inc.â€™s notice of appeal,â€ with leave to renew the motion in its brief.Â  GB&S reasserted its motion to â€œquashâ€ in its brief.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  HS never sought to be substituted for the County.
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  HS has never filed a pleading in this case.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Brian A. DiMarco,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cheryl A. Brooks DiMarco,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-173
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Brian A. DiMarco, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Kim R. Varner, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Brian DiMarco (Husband) petitioned the family court for a decrease in his child support obligation paid to his former wife, Cheryl DiMarco (Wife).Â  The family court denied Husbandâ€™s requests and awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband appeals and we affirm.[1]
FACTS
Husband filed a petition with the family court to, among other requests, decrease the amount of his child support obligation based on a change in circumstances.Â  After a hearing, the family court issued a temporary order denying Husbandâ€™s request based on his failure to supply the court with a financial declaration.Â  In addition to denying Husbandâ€™s other requests, the family court awarded Wife $3,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court based its decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees on Wifeâ€™s need to investigate Husbandâ€™s income, the numerous allegations made by Husband that Wife would be required to defend, and the fact Husband had the ability to pay and Wifeâ€™s inability to pay.Â  Husband filed a motion to reconsider, which the family court denied.Â  A final order has been issued resolving the dispute between the parties.Â  Husband appeals the temporary order.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be overturned absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 61, 552 S.E.2d 329, 336 (Ct. App. 2001). Husband asserts four arguments to support his contention the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Husband first argues that the family court judge has an alleged history of abusing his discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and cites only one instance where the judge was overruled by this court on that issue.Â  This argument is wholly without merit.Â  Whether the family court judge who presided over this case has been found to have abused his discretion once or one hundred times by an appellate court is irrelevant and has absolutely no bearing upon the case currently before us.Â  We decide the case based on the record that stands before us and refuse to consider this argument by Husband.
Secondly, Husband argues he was not given an opportunity to contest the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded because Wife did not make a written request for attorneyâ€™s fees and she did not submit an attorney fee affidavit.Â  However, Husband failed to provide us with any of Wifeâ€™s pleadings and affidavits.[2]Â  
Considering Husbandâ€™s argument in light of the inadequate record, we find it was not properly preserved for appeal.Â  The record reflects Wifeâ€™s attorney requested attorneyâ€™s fees at the hearing.Â  The record does not indicate Husband objected to Wifeâ€™s request for attorney fees, nor does it indicate he objected to the absence of an attorney fee affidavit.Â  â€œA contemporaneous objection is required to properly preserve an error for appellate review.Â  The failure to make an objection at the time evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object.â€Â  Doe v. S.B.M., 327 S.C. 352, 356, 488 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1997) (internal citations omitted).Â Â  Husband failed to preserve this argument for appeal and we are unable to address it.Â  
Husband also claims the family court abused its discretion in not considering the necessary factors in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  When deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay, whether beneficial results were obtained by the attorney, the financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each party.Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 645, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In determining what amount of attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider â€œthe nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; the professional standing of counsel; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Id. at 645, 506 S.E.2d at 534.Â  The order reflects the court considered and explicitly cited the necessary factors and we therefore find the family court did not abuse its discretion.
Husband also argues the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees because the family court based its determination of Wifeâ€™s ability to pay on fraudulent information.Â  The family courtâ€™s order did not address what it relied on in determining Wifeâ€™s ability pay her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Therefore, the family court did not specifically rule on this issue and Husband did not include this argument in his motion for reconsideration.Â  In order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â 
Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â  When a trial court makes a general ruling on an issue, but does not address the specific argument raised by the an appellant, the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.Â 
Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).Â  Accordingly, we are unable to address it upon review.Â  
II. Reduction in Husbandâ€™s Child Support
Husband also argues the family court abused its discretion in failing to reduce his child support obligation.Â  He contends on appeal that he is entitled to a reduction because the partiesâ€™ oldest child had reached the age of majority prior to the initiation of this action.Â  â€œ[A] parentâ€™s obligation to pay child support extends until the child reaches majority, become self-supporting, or marries, then ends by operation of law.â€Â  Purdy v. Purdy, 353 S.C. 400, 403, 578 S.E.2d 30, 31 (Ct. App. 2003); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(17) (Supp. 2004).Â  However, the record indicates Husbandâ€™s only argument for a reduction of child support at the hearing was based on a change in circumstances argument.Â  Therefore, Husband did not raise this issue to the family court, and thus, it was not ruled upon nor properly preserved for our review. 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ. concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The initial record contained only Husbandâ€™s complaint, the family courtâ€™s temporary order, the hearing transcript, and Husbandâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  Husband subsequently provided the final order.
