THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ida Mae Suber, individually,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dealva Taundolyn Suber, individually; and Helen Reese Bailey, individually; jointly and severally,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-174
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James H. Dickey, of Atlanta, for Appellant.
Robert A. McKenzie, Gary H. Johnson, II, and Robert Walton Buffington, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ida Mae Suber appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing her negligence claim against Dealva Taundolyn Suber and Helen Reese Bailey (Respondents) on the ground an identical case was already pending in circuit court.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On September 29, 2000, Suber filed an action for negligence against Respondents in the Richland County Court of Common Pleas for injuries she sustained in an automobile accident that occurred on October 3, 1997.Â  Suber was a passenger in the vehicle driven by Dealva Taundolyn Suber, and Helen Reese Bailey was the driver of the other vehicle.Â  Because Suberâ€™s attorney, James Dickey, failed to attend the scheduled depositions, Respondents filed motions to dismiss for failure to prosecute pursuant to Rule 41(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.[2]Â  Circuit Court Judge Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., scheduled a hearing on May 17, 2001, but Dickey did not attend.Â  Judge Cooper issued a rule to show cause and ordered Dickeyâ€™s appearance before the court.Â  When Dickey failed to appear, Judge Cooper granted the motion to dismiss in a form order.Â  On August 2, 2001, Judge Cooper issued a formal order dismissing the action against Respondents without prejudice on the condition that Suber would have to pay attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in the amount of $500 to Respondentsâ€™ counsel before filing another action against Respondents.[3]Â  Thereafter, Suber filed a motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  The motion is still pending. 
On August 1, 2002, Suber filed the instant lawsuit in the Richland County Court of Common Pleas.Â  The allegations against Respondents arise out of the same automobile accident and are identical to those in the earlier action.Â  Respondents again filed motions to dismiss.Â  In their motions, Respondents asserted the action should be dismissed on the following grounds:Â  (1). the second action was barred by the three-year statute of limitations; (2). Suber had not complied with the requirements of Judge Cooperâ€™s order with respect to the payment of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Respondentsâ€™ attorneys; and (3). Suber had not effectuated proper service of process. 
On January 9, 2003, Circuit Court Judge James R. Barber, III, heard arguments on Respondentsâ€™ motions to dismiss.Â  Subsequently, Judge Barber issued an order granting Respondentsâ€™ motions.Â  Specifically, Judge Barber found the current action involved the same parties seeking the same relief as in the initial lawsuit.Â  Thus, he found that if Suber prevailed on her Rule 59(e) motion, the initial action would be viable and would proceed to its conclusion.Â  Additionally, he held that if Judge Cooper denied the pending motion, Suber had not complied with the requirements set forth in Judge Cooperâ€™s order.Â  In a form order, Judge Barber denied Suberâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
I.
Suber argues Judge Barber abused his discretion in dismissing her second lawsuit based upon the â€œnon-finalâ€ order of Judge Cooper.Â  Because Suberâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion had not been ruled upon by Judge Cooper, Suber contends Judge Barber was required to stay the proceeding before ruling on the instant action.Â  Furthermore, Suber asserts Judge Barber failed to properly review the file of the original action in reaching his decision. Â Finally, Suber claims Judge Barber erred in ruling prior to hearing Suberâ€™s counselâ€™s argument regarding a stay of the proceeding.[4] Â We disagree.
Initially, we disagree with Suberâ€™s contention that Judge Barber relied on Judge Cooperâ€™s non-final order in dismissing the case.Â  Because Judge Cooper had not ruled on Suberâ€™s prior motion, the original lawsuit involving the same parties and request for relief was still pending in the circuit court.[5]Â  Thus, Judge Barber properly dismissed the case because the same two actions would impermissibly be proceeding in circuit court.Â  See Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP (A trial court may dismiss an action where â€œanother action is pending between the same parties for the same claim.â€); cf. Wessinger v. Rauch, 288 S.C. 157, 160, 341 S.E.2d 643, 644 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œAs a general rule, courts will not entertain an action for declaratory judgment if there is pending, at the time the action is commenced, another action between the same parties in which the same issues presented in the action for declaratory judgment can be adjudicated.â€).
With respect to Suberâ€™s assertion that Judge Barber did not review the file from the earlier action, we find this argument to be without merit.Â  Our review of the record reveals that Respondents provided Judge Barber with a copy of Judge Cooperâ€™s order.Â  Furthermore, Suberâ€™s attorney acknowledged the substance of the order in that he conceded:Â  (1). the Rule 59(e) motion was still pending; (2). the lawsuits were identical; and (3). he had not complied with the condition precedent ordered by Judge Cooper.
Finally, we question whether Suberâ€™s claim that her counsel was not provided sufficient time to present the case is preserved for our review.Â  Our review of the record does not reveal that Suberâ€™s attorney raised this argument to Judge Barber.Â  Furthermore, Suberâ€™s argument in her brief is conclusory and is not supported by any specific citations to authority.Â  Therefore, it is not properly before this court.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (stating appellant was deemed to have abandoned issue for which he failed to provide any argument or supporting authority); Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œ[S]hort, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€).Â  
In any event, we find this argument to be without merit.Â  During the hearing, Suberâ€™s attorney agreed with the essential facts stated by opposing counsel.Â  He informed the court that the Rule 59(e) motion in the initial lawsuit had not been ruled upon and, therefore, the current lawsuit should be held in abeyance.Â  After hearing these statements, the court questioned Suberâ€™s attorney whether the second lawsuit was â€œa duplicationâ€ of the first lawsuit.Â  Based upon Suberâ€™s attorneyâ€™s response, the court stated it was going to dismiss the suit due to the identical pending lawsuit and the fact that the required attorneyâ€™s fees and costs had not been paid before filing the second lawsuit. Â Based upon our reading of what transpired during the hearing, we find the court did not abuse its discretion given it provided Suberâ€™s attorney an opportunity to present arguments relevant to the disposition of the case.Â  See Sullivan v. Davis, 317 S.C. 462, 465, 454 S.E.2d 907, 909 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding trial court has discretion in deciding whether to admit or exclude evidence; the courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent clear showings of both abuse and prejudice); see also State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 539, 273 S.E.2d 765, 766 (1981)(holding the control of argument is normally within the discretion of the trial court, and we will not disturb its ruling where there is no abuse of discretion).
Thus, we find Judge Barber was well informed of the status of the case and properly dismissed Suberâ€™s second lawsuit pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8).
II.
As an additional sustaining ground, Respondents assert this court should affirm Judge Barberâ€™s order because Suberâ€™s second lawsuit is barred by the three-year statute of limitations.Â  We agree. 
Although Judge Barber did not explicitly rule on this issue it was raised by Respondents in their motions to dismiss and was noted in Judge Barberâ€™s written order.Â  Thus, we choose to address this argument.Â  See Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œThe appellate court may review respondentâ€™s additional reasons and, if convinced it is proper and fair to do so, rely on them or any other reason appearing in the record to affirm the lower courtâ€™s judgment.â€); Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
Actions to recover for personal injuries that arise after April 5, 1988, must be commenced within three years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (2005).Â  Here, the automobile accident for which Suber alleges she sustained injuries occurred on October 1, 1997.Â  Suber, however, did not file the second lawsuit until August 1, 2002, which was almost five years after the accident.Â  We hold Suberâ€™s second lawsuit was untimely and, thus, barred by the three-year statute of limitations.
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing this case is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Rule 41(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides in pertinent part:Â  â€œFor failure of the plaintiff to prosecute or to comply with these rules or any order of court, a defendant may move for dismissal of an action or of any claim against him.â€
[3]Â  In this order, Judge Cooper dismissed with prejudice Suberâ€™s action against State Farm Insurance Company, Dealva Taundolyn Suberâ€™s insurer.Â  State Farm is not a party to this appeal.
[4]Â Â  Although Suber raises three separate issues, all of her arguments challenge Judge Barberâ€™s dismissal of the instant action.Â  Therefore, in the interest of clarity and brevity, we have consolidated the arguments under one heading.
[5]Â  We note Suber has not appealed Judge Barberâ€™s finding that the two actions involved the same parties and sought the same relief.Â  Therefore, it is the law of the case.Â  See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (stating an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robbie McFalls, as Defendant; and Tracy Bowen DBA Bonds by Geynell and Allegheny Casualty Company; Beverly Rowland DBA R&R Bail Bonding and Safety National Casualty Corp.; Anthony W. Barrett DBA Barrett Bail Bonds and Accredited Property and Casualty Insurance; Ricky Hill DBA A Available and Roche Surety and Casualty Company, Inc.; Michael Curlee DBA All Out Bail Bonding and Accredited Property and Casualty Insurance; and Terry R. Dawkins DBA Dawkins Surety Company and Accredited Property and Casualty Insurance as Sureties,
Of whom Terry R. Dawkins DBA Dawkins Surety Company is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-177
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert T. Williams, Sr., of Lexington, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terry R. Dawkins d/b/a Dawkins Surety Company appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order for partial estreatment of an appearance bond entered into on behalf of Robbie McFalls.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
A Spartanburg County grand jury indicted McFalls for armed robbery, receiving stolen goods, and possession with intent to distribute drugs.Â  Dawkins agreed to act as a surety for McFalls in the amount of $50,000.Â  Other parties agreed to act as surety for McFalls in additional amounts totaling $250,000.Â  
The Dawkins bond was executed on January 20, 2003.Â  McFalls was required to appear in court on April 28, 2003, but did not do so.Â  A bench warrant was issued on April 29, 2003.Â  McFalls was apprehended in Florida on July 7, 2003.Â  
Several weeks after McFalls was captured and months after his failure to appear in court, Dawkins filed and served a motion to vacate the $50,000 bond.Â  The motion was filed on July 25, 2003.Â  A circuit court judge entered an order on August 1, 2003, granting Dawkinsâ€™ motion to vacate the bond.Â  
On August 15, 2003, a separate circuit court judge issued an order and rule to show cause to the bonding companies as to why the bond should not be estreated.Â  At a hearing on September 12, 2003, the circuit court orally ruled that $12,000 of Dawkinsâ€™ $50,000 bond should be estreated.Â  The court issued a written order on October 10, 2003.Â  
DISCUSSION
Dawkins contends the trial court abused its discretion by ordering partial estreatment after the bond had been vacated by the earlier order.Â  We disagree.
The primary purpose of requiring a criminal defendant to post bond is to insure his appearance at trial.Â  Ex Parte Polk, 354 S.C. 8, 11, 579 S.E.2d 329, 330 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The surety, as guarantor of a bond, undertakes to assure such appearance at the risk of forfeiting the bond amount.Â  As such, the bond is a contract with the surety guaranteeing the appearance of the criminal defendant, with any penalties for breach of that contract amounting to some monetary value up to the bond amount.Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 283, 423 S.E.2d 139, 140 (1992).Â  
Whether a bond should be remitted in cases where the defendant fails to appear is vested in the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Id. at 283, 423 S.E.2d at 141; Ex Parte Polk, 354 S.C. at 11, 579 S.E.2d at 330.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order will be overturned only upon a finding of abuse of discretion.Â  State v. White, 284 S.C. 69, 325 S.E.2d 64 (1985).
Dawkins argues the circuit court was without authority to estreat a portion of the $50,000 bond because he had been released as a guarantor of McFallsâ€™ appearance by an order entered on August 1, 2003.Â  Such an argument fundamentally misunderstands the nature of the bond and liability for its contractual breach.
We first note there is a question whether Dawkins preserved this issue for appeal.Â  Dawkins presents this argument for the first time on appeal.Â  While Dawkins mentioned the order at the hearing, at no time during that hearing or in any subsequent motion to reconsider did he set forth the argument the court lacked the authority to estreat the bond because it had previously been vacated.Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 121-22, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997) (a contemporaneous and specific objection is required to preserve an issue for appeal).Â  
Assuming Dawkins did preserve the issue for appeal, we are not persuaded by his argument, because by the time the bond was vacated, liability on it had already attached.
A bond is a contract guaranteeing the appearance of the defendant.Â  The failure to comply with the bond and appear for court creates a breach of that contract.Â  â€œUnder South Carolina law, when the terms of the bond are breached, the bond is estreated[.]â€Â  Boatwright, 310 S.C. at 286, 423 S.E.2d at 142 (Toal, J., dissenting).Â  Thus, the moment McFalls failed to appear when required, Dawkins was in breach of the bond contract and answerable for any penalty to be determined by the court.Â  
Dawkinsâ€™ argument is without merit because the breach occurred several months before the bond was vacated.Â  Since Dawkinsâ€™ liability to the State accrued at the point McFalls failed to appear for court, the bond may be estreated.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable issues that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss this appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jill Ann Bailey Boone and Paul Boone,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jerry D. Bailey and Tyra C. Bailey,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-186
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 11, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
David D. Armstrong, of Greenville, for Appellants. 
Jill Bailey Boone and Paul Boone, Pro Se, Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from a dispute between Jerry and Tyra Bailey and Jill and Paul Boone over the custody of children born during the marriage of Jerry Bailey and Jill Boone.Â  The Baileys appeal the family courtâ€™s decision to leave custody with the Boones.Â  We affirm as modified.[1] Â 
FACTS
Jerry Bailey and Jill Boone, whose marriage was terminated by a divorce order entered on March 5, 1998, have three minor children.Â  Pursuant to the divorce decree, Jill maintained custody of the children while Jerry received visitation rights.Â  
The Boones filed an action in family court seeking to place further restrictions on the Baileysâ€™ visitation rights.Â  The Baileys counterclaimed, seeking to revoke the Boonesâ€™ custodial rights, claiming they created a detrimental educational environment in the way they chose to home school the children.Â  
To support their claim, the Baileys contacted a licensed clinical psychologist who opined the Boones were not providing adequate educational or social opportunities for the children.Â  Further, the psychologist stated Jill had transferred her negative feelings about Jerry to the children, who were now exhibiting negative thoughts about him.Â  
On cross-examination, the psychologist admitted the majority of her information about the Boones came from Jerry and the Guardian ad Litem, not from direct interaction with Jill.Â  She also admitted to a lack of personal knowledge about the home schooling organization the Boones belonged to.Â  Further, she admitted to concerns about the Baileys as well as the Boones.Â  
The Guardianâ€™s report noted that each parent cared deeply for the children and wanted the best for them.Â  The Guardianâ€™s first recommendation was to leave the children in the custody of the Boones due to the upheaval a change in custody would cause.Â  However, a second report indicated any trauma over a change was outweighed by the benefits the children would receive by way of educational and social opportunities with the Baileys.Â  
Jill testified she home-schooled her children and met all guidelines for home schooling as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-65-47 (Supp. 2003).Â  She admitted the children showed some learning difficulties with certain subjects, but asserted they were close to their appropriate grade level.Â  Additional testimony indicated the children engaged in social and educational opportunities with other children through home school co-ops wherein parents brought their children together to be around other home-schooled children.Â  The children were also found to be active in youth sports programs and participants with their family in church activities.Â  
The family court declined to change the custodial arrangement.Â  It did, however, order the Boones to select a different, more stringent standard for home schooling the children.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court may find facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence in a case originating in family court.Â  Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 388, 597 S.E.2d 840, 842 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not relieve an appellant from the burden of convincing this court that the lower court erred.Â  Brown v. Brown, 362 S.C. 85, 89-90, 606 S.E.2d 785, 787 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Further, such a broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, especially in light of the knowledge that a trial judge is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of a witness through personal observation.Â  Roberson, 359 S.C. at 388, 597 S.E.2d at 842.Â  The inability of an appellate court to perform such observations necessitates we give great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings in cases involving the welfare and best interests of children.Â  See Brown, 362 S.C. at 89, 606 S.E.2d at 787.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Custody
The Baileysâ€™ principal contention is the family court failed to properly consider the testimony of the witnesses and thus erred in denying their motion for a change of custody.Â  We are not persuaded by this argument.
The paramount and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interests of the children.Â  Brown, 362 S.C. at 90, 606 S.E.2d at 788.Â  Custody decisions are normally matters left to the discretion of the trial court.Â  Id.
In situations where a change in custody is sought, the non-custodial parent bears the burden of showing changed circumstances occurring subsequent to the entry of the custody order.Â  Henggeler v. Hanson, 333 S.C. 598, 602, 510 S.E.2d 722, 725 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œA change in circumstances justifying a change in the custody of a child simply means that sufficient facts have been shown to warrant the conclusion that the best interests of the child will be served by the change.â€Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892-93 (1979).
The primary reason for the request for the change of custody was the perceived educational and social shortcomings resulting from the Boonesâ€™ home schooling of the children.Â  Both the Guardian and the psychologist testified to their belief the children would be presented with more social and cultural events with the Baileys.Â  However, both noted much of the information they received was through communications with Jerry.Â  
Jill testified to the cultural, social, and education opportunities her children were exposed to.Â  She also testified regarding their educational abilities and achievements.Â  
The family courtâ€™s order demonstrates a carefully considered opinion based on the testimony.Â  Although neither parent is perfect, the evidence indicates that neither is grossly insufficient.Â  Jill was thought by the psychologist to have failed to foster her childrenâ€™s relationship with their father.Â  Yet, the psychologist noted Jerry had disciplinary issues with the children.Â  In sum, each sought to provide what they felt best for their children, although each often failed to overcome the acrimony between themselves that is often present in such situations.Â  
The Guardianâ€™s reports were full of such tensions, with the first report recommending the present custody situation remain the same, while a subsequent report suggested it change.Â  From such evidence, the court could have concluded not enough evidence was presented by Jerry to order the change of custody.Â  As the family court noted, both parties have had changes in circumstances; however, the court is not convinced the changes warrant a change of custody. 
While the Baileys presented evidence regarding problems with the welfare of the children and the perceived need to alter the custody arrangement, there was also evidence indicating the children were doing well with the Boones and had problems when at the Baileysâ€™ household.Â  Based on our own view of the evidence, we cannot say the family court erred in concluding there are insufficient changes of circumstances to warrant a change of custody.
II.Â  Home School Choice
To combat possible perceived shortcomings in the childrenâ€™s home school environment, the family court required Jill to select either Option 1 or Option 2 of Section 59-65-47 of the South Carolina Code.Â  The Baileys argue this provision of the order is â€œambiguous and/or unclear,â€ because there is only one option provided in this specific section and we must therefore reverse.Â  We disagree.
The intent of the family court is readily discernible.Â  We may therefore modify what we determine to be a scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  
Home schooling is governed by sections 59-65-40, -45, and -47 of the South Carolina Code.Â  The three sections contain Options 1, 2, and 3, respectively, of the various disciplines allowed for home schooling.Â  Option 1 requires mandatory annual testing.Â  Option 2 requires instruction be conducted under the auspices of the South Carolina Association of Independent Home Schools, and Option 3 only requires the parent to be a member of an approved home school association with no fewer than fifty members.Â  Option 1 is considered the most stringent of the three, and Option 3 to be the least stringent.Â  
At the time of the hearing, Jill home-schooled the children under Option 3.Â  If the family court wished her to continue to home-school the children under section 59-65-47, there would be no need to give her the choice of selecting Option 1 or Option 2.Â  This fact, coupled with evidence before the family court that the children were not performing at adequate academic levels, evidences the family courtâ€™s clear intent to require more stringent oversight of the childrenâ€™s education to assure they have greater academic progress.Â  Option 1 and Option 2 in the order clearly reflect the family courtâ€™s desire, a desire with which we agree in light of the record, for Jill to select from the home schooling options in either sections 59-65-40 and -45, not -47 as the order indicates.
CONCLUSION
It is evident from the record and order that the family court considered all evidence in denying the motion to change custody.Â  The court did not abuse its discretion in retaining the existing custody arrangement.Â  Further, the courtâ€™s clear intention was to provide for greater oversight of the childrenâ€™s academic well-being by mandating Jill choose between the home schooling options under 59-65-40 or -45. 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.Â  
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Tara Dawn Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Keith Bradley Graham appeals his murder conviction, arguing he was entitled to a directed verdict because no credible evidence supported a finding of murder rather than voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594, 606 S.E.2d 475, 4778 (2004) (holding on motion for directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not with its weight); State v. Ham, 268 S.C. 340, 342, 233 S.E.2d 698, 698 (1977) (â€œWhere the determination of guilt is dependent upon the credibility of the witnesses, a motion for a directed verdict is properly refused.â€); State v. Scott, 330 S.C. 125, 131 n.4, 497 S.E.2d 735, 738 n.4 (Ct.App.1998) (holding issues of witness credibility are solely for the jury, not the appellate court); State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001) (holding on review of the denial of a directed verdict motion, the appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State and if there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence tending to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, the court must hold the case was properly submitted to the jury); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-10 (2003) (defining murder as â€œthe killing of any person with malice aforethought, either express or impliedâ€); Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, ___, 607 S.E.2d 82, 85 (2005) (â€œIn a murder prosecution, malice may be implied if the defendant uses a deadly weapon.â€); State v. Campbell, 287 S.C. 377, 379, 339 S.E.2d 109, 109 (1985) (defining a deadly weapon as any article, substance, or instrument likely to cause death or great bodily harm).Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Troy Alexander Zeigler,       
        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-188
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert D. Robbins, of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â Troy Alexander Zeigler appeals from his conviction for murder.Â  He argues the trial court erred in (1) denying his motion for a directed verdict; (2) giving an inadequate jury charge on mere presence; and (3) failing to take sworn juror testimony and denying Troyâ€™s motion for a new trial based on allegations of juror misconduct.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Gregory McDonald, also know as Boobie, was murdered on January 19, 2001, near a trailer on Land Fill Road in Orangeburg County.Â  On the night of the murder, McDonald traveled to the trailer with Larry Zeigler, George Zeigler, and Barry Collier.Â  Troy Zeigler, his cousin Antwan Zeigler, James Hallman, Germaine Eric Hallman, and Kenneth Kirk Thomas were already inside the trailer when McDonald arrived.
According to Collier, when he entered the trailer, Antwan looked at him as if Collier had â€œdone something bad.â€Â  Because Antwan and Troy were whispering to each other and staring at him, Collier began to feel uncomfortable and decided to exit the trailer.Â  Antwan and Troy attempted to prevent Collier from leaving.Â  Antwan and Troy followed Collier outside.Â  Collier stated he â€œfelt unsafe.â€Â  At that point, Antwan and Troy threw â€œone or twoâ€ beer bottles at Collier.Â  Collier jumped in his vehicle and drove away.
Kenneth Kirk Thomas testified Antwan entered the trailer and â€œtold Boobie he was the police,â€ meaning McDonald was working for the police as a confidential informant.Â  Troy, Antwan, and the Hallmans surrounded McDonald.Â  George Zeigler, Troy and Antwanâ€™s cousin, declared Antwan â€œtold [McDonald] he had to leaveâ€ and that Antwan and McDonald â€œgot into an argument.â€Â  Thomas observed Antwan throw a beer bottle at McDonald.Â  Larry Zeigler, Troyâ€™s brother and Antwanâ€™s cousin, saw Troy and Eric Hallman hit McDonald.Â  George testified he â€œthought that [Antwan] . . . thr[e]w a punch.â€Â  When McDonald attempted to leave, Troy and the Hallmans threw bottles at him.Â  McDonald ran out of the trailer onto Land Fill Road.Â  Troy, Antwan, and the Hallmans followed McDonald.
Approximately ten to fifteen minutes later, Antwan, Troy and the Hallmans had not returned.Â  Thomas, Larry Zeigler, and George Zeigler decided to leave.Â  As the men were leaving the trailer, Thomas saw Antwan and Troy walking back up the dirt road toward the trailer from about twenty feet away.Â  When Thomas, Larry Zeigler, and George Zeigler reached â€œthe end of the road,â€ they noticed McDonaldâ€™s body lying facedown on the side of the road.Â  McDonald was not moving.Â  George asked Thomas to stop the car so they could help McDonald.Â  Thomas refused to help and instructed George: â€œDonâ€™t get yourself in nothing.â€
Thomas, Larry Zeigler, and George Zeigler drove to the Zeiglersâ€™ grandmotherâ€™s house.Â  Antwan and Troy arrived at the home after the others.Â  Thomas testified Troy said: â€œI kicked that nigger to death.â€Â  Antwan responded: â€œHe deserved it.â€Â  Thomas noted Troy was walking with a limp and that he thought Troyâ€™s toe was swollen.
The police, acting on a tip, located McDonaldâ€™s body in a ditch near the trailer on Land Fill Road.Â  Dr. Janice Ross, a forensic pathologist, performed the autopsy on McDonald.Â  McDonald had suffered injuries to his eyeballs and both sides of his head, had bruising under the scalp, and bleeding around the brain.Â  Dr. Ross opined McDonald died from â€œbleeding around the brain . . . due to a beating.â€Â  McDonald died â€œwithin minutesâ€ from this severe beating.Â  Dr. Ross testified the type of injuries sustained by McDonald allowed her to discount an assertion that the injuries were caused by McDonald falling down or being struck by a car.Â  Dr. Ross concluded McDonaldâ€™s injuries were a result of â€œblows delivered by someone else.â€ Â She stated the injuries were consistent with â€œwhat [sheâ€™s] seen caused by fists.â€Â  The Solicitor asked Dr. Ross: â€œWould [McDonaldâ€™s injuries] also have been consistent with him being kicked?â€Â  Dr. Ross answered: â€œIt could.â€
Antwan and Troy were indicted for the murder of McDonald.Â  The case proceeded to trial.Â  At the close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, counsel for Antwan moved for a directed verdict, claiming there was â€œabsolutely no evidence to connect either of these defendants with the murder of Mr. McDonald.â€Â  Troyâ€™s attorney adopted Antwanâ€™s lawyerâ€™s argument.Â  The State argued the evidence showed â€œAntwan Zeigler started an altercation in the trailer, hit the deceased, threw a bottle at him, and chased him out of the trailer,â€ along with Troy Zeigler.Â  The trial court denied the motion, finding â€œthe fact that they left right after the victim did, came back without him, very shortly thereafter the body was seen, and weâ€™ve got . . . statements that . . . one of them kicked him and the other one said he deserved it, would be strong enough circumstantial evidence to make it a jury case.â€
The jury found both Troy and Antwan guilty of murder.Â  They were each sentenced to forty-five years.
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in denying Troyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court give a proper and correct instruction on mere presence?
III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in refusing to take sworn juror testimony and denying Troyâ€™s motion for a new trial based on allegations of juror misconduct?

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  DIRECTED VERDICT
Troy contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict because â€œthere was not any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence that [Troy] killed [McDonald].â€Â  Troy maintains his mere presence at the scene was insufficient to prove his guilt in the murder.Â  He asserts the â€œevidence against [him] only raised a suspicion of his guilt, and he was convicted based on that suspicion.â€Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Standard of Review
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004); State v. Crawford, Op. No. 3933 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Jan. 31, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 68); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 607 S.E.2d 82 (2005); State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 606 S.E.2d 475 (2004); State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 584 S.E.2d 138 (Ct. App. 2003).
If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593-94, 606 S.E.2d at 478; State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 267 (2002); State v. Follin, 352 S.C. 235, 573 S.E.2d 812 (Ct. App. 2002); see also State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 598 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting judge should deny motion for directed verdict if there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove accusedâ€™s guilt, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced).Â  When a motion for a directed verdict is made in a criminal case in which the State relies exclusively on circumstantial evidence, the trial judge is required to submit the case to the jury if there is any substantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 562 S.E.2d 313 (2002); State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 555 S.E.2d 402 (2001); Al-Amin, 353 S.C. at 411, 578 S.E.2d at 35; see also State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000) (stating trial court has duty to submit case to jury where evidence is circumstantial, if there is substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove guilt of accused or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced).Â  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593, 606 S.E.2d at 478; Horton, 359 S.C. at 563, 598 S.E.2d at 284; State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 580 S.E.2d 159 (Ct. App. 2003). 
The trial judge should grant a directed verdict when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 605 S.E.2d 529 (2004); State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 322 S.E.2d 450 (1984).Â  â€œSuspicionâ€ implies a belief or opinion as to guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to proof.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478; State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 541 S.E.2d 254 (2001).Â  However, a trial judge is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478; State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 196, 470 S.E.2d 851 (1996).
The appellate court may reverse the trial judgeâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).
B.Â  Definitional Analysis of Murder
South Carolina law defines murder as â€œthe killing of any person with malice aforethought, either express or implied.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-10 (2003); Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 607 S.E.2d 82 (2005).Â  Malice is the wrongful intent to injure another and indicates a wicked or depraved spirit intent on doing wrong.Â  State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998).
Any person who is present at a homicide, aiding and abetting, is guilty of the homicide as a principal, even though another does the killing.Â  State v. Crowe, 258 S.C. 258, 188 S.E.2d 379 (1972); State v. Griggs, 184 S.C. 304, 192 S.E. 360 (1937).Â  Mere presence at the scene of a crime is insufficient to convict one as a principal on the theory of aiding and abetting.Â  State v. Johnson, 291 S.C. 127, 352 S.E.2d 480 (1987); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 562 S.E.2d 320 (Ct. App. 2002).
Troy relies on State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000), arguing â€œ[t]here is less evidence against the two appellants in this case than there was against the defendantâ€ in Martin.Â  This reliance is misplaced as Martin is distinguishable from the case at bar.
In Martin, the supreme court found the trial court erred in failing to grant the defendantâ€™s motion for directed verdict because there was a total lack of evidence, either direct or circumstantial, linking the defendants to the murder.Â  In that case, the State was unable to establish a time of death of the victim, lacked any witnesses identifying the defendants at the scene of the crime at the time of the murder, and had no evidence of the defendants being in the victimâ€™s apartment any time after the victim was last seen.Â  The Martin court inculcated:

In this case, the State failed to meet the â€œany substantial evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Most significantly, the Stateâ€™s evidence failed to place either defendant inside the apartment.Â  The Solicitor himself summed up the Stateâ€™s failure of proof by confessing to the trial judge â€œwe donâ€™t know which person actually held [Victimâ€™s] head in that pan of waterâ€ and â€œYour Honor, the whole point is we donâ€™t know if they acted in concert.â€Â  Put another way, unlike the usual accomplice liability case or aiding and abetting situation, here the State had no proof that either defendant held Victimâ€™s head under water and the State had no proof that the defendants were working together to bring about the Victimâ€™s death.
Taken in a light most favorable to its position, the State has shown that a car resembling the one in possession of the Defendant was parked at the Victimâ€™s apartment complex the night the murder was committed.Â  There is no evidence (such as a license tag number) that the black car was actuallyÂ  [defendantâ€™s girlfriendâ€™s] black mustang.Â  The State also presented no evidence that both defendants arrived at the apartment complex in that car or that either defendant entered Victimâ€™s apartment.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence establishing the death occurred during the time the black car was in front of the building.
This case is similar to State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 322 S.E.2d 450 (1984), in which this Court reversed the denial of a directed verdict in a murder conviction.Â  In Schrock, the State presented evidence the defendant was in the area of the murders and that footprints at the scene of the crime were similar to footprints found in the area in which Schrock admitted he had been walking.Â  In this case, the black car seen at the apartment is not identified as [the defendantâ€™s girlfriendâ€™s] car.Â  Like the footprints in Schrock, the possibility that it was the same car, without any other evidence placing the defendants at the scene, is not enough evidence to place Defendant inside Victimâ€™s apartment.

Martin, 340 S.C. at 602-03, 533 S.E.2d at 574-75.Â  In contrariety to the present case, there was virtually no evidence linking the defendants in Martin to the drowning death of the victim.
C.Â  Evidentiary Record
In the instant case, the record provides substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove Troyâ€™s guilt.Â  Viewed in the light most favorable to the State, there was substantial circumstantial evidence to submit the murder charge to the jury.Â  Antwan accused McDonald of working for the police and told him he had to leave the trailer.Â  Antwan and McDonald then â€œgot into an argument.â€Â  Thomas saw Antwan throw a beer bottle at McDonald.Â  Larry Zeigler observed Troy and Eric Hallman hit McDonald.Â  George Zeigler stated he â€œthought that [Antwan] . . . thr[e]w a punch.â€Â  When McDonald attempted to leave, Troy and the Hallmans threw bottles at him.Â  McDonald ran out of the trailer onto Land Fill Road.Â  Troy, Antwan, and the Hallmans pursued McDonald.Â  Approximately ten to fifteen minutes later, when Thomas, Larry Zeigler, and George Zeigler decided to leave the trailer, Antwan, Troy and the Hallmans had not returned.Â  As the three men left the trailer, Thomas noticed Antwan and Troy walking back up the dirt road toward the trailer from about twenty feet away.Â  At â€œthe end of the road,â€ Thomas, Larry Zeigler, and George Zeigler observed McDonaldâ€™s body lying motionless facedown on the side of the road.Â  Importantly, there was a specific window of about ten to fifteen minutes from the time (1) McDonald ran out of the trailer; (2) he was chased by Troy and Antwan; (3) he suffered a severe beating; (4) Thomas saw Antwan and Troy walking back up the dirt road toward the trailer; and (5) McDonald was seen lying motionless on the side of the road.Â  The pathologist confirmed McDonald died â€œwithin minutesâ€ from bleeding around the brain due to a beating.Â  Later that night, at the Zeiglersâ€™ grandmotherâ€™s house, Troy informed Thomas: â€œI kicked that nigger to death.â€Â  Antwan then stated: â€œHe deserved it.â€Â  Thomas noted Troy was limping and that he thought Troy had a swollen toe.
The trial judge did not err in denying Troyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the charge of murder.
II.Â  JURY CHARGE
Troy asserts the trial court â€œerred by refusing to give a proper mere presence charge.â€Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Generally, the trial judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 594 S.E.2d 462 (2004); State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002); see also State v. Buckner, 341 S.C. 241, 534 S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding jury charge is proper if, as a whole, it is free from error and reflects current and correct law of South Carolina).Â  In reviewing jury charges for error, we must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 577 S.E.2d 460 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If, as a whole, the charges are reasonably free from error, isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.Â  State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 405 S.E.2d 377 (1991); State v. Jackson, 297 S.C. 523, 377 S.E.2d 570 (1989).
A jury charge is correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately covers the law.Â  In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 551 S.E.2d 235 (2001); State v. Johnson, 315 S.C. 485, 445 S.E.2d 637 (1994); see also State v. Burton, 302 S.C. 494, 397 S.E.2d 90 (1990) (charge is sufficient if, when considered as a whole, it covers law applicable to case).Â  The substance of the law is what must be charged to the jury, not any particular verbiage.Â  Burkhart, 350 S.C. at 261, 565 S.E.2d at 303; State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 446 S.E.2d 411 (1994); Adkins, 353 S.C. at 318-19, 577 S.E.2d at 464.
A jury charge which is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  State v. Foust, 325 S.C. 12, 479 S.E.2d 50 (1996); State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 440 S.E.2d 869 (1994).Â  To warrant reversal, a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721 (2000); Adkins, 353 S.C. at 319, 577 S.E.2d at 464.
As an initial matter, Troyâ€™s argument regarding the sufficiency of the mere presence charge may not be preserved for appellate review.Â  Troyâ€™s counsel did not specifically join in Antwanâ€™s objection to the jury charge.Â  An issue is not preserved for review where the appellant failed to object at trial or join in his co-defendantâ€™s objection.Â  See State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 481 S.E.2d 118 (1997); State v. Carriker, 269 S.C. 553, 238 S.E.2d 678 (1977).
Even if the issue was preserved at trial, the mere presence charge was sufficient.Â  To be guilty as an aider or abettor, the participant must have knowledge of the principalâ€™s criminal conduct.Â  State v. Leonard, 292 S.C. 133, 355 S.E.2d 270 (1987).Â  Mere presence at the scene is not sufficient to establish guilt as an aider or abettor.Â  Id. at 137, 355 S.E.2d at 272; State v. Johnson, 291 S.C. 127, 352 S.E.2d 480 (1987); State v. Green, 261 S.C. 366, 200 S.E.2d 74 (1973).
The trial court gave the following jury instruction in regard to mere presence:

The mere knowledge that another person is going to commit a crime, even if the defendant is present when the crime is committed is not sufficient to convict the defendant as a principal.Â  Guilt is shown by active or constructive presence at the scene, and the State must prove beyond a reasonable doubt by competent evidence the theory of the hand of one is the hand of all.Â  A principal in a crime is one who either actually commits the crime or who is present, aiding, abetting or assisting in the commission of the crime.Â  When a person does an act in the presence of and with the assistance of another, the act is done by both.Â  Where two or more acting with a common plan or intent [are] present at the commission of a crime, it does not matter who actually commits the crime, all are guilty.Â  The hand of one is the hand of all.Â  Present means to be sufficiently near to aid and abet and assist in the commission of the crime.Â  Intent is also a necessary element, for there must have been a common design or intent to commit the crime, and the crime must have been committed pursuant to that plan, with the person aiding and abetting by some overt act. 

The charge in the case sub judice adequately apprises the jury as to the law regarding mere presence.Â  The charge contains the correct definition for mere presence and adequately covers the law.
Additionally, Troy claims the charge was not sufficient because it did not track the jury instruction given in State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998).Â  We find this argument to be without merit.Â  The substance of the law is what must be charged to the jury, not any particular verbiage.Â  See Burkhart, 350 S.C. at 261, 565 S.E.2d at 303.Â  Because the trial judge adequately charged the jury as to the law of mere presence, we need not look to the particular verbiage used in giving the instruction.
III.Â  JUROR MISCONDUCT
Troy alleges the trial court erred in finding he failed to present any evidence regarding juror misconduct that would warrant sworn juror testimony or a new trial.Â  We disagree.
On appeal, the denial of a new trial motion will be disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Kelly, 331 S.C. 132, 502 S.E.2d 99 (1998); State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 447 S.E.2d 175 (1993).Â  A denial of a new trial based on alleged jury misconduct is reviewed for an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Covington, 343 S.C. 157, 539 S.E.2d 67 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The trial court has broad discretion in assessing allegations of juror misconduct.Â  Kelly, 331 S.C. at 141, 502 S.E.2d at 104.Â  Unless the misconduct affects the juryâ€™s impartiality, it is not such misconduct as will affect the verdict.Â  State v. Grovenstein, 335 S.C. 347, 517 S.E.2d 216 (1999); Kelly, 331 S.C. at 141, 502 S.E.2d at 104.
The general test for evaluating alleged juror misconduct is whether there in fact was misconduct and, if so, whether any harm resulted to the defendant as a consequence.Â  State v. Smith, 338 S.C. 66, 525 S.E.2d 263 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Where a defendant seeks a new trial on the basis of juror misconduct, he is required to prove both the alleged misconduct and the resulting prejudice.Â  State v. Galbreath, 359 S.C. 398, 597 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 2004); see also State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999) (a defendant must demonstrate prejudice from jury misconduct in order to be entitled to a new trial).Â  Misconduct of a juror is a fact to be determined by the trial judge from the circumstances of each case.Â  Smith, 338 S.C. at 71, 525 S.E.2d at 266.
In a criminal prosecution, the conduct of the jurors should be free from all extraneous or improper influences.Â  Kelly, 331 S.C. at 141, 502 S.E.2d at 104; see also State v. Salters, 273 S.C. 501, 257 S.E.2d 502 (1979) (finding a defendant in a criminal prosecution is constitutionally guaranteed a fair trial by an impartial jury and, in order to fully safeguard this basic protection, it is required that the jury render its verdict free from outside influences).
Initially, the trial judge must make a factual determination as to whether juror misconduct has occurred.Â  See Smith, 338 S.C. at 71, 525 S.E.2d at 266; see also Aldret, 333 S.C. at 315, 509 S.E.2d at 815 (holding where affidavits supporting juror misconduct are credible, the trial court must conduct an evidentiary hearing to determine if misconduct occurred).Â  â€œOnly if the trial court finds a juror is guilty of misconduct must the judge determine whether the misconduct affected the verdict, warranting a new trial.â€Â  Covington, 343 S.C. at 164, 539 S.E.2d at 70.
As a general rule, juror testimony is inadmissible to impeach a jury verdict.Â  State v. Hunter, 320 S.C. 85, 463 S.E.2d 314 (1995).Â  Normally, courts should not intrude into the privacy of the jury room to scrutinize how jurors reached their verdict.Â  Id.Â  Traditionally, a jurorâ€™s testimony was not admissible to prove either his own misconduct or the misconduct of other jurors.Â  Galbreath, 359 S.C. at 405, 597 S.E.2d at 848.Â  However, Rule 606(b), SCRE, altered this common law rule, and now, juror testimony regarding external prejudicial information or improper outside influence is allowed.Â  Rule 606(b) provides:

Upon an inquiry into the validity of a verdict or indictment, a juror may not testify as to any matter or statement occurring during the course of the juryâ€™s deliberations or to the effect of anything upon that or any other jurorâ€™s mind or emotions as influencing the juror to assent to or dissent from the verdict or indictment or concerning the jurorâ€™s mental processes in connection therewith, except that a juror may testify on the question whether extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the juryâ€™s attention or whether any outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror.Â  Nor may a jurorâ€™s affidavit or evidence of any statement by the juror concerning a matter about which the juror would be precluded from testifying be received for these purposes.

Thus, juror testimony or affidavits are admissible to prove an allegation of extraneous information or influence.Â  See State v. Franklin, 341 S.C. 555, 534 S.E.2d 716 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Aldret, 333 S.C. at 310, 509 S.E.2d at 812 (juror testimony or affidavits are generally admissible in the case of an extraneous influence); Hunter, 320 S.C. at 88, 463 S.E.2d at 316 (juror testimony may normally be used when an extraneous influence is alleged).Â  External influence on a jury involves situations where jurors receive information during deliberations from some outside source.Â  Galbreath, 359 S.C. at 405, 597 S.E.2d at 848.Â  The judge noted that no extraneous influence was present in the case at bar.Â  In addition, Troy concedes the misconduct alleged in this case is internal juror misconduct.
If the alleged misconduct is internal, as we have in this matter, courts are more strict.Â  Hunter, 320 S.C. at 88, 463 S.E.2d at 316.Â  Internal influences involve information coming from the jurors themselves.Â  Galbreath, 359 S.C. at 406, 597 S.E.2d at 849.Â  Until 1995, the prohibition against juror testimony regarding allegations of internal jury misconduct remained intact.Â  In State v. Hunter, our supreme court carved out an exception to this rule, holding that juror testimony is competent in cases involving internal misconduct where necessary to ensure due process, i.e., fundamental fairness.Â  Id.; see also Aldret, 333 S.C. at 312, 509 S.E.2d at 813 (finding premature jury deliberations may affect fundamental fairness of a trial such that the trial court may inquire into such allegations and may consider juror affidavits in support of such allegations); Ex Parte Greenville News, 326 S.C. 1, 482 S.E.2d 556 (1997) (stating juror testimony regarding internal misconduct is generally inadmissible to impeach a verdict except when necessary to ensure fundamental fairness); Hunter, 320 S.C. at 88, 463 S.E.2d at 316 (noting jurorâ€™s testimony was properly considered as basis for impeaching jury verdict, where juror claimed racial prejudice played role in determining defendantâ€™s guilt).Â  In State v. Franklin, the court of appeals held:

[W]e emphasize that the exception to the general rule against review of internal jury deliberations carved out in Hunter is a narrow one, limited by our supreme court to those few situations which implicate due process raising a question of fundamental fairness. . . . But the integrity of the jury system is jeopardized any time a court finds it necessary to intrude into the internal deliberation process.Â  Such an inquiry should not be lightly made.

Franklin, 341 S.C. at 562, 534 S.E.2d at 720.
After a three-day trial, the judge submitted the case to the jury.Â  On the second morning of deliberations, the jury sent the trial court a note, asking: â€œIs it a possibility that the defendants go under oath and tell their side of the story?â€Â  After a brief discussion with counsel for Antwan and Troy Zeigler, the trial court instructed: â€œ[W]e cannot receive new evidence at this time.Â  Please remember that you should not consider the fact that defendants did not testify.â€Â  Counsel for Antwan and Troy concurred in the instruction.Â  The jury resumed deliberations and returned a guilty verdict as to both defendants.Â  Attorneys for Antwan and Troy moved for a new trial, arguing the jury â€œmade it clear that they were considering things that [the trial court] specifically instructed them not to consider when they sent out the note saying that they wanted testimony from the defendants.Â  Clearly, they were considering whether the defendants testified or not.â€Â  The trial court denied the motion.
Lawyers for both Antwan and Troy filed a joint motion to impeach the verdict, take sworn testimony of jurors, and for a new trial.Â  At the hearing, it was argued that the jurors â€œwere basing their verdict, many of them, on the fact that the Zeiglers did not testify.â€Â  The trial court considered the statements taken from the jurors by investigators hired by the Zeiglers, even though the statements were not sworn affidavits.Â  The court ruled: â€œI just donâ€™t see any evidence that this jury made its decision based on an improper consideration of the defendants failing to testify.â€
Initially, we note that at the end of the trial the judge gave a detailed charge to the jury instructing them not to consider the fact that the defendants did not testify:

Because the defendant, ladies and gentlemen, in a criminal trial, is presumed to be innocent, as I told you, the law never imposes upon a defendant the burden or the duty of testifying, of calling any witnesses, or producing any evidence.Â  The defendant in a criminal trial has the absolute right under the Constitution of the United States and the State of South Carolina not to take the witness stand and testify.Â  The exercise by a defendant of this right not to testify or present any evidence must not be considered by you in any way against the defendant, and should play no role whatsoever in your discussions or your deliberations.Â  No inference of any kind may be drawn from the defendantâ€™s exercise of his constitutional right not to testify or present other evidence.

The judge reiterated this principle in a charge after receipt of the jury note.
Investigators for Antwan and Troy contacted eight jurors.Â  Seven of the jurors provided statements, not affidavits, to the investigators.Â  Three of the jurors expressed very clearly they based their decision in the case on the evidence presented at trial only.Â  Although the other four jurors who provided statements all professed they thought the defendants should have testified, none of the jurors stated that was the reason they found the defendants guilty.Â  Each of the four jurors declared their decision was based upon the evidence presented by the State at trial.Â  The statements given by the four jurors support the trial courtâ€™s finding that further investigation was not merited.
Troy relies on State v. Bryant, 354 S.C. 390, 581 S.E.2d 157 (2003), for the proposition that the judge â€œshould have heard the testimony from the jurors as requested in the motion.â€Â  Bryant is distinguishable from the case sub judice.Â  Bryant involved the questioning of jurorsâ€™ family members by Horry County Police detectives before trial in a death penalty setting in a case in which the victim was a Horry County Police Department Officer. Â Thus, unlike the present case, Bryant was an extraneous influence case.
Here, the trial judge considered the statements even though no sworn affidavits of the jurors were introduced at the hearings.Â  The judge noted: â€œ[W]e donâ€™t have any affidavits . . . . Iâ€™m not sure we really have any competent evidence before the court, but Iâ€™m considering what evidence we have as competent evidence, even though there are no affidavits.â€Â  The extant precedent mandates the presentation of affidavits or sworn testimony of jurors.Â  This evidentiary record is devoid of the required showing in a case involving internal juror misconduct.
The trial court did not err in refusing to take sworn juror testimony and denying Troyâ€™s motion for a new trial based on allegations of juror misconduct.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, Troy Zeiglerâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Altore Randolph appeals after pleading guilty to assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and robbery.Â  Randolph argues that he did not receive effective assistance of counsel.Â  His counsel attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating he reviewed the record and concluded Randolphâ€™s appeal was without merit.Â  Randolph filed a pro se response.Â

title: Neal v. Ashleigh Place
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Frankie Neal, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Francesca L. Neal,
Appellant,
v.
Ashleigh Place, Inc., S.C. Department of Juvenile Justice and S.C. Department of Mental Health,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-190
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles B. Ridley, Sr., of Rock Hill, and Mitchell Jerry Williams, of Columbia, for Appellant.
James E. Parham, Jr., of Irmo; James M. Davis, of Columbia; and Terry E. Richardson, Daniel S. Haltiwanger, and J. David Butler, all of Barnwell, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Frankie Neal, as personal representative of the estate of Francesca Neal, appeals from a grant of summary judgment in his wrongful death and survival action against Ashleigh Place, Inc., the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (DMH), and the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
 FACTS
    On June 27, 2002, Nealâ€™s 14-year-old daughter, Francesca Neal, stole a car and was involved in a one-car accident that resulted in her death.Â  Francesca had stolen vehicles on three occasions in the fifteen months prior to her death.Â  
    The first theft occurred on April 12, 2001 when Francesca broke into a neighborâ€™s home and stole her vehicle.Â  As a result, Francesca was admitted to several institutions under the care of DMH and DJJ.Â  After her release, on June 19, 2001, Francesca was placed at the Rock Hill Girls Home until eight days later, when she stole a van from the home and ran away.Â  Francesca was again admitted to several DMH and DJJ facilities.Â  
    On October 1, 2001, Francesca was placed at the Ellen Hines Smith Girls Home in Spartanburg; however, six days later, she ran away from the home.Â  Again, Francesca was placed in various DMH and DJJ facilities until she was discharged into Nealâ€™s care.Â  Francesca was assigned a mentor to help her readjust to family life; however, on May 19, 2002, she stole her mentorâ€™s car keys and took her car without her permission.Â  Francesca was charged with grand larceny auto and sentenced to 90 days in a DJJ facility.Â  
    On June 5, 2002, DJJ and DMH placed Francesca at Ashleigh Place, a charitable organization that serves as an unsecured high management group home for troubled female juveniles.Â  On June 17, 2002, Francesca stole a staff memberâ€™s car keys; however, they were found in her possession before she could steal the car.Â  Francescaâ€™s DJJ probation officer was informed on June 25, 2002 that Francesca had been caught with a staff memberâ€™s keys.Â  She then contacted Francescaâ€™s DMH counselor, who called Ashleigh Place and was assured that the facility could â€œmanage [Francescaâ€™s] threats.â€Â  One of the precautions Ashleigh Place took to prevent Francesca from stealing again was to require her to wear a white outfit that had no pockets so she could be observed.Â  However, just two days later, Francesca left the residence building without permission, broke into the locked Directorâ€™s office, and removed the Directorâ€™s keys from her desk.Â  She then stole the Directorâ€™s vehicle and sped off from the facility at a high rate of speed, estimated at 70 miles per hour.Â  Staff immediately called 911 to report the stolen vehicle.Â  About a quarter of a mile away from the facility, Francesca ran off the road and flipped the vehicle.Â  Francesca was not wearing a seatbelt, was thrown from the vehicle, and was killed as a result.Â  Members of the Ashleigh Place staff drove out to meet the police when they found the overturned vehicle.Â  There were no witnesses to the accident and there was no indication that anyone did anything to prompt Francesca to drive in a dangerous manner.
    On May 15, 2003, Neal brought an action against Respondents for the wrongful death of Francesca, alleging that Ashleigh Place was negligent in failing to prevent Francesca from stealing the vehicle, and DJJ and DMH were grossly negligent in placing Francesca at Ashley Place and in failing to use slight care when they were notified that Francesca had stolen a staff memberâ€™s car keys.Â  Respondents filed motions for summary judgment.Â  After a hearing on February 2, 2004, the trial judge granted Respondentsâ€™ motions, holding that â€œno jury under these facts could determine that [Francesca] did not contribute to her death in a percentage of fault and wrongdoing that exceeded 50%.â€Â  Neal now appeals.Â Â  
     LAW/ANALYSIS
        Neal argues the trial court erred by granting Respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment because issues of a partyâ€™s negligence are a question of fact for a jury in both negligence and comparative negligence scenarios.Â  We disagree.
        Summary judgment is appropriate when it is clear there is no issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the evidence and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 115, 410 S.E.2d 537 at 545.Â  In reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Id. at 114, 410 S.E.2d 537 at 545.Â  
        To establish a cause of action in negligence, Neal must prove three elements: (1) a duty of care owed by Respondents to Francesca; (2) breach of that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage proximately resulting from the breach of duty.Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 422, 529 S.E.2d 710, 712 (2000).Â  
        Neal argues the trial court erred by granting summary judgment to Respondents DJJ and DMH because the evidence was sufficient for a jury to find gross negligence on their part.Â  
        South Carolina Code section 15-78-60(25) (2005) states that a governmental entity is only liable for a loss resulting from the â€œsupervision, protection, control, confinement, or custody of any student, patient, prisoner, inmate, or client of any governmental entityâ€ when the responsibility or duty is exercised in a grossly negligent manner.Â  Our supreme court has defined gross negligence, as applied to a governmental entity, as â€œthe intentional conscious failure to do something which it is incumbent upon one to do or the doing of a thing intentionally that one ought not to do.â€Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  â€œIt is the failure to exercise slight care.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œGross negligence has also been defined as a relative term and means the absence of care that is necessary under the circumstances.â€Â  Id.Â  Â Â 
        Neal claims that DJJ and DMH were grossly negligent in placing Francesca at Ashley Place.Â  It appears that Neal postulates that DJJ and DMH should have placed Francesca in a secure facility; however, the family court order stated she was to be placed in a group home.Â  Furthermore, Ashleigh Place is a high management facility, which is the highest level of security short of confinement in a secure facility, and placing Francesca in a secure facility would have violated the family court order.Â  Neal also claims that DJJ and DMH were grossly negligent in failing to use slight care when they were alerted that Francesca had stolen a staff memberâ€™s car keys; however, when notified of the incident, Francescaâ€™s DJJ probation officer and DMH counselor contacted Ashleigh Place to confirm the facility was aware of Francescaâ€™s history of car theft and was capable of handling Francescaâ€™s threats.Â  
        Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Neal, it cannot be said that DJJ and DMH intentionally failed to do what they were obligated to do, which was to place Francesca in a group home and monitor her progress.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err by granting DJJ and DMHâ€™s motions for summary judgment.
        Neal also argues the trial court erred by granting summary judgment to Respondent Ashleigh Place because the evidence was sufficient for a jury to find simple negligence on its part.Â  
        Neal claims that Ashleigh Place was negligent by taking insufficient precautions to keep Francesca from stealing a staff memberâ€™s keys a second time.Â  However, Ashleigh Place took several precautions to prevent Francesca from obtaining car keys: Ashleigh Place made Francesca wear a suit without pockets and stored the keys in a locked office that Francesca was not permitted to enter.Â  Thus, Ashleigh Place was not negligent in its efforts to prevent Francesca from stealing a car and the trial court did not err by granting Ashleigh Placeâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â Â Â Â Â  
        Furthermore, Neal argues the issue of Respondentsâ€™ negligence is a question of fact for a jury in a comparative negligence scenario.Â  â€œHowever, under South Carolinaâ€™s doctrine of comparative negligence, a plaintiff may only recover damages if his own negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.â€Â  Bloom, 339 S.C. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 712-713.Â  While the issue of a partyâ€™s negligence is generally a question of fact for a jury, in a comparative negligence case, the trial court should â€œdetermine judgment as a matter of law if the sole reasonable inference which may be drawn from the evidence is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.â€Â  Id. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 713.Â  Thus, viewing the facts in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, the court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party would be reasonably possible under the facts.Â  Id. at 423, 529 S.E.2d at 713.
        In this case, the trial judge found that the â€œundisputed facts in this case cause the court to determine as a matter of law that any negligence on the part of the [Respondents] was exceeded by relevant conduct of [Francesca] that was negligent and reckless, at a minimum.â€Â  The court determined that even if Ashleigh Place had a duty to keep Francesca from stealing cars (which it declined to do), the theft of the car alone did not kill her.Â  Despite Ashleigh Placeâ€™s efforts to keep Francesca from acquiring anyoneâ€™s car keys, she broke into a locked office, searched through a desk, took the keys to a car, and stole a vehicle.Â  Considering these facts, the trial court did not err by granting summary judgment to Respondents.
        AFFIRMED.Â Â Â  
        ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Woodall v. Williamson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lillie Woodall, Respondent,
v.
Dorothy Williamson and David Woodall, Personal Representative for the Estate of Nadine Mary Woodall, Defendants,
of whom Dorothy Williamson is, Appellant,
and
David Woodall, Personal Representative for the Estate of Nadine Mary Woodall is,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-191
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chace Damon Campbell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Donald R. McAlister, Jack Griffith, and Susan Cobb Singleton, all of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dorothy Williamson appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order affirming the probate courtâ€™s decision to grant Lillie Woodall an award of $33,912 from Nadine Woodallâ€™s estate as reasonable compensation for personal caregiver services.Â  We affirm.[1] Â 
FACTS
Following the death of Nadine Woodall in January 2001, Lillie Woodall, Nadineâ€™s daughter-in-law, filed a creditorâ€™s claim in the amount of $49,275 against Nadineâ€™s estate, claiming a portion of the estate as payment for personal caregiver services rendered for the nine years prior to Nadineâ€™s death.Â  Nadineâ€™s daughter, Dorothy Williamson, disputed Lillieâ€™s claim, alleging Lillie neither render services nor did Nadine require any services.Â  The probate court appointed David Woodall, son of Nadine and husband of Lillie, as personal representative of the estate.Â  However, because of the possible conflict of interest resulting from Lillieâ€™s claim, the probate court appointed Daniel Pruitt as special administrator to review Lillieâ€™s claim.Â  
Following a hearing, the probate court ordered a partial award to Lillie, â€œgiv[ing] great weight to the evidence resulting from the investigation conducted by the Special Administrator and the medical records.â€Â  Following the probate courtâ€™s denial of Williamsonâ€™s motion for reconsideration, Williamson appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the probate court.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Williamson claims the probate court erred in relying on testimony by Pruitt, who was never sworn under oath.Â  We find this issue was not preserved. 
It is well settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.Â  Holy Loch Distributors, Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000).
When Pruitt took the stand, the probate court told him, â€œIâ€™m not going to administer the oath because youâ€™re an attorney and Officer of the Court with a glowing reputation here.â€Â  At that point, to preserve the issue on appeal, Williamson should have objected to the testimony of Pruitt without his being under oath.Â  No actions were taken in this case to preserve the issue for appellate review; therefore, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â Â  
Williamson also argues the circuit court erred in allowing the attorney for the estate to speak on behalf of the estate and the probate courtâ€™s decision to honor Lillieâ€™s claim.Â  We disagree.
Amy Richmond was the attorney for the estate during the trial in the circuit court.Â  She also represented David Woodall, Lillieâ€™s husband, in his capacity as the personal representative of the estate.Â  Williamson objected to Richmondâ€™s representation of the estate because she thought Richmond was also representing Lillie.Â  The circuit court dealt with Williamsonâ€™s objection by reminding her that Richmond represented the estate, which did not belong to anyone yet, and that she was merely presenting the facts as the probate court deemed them to be.Â  We find the circuit court had sufficient evidence to overrule Williamsonâ€™s objection.Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
