title: Mathias v. Rural Community Insurance Company
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ervin M. Mathias, Jr., and Ervin M. Mathias, III, doing business as T & M Farm, a General Partnership,
Respondents,
v.
Rural Community Insurance Company and Jackie Starnes, individually and doing business as Starnes Insurance Agency,
Defendants,
Of whom Rural Community Insurance Company is the,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-192
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed March 15, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard Ashby Farrier, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
Richard B. Ness, of Bamberg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ervin M. Mathias, Jr. and Ervin M. Mathias, III doing business as T & M Farm, brought several claims against Rural Community Insurance Company (RCIC) and its agent Jackie Starnes, arising out of Starnesâ€™ procurement of Multiple Peril Crop Insurance for T & M.Â  RCIC filed a motion to compel arbitration pursuant to an arbitration clause in the policy.Â  The trial judge denied this motion.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 2000, T & M Farm purchased Multiple Peril Crop Insurance (MPCI) from RCIC through its agent Jackie Starnes.Â  The policy covered T & Mâ€™s crops in Allendale and Hampton counties.Â  As part of procuring the policies, RCIC asked T & M to provide a crop production history for each location.Â  RCIC used this information to determine the amount of insurance T & M could purchase.Â  Although T & M previously produced crops in Allendale County, it did not previously farm in Hampton County.Â  T & M alleges Starnes communicated that production history from other counties could be used to establish the insured production level for Hampton County.Â  Based on Starnesâ€™ assurances, the crop production history for the crops grown in Allendale County was used to determine the crop history calculation for Hampton County.Â  RCIC issued the policies based on this information.Â  
In 2000 and 2001, T & M experienced crop losses and filed claims with RCIC.Â  RCIC paid the claims, but later notified T & M that the indemnifications paid were greater than the amount of insurance T & M was entitled to purchase.Â  RCIC informed T & M that because the policies were issued on erroneous crop production history for the Hampton County crops, it would reduce T & Mâ€™s indemnity amount and T & M was responsible to repay the overpayment on its claims.Â  
T & M brought suit alleging negligence by Starnes for which RCIC is vicariously liable, seeking an accounting as to the amount of overpayments calculated by RCIC, breach of contract and bad faith by RCIC, indemnification, breach of fiduciary duty by Starnes, and negligent misrepresentation by both Starnes and RCIC.[1]Â Â Â  
RCIC filed a motion to compel arbitration and to stay the proceedings based on an arbitration clause in the policy.Â  The RCIC policy, contains the following arbitration clause: 

If you and we fail to agree on any factual determination, the disagreement will be resolved in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association.Â  Failure to agree with any factual determination made by FCIC must be resolved through the FCIC appeal provisions published at 7 CFR part 11. 

The trial judge denied RCICâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination, unless the parties provide otherwise.â€Â 
Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  Both South Carolina and the United States have a policy of favoring arbitration.Â  Id. (citation omitted).Â  However, arbitration is a matter of contract and parties may not be forced to arbitrate claims they have not contractually agreed to arbitrate.Â  Towles v. United HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 37, 524 S.E.2d 839, 843-44 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  An appeal from the denial of a motion to compel arbitration is subject to de novo review.Â  Rich v. Walsh, 357 S.C. 64, 68, 590 S.E.2d 506, 508 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
RCIC initially appealed on two grounds.Â  First, RCIC maintains the trial judge erred in finding that claims brought by T & M were not subject to the arbitration clause in the policy.Â  Second, RCIC argues the South Carolina Arbitration Act did not reverse preempt the Federal Arbitration Act.Â  The trial judge did not rule upon the second issue, and T & M conceded no dispute existed over the application of the Federal Arbitration Act to any arbitable aspect of this cause of action.Â  Therefore, we only address the first issue.Â  
RCIC contends the causes of action brought by T & M are within the scope of the arbitration clause contained in the policy.Â  We disagree. 
â€œTo decide whether an arbitration agreement encompasses a dispute, a court must determine whether the factual allegations underlying the claim are within the scope of the broad arbitration clause, regardless of the label assigned to the claim.â€Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 S.E.2.d at 118.Â  Any doubts concerning the scope of the arbitration clause, should be resolved in favor of arbitration.Â  Id.  
RCIC argues the claims brought by T & M are squarely within the scope of the arbitration clause because they involve a â€œfactual determinationâ€ as set forth in the language of the arbitration clause.Â  RCIC cites several federal district court cases finding factual determinations pursuant to the language in the policy.[2]Â  These cases, however, are distinguishable from the case at bar because each involved a specific factual discrepancy related to coverage under the policies.Â  Although RCIC argues that â€œthe claims of T & M farm are based on a number of factual determinations by RCIC,â€ it fails to show any such determinations.Â  
T & M asserts no factual dispute exists, and we agree.Â  T & M does not dispute RCICâ€™s interpretation of the language in the policy with regard to coverage.Â  T & M does not disagree with the findings of RCICâ€™s audit, which uncovered the use of the incorrect production history data.Â  In addition, T & M does not dispute that incorrect data was used to determine the amount of insurance T & M was allowed to purchase and as a result, the indemnification received by T & M needed to be adjusted.Â  The crux of T & Mâ€™s action is not whether RCIC was incorrect in determining it received an indemnification greater than T & M was allowed to receive, but whether RCIC is vicariously liable for the negligence of its agent.Â  This action relates not to the policy, but to the actions of RCICâ€™s agent in procuring the policy for T & M and RCICâ€™s actions after it discovered the wrong information was utilized.Â  Therefore, we find the causes of action alleged by T & M do not involve a â€œfactual determination.â€Â  Thus, these causes of action lie outside the scope of the arbitration clause in the policy and are not subject to arbitration.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s order denying RCICâ€™s motion to compel arbitration is therefore
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  Jackie Starnes did not appeal from the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Therefore, the current appeal concerns only those claims T & M asserts against RCIC.Â  
[2] See, e.g.,Â  In re 2000 Sugar Beet Crop Ins. Litig., 228 F. Supp. 2d 992 (D. Minn. 2002) (finding denial of coverage to be a factual determination); Ledford Farms, Inc. v. Firemanâ€™s Fund Ins. Co., 184 F. Supp. 2d 1242 (S.D. Fla. 2001) (finding the issue of whether it was practical to replant a crop, as required under the policy, was a factual determination); Nobles v. Rural Cmty. Ins. Servs., 122 F. Supp. 2d 1290 (M.D. Ala. 2000) (finding the issue of whether a portion of the crop had been harvested within the time allowed under the policy to be a factual determination).

title: Robinson v. Robinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cassandra Robinson, Respondent,
v.
Alvin Robinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-193
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 15, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Leon Edward Green, of Aiken, for Appellant.
Vicki Johnson Snelgrove, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the family court.Â  The Husband appeals from the portion of the order regarding the marital debt, the valuation of the marital property, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
The parties married on September 10, 1994.Â  Three children were born into the marriage.Â  In July 2002, Wife brought this action, seeking separate support and maintenance, custody of the coupleâ€™s three minor children, alimony, an equitable property division, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband did not file an answer.Â  At trial, Wifeâ€™s motion to amend to seek a divorce was granted.Â  The family court issued an order denying Wifeâ€™s claim for alimony but granting the divorce, an equitable distribution of marital property, and awarding custody of the children to Wife together with child support.Â  The order further required Husband to contribute to the Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Additionally, the court ordered Husband to be responsible for the 1997 tax obligation. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the court of appeals has jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).  Although this court may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, we are not required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996). Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of his burden to convince this court the family court committed error.  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Tax Debt
Husband argues the family court committed error by failing to include as marital debt the tax liabilities accrued during 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, and 2001.[1]Â  As an initial matter, we note that the challenge in connection with years 1998 through 2001 is not preserved for review.Â  The final order addressed only the 1997 tax liability.Â  Husband did not file a motion to reconsider pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP.[2]Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (where the Husband did not raise issues to the family court at trial or through a motion to amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the issues were not properly before the appellate court for review).
The family court rejected Husbandâ€™s argument that the 1997 tax liability to the Internal Revenue Service was a marital debt subject to equitable apportionment.Â  We agree with Husband that the family court erred in this regard.
â€œMarital propertyâ€ for purposes of the South Carolina Equitable Apportionment of Marital Property Act is defined in section 20-7-473 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) as â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . . .â€Â  In making an equitable apportionment, the family court should consider â€œany other existing debts incurred by the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(13) (Supp. 2004). Debts incurred for marital purposes are subject to equitable distribution.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 103, 545 S.E.2d 531, 539 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œMarital debtâ€ has been defined as debt incurred for the joint benefit of the parties regardless of whether the parties are legally jointly liable for the debt or whether one party is legally individually liable.Â  Thomas v. Thomas, 346 S.C. 20, 27, 550 S.E.2d 580, 584 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â  The 1997 tax liabilityâ€”incurred from Husbandâ€™s 1997 marital earningsâ€”was clearly â€œincurred . . . during the course of the marriage,â€ and the partiesâ€™ unwillingness or inability to ascertain the precise amount of this debt prior to the commencement of marital litigation is of no moment for classification purposes.Â  
In this matter, after identifying and valuing the various items of marital and non-marital propertyâ€”exclusive of the 1997 tax liabilityâ€”the family court apportioned the marital property equally between the parties.Â  The 1997 tax liability was, to be sure, â€œacquiredâ€ during the marriage within the meaning of section 20-7-473, and it is presumptively marital debt. We have reviewed the record and find, as Husband avers, the 1997 tax liability constitutes marital debt and is subject to apportionment. 
The 1997 tax liability is $5,465.98.Â  We modify the equitable division award to reflect an equal apportionment of this additional marital debt.[3]Â  Each party would, therefore, be responsible for $2,732.99, rounded to $2,733.Â  We thus reduce the amount owed to Wife to effect an equal division of the marital estate to $22,905 ($25,638 minus $2,733).Â  Husband shall pay to Wife a minimum of $500 per month until the amount is paid in full.Â Â Â  
II.Â  Valuation of the Marital Property
Husband contends the family court erred in valuing the marital residence and the 1994 Volvo truck.Â  We disagree.
Husband contends the family court erred in valuing the marital residence at $145,000.Â  We disagree.Â  Wife valued the residence at $145,000 and admitted the deed and related documents to support her valuation.Â  The Husband valued the residence at approximately $131,000.Â  The family court, which saw and heard the testimony and evidence presented by both Husband and Wife as to the value of the marital residence, valued the marital residence at $145,000.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the family court establishing this amount as the value for equitable apportionment purposes.
Husband also claims the family court erred in valuing the 1994 Volvo tractor truck.Â  We disagree.Â  Wife presented testimony, admitted without objection, valuing the 1994 Volvo tractor truck at $10,845.Â  The record reflects the husband offered no other valuation of the truck.Â  We find the family court did not abuse its discretion in accepting Wifeâ€™s valuation of the Volvo truck, especially in the absence of a contrary value from Husband.
Husband alleges the family court erred in not including a â€œleaf and six chairs,â€ which are in the possession of Wife, as marital assets.Â  We disagree.Â  Nothing in the record indicates whether Husband made this request at trial, nor does he cite the record to support this claim in his brief.Â Â  Husband offered no testimony as to this specific piece of personal property at the family court hearing, and the family court order does not mention this specific item.Â  Moreover, no Rule 59 motion was filed with the family court addressing this piece of personal property.Â  Therefore, this issue is not properly before this court.Â  See Zaman v. S.C. Bd. of Med. Examâ€™rs, 305 S.C. 281, 285, 408 S.E.2d 213, 215 (1991) (holding this court will not consider any fact not appearing in the record on appeal).Â  Â 
III.Â  Admission of Documents
Husband alleges the family court erred in admitting the income and expense reports from Husbandâ€™s employer into evidence to establish his income.Â  Moreover, Husband argues the family court erred in admitting the deed and related documents associated with the former marital residence.Â  We disagree.
As to the income and expense reports of Husbandâ€™s employer, Rule 7, SCRFC, provides certain documents shall be admissible â€œwithout requiring that the persons or institutions issuing the documents or statements be present in court.â€Â  Rule 7(e) allows admissibility of a â€œwritten statement of an employer showing wages either weekly or monthly for a given period of time and W-2 statement, income tax returns and other reports of like nature.â€Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the admission of the income and expense reports to calculate the income of Husband, as the documents fit comfortably within the parameters of Rule 7(e).
As to the deed and related mortgage documents admitted in evidence over Husbandâ€™s objection, we find no abuse of discretion in their admission.Â  Rule 902 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence allows admission of deed and mortgage documents as self-authenticating documents.Â  The deed and other documents are those documents authorized by law to be recorded in a public office, and therefore, fall within the purview of Rule 902.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 30-9-30 (Supp. 2004); Rule 803(14),
SCRE. 
IV.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the family court abused its discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 563, 490 S.E.2d 271, 272 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The family court, in determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  The family court appropriately considered these factors. 
The family court further noted Husbandâ€™s recalcitrance and lack of good faith.Â  Husband â€œfiled no answer,â€ â€œmade no good faith efforts to negotiate a settlement,â€ â€œwas not truthful on his financial declaration as to his income,â€ and forced â€œWifeâ€™s attorney to go through the efforts of obtaining a foreign subpoena to obtainâ€ his income records.Â  The family court order reflects other similar negative findings concerning Husbandâ€™s lack of good faith in the family court litigation.Â  Husbandâ€™s lack of cooperation throughout the process clearly burdened Wifeâ€™s counsel with considerable efforts that would have otherwise been unnecessary. We find no abuse of discretion in the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.
CONCLUSION
The order of the family court is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Husband did not file an answer.Â  Rule 17(a), SCRFC, provides in part that a non-answering â€œdefendant may be heard at the merits hearing on issues of . . . equitable distribution.â€Â  We need not decide the extent of the privilegeâ€”to be â€œheardâ€â€”available to a non-answering defendant in family court in connection with the equitable distribution of the marital estate, for Husbandâ€™s efforts to classify the purported tax liabilities as marital debt were not challenged at trial.Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP, which is applicable in family court, provides that issues tried with the consent of the parties â€œshall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings.â€ 
[2] Rule 59, SCRCP, is applicable in family court pursuant to Rule 2,
SCRFC.
[3] Although the 1997 tax liability is apportioned between the parties for equitable division purposes, we direct that Husband shall remain solely responsible for this obligation to the taxing authorities.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Mac Babb, Appellant,
        v.
        J. Theron Floyd, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry CountyÂ 
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-195
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled May 19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Mac Babb, pro se Appellant.
        William A. Bryan, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action on a note and guaranty, Mac Babb contests the trial court's order granting J. Theron Floydâ€™s motion for summary judgment. We affirm. [1]
Thomas Crowley executed a note with 1st Atlantic Bank on July 17, 1989.Â  Babb personally endorsed and guaranteed the note.Â  Crowley subsequently filed for bankruptcy and his liability on the note was discharged. Crowley later reaffirmed his debt by renewing the note with the bank.Â  Babb again guaranteed the note. Crowley ultimately defaulted.Â Â  
Anchor Bank, as successor to 1st Atlantic Bank, brought an action against Babb to recover on Babbâ€™s guarantee.Â  In his answer, Babb denied liability and asserted a third-party complaint against Crowley and Floyd.Â  Babb alleged he detrimentally relied on a promise by Floyd to pay toward the satisfaction of Crowleyâ€™s note.Â  A jury returned a verdict in favor of the bank against Babb and in favor of Babb against Crowley.Â  The trial court dismissed Babbâ€™s action against Floyd pursuant to Rule 40(j), SCRCP.Â  Babb moved to restore the action against Floyd, and the trial court granted his motion.Â  Floyd moved for summary judgment, arguing Babb failed to produce a written document evidencing Floydâ€™s promise to pay as required by the Statute of Frauds.Â  The trial court granted Floydâ€™s motion.Â  Babb appeals.Â Â Â  
Babb argues the trial court erred in granting Floydâ€™s motion for summary judgment because his detrimental reliance on a promise by Floyd to pay toward the satisfaction of Crowleyâ€™s note rendered the Statute of Frauds inoperative.Â  We disagree.Â  
To establish detrimental reliance on a promise to pay, a party must show he suffered a greater detriment than he would have incurred had the promise to pay not been made.Â  Wachovia Bank of SC v. Thomasko, 339 S.C. 592, 529 S.E.2d 554 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In this case, Babb cannot demonstrate he suffered a greater detriment.Â  This is because he remained liable on the original note notwithstanding Crowleyâ€™s bankruptcy.Â  See AMA Mgt Corp. v. Strasburger, 309 S.C. 213, 420 S.E.2d 868 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding a guarantor is not discharged if the debtor files a petition for bankruptcy).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Spartanburg County grand jurors indicted Mondrecco Glenn for trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  At trial, the State identified four prior convictions that it planned to use for impeachment purposes if Glenn chose to testify.Â  The trial court made a preliminary ruling that three of the convictions were admissible for impeachment.Â  Glenn did not testify and he was convicted.Â  Glenn appeals on the ground that the trial court erred in ruling that the State could use his prior convictions for impeachment purposes.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Luce v. United States, 469 U.S. 38, 43 (1984) (â€œTo raise and preserve for review the claim of improper impeachment with a prior conviction, a defendant must testify.â€); State v. THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Landrecus Orlando Cowan, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-197
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne D. White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from the conviction of Landrecus Cowan for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime.Â  Cowan argues that hearsay was improperly admitted under the excited utterance exception and that the court improperly allowed the State to shift the burden of proof.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 14, 2001, Maurice Holloway won a substantial amount of money while playing craps at a â€œgambling trailer.â€[1] Appellant Landrecus Cowan was also at the trailer that day.Â  During the evening, Holloway was shot in the arm and head, and he later died in the hospital.
At trial, Deputy Darryl Hill testified he was the first officer on the scene.Â  Hill testified that he accompanied the victim to the hospital, and at the hospital Stanley Brownlee and Larry Stowers told him Cowan had shot the victim twice.Â  The defense objected to the introduction of Hillâ€™s testimony concerning Brownlee and Stowers on the grounds it was hearsay.Â  The trial court overruled the objection, finding the statements were excited utterances and therefore fell within an exception to the rule against hearsay. 
When the defense presented its case, Cowan testified and admitted going into the trailer to place bets at the craps table; however, he claimed he was outside drinking beer with other people when the shooting occurred.Â  The solicitor challenged his testimony in her cross-examination as follows:

  
    STATE: Now you knew who was playing at the craps table because you were in and out; isnâ€™t that right?
    COWAN: Yes, maâ€™am.
    STATE: Where is the person that was at the craps table that saw the real shooter?Â  You have subpoena power, donâ€™t you?
    COWAN: I donâ€™t know.
    STATE: Well, there were a bunch of people in the trailer, werenâ€™t there? 
    COWAN: Yes maâ€™am.
    STATE: And you know them.Â  You hang out there.Â  Your friends, your family hang out there, donâ€™t they?
    DEFENSE COUNSEL:Â  I object to this line of questioning your honor.
    THE COURT: Whatâ€™s your objection?Â  Whatâ€™s your legal objection?
    DEFENSE COUNSEL: Itâ€™s a burden-shifting type question.
    THE COURT: I overrule at this time.Â  Go ahead, solicitor.Â  Do you want to rephrase your question?
    STATE: So, whoâ€™s the real shooter, Mr. Cowan?
    COWAN: To me, Darius Thomas was the real shooter.
    STATE: Oh, heâ€™s the real shooter?
    COWAN: Thatâ€™s what I believe.
    STATE:Â  I see.Â  But itâ€™s not you?
    COWAN: No , Maâ€™am, it wasnâ€™t me.
  

At the conclusion of the trial, the court charged the jury on the law, including the statement, â€œthe burden of proof is upon the State to establish by evidence to your satisfaction the guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. . . .â€Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty on the offenses of murder and possession of a firearm or knife during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Cowan was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder and five years for the weapons charge.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Excited utterance
Cowan argues the trial court improperly used the excited utterance exception to admit hearsay evidence regarding his guilt.Â  We disagree.
"'Hearsay' is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  While the general rule is that hearsay evidence cannot be admitted at trial, a number of exceptions exist.Â  See Rules 802 and 803, SCRE.Â  One exception is an excited utterance.Â  Rule 803(c), SCRE.Â  An excited utterance is a â€œstatement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition.â€Â  Id.Â  
"The rationale behind the excited utterance exception is that the startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication."Â  State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 20, 558 S.E.2d 518, 521 (2002).Â  For a statement to be considered an excited utterance, three elements must be met: (1) the statement must relate to the startling event; (2) it must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement; and (3) the stress of excitement must be caused by the startling event or condition.Â  Id. at 21, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  It is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion to determine whether, under the totality of the circumstances, a statement falls within the excited utterance exception.Â  Id.; State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 94, 544 S.E.2d 30, 34 (2001). 
In this case, Brownlee and Stowers witnessed a shooting and death.Â  It cannot be seriously argued they were not impacted by a startling event.Â  What is argued, however, is that the statements were not made when Brownlee and Stowers were still under the stress of the startling event.Â  
In laying the foundation for an excited utterance, Officer Hill explained he arrived at the scene of the shooting approximately three minutes after he was dispatched to the scene, he saw people running from a trailer, and his exchange with Stowers and Brownlee took place fifteen to twenty minutes after the shooting.Â  Hill explained that Stowers â€œhad been cryingâ€ and â€œwas real upset.â€Â  Brownlee was described as acting â€œ[n]ormal.Â  Maybe a little agitated, maybe.â€Â  Hill also testified that in his experience people respond to tragic events in different ways.Â  The demeanor of Stowers supports the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow the evidence because it suggests Stowers was still impacted by the shooting.Â  
Whether Brownlee, who was acting â€œnormalâ€ or â€œa little agitated,â€ was still under the stress of the event is a closer question.Â  However, the declarantâ€™s demeanor is not the only circumstance to consider; the court should also look to the severity of the startling event.Â  Sims, 348 S.C. at 22, 558 S.E.2d at 521.Â  Considering Browlee witnessed a fatal shooting within thirty minutes of his statement, we do not believe the trial judge abused his discretion by allowing the statement into evidence.
II.  Burden shifting
Cowan also argues the trial court erred by allowing the State to improperly shift the burden of proof.Â  We disagree.
While being cross-examined, Cowan admitted he knew the people who were playing craps with the victim.Â  The solicitor asked Cowan: "Where is the person that was at the craps table that saw the real shooter?Â  You have subpoena power, donâ€™t you?" Â The defense objected to the line of questioning, arguing it shifted the burden of proof onto the defense.Â  The trial court overruled the objection, and the solicitor next challenged Cowan to name the real shooter.Â  Cowan argues these questions constituted impermissible burden-shifting.[2]Â  
It is the burden of the State to establish each element of each offense by proof beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  In re Winship, 397 U.S. 358 (1970). â€œA shifting of the burden of proof would impose a significantly greater onus on the defendant and, even more significantly, it would obliterate the presumption of innocence.â€Â  State v. Attardo, 263 S.C. 546, 552, 21 S.E.2d 868, 870 (1975).Â  Ordinarily, the trial court should instruct the jury not to draw inferences from the defendantâ€™s failure to call witnesses.Â  Douglas v. State, 332 S.C. 67, 71, 504 S.E.2d 307, 309 (1998).Â  â€œHowever, where . . . the defendant presents evidence at trial, and â€˜there are witnesses, seemingly accessible to the accused, or under his control, who are or should be cognizant of material and relevant facts and competent to testify thereto, and whose testimony would presumably aid him or substantiate his story if it were true, it is not improper for the prosecuting attorney to comment upon [defendantâ€™s] failure to produce them.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting State v. Shackelford, 228 S.C. 9, 11, 88 S.E.2d 778, 779 (1955)) (brackets in original).Â  Cf. State v. Posey, 269 S.C. 500, 504, 238 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1977) (prohibiting the State from telling the fact-finder to draw a negative inference when the defendant fails to present any evidence at trial).
In Douglas v. State, an appeal from a post-conviction relief hearing, Douglas argued the trial court erred in refusing to give a curative instruction after the solicitor referred to his failure to call certain witnesses.Â  332 S.C. at 70, 504 S.E.2d at 308. During the Stateâ€™s closing argument, the solicitor stated, â€œOne thing they short me on is I didnâ€™t put these officers up.Â  Well, I tell you one thing, they can call witnesses just like I can.â€ Defense counsel objected, but the trial judge refused to give a curative instruction.Â  Our supreme court affirmed, finding the solicitorâ€™s argument was proper because Douglas had produced other witnesses. Id. at 71, 504 S.E.2d at 309.Â  Likewise, in State v. Bamberg, our supreme court found no error in allowing the State to comment on the defendantâ€™s failure to call witnesses to establish his alibi defense.Â  270 S.C. 77, 80-81, 240 S.E.2d 639, 640 (1977); see also Shackelford, 228 S.C. at 9, 88 S.E.2d at 779 (allowing comment regarding defendantâ€™s failure to call alibi witness).
In this case, Cowan also produced other witnesses on his behalf.Â  Thus, it was not improper for the solicitor to comment on Cowanâ€™s failure to produce the individuals who were playing craps with the victim and whose testimony would substantiate Cowanâ€™s story if it were true.Â  Additionally, the trial judgeâ€™s jury charge explained that the State had the burden of proving Cowanâ€™s guilt, thereby mitigating any possible confusion caused by the solicitorâ€™s cross-examination.Â  Accordingly, Cowanâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

[1] The "gambling trailer" was a modified mobile home where people gathered to play cards, drink alcohol, and socialize.
[2] In addition to claiming Cowanâ€™s argument has no merit, the State argues this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  However, we find defense counselâ€™s objection was sufficiently contemporaneous to preserve the error.Â  See State v. Gray, 304 S.C. 482, 484, 405 S.E.2d 420, 421 (Ct. App. 1991).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Greg S. Baker, Respondent,
        v.
        Williams Roofing and Construction, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-198
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        M. Anderson Griffith, of Aiken, for Appellant.
        Greg S. Baker, of Evans, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Williams Roofing and Construction appeals a circuit court order affirming, as modified, a decision rendered by the magistrateâ€™s court.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
Greg Baker contracted with Williams Roofing and Construction (Williams) to replace the roof on his home for the quoted price of $7,500.Â  Williams replaced the roof, but Baker was not satisfied and subsequently complained of problems with the roof and Williamsâ€™ performance under the contract.Â  
Approximately a year later, Baker filed a breach of contract action against Williams in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  In his complaint, Baker complained of delay in replacing the roof, substandard workmanship, and various other problems.Â  At the close of Bakerâ€™s case, Williams moved for a directed verdict asserting Baker failed to present any evidence of his damages.Â  The magistrateâ€™s court denied Williamsâ€™ requests â€œfor the fact that the defense used a transcript from a previous hearing and the plaintiff stated damages made by the defendant in that hearing.â€Â  
The magistrateâ€™s court found in favor of Baker and awarded him $3,750 in damages and $55 in costs.Â  Williams filed a motion for reconsideration, which the magistrateâ€™s court denied.Â  Subsequently, Williams appealed the magistrate courtâ€™s decision to the circuit court arguing the magistrateâ€™s court erred in denying its motion for directed verdict or alternatively, that â€œthe court erred in rendering a verdict for the [defendant] based on evidence which was not submitted at this trial.â€Â  The circuit court conducted a hearing and determined Baker did indeed provide evidence of his damages.Â  
The circuit court based its determination on the undisputed testimony that Williams agreed to replace his entire roof for $7,500, photos of the roof depicting the damage, and Bakerâ€™s testimony that several roofers told him that in order to guarantee their work the entire roof would have to be replaced.Â  The circuit court affirmed the magistrate courtâ€™s order, but modified it by increasing the award to Baker to $7,500 plus $55 in costs.Â  The circuit court increased the award based on its finding that there was no evidence to â€œsustain the amount awarded to the plaintiff by the magistrate.â€Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 14-5-340 of the South Carolina Code (1976), allows a circuit court to hear appeals from magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Section 18-7-170 of the South Carolina Code (1976), provides:Â  

  Upon hearing the appeal the appellate court shall give judgment according to the justice of the case, without regard to technical errors and defects which do not affect the merits.Â  In giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties and for errors of law or fact.

This section allows the circuit court, in its review of the magistrate courtâ€™s decision, to correct errors of law or fact.Â  In our review of the circuit courtâ€™s decision, we may not reverse findings of fact if any evidence exists to support them.Â  Vacation Time of Hilton Head Island, Inc., v. Kiwi Corp., 280 S.C. 232, 233, 312 S.E.2d 20, 21 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Directed Verdict
Williams argues the circuit court erred in finding the magistrateâ€™s court properly denied its motion for a directed verdict.Â  Williams asserts Baker failed to present any evidence of his damages at the magistrateâ€™s court hearing, and therefore, the magistrateâ€™s court erred in denying his motions for directed verdict.Â  We disagree.

  When reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, an appellate court must employ the same standard as the trial court by viewing the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  The appellate court will reverse the trial court only where there is no evidence to support the ruling below.Â  

Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 27-28, 602 S.E.2d 772, 782 (2004) (citations omitted).Â  
The record supports the circuit courtâ€™s determination that evidence of Bakerâ€™s damages did exist.Â  Although we do not have a complete transcript from the hearing before the magistrateâ€™s court, the pleadings undisputedly indicate the parties entered into a contract in which Williams agreed to replace the roof on Bakerâ€™s home for $7,500.Â  Additionally, Baker testified during the magistrateâ€™s court hearing, â€œI couldnâ€™t get nobody out to give me a price because they wonâ€™t do it.Â  They said theyâ€™ll have to do the whole roof.Â  Everybody weâ€™ve called.â€Â  Bakerâ€™s testimony provides evidence of the need for the roof to be replaced.Â  In addition, the contract itself provides evidence of the cost to replace the roof.Â  Thus, we find evidence exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s decision to deny Williamsâ€™ request for a directed verdict. 
In addition, Williams challenges the magistrate courtâ€™s reliance on a transcript from a previous hearing for evidence of Bakerâ€™s damages.Â  He asserts this transcript was not admitted into evidence, and therefore, the magistrateâ€™s court incorrectly relied upon it.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order does not indicate it relied on the transcript in finding evidence of Bakerâ€™s damages.Â  In fact, the circuit court, in its order, specified that evidence of Bakerâ€™s damages consisted of the original agreement between the parties, the photographs provided by Baker, and Bakerâ€™s own testimony.Â  Because the circuit court may make its own findings of fact in reviewing an appeal from the magistrateâ€™s court, we need not address this issue.Â  See Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 S.C. 484, 490, 548 S.E.2d 605, 608 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating section 18-7-170 of the South Carolina Code allows the circuit court to make its own findings of fact on an appeal from magistrateâ€™s court).Â  
II.Â  Modification of Award
Next, Williams argues the circuit court improperly increased the magistrate courtâ€™s award from $3,750 to $7,500.Â  We agree.
Notwithstanding the circuit courtâ€™s broad standard of review in hearing appeals from magistrate courts, the circuit court erred in increasing the amount of the award.Â Â  In this case, the circuit court increased the award based on its finding that there was no evidence to sustain the amount awarded by the magistrate.Â  
This holding incorrectly suggests that a verdict must strictly conform to the testimony concerning damages presented at trial, which it does not.Â  In Powers Construction Company, Inc. v. Salem Carpets, Inc., 283 S.C. 302, 322 S.E.2d 30 (Ct. App. 1984), a defendant asserted that a jury verdict of one-half the amount of damages proven was inconsistent with the evidence presented at trial and thus was an improper decision by the fact finder.Â  Id. at 310, 322 S.E.2d at 35.Â  We disagreed, finding that â€œproof of the larger amount necessarily included the smaller,â€ thus â€œappellant has no ground to complain of the favorable consideration of the jury.â€Â  Id. at 311, 322 S.E.2d at 35; see also, Piedmont Aviation, Inc., v. D. Quinn, 294 S.C. 502, 504-05, 366 S.E.2d 31, 32 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding same).[1]
Therefore, after determining that Baker presented evidence of his damages, the circuit court should have affirmed the magistrate courtâ€™s award of $3,750 and costs.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The circuit courtâ€™s increase in Bakerâ€™s award is particularly troubling considering that Baker did not appeal from the magistrateâ€™s order.Â  See, e.g., Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Co. Inc. v. Williamsburg County Water and Sewer Authority, 357 S.C. 251, 272, 593 S.E.2d 154, 165-66 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding issues not raised on appeal become the law of the case).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Matherine Brown, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Herbert L. Brown, Respondent,
				v.
				Clara McCray, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Clarence Bright, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-201
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John H. Tiller and Neil D. Thompson, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Helen Tyler McFadden and Ronnie Alan Sabb, both of Kingstree, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Clara McCray, personal representative for the estate of decedent Clarence Bright, appeals from a jury verdict in favor of Matherine Brown, personal representative for the estate of decedent Herbert L. Brown.Â  Brightâ€™s estate asserts that the trial court erred in denying her motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  We affirm.
 
This case arises from a fatal automobile accident involving a truck driven by Bright.Â  Brown was a passenger.Â  The accident occurred when Bright failed to negotiate a curve and the truck struck two trees.Â  Expert testimony reveals that approximately seven seconds elapsed from the time the truck left the road until it came to a rest.Â  A witness who arrived at the scene shortly after the accident testified that when she looked into the truck, she noticed that the Bright was already dead, but she observed Brown moving, breathing, and moaning.Â  She also observed that the interior light was on.Â  The witness further testified that she left the scene for about fifteen minutes to call an ambulance, and Brown was still alive when she returned.Â  Brown died, however, before the ambulance arrived.
Brownâ€™s estate brought a wrongful death and a survival action against Brightâ€™s estate.Â  Brightâ€™s estate moved for a directed verdict on the survival action, and the motion was denied.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Brownâ€™s estate. Brightâ€™s estate moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict arguing Brownâ€™s estate failed to establish conscious pain and suffering. The trial court denied the motion, and this appeal followed.
 
In ruling on a motion for JNOV, the trial judge must view the evidence and the inferences that can reasonably be drawn from it in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Force v. Richland Memâ€™l Hosp., 322 S.C. 283, 284, 471 S.E.2d 714, 715 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The trial judge must deny the motion when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inferences are in doubt.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  Moreover, a motion for JNOV may be granted only if no reasonable jury could have reached the challenged verdict.Â  Gastineau v. Murphy, 331 S.C. 565, 568, 503 S.E.2d 712, 713 (1998).Â  The verdict will be upheld if there is any evidence to sustain the factual findings implicit in the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Shupe v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 515, 445 S.E.2d 651, 654 (Ct. App.1994).
The South Carolina survival statute provides that a cause of action for personal injuries survives the decedentâ€™s death.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-90 (1976).Â  Damages for a decedentâ€™s conscious pain and suffering are recoverable, but there must be proof that the decedent consciously suffered prior to death.Â  Smalls v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 S.C. 208, 216, 528 S.E.2d 682, 686 (Ct. App. 2000); Croft v. Hall, 208 S.C. 187, 193, 37 S.E.2d 537, 539 (1946).Â  A scintilla of evidence that the victim was conscious prior to death is sufficient to create a jury question.Â  Smalls, 339 S.C. at 216-17, 528 S.E.2d at 686-87. 
 
South Carolina courts have examined the existence of evidence of conscious pain and suffering on several occasions.Â  In Croft v. Hall, 208 S.C. 187, 194, 37 S.E.2d 537, 539 (1946), the supreme court found witness testimony that the decedent made â€œterrible noises,â€ talked, and appeared to recognize her mother sufficiently created a jury question.Â  In Bowers v. Charleston & W.C. Ry. Co., 210 S.C. 367, 372, 42 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1947), a witness testified the decedent was â€œwhining and drawing up,â€ and groaning and struggling for breath.Â  Again, the supreme court allowed the case to go to the jury.Â  This Court recently considered the issue in Smalls v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 S.C. 208, 216, 528 S.E.2d 682, 686 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In Smalls, the decedentâ€™s father testified that he observed the decedent â€œgasping for air and moaning somewhat.â€ Id. at 217, 528 S.E.2d at 686-87.Â  He further testified he believed she could hear him and believed that she responded through movement of her fingers. Id.Â  This court held the evidence was sufficient to create a jury question, and noted â€œ[i]f there is any evidence from which a jury could reasonably conclude a decedent experienced conscious pain and suffering, the issue must be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Id., (quoting Vereen v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 306 S.C. 423, 432, 412 S.E.2d 425, 431 (Ct. App. 1991)).Â  But cf. Camp v. Petroleum Carrier Corp., 204 S.C. 133, 28 S.E.2d 683 (1944) (holding the evidence failed to show an accident victim was conscious of pain and suffering where one witness heard the victim groan and the other witnesses saw no signs of life.) 
 
We think the evidence, recited above, is sufficient to allow a reasonable jury to find Brown experienced conscious pain and suffering.Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.

title: Crotts v. Crotts
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Gary L. Crotts, Respondent,
				v.
				Sandra Crotts, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-202
Heard February 9, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Kathryn Walsh Gooch, of Simpsonville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Sandra Crotts (Wife) appeals a family court order granting her husband, Gary Crotts, a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Wife argues, inter alia, that the family court erred in excluding her doctorâ€™s testimony.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Gary L. Crotts and Sandra Crotts married in 1981.Â  They raised one child who is now an adult.Â  Throughout the marriage, Husband worked in the sanitation business.Â  Wife was employed in the textile industry, but left the workforce in 1995 as a result of suicidal thoughts, severe depression, and bipolar disorder.Â  After consulting with a physician, Wife made a claim for social security disability benefits. Â Beginning in 1996 and continuing until the time of marital litigation, Wifeâ€™s monthly disability checks have been her sole source of personal income.Â 
 
Wifeâ€™s mental illness took its toll on the coupleâ€™s marriage.Â  After her diagnosis, Wife was treated by physicians, took prescription medication, and was hospitalized several times.Â  Because of her illness, Husband took primary responsibility for household duties.Â  The couple eventually decided to separate, and Husband moved out of the marital residence.
 
In December 2001, Husband filed for divorce on the ground of habitual drug use.Â  Wife submitted an answer in which she denied the allegation of habitual drug use and filed a counterclaim seeking an order of separate support and maintenance, equitable distribution of the marital estate, attorneyâ€™s fees, and alimony.Â  The family court issued a temporary order awarding Wife $650 per month in alimony until the caseâ€™s final resolution.
 
After the temporary hearing, but before the final divorce hearing, Husband hired a private investigator to look into Wifeâ€™s relationship with an alleged paramour, Winfred Crowe.Â  The private investigator conducted surveillance of Wife for two months.Â  Thereafter, Husband amended his complaint to seek divorce on the ground of adultery.
 
At trial, Husband submitted an â€œInvestigative Reportâ€ by the private investigator into evidence.Â  The private investigator testified he saw Croweâ€™s car at Wifeâ€™s home on several occasions and once saw Crowe enter Wifeâ€™s home at night and leave the next morning.Â  Based upon these observations, he concluded Crowe was living with Wife and they were participating in an adulterous relationship.Â  Husbandâ€™s daughter from a previous marriage testified Wife once inadvertently referred to Crowe as her â€œboyfriend.â€Â  It was also undisputed that Wife included Crowe on her car insurance.Â Â Â Â Â 
 
Wife admitted that Crowe did in fact live in her house, but insisted they did not engage in a sexual relationship.Â  Wife asserted that Crowe, although he did not contribute to household expenses, was allowed to sleep in an extra bedroom in exchange for performing various chores and driving her around when medication prevented her from safely doing so herself.Â  This living situation, according to Wife, resulted in the decision to include Crowe on her car insurance.Â  Wife sought to corroborate this position with testimony from her psychiatrist, but the family court excluded his testimony on the ground of unfair surprise to Husband.[1]Â  The court did, however, allow Wife to proffer the doctorâ€™s testimony regarding her medications and their possible side effects, including sexual dysfunction.
The family court awarded Husband a divorce on the ground of adultery and thus barred Wife from receiving alimony.Â  The court also distributed the marital estate and denied both partiesâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  This court, however, is not required to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings; nor should we ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their testimony.Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999); Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 453, 486 S.E.2d 516, 519 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Questions regarding alimony and equitable distribution are committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997); Rogers v. Rogers, 280 S.C. 205, 207, 311 S.E.2d 743, 744 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â  Exclusion of Witness
Wife argues the family court erred in excluding the testimony of her doctor.Â  We agree.
Determining the appropriate sanction for late disclosure of a witness generally lies within the discretion of the trial court.Â  Barnett v. Adams Brothers Logging, 355 S.C. 588, 592, 586 S.E.2d 572, 574 (2003).Â  This rule, however, is designed to promote decisions on the merits, and the sanction of exclusion of a witness should never be lightly invoked.Â  Id.Â  A trial judge is required to consider and evaluate the following factors before imposing the sanction of exclusion of a witness:Â  (1) the type of witness involved; (2) the content of the evidence emanating from the proffered witness; (3) the nature of the failure or neglect or refusal to furnish the witnessâ€™ name; (4) the degree of surprise to the other party, including the prior knowledge of the name of the witness; and (5) the prejudice to the opposing party.Â  Id. (citing Jumper v. Hawkins, 348 S.C. 142, 152, 558 S.E.2d 911, 916 (Ct. App. 2001)). 
 
In the present case, the trial court made no specific findings concerning the required considerations enumerated above.Â  Instead, his decision to exclude the doctorâ€™s testimony was based solely on Wifeâ€™s counselâ€™s statement at the prior hearing that he planned on calling Wife as his only witness.Â  Although Wifeâ€™s counsel did make this statement at the initial hearing while the court was considering a prudent resolution to a scheduling dilemma, we do not believe it was binding on Wife.Â  Husband did not seek discovery in this case, nor was there a pre-trial order requiring the parties to exchange a list of witnesses; thus, Wife was under no obligation to limit her case to just her testimony.Â  Because no such obligation arose, Husband claims of unfair surprise and prejudice are weak, and there is no basis for finding fault in Wifeâ€™s failure to name the witness.
We are further persuaded that this exclusion was erroneous when considering the type of witness excluded and the probable content of his testimony.Â  In order to establish a prima facie case of adultery, a party must present evidence of both the opportunity and the inclination to commit adultery.Â  Panhorst v. Panhorst, 301 S.C. 100, 102, 390 S.E.2d 376, 377 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  When attempting to prove inclination,â€œ[e]vidence placing a spouse and a third party together on several occasions, without more, does not warrant the conclusion that adultery was committed.â€Â  Hartley, 292 S.C. at 246-47, 355 S.E.2d at 871.Â  Wifeâ€™s doctorâ€™s testimony was offered to show she lacked the inclination to commit adultery and was her sole evidentiary corroboration of this assertion.Â  Consideration of his testimony was critical to her case, especially when considering the tenuous nature of Husbandâ€™s evidence on the element of inclination.
Our review of the record indicates the family court erred in excluding Wifeâ€™s doctorâ€™s testimony. We therefore reverse the family courtâ€™s order on that basis and remand the case for a full review of whether a statutory ground for divorce exists, adultery or otherwise.Â  Should the family court find grounds for divorce on remand, we also invite reconsideration of the applicable factors enumerated in section 20-3-130 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) and a possible determination of alimony. 
 
II. Equitable Apportionment of the Marital Property
Wife also seeks a revision of the equitable apportionment of the marital estate.Â  She argues the trial court erred when it failed to identify and value the marital property.Â  We agree.
Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) lists fifteen factors the court must consider in making an equitable apportionment of the marital estate, including the identity and value of the marital property.Â  This court will affirm the family court if it can be determined that the judge addressed these factors in a manner sufficient for us to conclude he was cognizant of them. Walker v. Walker, 295 S.C. 286, 288, 368 S.E.2d 89, 90 (Ct. App. 1988); see also Rule 26(a), SCRFC (â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the court's decision.â€).
Although the order states the family court gave â€œdue consideration to all the statutory factorsâ€ in arriving at its decision, the family court merely granted each party the personal property currently in their possession.Â  We cannot glean from the record or the family courtâ€™s order that the court properly addressed the statutory factors, namely the identity and value of the marital property, in determining that this distribution was equitable.Â  Furthermore, the statute calls for consideration of the partiesâ€™ marital misconduct or fault when determining the equitable distribution of the marital assets.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(2) (Supp. 2004).Â  Because we find that the exclusion of Wifeâ€™s doctorâ€™s testimony tainted the family courtâ€™s finding of infidelity, we are further persuaded to remand the equitable distribution of the marital estate for reconsideration.[2]
For the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 


[1] The final divorce hearing was scheduled to last until 12:30 on May 30, 2003, but around noon it became clear the hearing would probably run over the allotted time as Wife had yet to begin her case.Â  Wifeâ€™s counsel indicated that Wife would be his sole witness, but the court nevertheless decided to continue the case until June 20.Â  On that date, Wifeâ€™s counsel sought to submit the testimony of both Wife and her doctor.Â  Husband objected based on Wifeâ€™s counselâ€™s prior statement that he would only be presenting Wifeâ€™s testimony. The court agreed.
[2]Â  We leave the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees to the family courtâ€™s discretion upon reconsideration of the issues addressed herein.

title: Germeroth v. Thomasson Brothers
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Paul W. & Dell Germeroth, Brian L. & Martha B. Andersen, Fred & Betsy Angerman, Bill & Paulette Bradford, Patrice & Dana Bruneau, Cynthia Fry, Charles Garrison, David & Reggie Grigg, Walter and Marjorie Guth, Martha Hinson, Larry & Mary Hutchinson, Ken & Jeri Johnson, Brett Lenyszyn, Bill & Beth Lifsey, Tony & Marci Lisee, Gerald & Kay Lynes, Mike McFall, Kirils & Mara Michailovs, Bobby & Jane Page, Steven & Carolyn Parker, George & Judith Pitteklo, Bob & Terry Schavey, Michael & Majorie Senhouse, WIlliam & Evelyn Sparks, Bryan & Jennifer Townson, Jack & Joan Vance, Janis Wilkins, and Denny & Connie Wise, Plaintiffs,
				Of whom Paul W. & Dell Germeroth, Brian L. & Martha B. Andersen, Fred & Betsey Angerman, Ken & Jeri Johnson, Brett Lenyszyn, Bill & Beth Lifsey, Mike McFall, Kirils & Mara Michailovs, Bobby & Jane Page, George & Judith Pittelko, Brian & Jennifer Townson, and Jack & Joan Vance are Appellants,
				v.
				Thomasson Brothers, L.P., a South Carolina Limited Partnership and Carolina Community Care, Inc. d/b/a Hospice & Community Care, Respondent.
				Of Whom Thomasson Brothers, L.P., a South Carolina Limited Partnership is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
 J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.   2005-UP-203
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Christian Stegmaier, of Columbia; for Appellants.
				Lucy London McDow, of Rock Hill; for Respondent.
			
		
	

 PER CURIAM:   Appellants brought the underlying declaratory judgment action seeking to determine the applicability of restrictive covenants to property purchased by Thomasson Brothers, L.P.  The court granted summary judgment to Carolina Community Care, Inc. d/b/a Hospice & Community Care (â€œHospiceâ€) and Thomasson, and determined the property was not restricted by the covenants.  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1973, PAR Associates purchased a tract of approximately 120 acres of land to be used as a residential subdivision known as Brookwood. In September 1978, PAR recorded a preliminary plat, which showed the subdivision of a portion of the tract into residential lots.  Later that year, covenants were filed, restricting the use of the lots to single family residential use.  The covenants were expressly limited to only a portion of the larger tract as follows:

	All those certain lots or tracts of land lying, being and situate[d] off India Hook Road . . . and being shown and designated as Lots 3 through 52, inclusive as shown on map of Brookwood Subdivision, drawn by Campco Engineering recorded in Plat Book 56 at Page 39 in the Office of the Clerk of Court for York County, South Carolina. 
	

Paragraph 18 of the covenants provided for a possible expansion of the covenantsâ€™ applicability:

	It is understood that grantor may expand the area covered by these Restrictions to a maximum of 121.124 acres presently owned by grantor and as further portions of said property are developed and subdivision plats recorded, then lots as shown on such recorded plats shall be included within the total number of lots as are affected by the provisions of this paragraph.  
	

A final plat was filed in 1979.  It designated several new residential lots, but contained one large unidentified parcel abutting India Hook Road. 
 
The large parcel was sold to Thomasson in 1981.  The deed does not mention the restrictions placed on the residential lots in Brookwood; however, it does contain its own restrictions.  Some of the restrictions in the deed for the large parcel are contradictory to the restrictions placed on the numbered residential lots in the Brookwood subdivision. 
 
Sometime in late 2002 or early 2003, Hospice agreed to purchase a portion of Thomassonâ€™s property to build and operate a Title 44 hospice facility and administration building.  Appellants, residents of the Brookwood Subdivision, oppose the construction of the facility and instituted this action seeking to restrict the property based upon the restrictive covenants filed for the lots of Brookwood.
 
Thomasson and Hospice filed a motion to dismiss, which was later considered as a motion for summary judgment.  Appellants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.  The court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion for summary judgment and granted the motions by Hospice and Thomasson.  This appeal followed the trial courtâ€™s denial of Appellantsâ€™ motion to alter or amend the judgment.  Prior to this courtâ€™s consideration of the appeal, Hospice entered a settlement with Appellants and has been dismissed from the case by consent of the parties.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).  When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 108, 584 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2003).  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party.  Sauner v. Public Serv. Auth., 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003);  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 353 S.C. 449, 455-56, 578 S.E.2d 711, 714 (2003). 
 
LAW / ANALYSIS
I. Mootness
As stated previously, Hospice settled with Appellants during the pendency of this appeal and agreed not to build on the Brookwood site.  Appellants devote much of their brief to the issue of Hospiceâ€™s attorneyâ€™s disqualification, an issue we now find moot due to Hospiceâ€™s withdrawal from the present appeal.  However, because Thomasson has repeatedly expressed, in word and action, its intention of developing the parcel, we address Appellantâ€™s other issues. See Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 568,  549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (â€œ[I]f a decision by the trial court may affect future events, or have collateral consequences for the parties, an appeal from that decision is not moot . . . .â€).
II. Restrictive Covenants
Appellants contend the trial court erred in finding Thomassonâ€™s property was not bound by the same restrictive covenants as the residential lots of the Brookwood Subdivision.  We disagree.

	As explained in Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 498 S.E.2d 862 (1998):
	
		Restrictive covenants are contractual in nature, so that the paramount rule of construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties as determined from the whole document.  
		
		The court may not limit a restriction in a deed, nor, on the other hand, 
		will a restriction be enlarged or extended by construction or implication beyond the clear meaning of its terms even to accomplish what it may be thought the parties would have desired had a situation which later developed been foreseen by them at the time when the restriction was written.   It is still the settled rule in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument.  It follows, of course, that where the language of the restrictions is equally capable of two or more different constructions that construction will be adopted which least restricts the use of the property.  A restriction on the use of property must be created in express terms or by plain and unmistakable implication, and all such restrictions are to be strictly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of the free use of property.  
		
	

Taylor, 332 S.C. at 4-5, 498 S.E.2d at 863-64 (emphasis added)(internal citations omitted).  The same passage was reiterated with emphasis recently by the South Carolina Supreme Court in South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).
We must first determine whether the language of the Brookwood covenants is ambiguous.  We find the provisions related to the restrictive covenants are clear and capable of construction using the plain and ordinary meaning of the words found therein.  See Heape v. Broxton, 293 S.C. 343, 345, 360 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œWhere the language used in a restrictive covenant is unambiguous, there is no room for construction and the language must be enforced in accordance with its plain meaning.â€).    
 
The covenantsâ€™ application was initially expressly restricted to the residential lots numbered 3 through 52.  Appellants, however, contend Paragraph 18 of the covenants expands their coverage to include the Thomasson property.  We disagree.
First, we note that the paragraph begins by using the word â€œmayâ€ in regards to the expansion of the area covered by the restrictive covenants.  There is no indication, and Appellants do not appear to argue, the developers ever created and filed any documents expressly expanding the area restricted to include the Thomasson property.
Second, while the next portion of the paragraph does seem to indicate mandatory expansion of the restrictive covenants, this expansion is limited to â€œfurther portions of said property [which] are developed and subdivision plats recorded.â€  Once recorded, only the â€œlots as shown on such recorded plats shall be included within the total number of lots as are affected by the provisions of this paragraph.â€ (Emphasis added). Nothing in the record indicates the Thomasson property, much larger than the residential parcels, was intended to be a â€œlotâ€ within the terms of the covenants.  See Davey v. Artistic Builders, Inc., 263 S.C. 431, 211 S.E.2d 235 (1975) (refusing to expand the applicability of restrictive covenants to property on a subdivision plat, but not subdivided into residential lots or assigned a residential lot number).  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly concluded the covenants, by their express terms, do not apply to the Thomasson property.
Even if we were to conclude an ambiguity exists in the paragraphs of the covenant, we are bound by the recent decisions of the South Carolina Supreme Court, which require us to construe the covenants to place the least possible restriction on the fair use of the land. See Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. at 622, 550 S.E.2d at 302; Taylor, 332 S.C. at 4-5, 498 S.E.2d at 863-64.  Appellants would have us resort to a 1958 Kentucky case for the more â€œmodernâ€ proposition that â€œbuilding restrictions are regarded more as a protection to the property owner and the public rather than as a restriction on the use of property.â€  Brandon v. Price, 314 S.W.2d 521, 523 (Ky. 1958).  We decline this interpretation and find the law as expressed in 2001 by our supreme court to be the accurate statement of the law in South Carolina.
Interpreting the covenants pursuant to recent South Carolina case law, we conclude they do not apply to the Thomasson property.  The record does not indicate the parties intended the large tract to be subject to the same restrictions as the lots developed specifically for residential use.  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Thomasson on Appellantsâ€™ claim that the property is bound by the covenants.
III. Implied Reciprocal Negative Easement
Appellants also contend the trial court erred in granting Thomasson summary judgment on Appellantsâ€™ claim for an implied reciprocal negative easement.  We disagree.
The South Carolina Supreme Court established the elements necessary to show an implied reciprocal negative easement as follows:

	Ordinarily, four elements must be established to show a reciprocal negative easement:
	(1) There must be a common grantor; (2) There must be a designation of the land or tract subject to restrictions; (3) There must be a general plan or scheme of restriction in existence for the designated land or tract; and (4) The restrictive covenants must run with the land.  
	
	If the above elements are satisfied, the restrictions are enforceable against the grantor and subsequent grantees of lots in the restricted area who take with actual or constructive notice of the restrictions.   
	

Bomar v. Echols, 270 S.C. 676, 679-80, 244 S.E.2d 308, 310 (1978).
In the instant case, the Thomasson property was not part of the general plan or scheme of restriction.  The parcel is much larger than the residential tracts and not subdivided or assigned a lot number.  If the grantor intended the Thomasson property to be included under the Brookwood Covenants, the deed for the Thomasson Property would not have contained its own set of restrictive covenants, some of which conflict with the provisions in the Brookwood Covenants.
 
As has previously been found by courts of this State, and was specifically noted by the trial court, grantors have a right to place restrictions on part of the property without restricting the remainder.  See Dunlap v. Beatty, 239 S.C. 196, 207, 122 S.E.2d 9, 15 (1961) (finding, under circumstance of the case, grantor â€œhad a right to impose restrictions on a portion of her property without creating any obligation to restrict the remainder.â€).  Under the circumstances of this case, we find PAR Associates never intended the Thomasson property to be included under the residential restrictions and, therefore, had the right to provide a different set of restrictive covenants for that portion of its property.  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Thomasson on Appellantsâ€™ claims for an implied reciprocal negative easement.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Thomasson regarding Appellantsâ€™ claims for enforcement of the Brookwood subdivision restrictive covenants and the imposition of an implied reciprocal negative easement on the Thomasson property.  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
