title: State v. Mack
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Lavanza Cory Mack, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Calhoun County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-204
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe, Jr., of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Lavanza Cory Mack appeals his conviction for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN), arguing (1) the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the charge because the indictment failed to specify an aggravating circumstance; and (2) the circuit court erred in failing to instruct the jury on any aggravating circumstances required to find ABHAN.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDUREAL BACKGROUND
In February 2003, Mack was indicted for strong-armed robbery and ABHAN.Â  The ABHAN indictment stated in pertinent part:

	That Lavanza Mack, did in Calhoun County, on or about September 24, 2002,
	commit an assault and battery upon the victim, John A. Stoor, constituting an unlawful act of violent injury to the person of the said victim,
	accompanied by circumstances of aggravation to wit:Â  he was struck from behind requiring medical attention, and as a result violated the Common Law offense of Assault and Battery of a High and Aggravated Nature.

(Emphasis added.).Â  Mack sought to quash the indictment in pretrial proceedings, arguing it was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction because the indictment failed to allege the assault and battery was of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Specifically, he argued that the language â€œrequiring medical attentionâ€ is not the equivalent of â€œserious bodily injury,â€ which is among the aggravating circumstances that may elevate a simple assault and battery to ABHAN.Â  The trial court denied the motion.
The trial court did not charge the jury on the typical examples of circumstances of aggravation, but defined circumstances of aggravation as an assault and battery â€œcommitted in a spirit of wantonness, or with a reckless disregard for the rights and safety of another . . . [and] [i]tâ€™s basically for you to determine whether there was (sic) circumstances of aggravation.â€Â  Mack objected, arguing the court erred in â€œnot requiring this jury to find the aggravating circumstance alleged in the indictment.â€Â  He added, â€œI object to not requiring them to do that, this is an open ended, they can find anything to be a circumstance of aggravation.â€Â  The court overruled the objection.
Mack was convicted of ABHAN and strong-armed robbery.[1]Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
I. Motion to Quash ABHAN Indictment
Mack first argues the trial court erred in refusing to quash the ABHAN indictment because it purportedly did not specify an aggravating circumstance.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn indictment survives legal scrutiny if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon.â€Â  State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 355, 510 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œSouth Carolina courts have held that the sufficiency of an indictment must be viewed with a practical eye.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 108, 572 S.E.2d 309, 312 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
 
Here, Mack apparently argues that the indictmentâ€™s allegation that Mack â€œ[s]truck [the victim] from behind requiring medical attentionâ€ was not an aggravating circumstance because it was not among those detailed in State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 518 S.E.2d 278 (1999).Â  We find this argument unavailing.Â  In Tyndall, our supreme court stated:

	Examples of circumstances of aggravation include the use of a deadly weapon, the infliction of serious bodily injury, the intent to commit a felony, great disparity between the ages and physical conditions of the parties involved, and the difference in the sexes.Â  Other circumstances include indecent liberties or familiarities with a female, the purposeful infliction of shame and disgrace, and resistance to lawful authority.

Id. at 21, 518 S.E.2d at 285 (internal citation omitted).Â  Nothing in Tyndall suggests this list is exhaustive.Â  
 
The indictment clearly charged Mack with â€œAssault and Battery of a High and Aggravated Natureâ€ on its inside and outside captions.Â  It undisputedly alleged assault and battery.Â  Then, it specifically alleged the assault and battery was â€œaccompanied by circumstances of aggravation,â€ which it described as Mackâ€™s having â€œstruck [the victim] from behind requiring medical attention . . . .â€Â  We find the indictment, when viewed with a practical eye, clearly informed Mack that he was being charged with ABHAN and included a specific reference to an alleged â€œaggravating circumstance.â€Â  
 
II. Jury Instruction
Mack next argues the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury on any of the aggravating circumstances that constitute ABHAN.Â  It is true that the trial court did not charge the generally recognized examples of circumstances of aggravation.Â  At trial Mack objected to the relevant instruction on a different basis, arguing the court erred in â€œnot requiring this jury to find the aggravating circumstance alleged in the indictmentâ€ and adding, â€œI object to not requiring them to do that, this is an open ended, they can find anything to be a circumstance of aggravation.â€Â  Moreover, Mackâ€™s position at trial is at odds with the very thing he now argues on appealâ€”error in failing to charge the typical examples of circumstances of aggravation.Â  Mackâ€™s trial counsel informed the trial court, â€œI also would have objected if you had given the whole laundry list [of circumstances of aggravation].â€Â  The precise issue argued in Mackâ€™s brief is therefore not preserved for appellate review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œA party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appealâ€).
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] This appeal does not involve Mackâ€™s strong-armed robbery conviction.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Frank R. Sennewald, Respondent,
				v.
				Tiger Aviation, Inc., Peter Tremblay and Roger Larsen, Defendants,
				of whom Roger Larsen is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge
Â James L. Verenes, Special Referee
Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-205
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005Â Â Â  

APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Roger Larsen, of St. George, Utah and Sacramento, California, 
				pro se, for Appellant.
				Bradley A. Brodie, of Aiken, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Roger Larsen appeals the special refereeâ€™s order awarding Frank R. Sennewald a judgment jointly and severally against Tiger Aviation, Inc., Peter Tremblay, and Larsen.Â  We dismiss the appeal as moot.
On September 2, 2004, Sennewaldâ€™s attorney filed a â€œSatisfaction of Judgmentâ€ with the Aiken County Clerk of Court in Satisfaction Book Number 24 at page 307.Â  The document stated, in pertinent part:

	FOR AND IN CONSIDERATION of payment, the receipt and sufficiency of which is herewith acknowledged, I, the undersigned attorney and agent of record for the Plaintiff, herewith declare the judgment in the above-entitled action to be paid and satisfied and do hereby further request the Clerk of Court to mark said judgment satisfied of record in the said Clerkâ€™s Office, and discharge the same completely.

On February 11, 2005, this court granted the motion to be relieved as counsel filed by Larsenâ€™s appellate counsel.Â  We informed Larsen of this fact by letter, and explained that he would be given two weeks to advise this court of the name of his new counsel or he would â€œbe noted as proceeding pro se on appeal.â€Â  Larsen failed to respond to this correspondence.
We dismiss the appeal pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 361 S.C. 568, 572, 606 S.E.2d 464, 466-67 (2004) (â€œAn appellate court will not pass on moot and academic questions or make an adjudication where there remains no actual controversy . . . . A case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon the existing controversy . . . . This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for the reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€); McGee v. Bruce Hosp. Sys., 344 S.C. 466, 470, 545 S.E.2d 286, 288 (2001) (â€œ[T]here can be only one satisfaction for an injury or wrong.â€).
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Shelly v. Carolina Air Services
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Sandra Shelly, f/k/a Sandra Shelly Foxworth, Respondent,
				v.
				Carolina Air Services, Inc., E.M. Lemmond, Jr., and David Dolber, Defendants,
				of whom E.M. Lemmond, Jr., and David Dolber are Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-206
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Edward L. Graham, of Florence, for Appellants.
				G. Miles Gordon, Irby E. Walker, Jr., of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  E.M. Lemmond and David Dolber (â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal a circuit court order enjoining them from transferring certain assets during the pendency of Sandra Shellyâ€™s action against them.Â  We affirm.Â Â 
 
FACTS
In a prior action, Shelly sued Carolina Air Services, Inc., and Appellants, its sole shareholders, for damages arising out of work performed on her airplane.Â  While this action was pending, most of Carolina Airâ€™s assets were sold to Powerâ€™s Aviation, Inc., a separate corporate entity.Â  Although other corporate debts were paid from the gross proceeds of this sale, no funds were withheld for Shellyâ€™s possible judgment.Â  Instead, the remaining proceeds, between $200,000 and $400,000, were distributed to Appellants as shareholders.Â Â  
 
The circuit court subsequently awarded Shelly almost $43,000 against Carolina Air.[1]Â  By that point, Carolina Air was merely an empty corporate shell and did not pay the judgment.Â  Shelly then brought a second suit against Carolina Air and Appellants alleging fraudulent conveyance,[2] civil conspiracy, and facts warranting a piercing of the corporate veil.Â  As part of discovery, Shellyâ€™s attorney deposed Lemmond.Â  During the deposition, he inquired about the disposition of the proceeds Lemmond received from the sale of Carolina Airâ€™s assets, as well as his current assets and liabilities.Â  Lemmondâ€™s attorney objected to this inquiry and filed a motion for a protective order to preclude its discovery.Â  Dolber joined in the motion, which the trial court granted based on a determination that it was not relevant or likely to be admissible evidence at trial.Â  In order to quell Shellyâ€™s concerns regarding the availability of the proceeds, the trial court also enjoined Appellants, in the same order, from disposing of the proceeds other than in their normal course of business, investment activities, and for living expenses.Â  This appeal followed.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant injunctive relief is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 601, 553 S.E.2d 110, 121 (2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs where the trial court is controlled by an error of law or where the trial court's order is based on factual conclusions without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend the trial court abused its discretion in granting injunctive relief to Shelly because the court did not comply with the requirements for issuing injunctive relief.Â  Specifically, they argue:Â  (1) the parties did not receive notice and an opportunity to be heard as required by Rule 65(a), SCRCP; (2) Shelly did not allege facts sufficient to state a cause of action for injunctive relief; (3) no evidence existed to show Shelly would be irreparably harmed or damaged if the court did not issue an injunction; and (4) the trial court failed to comply with Rule 65(c), SCRCP, by not requiring Shelly to post security.Â 
 
We find Appellants did not preserve these issues for our review.Â  â€œA contemporaneous objection is required to preserve an issue for appellate review.â€Â  
Hawkins v. Pathology Assocs. of Greenville, P.A., 330 S.C. 92, 111, 498 S.E.2d 395, 406 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThis principle underlies the long-established preservation requirement that the losing party generally must both present his issues and arguments to the lower court and obtain a ruling before an appellate court will review those issues and arguments.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000).Â  
 
At the hearing on Appellantsâ€™ motion for a protective order, Shellyâ€™s counsel raised concerns regarding the proceeds from the sale of Carolina Air, stating â€œtheyâ€™ve done this one time before . . . and I donâ€™t want the assets to be gone before I have a chance to collect my judgment.â€Â  In response, Appellantsâ€™ attorney, not Shellyâ€™s, first suggested some kind of injunctive action:Â 
 

	They just - - I mean, I can tell your honor they - - theyâ€™ve suffered significantly from stock market travails, as have many others.Â  They - - They - - You know, they face someÂ  - - some - - some financial challenges; but I mean, Iâ€™d be willing - - I think that they would be willing to consent perhaps to an order that they not give away assetsÂ  . . . I mean, they need to run their personal lives, be able to pay bills and that sort of thing.Â  I donâ€™t think they have any interest whatsoever in - - in, you know, taking assets and - - and trying to hide them in some fashion.Â  
	

The trial court then asked Appellantsâ€™ counsel to draft an order barring any inquiry into Appellantsâ€™ assets, but stating they were not allowed to dispose or transfer any of the proceeds except in the normal course of their business and personal lives.Â  Appellantsâ€™ attorney agreed, but asked the court, if his clients did not agree to the injunction, whether it would suffice for them to merely answer Shellyâ€™s questions. The court responded in the negative.Â  
 
Appellants never objected to this order, nor did they file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to have it altered or amended.Â  Instead, Appellants waited almost nine months until the first scheduled day of trial to raise exception to the injunctive relief.Â  The issue was raised with a bevy of other issues, including a motion to have Shellyâ€™s counsel relieved due to the possibility he may be a witness in the case.Â  Following her counselâ€™s voluntary withdrawal, the circuit court granted Shelly a continuance to hire a new attorney, which is where the case stands today.Â  The court never addressed Appellantsâ€™ objections concerning the injunctive relief.
â€œ[A] great number of reported cases in South Carolina for at least four generations, and more recently the appellate court rules and rules of civil procedure, have emphasized the importance and absolute necessity of ensuring that all issues and arguments are presented to the lower court for its consideration.â€Â  Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779 (2004).Â  At the initial hearing, Appellants failed to object to the injunctive relief or present any argument as to why it was improper.Â  If Appellants were convinced that the order went beyond the courtâ€™s injunctive authority, as they claim on appeal, then they were required to raise their arguments to the circuit court in a motion to alter or amend the injunctive order, which they also failed to do.Â  See 
Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 403-04, 566 S.E.2d 193, 196 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œIf a trial judge grants relief not previously contemplated or presented to the trial court, the aggrieved party must move, pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appeal.â€).Â  Even if we were to find that the arguments presented over nine months later sufficiently raised Appellantsâ€™ issues, they were never acknowledged, much less ruled upon, by the circuit court and, again, no Rule 59(e) motion was filed.Â  Accordingly, the issues are not preserved for our review and we do not address them here.Â  See Iâ€™On, 338 S.C. at 422, 526 S.E.2d at 724 (â€œIf the losing party has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to alter or amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review.â€).
CONCLUSION
Because we find Appellantsâ€™ issues are not preserved for our review, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The circuit court did not find Appellants personally liable to Shelly in the initial action.
[2] The trial court subsequently dismissed the action for fraudulent conveyance.Â Â

title: Walker v. Lindsey
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Lewis Gromyko Walker, Personal representative of the Estate of George Walker, Deceased, Plaintiff,
				v.
				Ellen W. Lindsey; Carol T. Jenkins a/k/a Carol T. Scotland; The Provident Bank; CIT Financial; and Connestee Falls Property Owner's Association, Inc., Defendants,
				Of whom Ellen W. Lindsey is the, Appellant,Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
				
				and
				Carol R. Jenkins, a/k/a Carol T. Scotland, The Provident Bank, and CIT Financial are, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-207
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Charles W. Whiten, Jr., for Appellant.
				Mason A. Goldsmith, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Ellen Lindsey appeals the Master-in-Equityâ€™s decision awarding ownership of certain property to Carol Jenkins pursuant to an adverse possession claim.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Plat Book 26 in the Anderson County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office[1] describes, inter alia, four adjoining residential lots, designated lots 6, 7, 8, and 9.Â  Carol Jenkins is the record owner of lots 8 and 9.Â  George Walker was the record owner of lot 7, situated, as one would imagine, between lots 6 and 8.Â  Ellen Lindsey was the record owner of lot 6.
In 1965, Jenkins and her husband purchased lots 8 and 9, as well as an abandoned and dilapidated structure that they believed was situated on those lots. Around December 1967, they moved into a home that Mr. Jenkins built from the remains of the preexisting structure. Unbeknownst to the Jenkins at the time it was erected, the home is actually situated entirely within the boundaries of lots 6 and 7, and not the lots they purchased. Jenkins has occupied the residence continuously since moving in.
 
After a survey revealed Jenkinsâ€™s home was situated on his lot, George Walker brought suit in 2001, seeking to establish title to lot 7 and damages for Jenkinsâ€™s encroachment.Â  Ellen Lindsey, owner of lot 6, filed a cross-complaint alleging Jenkins also encroached upon her land and should pay for diminution in the value of her property.Â  Jenkins answered by a letter to the court indicating she was willing to trade her lot 9 for Walkerâ€™s lot 7, but that she was not willing to be relocated from the home she has lived for over twenty years.
Throughout her testimony at trial, Jenkins expressed her belief that she owned the land upon which her residence was situated.Â  She asserted that she believed the property was properly mortgaged and that she paid taxes on the lots.Â  She reiterated that the lots were hers and claimed ownership through adverse possession.
The master concluded Jenkins established all the requisite elements of adverse possession.Â  As to the element of hostility, the master specifically found her claim concerned the possession of both lots in their entirety and was not a mere boundary dispute.Â  Accordingly, he determined that even if Jenkins had a mistaken belief regarding her ownership of lot 6 and 7, she could still set forth a claim of adverse possession.Â  This appeal followed.[2]Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of title to real estate is legal in nature.Â  Wigfall v. Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 60, 367 S.E.2d 156, 157 (1988); Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 87, 473 S.E.2d 474, 476 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Likewise, an adverse possession claim is an action at law.Â  Miller v. Leaird, 307 S.C. 56, 61, 413 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1992).Â  In an action at law, â€œthe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to the correction of any error of law; it must affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings unless there is no evidence that reasonably supports those findings.â€Â  Clark, 323 S.C. at 87, 473 S.E.2d at 476 (citing Jefferies v. Phillips Constr. Co., 316 S.C. 523, 451 S.E.2d 21 (Ct. App. 1994)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Lindsey contends the master erred in finding the case was not a boundary dispute.Â  Lindsey argues the controversy actually amounts to a mere disagreement between adjacent landowners regarding the location of their shared property line; thus, Jenkinsâ€™s mistaken belief that she owned the lots does not satisfy the requirement that her possession was hostile.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, adverse possession is established under a ten-year statutory period.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-210 (2005). â€œTo constitute adverse possession, the possession must be continuous, hostile, open, actual, notorious and exclusive for the entire ten year statutory period.â€Â  Davis v. Monteith, 289 S.C. 176, 180, 345 S.E.2d 724, 726 (1986) (emphasis added).Â  Hostile possession has been defined as possession â€œwith the intention to dispossess the owner.â€Â  Lynch v. Lynch, 236 S.C. 612, 623, 115 S.E.2d 301, 306 (1960).
In interpreting this hostility requirement, South Carolina has adopted a minority position regarding mistaken belief of ownership as a basis for adverse possession.Â  Lusk v. Callaham, 287 S.C. 459, 461, 339 S.E.2d 156, 158 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  In controversies involving a disputed boundary line between adjacent properties, our courts have held that an encroachment onto a portion of anotherâ€™s land under a mistaken belief as to the location of the true boundary line does not constitute hostile possession.Â  See Brown v. Clemens, 287 S.C. 328, 331, 338 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1985); Lynch, 236 S.C. at 623, 115 S.E.2d 301, 306-307.Â  In other words, â€œwhere one . . . in the possession of land up to a supposed line intends to claim only to the true line, his possession is not hostile and will not ripen into title.â€Â  Lynch, 236 S.C. at 623, 115 S.E.2d 301, 307. 
 
This minority interpretation of the hostility requirement, however, has been expressly limited to only those cases involving mere boundary disputes.Â  See Perry v. Heirs at Law & Distributees of Gadson, 316 S.C. 224, 226, 449 S.E.2d 250, 251 (1994); Wigfall, 295 S.C. at 61-62, 367 S.E.2d at 157; Clark, 323 S.C. at 89, 473 S.E.2d at 477-478.Â  The rule that a mistaken belief of ownership fails to establish the element of hostility does not apply to cases involving a dispute over an entire tract of land.Â  Id.Â  Because no other element of adverse possession is in contention, the present case hinges on the masterâ€™s determination that Jenkinsâ€™s claim involved both parcels in their entirety and is not a mere boundary dispute between adjacent land owners.
As found by the master, we conclude the instant case does not involve a boundary dispute or a structure that merely encroaches onto a portion of a neighboring lot.Â  Jenkinsâ€™s home is entirely contained within lots 6 and 7. She has openly maintained the lots and utilized the entire property as if it were her own.Â  The evidence indicates that the portion of the lots not containing the house was cleared or had obvious landscaping that was regularly maintained by Jenkins.Â  Accordingly, the master properly concluded this case was not a boundary dispute, but was instead a claim to the entire tracts of land designated as lots 6 and 7.Â  Jenkinsâ€™s mistaken belief regarding her ownership of the lots, therefore, satisfies the hostility element of adverse possession.
CONCLUSION
Because the record is replete with evidence supporting the masterâ€™s conclusion that Jenkins satisfied the elements of adverse possession for the entire ten-year statutory period, the masterâ€™s decision is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Page 176.
[2] George Walker passed away in early 2003, and his estate then pursued his claim.Â  Because the estate has not filed an appeal, Jenkins has obtained possession of lot 7 by virtue of adverse possession.Â  Lindsey brings this appeal solely in regard to whether Jenkins has properly obtained possession of lot 6.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Linda Lundstrom, Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kathleen Jennings DBA The Southern Cottage,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Joseph J. Watson , Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-209
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kathleen Jennings, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Leo A. Dryer, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Katheen Jennings appeals an order by the trial judge denying her request for relief from judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
In October of 2000, Linda Lundstrom, Inc. (Lundstrom), filed suit against Kathleen Jennings, doing business as The Southern Cottage at the Falls, Inc. (Southern Cottage), seeking payment for merchandise delivered to Jennings.Â  Jennings filed an answer denying Lundstromâ€™s allegations and asserting a counterclaim for repayment and costs associated with returned merchandise.Â  According to Lundstrom, it served requests for admission on Jennings on February 14, 2001, for which it did not receive a timely response.Â  Subsequently, Lundstrom filed a motion to strike Jenningsâ€™ answer and a motion for summary judgment.Â  Jennings retained counsel and filed a motion to dismiss claiming Southern Cottage, a South Carolina Corporation, not Jennings, placed the orders in question with Lundstrom.Â  In addition, Southern Cottage filed a motion to intervene in the matter, and Jennings filed a motion to amend her answer to include these arguments as a defense.Â Â  
The trial judge issued an order on October 16, 2001, deeming Lundstromâ€™s requests for admission admitted and granting Lundstromâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Jennings filed a motion to reconsider, arguing the trial judge should have recused himself.Â  In Jenningsâ€™ memorandum in support of her motion, she stated she asked her attorney to file a motion requesting the judge to recuse himself, but her attorney did not.Â  In addition, Jennings argued Lundstrom failed to provide her with sufficient discovery responses and she was not the correct defendant to be sued.Â  In an order signed on November 6, 2001, the trial judge denied Jenningsâ€™ motion to reconsider.Â  Jennings did not file an appeal.Â  
On January 8, 2002, Jennings filed a renewed motion to reconsider, to vacate the judgment, and to have the trial judge recused.Â  In an order dated January 9, 2002, the trial judge again denied Jenningsâ€™ requests for reconsideration and for recusal, but the judge allowed her to proceed with a motion to vacate the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Jennings filed another motion, entitled â€œAmended Renewed Motion for Reconsideration, Motion to Vacate Judgment, Motion to Recuse, and Motion for Leave to Withdraw Admissions and Memorandum in Support.â€Â  This motion was treated as a Rule 60(b) motion to vacate.Â  Jennings argued in the motion that she did not receive Lundstromâ€™s requests for admission until after it filed its motion to strike and its motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial judge conducted a hearing on the Rule 60(b) motion and subsequently issued an order dated February 22, 2002, denying Jenningsâ€™ request.Â  The trial judge determined he addressed, in his previous order, Jenningsâ€™ arguments that she was not the correct defendant and that she was due credits for returned merchandise.Â  In addition, the trial judge reasoned Jenningsâ€™ argument that she did not receive the requests for admission was without merit because the rule regarding requests for admission does not require certified mailing and Jennings did not previously assert this argument.Â  Jennings appealed the denial of her motion to vacate.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.Â  Our standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining whether there was an abuse of discretion.â€Â 
Raby Constr., L.L.P. v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 17-18, 594 S.E.2d 478, 482 (2004) (citation omitted).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises where the trial judge was controlled by an error of law or where his order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€Â 
Tri-County Ice & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Withdrawal or Amendment of Requests for
Admission
Jennings argues the trial judge erred in failing to allow her to withdraw or amend her requests for admission.Â  We disagree.
We find this issue not properly preserved for our review on appeal.Â  An issue must be ruled upon by the trial judge or raised by way of a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to be preserved for appellate review.Â 
Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).Â  Although Jennings asserted this argument in her Rule 60(b) motion, the trial judgeâ€™s order does not specifically address this issue.Â  In addition, Jennings did not assert this argument in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the trial judgeâ€™s order denying her request for relief from judgment.Â  Because Jennings raises the issue regarding the withdrawal or amendment of her requests for admission for the first time in her Rule 60(b) motion, we find this issue not preserved for our review.Â  
II.Â  Individual Liability for Corporate Debts 
Jennings maintains the trial judge erred in entering summary judgment against her for liabilities incurred by Southern Cottage.Â  Specifically, Jennings contends that Southern Cottage is a registered corporation in South Carolina and this corporation, not Jennings, placed the order for the merchandise for which Lundstrom seeks payment.Â  Therefore, Jennings argues absent an assertion that Southern Cottage, as a corporate entity, should be disregarded, she, as a shareholder, cannot be held personally liable for its obligations.Â Â  
Without addressing the merits of Jenningsâ€™ argument, we find her presentment of this argument in a Rule 60(b), SCRCP motion for relief from judgment improper.Â  â€œRelief from judgment under Rule 60 should not be considered a substitute for appeal from a final judgment, particularly when it is clear the party seeking relief could have litigated at trial and on appeal the claims he now makes by motion.â€Â 
Smith Co. of Greenville, Inc. v. Hayes, 311 S.C. 358, 359, 428 S.E.2d 900, 902 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
Jennings raised this argument before the trial judge in both her amended answer and her motion to dismiss prior to the trial judgeâ€™s order granting Lundstrom summary judgment.Â  Although the trial judge did not specifically rule on this issue in his order granting summary judgment, Jennings asserted this argument in both of her Rule 59(e), SCRCP motions, which the trial judge denied.Â  Jennings, however, did not subsequently appeal either of the trial judgeâ€™s orders denying her motions to reconsider.Â  Instead, Jennings filed a Rule 60(b) motion, which is not a substitute for an appeal.Â  Therefore, we find Jenningsâ€™ assertion of this issue pursuant to a Rule 60(b) motion improper.
III.Â  Rule 60(b) Motion 
Jennings argues the trial judge erred in denying her request for relief from the order granting Lundstrom summary judgment.Â  Jennings presents two arguments in support of her request for relief from judgment.Â  First, Jennings asserts the trial judge based his order upon the mistaken belief that Lundstrom delivered requests for admission to Jennings prior to the due date for such requests.Â  Second, Jenningsâ€™ failure to answer Lundstromâ€™s requests constituted excusable neglect because Jennings should not be required to timely answer requests for admission she did not receive.Â  In addition, Jennings contends she has several meritorious defenses she can assert should the court grant her motion.Â  
â€œThe movant in a Rule 60(b) motion has the burden of presenting evidence proving the facts essential to entitle him to relief.â€Â 
Bowers v. Bowers, 304 S.C. 65, 67, 403 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Rule 60(b) provides in pertinent part: 

(b) Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc. Â On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
    
  (1) mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect; . . . .

â€œIn determining whether to grant a motion under Rule 60(b), the trial judge should consider: (1) the promptness with which relief is sought, (2) the reasons for the failure to act promptly, (3) the existence of a meritorious defense, and (4) the prejudice to the other party.â€Â 
Mictronics, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510-11, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001). 
In the present case, Jennings seeks relief from a judgment based upon requests to admit which were deemed admitted.Â  The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provide that unless a party served requests to admit answers and denies the request within thirty days, the matters in the requests are deemed admitted.Â  Rule 36(a), SCRCP.Â  The rule further provides that matters admitted pursuant to the rule are conclusively established unless a withdrawal or amendment of the admission is allowed by the trial judge.Â  Rule 36(b),
SCRCP.
We find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Jenningsâ€™ request for relief from judgment because Jennings did not meet her burden of proving any mistake or excusable neglect.Â  The record indicates Jennings knew she did not timely answer Lundstromâ€™s requests for admission before the trial judge granted summary judgment to Lundstrom.Â  Jennings admitted in an affidavit that she learned of the requests to admit when she received Lundstromâ€™s motion for summary judgment based upon Jenningsâ€™ failure to answer the requests to admit on April 9, 2001.Â  Nevertheless, Jennings still failed to answer the requests to admit until August 15, 2001.Â  In a letter to counsel for Lundstrom, dated August 15, 2001, Jenningsâ€™ counsel wrote: â€œEnclosed is the Defendantâ€™s Answers to Plaintiffâ€™s Request for Admissions and Verification.Â  I apologize for the delay in sending the answers to you.â€Â  The trial judge addressed this failure in the order granting Lundstromâ€™s motion for summary judgment, stating:Â  â€œThe Court is first required to address Plaintiffâ€™s (earlier) Motion; Plaintiffâ€™s Request to Admit are deemed admitted, and this Court need inquire no further; the Plaintiff is entitled to the relief of Summary Judgment.â€Â Â  
The record does not contain any indication that Jennings filed a motion to withdraw the deemed admissions or to amend the deemed admissions.Â  In fact, in Jenningsâ€™ subsequent motions to reconsider, she does not assert any error by the trial judge in regard to this issue.Â  Because Jennings failed to answer the requests to admit within thirty days of service, the matters contained therein were deemed admitted pursuant to Rule 36, SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge correctly granted summary judgment to Lundstrom.Â  Therefore, there was no evidence of mistake or excusable neglect and we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Jenningsâ€™ request for relief from judgment.

    IV.Â  Recusal 
Jennings argues the trial judge erred in refusing to recuse himself from the case due to a negative and hostile relationship with her.Â  
We find this issue not preserved for our review.Â  In order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â 
Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â  When a trial judge does not address the specific argument raised by the an appellant and the appellant does not make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on the argument, the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.Â 
Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).Â  
In the case at bar, Jennings argued this issue in her motion for relief from judgment, but the trial judge did not rule upon this issue in his order.Â  In addition, Jennings did not file a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP to attempt to obtain a ruling on this issue.Â  Therefore, we find this argument not preserved for our review.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find Jenningsâ€™ arguments that the trial judge erred in refusing to allow her to withdraw or amend her requests for admission and in refusing to recuse himself from this action not preserved for our review.Â  In addition, Jenningsâ€™ claim that she cannot be held personally liable for obligations incurred by Southern Cottage is not properly before this court in this appeal from the trial judgeâ€™s denial of request for relief from judgment.Â  Finally, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Jenningsâ€™ request for relief from judgment.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial judge is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Audrey Lauren Sladek,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gerard R. Sladek,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 05-UP-210
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Audrey Sladek McCarson, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Brian M. Gibbons, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Audrey Lauren Sladek[1] (â€œDaughterâ€) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of her accounting action against her father, Gerard R. Sladek (â€œFatherâ€), pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP.Â  We affirm. [2]
FACTS
Daughterâ€™s parents, Deborah Sharp
(â€œMotherâ€) and Father, divorced in 1991.  Pursuant to the divorce
decree, Mother retained custody of Daughter and Father agreed to pay child support and establish a trust for Daughter, to be used in part for her college education, consisting of funds from the sale of certain real property.Â  The order required Father to give Mother a full accounting of the trust every six months.Â  Daughter was emancipated by age in 1998.Â  
In 2001, Mother filed a contempt action in the family court against Father, alleging that he failed to set up the trust for Daughter, he commingled Daughterâ€™s funds with his own, and he failed to provide an accounting or access to records.Â  On September 9, 2002, while Motherâ€™s contempt action was still pending, Daughter filed a separate action in circuit court against Father seeking an accounting of the funds in her trust, alleging breach of fiduciary duty and conversion, and seeking actual and punitive damages.[3]Â  Daughter believed that Father had misappropriated between $50,000 and $92,000 from her trust.Â  Father moved to dismiss Daughterâ€™s accounting action pursuant to â€œapplicable cases and statutes including but not limited to Rule 12(b)(8),â€ because the issue was still pending in family court.Â Â Â  
On February 20, 2003, the family court issued an order in Motherâ€™s contempt action finding Father had misused Daughterâ€™s funds in violation of the divorce decree.Â  The family court found Father had inappropriately commingled Daughterâ€™s funds with his own funds and applied Daughterâ€™s funds to his own obligations.Â  The evidence presented to the family court showed that Father inappropriately deducted child support payments from Daughterâ€™s funds and inappropriately purchased a car for Daughter from the funds.Â  The family court found that the evidence was insufficient to establish the sums of any other funds which may have been misappropriated.Â  Finally, the family court found Father in contempt and sentenced him to twelve months in jail, suspended upon the repayment of $9,750 in funds used to pay the child support obligation and $8,000 deducted from the fund to purchase Daughter a car.Â  The court awarded Mother partial attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â Â Â  
On July 30, 2003, the circuit court issued an order granting Fatherâ€™s motion to dismiss Daughterâ€™s accounting action.Â  The circuit court found Motherâ€™s contempt action and Daughterâ€™s accounting action had essentially the same parties, dealt with the same exact issues, and even had the same attorneys.Â  The court found that Daughter was the real party at interest in Motherâ€™s contempt action and noted that because the two actions dealt with the same matters, the order from Motherâ€™s contempt action barred Daughterâ€™s accounting action under the doctrines of both res judicata and collateral estoppel.Â  Thus, the court dismissed the action with prejudice pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Upon review of dismissal of a cause of action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP, the appellate court applies the same standard of review as that implemented by the trial court.Â  In determining whether the trial court properly granted the motion to dismiss because another action with the same parties for the same claim was pending, we must consider whether the subsequent complaint, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, states any new claim.Â  If the parties and the claims are the same in both pending actions, dismissal is appropriate.Â  Rule 12(b)(8) should be read in conjunction with Rules 8 and 10, SCRCP. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Daughter argues the circuit court erred in dismissing her accounting action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP, because strict compliance with the rule is required, the named parties in the two cases were different, and there were different claims.Â  We disagree.Â  
A party may move to dismiss an action where â€œanother action is pending between the same parties for the same claim.â€Â  Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP.Â  Although our courts have not directly ruled on whether the same exact named parties and the same exact claims be present to trigger the rule, the circuit court in this case found that Daughter was the real party at interest in Motherâ€™s contempt action.Â  Daughter does not appeal the circuit courtâ€™s finding that she was the real party at interest in Motherâ€™s contempt action; she merely argues that the named parties in the two actions were different.Â  Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Daughter was the real party at interest in the family court matter is the law of the case.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (holding that an unappealed ruling is the law of the case).Â  Thus, the fact that the parties named in the captions of the two lawsuits are different in the present action is of no consequence as Daughter was the real party at interest in both actions.Â  
Daughter also argues that Rule 12(b)(8) was inapplicable because the claims brought in the two actions were different.Â  Both actions sought an accounting from Father to explain how money earmarked for Daughterâ€™s trust was spent.Â  Both actions also sought the return of the money mismanaged.Â  Daughter additionally requested punitive damages for conversion in her accounting action.Â  The gist of Motherâ€™s contempt action was that Father inappropriately managed, or converted, Daughterâ€™s funds for his personal use.Â  Thus, although Daughter could not obtain the relief of punitive damages in the family court matter, the claims in both matters were the same.Â  See Plum Creek Dev. Co. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 35, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999) (noting that the fact that different remedies were sought in a subsequent action did not alter the fact that the claims from both actions arose from the same exact factual basis and were identical). 
Finally, we note that whether Rule 12(b)(8) was appropriately followed in this matter is of no consequence because the circuit court dismissed Daughterâ€™s accounting action based upon alternate grounds.Â  Despite the fact that the order cites Rule 12(b)(8) as the reason for the dismissal of Daughterâ€™s action, the court actually found the action was barred based upon the doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel.[4]Â  
â€œUnder the doctrine of res judicata, â€˜[a] litigant is barred from raising any issues which were adjudicated in the former suit and any issues which might have been raised in the former suit.â€™â€Â  Plum Creek Dev. Co., 334 S.C. at 35, 512 S.E.2d at 109 (quotingÂ  Hilton Head Ctr. of South Carolina, Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987)).Â  â€œTo establish res judicata, the defendant must prove the following three elements: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, a subsequent action between the same parties for the same claim will be barred by a judgment on the merits in a prior action pursuant to res
judicata. 
The doctrine of collateral estoppel, or issue preclusion, provides that issues finally determined on the merits in one action precludes relitigation of those issues in a subsequent action based on different claims between the same parties or their privies.Â  See Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 79-80, 552 S.E.2d 767, 770 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€˜â€œUnder the doctrine of collateral estoppel, once a final judgment on the merits has been reached in a prior claim, the relitigation of those issues actually and necessarily litigated and determined in the first suit are precluded as to the parties and their privies in any subsequent action based upon a different claim.â€â€™); see also Shelton v. Oscar Mayer Foods Corp., 325 S.C. 248, 251, 481 S.E.2d 706, 708 (1997) (noting collateral estoppel prevents a party from â€œrelitigating in a subsequent suit an issue actually and necessarily litigated and determined in a prior actionâ€). 
In both Motherâ€™s contempt action and Daughterâ€™s accounting action, Daughter was the real party at interest and Father was the defendant.Â  Both actions raised the claim that Father misappropriated funds from Daughterâ€™s trust account and demanded an accounting.[5]Â  A final ruling was issued from the family court that Father had misappropriated funds from Daughterâ€™s trust account.Â  Because the same parties were involved, both actions concerned the same claim, and a final ruling was issued on the merits in the family court matter, the circuit court correctly found Daughterâ€™s accounting action was barred by the doctrine of res
judicata.
Further, the circuit court was correct in finding Daughterâ€™s accounting action was barred by the doctrine of collateral estoppel.Â  Assuming Daughterâ€™s claim for conversion could be considered a different claim, the issue of whether Father inappropriately used Daughterâ€™s trust funds was necessarily decided in the prior family court action.Â  Although the family court found the evidence supported a finding that some of the funds had been mismanaged, the issue of Fatherâ€™s mismanagement has been conclusively proven and Daughter does not get a second attempt to prove a higher amount.Â  
Accordingly, because Daughter was the real party at interest in both actions, both actions dealt with the claim of Fatherâ€™s impropriety in managing Daughterâ€™s trust, and the matter was finally determined in the family court, the circuit court appropriately dismissed Daughterâ€™s accounting action.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s dismissal is 
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  It appears that Audrey Lauren Sladek married during the pendency of this appeal, and she is now known as Audrey Sladek McCarson.
[2] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[3]Â  The same attorney representing Mother in the contempt action represented Daughter in the accounting action and, initially, represented Daughter in this appeal.Â  Daughter now represents herself in this appeal.
[4]Â  We note that Rule 12(b)(8) appears to apply only to pending matters.Â  Here, Father filed the motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(8) when, as the rule requires, another action concerning the same parties and matter was pending in the family court.Â  At the time of the hearing on the motion, the family court matter was no longer pending and a final ruling on the matter was issued.Â  However, Daughter does not raise this argument in her appeal and we decline to address it.Â  
[5]Â  We note that the record does not indicate whether the time periods involved in both actions are the same; however, Daughterâ€™s action was filed at least a year after Motherâ€™s contempt action.Â  Fatherâ€™s actions in managing the trust after the family courtâ€™s decision would present a different claim.Â  However, it is incumbent upon Daughter, as the appellant, to provide this court with a sufficient record upon which to make a decision.Â  Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 533 S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donald J. Brown,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Li'l Cricket Food Stores, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-211
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Donald C. Coggins, Jr., David H. Tyner and Harrison, White, Smith, all of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Albert V. Smith, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Liâ€™l Cricket Food Stores, Inc. (Store) appeals from the trial courtâ€™s judgment in favor of Donald J. Brown for $3500 on his claim for false imprisonment.Â  We reverse.[1]  
FACTS
Brown is a former employee of the Store.Â  This matter arose after Eddie Morman, the manager, discovered on October 6, 1999 that $500 was missing from a deposit that was left overnight in his desk drawer.Â  After a search revealed that the money was indeed missing, corporate management told Morman to call the police and have them fill out a report.Â  
On October 9, 1999, an officer from the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Department filled out an incident report and took a voluntary statement from Morman.Â  In the statement, Morman indicated he had informed his superiors that only three employees had access to the money:Â  Brown, Sara Strong, and himself.Â  Brown and Strong were listed as suspects on the incident report.Â  
The Store also conducted an in-house investigation.Â  Corporate management watched videotape from the security cameras and noticed that on several occasions Brown allowed customers to leave the store with beer and cigarettes without paying for them.Â  This information was turned over to Wayne Butler, head of security for the Store. 
On October 18, 1999, Butler and other corporate management officers interviewed Brown, Morman and Strong separately.Â  All three denied any knowledge of the moneyâ€™s whereabouts.Â  Brown testified Butler told him during that conversation that â€œif [Brown] didnâ€™t tell [Butler] that [Brown] took the money, [Brown] was going to jail.â€Â  Brown responded that they â€œmight as well go ahead and get a warrant on [him] because [Brown] knew [he] didnâ€™t take the money.â€Â  Another employee, Pamela Rice, asked to speak to the corporate management officers.Â  Rice told management she had seen Brown take money and put it into his pocket on one occasion.Â  Additionally, Rice said she had seen Brown allow customers to leave the store without paying for beer and cigarettes.Â  Rice gave a written statement relating the same information.Â  
Because the videotape corroborated what Rice said, corporate management questioned Brown about the beer and cigarettes, and he admitted giving them to friends of his.Â  The Store suspended Brown from employment because of the video evidence of him giving away store merchandise.Â  
After completing the interviews, Butler turned the results of the Storeâ€™s investigation, including Riceâ€™s statement, over to the police.Â  Corporate management and the investigating officer both testified that no accusations were made against Brown at that time.Â  Butler testified he never suggested to police that Brown be arrested.Â  Additionally, Brown admitted he never heard either Morman or Butler make any accusations against him to the police.Â  
On October 22, 1999, Officer John Hudson presented the results of the police investigation to a magistrate and obtained an arrest warrant for breach of trust under $1,000.Â  Officer Hudson testified that it was departmental policy for officers to request a warrant once the investigation was concluded to determine whether probable cause existed.Â  Officer Hudson further testified that Butler had no part in the decision to seek a warrant.Â  
Brown was subsequently arrested pursuant to the warrant.Â  He spent approximately eight hours in jail.Â  A trial date was set, and notice of a hearing was mailed to the Store.Â  Butler testified that as there is no mail receptacle at the Store, any mail addressed to that location would be returned.Â  In addition, Butler was out of the office for about a month during this time for medical reasons.Â  No one from the Store appeared at the hearing.Â  As a result, the charges against Brown were dismissed.Â  
Brown then brought an action against the Store for false imprisonment and liable per se, seeking actual and punitive damages.Â  The Store asserted a counterclaim pursuant to the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Sanctions Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10 through -50 (2005).Â  After a bench trial, the trial court found in favor of the Store on the libel per se action but in favor of Brown on the false imprisonment claim and the Storeâ€™s counterclaim.Â  The court awarded Brown $3,500 in damages.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This is an action at law.Â  See Culler v. Blue Ridge Elec. Co-op., Inc., 309 S.C. 243, 246, 422 S.E.2d 91, 93 (1992) (stating an action in tort is generally an action at law).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Store argues that the circuit court erred as a matter of law in finding that its actions constituted false imprisonment.Â  We agree. 
â€œFalse imprisonment is â€˜deprivation of a personâ€™s liberty without justification.â€™â€Â  Gist v. Berkeley County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 336 S.C. 611, 615, 521 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 1999) (quoting Caldwell v. K-mart Corp., 306 S.C. 27, 30, 410 S.E.2d 21, 23 (Ct. App. 1991)).Â  â€œIn order to prevail on a claim for false imprisonment, the plaintiff must establish:Â  (1) the defendant restrained the plaintiff, (2) the restraint was intentional, and (3) the restraint was unlawful.â€Â  Id. at 618-19, 521 S.E.2d at 167.Â  
A private party at whose request, direction, or command a police officer makes an unlawful arrest may be liable for false imprisonment 32 Am. Jur. 2d False Imprisonment Â§ 40 (1995); see, e.g., Wingate v. Postal Tel. & Cable Co., 204 S.C. 520, 30 S.E.2d 307 (1944) (holding a company liable for false arrest based on conduct by one of its employees).Â  Although it is not necessary that the defendant expressly direct the arrest, â€œthere must be some affirmative act on the defendantâ€™s part which induces the officer to make the arrest.â€Â  32 Am. Jur. 2d False Imprisonment Â§ 41 (1995).Â  The instigation must be such that the arrest is not carried out by the officerâ€™s own volition, but to carry out the request of the third party.Â  Id.Â  â€œAlso, no liability is incurred if a person merely gives information to an officer tending to show that a crime has been committed; this is so even if the information purports to show that the person later falsely arrested is the one who committed the alleged crime.â€Â  Id.Â  
The supreme court in Wingate elucidated:

Where a person merely directs the attention of a police officer to what he supposes to be a breach of the peace, or gives to such officer facts indicating such, and the officer, without other direction, arrests the offender on his own responsibility, the person who did nothing more than communicate the facts to the officer is not liable for causing the arrest, even though it is made without a warrant.Â  Where a person has information or knowledge that the law has been violated, he not only has a right, but frequently it is his duty, to communicate such information or facts to the proper officer so as to give such officer the opportunity, if in his judgment it is proper to do so, to take whatever steps may be necessary to apprehend the offender. . . . Those who honestly seek the enforcement of the law and who are supported by circumstances sufficiently strong to warrant a cautious man in the belief that the party suspected may be guilty of the offense charged, should not be made unduly apprehensive that they will be held answerable in damages.
But it is equally well settled that where a private person induces an officer by request, direction or command to unlawfully arrest another, he is liable for false imprisonment.Â  The charge of false imprisonment is not confined to the party who unlawfully seizes or restrains another, but it likewise extends to any person who may cause, instigate or procure an unlawful arrest.

Wingate, 204 S.C. at 527-28, 30 S.E.2d at 310-11 (internal citations and quotation marks omitted). Â 
In Wingate, an employee of the defendant company went to police, complained of the suspectsâ€™ actions, and told the officer that â€œthey ought to be arrested.â€Â  Wingate, 204 S.C. at 524, 30 S.E.2d at 309.Â  The court held that a jury question was created as to liability.Â  Id. at 28, 30 S.E.2d at 311. 
Here, there is no indication in the record that the Store or any of its agents requested, directed, or commanded Brownâ€™s arrest.Â  Mormanâ€™s statement did not specifically accuse Brown.Â  Morman listed three people with access to the area where the money had been, including himself.Â  The police report named both Brown and Strong as suspects.Â  
The in-house investigation was conducted on October 18, 1999, over a week after police took the statement.Â  After interviewing Strong, Morman and Brown, and taking Riceâ€™s voluntary statement, corporate management turned the information over to the police because it was part of an ongoing criminal investigation.Â  The only evidence regarding an accusation was Brownâ€™s testimony that Butler, the head of security, accused him of taking the money.Â  However, this accusation was not made in the presence of law enforcement.Â  The investigating officersâ€™ testimony at trial corroborated the testimony of the Storeâ€™s employees, who uniformly testified that the results of their investigation were turned over to law enforcement without comment.Â  Officer Hudson denied any employee of the Store accused Brown of taking the money.Â  Finally, Officer Hudson testified that departmental policy required the results of the investigation to be presented to the magistrate for a warrant once it was completed.Â  He further testified that Butler â€œwas in no position to request [a warrant] whatsoever.â€Â  
We find no evidence in the record supporting a finding that the Store or any of its agents communicated any accusation against Brown to the police.Â  Brown failed to show an inducement by request, direction, or command to unlawfully arrest him.Â  Accordingly, we hold that Brownâ€™s false imprisonment claim fails as a matter of law.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the trial court is hereby 
 REVERSED. Â 
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant toÂ  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Denise Craddock,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael Glenn Craddock,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Union County
Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-212
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William E. Whitney, Jr., of Union, for Appellant.
GeorgeÂ  Brandt, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Michael Glenn Craddock (â€œHusbandâ€) appeals a family courtâ€™s award of alimony and retirement benefits to Denise Craddock (â€œWifeâ€).Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on March 31, 1972.Â  The couple parented two children, both having reached the age of majority by the time this action commenced.Â  Throughout the marriage, Husband worked for Norfolk Southern Railroad where he accumulated certain retirement benefits.Â  The parties purchased a home in Union County in 1988 and resided there together as husband and wife until they separated.Â  Â Â Â Â 
On January 14, 2002, Wife commenced this action by filing a â€œPetition for Decree of Separate Maintenance.â€Â  In her petition, Wife sought, inter alia, the marital residence, alimony, and a division of marital property.Â  Wife asserted the couple separated on November 19, 2001.Â  In his answer and counterclaim, Husband contested Wifeâ€™s claim to the marital home and disputed the date of separation.Â  Husband alleged the parties separated on January 15, 2000, and lived separate and apart continuously since that time.Â  Therefore, Husband asserted he was entitled to a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  Wife filed an answer to Husbandâ€™s counterclaim reaffirming the date of separation put forward in her pleadings.
A hearing on the merits was held on January 27, 2003.Â  At the beginning of the proceedings, Wife moved to amend her pleadings to request a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  The trial court granted the request without objection from Husband.Â  On June 25, 2003, the court issued an order granting a divorce to Wife.Â  
Relying partially on the testimony presented as well as general agreement among the parties, the court found Wife earned approximately $2,000.00 a month, while Husband earned $5,655.00 per month.Â  Based on this finding, the court awarded Wife alimony in the amount of $1,075.00 a month.Â  In addition, using a property division of 50 percent, the court apportioned the marital property, including funds that accumulated in Husbandâ€™s retirement account during the marriage.Â  Specifically, the court awarded Wife the marital residence, half of the proceeds in the partiesâ€™ bank account, and a portion of the Husbandâ€™s retirement benefits.
Husbandâ€™s retirement benefits with Norfolk Southern Railroad are divided into two categories â€“ Tier I and Tier II.Â  The distribution amounts of Tier I benefits are controlled by federal law and cannot be altered by a state court order.Â  Under Tier I, a divorced spouse meeting certain requirements will automatically receive benefits.Â  Tier II is not as strictly regulated and may be subject to equitable distribution.Â  
The court determined it would take a period of 40 years for Husbandâ€™s retirement benefits to fully vest.Â  Because the parties were married for 30 years, or 75 percent of the time it would take for the benefits to vest, the court held Wife would be entitled one-half of 75 percent or 37.5 percent of the total Tier II benefits.[2]Â  Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard the factual findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither are we required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband first asserts the trial court erred in awarding alimony because the divorce should have been granted to him and there was no finding of fault.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 357 S.C. 354, 358, 592 S.E.2d 637, 639 (Ct. App. 2004) (citation omitted).Â  A court abuses its discretion when its decision is controlled by some error of law or its ruling lacks evidentiary support.Â  Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 23, 590 S.E.2d 495, 497 (Ct. App. 2003).
There is no fixed standard as to the amount of alimony to be awarded.Â  A family court has discretion to determine the award after taking into consideration all of the relevant factors.Â  Rimer v. Rimer, 361 S.C. 521, 524, 605 S.E.2d 572, 574 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Section 20-3-130(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) contains thirteen factors a court must consider, including: the duration of the marriage, the age and physical condition of both parties, their educational background, employment history, and the marital and nonmarital properties of the parties.Â  Fault is but one of the many factors a family court must consider when making such a decision.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(10) (Supp. 2004).Â  Because it is clear from the family courtâ€™s ruling that the appropriate factors were considered, we find Husbandâ€™s argument that Wife was not entitled to alimony because there was not a finding of fault to be without merit.Â Â  
Similarly, Husbandâ€™s argument that the trial court erred in granting alimony to Wife because he should have been granted the divorce is unconvincing.Â  For all practical purposes this argument is the equivalent of the former.Â  As noted previously, Husband petitioned the court for divorce on the non-fault ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  Wife moved, without objection from Husband, to amend her pleadings to also include the no-fault ground.Â  It is clear from a review of the record that the court merely considered the testimony and made a factual determination that the parties separated on the date asserted by Wife.Â  Therefore, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s award of alimony to Wife.
The Husband next contends the family court erred in awarding Wife a portion of his Tier II retirement benefits.Â Â Â  We disagree.Â  
The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Morris v. Morris, 295 S.C. 37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004) requires that the family court consider fifteen factors and give each weight as it determines.Â  On review, this court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and if the end result is equitable, the fact that this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988); Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996) (the reviewing court will affirm the family court judgeâ€™s apportionment of marital property if it can be determined the judge addressed the relevant factors under section 20-7-472 with sufficiency for the reviewing court to conclude the judge was cognizant of statutory factors).
Significantly, Husband correctly admits his Tier II retirement benefits are marital property and subject to equitable distribution.Â  See e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(8) (Supp. 2004).Â  Husband argues, however, that the family court erred in awarding Tier II benefits to Wife because she did not specifically ask for them.Â  We disagree.
Wife specifically asked in her pleadings for the court to grant her an order â€œequitably dividing the real and personal property accumulated by the parties during the course of the marriage.â€Â  The parties also stipulated to the admission of a statement of Husbandâ€™s retirement benefits.Â  Thus, having already found that Husbandâ€™s Tier II benefits constitute marital property, we find the trial court properly considered the stipulated documents and made an appropriate award based on Wifeâ€™s request.Â  
In this case, the overall distribution was 50 percent.Â  We find, given the statutory factors, that this distribution is fair and equitable.Â  Given the length of the marriage, the value of the marital property, and the incomes of both parties, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in its distribution of the marital property, including Husbandâ€™s Tier II retirement benefits.Â  In identifying, valuing, and apportioning the property, the family court relied upon the testimony and stipulations from both parties.Â  After examination of both the partiesâ€™ testimony and the fifteen statutory factors listed in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472, it is clear the family court divided the marital property in a fair manner.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In its final order, the family court rounded Wifeâ€™s award up to 38 percent.Â  Although Husband mentions this in his appeal, he does not specifically take exception to it, and thus, it has become the law of the case.Â  Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Trident Constr. Co., 355 S.C. 605, 610, 586 S.E.2d 581, 584 (2003) (holding unappealed portion of judgment becomes the law of the case).

PER CURIAM:Â  Roy Steven Grindle appeals his convictions for involuntary manslaughter and possession of a sawed-off shotgun.Â  Grindleâ€™s appellate argues on appeal that the trial court should have directed a verdict of acquittal.Â  Counsel attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating she reviewed the record and concluded Grindleâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Grindle filed a pro se response alleging the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to try him for possession of a sawed-off shotgun.
