THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(1), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In The Interest of John Thomas E., Jr. A Minor Under The Age of Seventeen,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-214
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bruce A. Byrholdt,Â  of Anderson, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: John Thomas E., Jr. appeals from his adjudication of delinquency, arguing the family court failed to direct a verdict of acquittal on two charges of auto breaking and two counts of petit larceny.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On February 20, 2001, a bus driver called the Clemson University campus police to report a suspicious vehicle in one of the University parking lots.Â  The driver observed the vehicle, a white Ford Explorer, on row four of a residential parking lot at 12:45 a.m.Â  Approximately five minutes later, the Explorer was idling on row ten of the lot, but its lights had been turned off. Thinking the occupants in the vehicle might need a ride to another campus location, the bus driver stopped in an adjacent row and opened the bus door.Â  Once the door opened, the driver of the Explorer turned on the lights, drove in reverse down row ten, and turned out of the parking lot. 
Campus police officers, who were responding to the bus driverâ€™s call, saw the Explorer exiting another campus parking lot.Â  One officer, Officer Smith, stopped the vehicle, and explained to the driver what had been reported.Â  Smith further explained that numerous cars had recently been broken into while parked in campus lots, and in an effort to â€œclear this up very quickly,â€ asked if he could search the vehicle.Â  The driver consented to a search.
To conduct the search, Officer Smith asked the other two occupants in the Explorer to step out of the vehicle.Â  Appellant John Thomas was the front seat passenger. 
Inside the vehicle, Officer Smith found two car radios and numerous tools lying on the floor in the back seat.Â  In the front of the car, he found a â€œwindow busting toolâ€ and miscellaneous car parts on the floor in front of the passengerâ€™s seat. 
As Officer Smith searched the vehicle, two other officers who were on the scene separated the occupants of the vehicle.Â  Appellant requested to speak with Officer Smith.Â  Upon this request, he was brought to Officer Smithâ€™s car, where he made a statement. 
In this statement, Appellant admitted to sneaking out of his house and driving to Wal-Mart with his two friends.Â  He claimed they were going to the Wal-Mart parking lot to play with a remote control car.Â  Because the remote control car broke, they left Wal-Mart and went to the Clemson parking lots where his friends broke into a number of vehicles.Â  Appellant then rode with Officer Smith and pointed out three vehicles in three different lots that had been broken into.Â  
While riding with Officer Smith, Appellant continued to talk about the events of that evening.Â  Appellant explained that he was playing with his remote control car in a University parking lot when he heard a crash and then saw his friend running towards him with a car radio under his shirt.Â  At some point during the car ride with Officer Smith, Appellant also claimed that his friends had dropped him off at a store for approximately forty-five minutes while they stole a moped and went joyriding.Â  His friends then picked him back up, and all three proceeded to a strip mall parking lot where his friends broke into several cars.Â  After doing that, they proceeded to the campus parking lots.
Officer Smith testified that Appellant explained to him that he needed to be in a parking lot to play with his remote control car because the car was very fast and he needed an open area.Â  Both Officer Smith and the bus driver testified that the lots in which cars were broken into were quite full while other lots nearby were virtually empty.
After the State presented its case against Appellant, defense counsel moved for a directed verdict, arguing Appellant was merely present at the crime scene and there was no evidence he had participated in any crime.Â  The family court denied the motion.Â  The defense rested its case without presenting any witnesses, and counsel renewed his motion for directed verdict, which was again denied. 
The family court adjudicated Appellant delinquent, finding beyond a reasonable doubt he was guilty under the doctrine of â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues the trial court erred by failing to direct a verdict of acquittal on all four charges he faced.Â  Specifically, Appellant claims the State failed to prove â€œany overt act by [him] to prove him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt . . .under a theory of the hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  We disagree.
In reviewing the refusal to grant a directed verdict in a criminal case, the evidence is viewed in the light most favorable to the State to determine whether there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â  The court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2000).Â  
â€œUnder the â€˜hand of one is the hand of allâ€™ theory, one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design or purpose.â€ State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 194, 562 S.E.2d 320, 324 (Ct. App. 2002). 
Viewing all the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, we find there was sufficient circumstantial evidence to deny the motion for a directed verdict.Â  A â€œwindow busting toolâ€ was found on the floor in front of the seat in which Appellant was riding when the Explorer was stopped by campus police.Â  Furthermore, Appellantâ€™s story about playing with his remote control car while his friends broke into cars was suspect considering he had told the officer that his remote control car had become broken in the Wal-Mart parking lot and considering the testimony of the bus driver who saw the Explorer inching its way around a parking lot as if the occupants were carefully choosing which cars to break into.Â  Furthermore, if Appellant were merely playing with his remote control car, there would be no reason to move from one parking lot to another, especially when each of those lots were nearly full with parked cars and other nearby lots were empty.Â  Appellantâ€™s ability to directly lead Officer Smith to each vehicle also suggests he was actively involved in the crime spree.
All of the foregoing is substantial circumstantial evidence supporting the Stateâ€™s theory that Appellant and his friends shared a common intent to break into vehicles when they drove to three different parking lots at Clemson University with a â€œwindow busting toolâ€ in their vehicle.Â  Therefore, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s denial of Appellantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s finding of delinquency is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
JoAnn C. Hardin,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Thomas L. Hardin, and Cheryl Hardin f/k/a Cheryl D. Watts,       
Defendants,
Of whom Thomas L. Hardin is the,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-215
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James W. Boyd, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Jane M. Randall and Thomas F. McDow,both of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Thomas L. Hardin (Husband) appeals from the final order of the family court awarding JoAnn C. Hardin (Wife) one-half of the partiesâ€™ retirement accounts, alimony in the amount of $400 per month, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The parties married in 1984 and separated in 1993.Â  While still married to Wife, Husband entered a â€œceremonial marriageâ€ with defendant Cheryl Watts.Â  Wife filed an action in 2001, seeking a divorce on the grounds of adultery, alimony, equitable division of the marital property, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Watts was named a defendant due to her joint ownership with Husband of property, which Wife sought to have declared marital property.Â  
The family court granted Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  The court determined the partiesâ€™ retirement accounts were the only marital property to be divided.Â  The court divided the accounts equally, with Wife retaining her account and being entitled to a share of Husbandâ€™s larger account.Â  Wife was awarded $400 in alimony and $3,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.      
Equitable Division of Retirement Accounts
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding Wife over $16,000 in Husbandâ€™s retirement funds because the parties were separated for over ten years.Â  Additionally, he contends the family court failed to properly consider the fifteen relevant factors for equitably dividing the partiesâ€™ marital property.Â  We disagree. 
First, we note these issues may not be preserved for appellate review.Â  While Husband contested the equitable division during trial, he never specifically raised the issue of the family courtâ€™s failure to consider the fifteen factors under section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) or Wifeâ€™s lack of contribution to the retirement accounts.Â  After receiving the order, he was required to raise the issues before the family court in a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rules 52 and 59, SCRCP.Â  See Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 625, 576 S.E.2d 156, 163 (2003) (finding issue raised for the first time on appeal is not preserved for review by appellate court when it could have been raised by a Rule 59(e) motion).
Additionally, the claim fails on its merits.Â  The family courtâ€™s order specifically stated:Â  â€œ[t]hat due to the length of the marriage . . . being over nineteen (19) years, the marital property should be divided equally.Â  All assets . . . were acquired during the partiesâ€™ marriage and both parties made contributions, either directly or indirectly, to their accumulation.â€Â  Additionally, the court noted the considerations â€œgoverning equitable apportionment of property are governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-471, et seq (1985).â€Â  These considerations would include the factors listed under section 20-7-472.Â  In this regard, we reject Husbandâ€™s invitation to concentrate on the factor of his direct contributions to the exclusion of the other statutory factors.
Finally, based on our independent review of the record, we find the family court acted well within its discretion in equally dividing the partiesâ€™ retirement accounts.Â  This was a nineteen-year marriage.Â  Even though the parties were separated for a number of years, â€œa marriage is not terminated as of the date the parties separate . . . .â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family court is statutorily mandated to identify and value the marital estate â€œas of the date of commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§20-7-473 (Supp. 2004); Shannon v. Shannon, 301 S.C. 107, 111, 390 S.E.2d 380, 382-83 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Thus, even if this issue were preserved for review, the equitable division established by the family court is appropriate and is affirmed.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony
Husband asserts the family court erred in calculating the financial needs of Wife and in awarding her $400 in alimony.Â  We disagree.
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The family court judge may grant alimony in an amount and for a term as the judge considers appropriate under the circumstances.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2004).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Factors considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004).Â  No one factor is dispositive.Â  Lide v. Lide, 277 S.C. 155, 157, 283 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1981).Â  While it is preferable for the trial court to discuss all relevant factors, we may still affirm if we can discern from the record that the trial court properly considered all appropriate statutory factors.Â  See Doe v. Doe, 319 S.C. 151, 156, 459 S.E.2d 892, 895 (Ct. App. 1995).
The family court specifically enumerated the factors for making an award of alimony.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130 (Supp. 2004).Â  In its findings, the court focused on the greater income earned by Husband compared to Wifeâ€™s income.Â  Additionally, Wifeâ€™s health impacts her current and future earnings.Â  Finally, the court calculated that Wife had a deficit of approximately $300 per month after subtracting her expenses from her income.
Husband contends the calculation was in error because it included a period of time in which Wife did not work.Â  However, while her income may have been higher if she had worked during the entire period, it was clear from the testimony that her health will continue to impact her ability to earn to her maximum potential.Â  Wife also testified $22,687 was the most she ever made and that was with working overtime.Â  Her financial declaration shows almost $22,000 in income.Â  We find the amount listed on her financial declaration and the amount used by the court in its calculations are supported by the evidence in the record.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife $400 per month in alimony, and the award is affirmed.
III.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband maintains the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife because the equitable division should be reversed and because a portion of the litigation involved Watts.Â  We disagree.
Attorneyâ€™s fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the family court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless there is an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee, the beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).
The trial court specifically found the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was proper because of Husbandâ€™s adulterous conduct, his greater ability to pay compared to Wife, and the beneficial results obtained by Wife.Â  Based upon the record, we agree with the findings of the family court.Â  
Husband points to Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993), in which the South Carolina Supreme Court found an award of attorneyâ€™s fees â€œshould be reduced by the amount of hourly fees incurred in litigating . . . an issue litigated solely between Wife and a third party.â€Â  However, while Watts was named as a party, the record reveals her involvement was minor during the course of trial.Â  Watts was named because she, along with Husband, owned an interest in property in which Wife sought a determination of whether it was marital property. The issue was not litigated solely between Wife and a third party, but was based upon Husbandâ€™s ownership of the property.Â  Additionally, Husband failed to demonstrate the inclusion of Watts in the litigation increased the fee incurred by Wife.Â  In any event, the joinder of Watts was necessitated by Husbandâ€™s purported marriage to Watts.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s award of $3,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.
CONCLUSION
The decision of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Hiott v. Kelly
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Margaret R. Hiott, Appellant,
v.
Gerald W. Kelly and Elizabeth R. Kelly, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-216
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Sherwood M. Cleveland, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Jack M. Scoville, Jr., of Georgetown, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Margaret R. Hiott appeals from an order of the master-in-equity denying her claim for breach of a contract to sell real property, in which the master held Hiott failed to deliver marketable title.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
On March 3, 1999, Hiott entered into a contract with Gerald and Elizabeth Kelly for the sale of her residence on Pawleys Island.Â  Closing was to take place on April 26, 1999.Â  The sale price was $728,000.Â  The contract did not expressly provide that time was of the essence.Â  The Kellys provided $25,000 in earnest money, which was held in an escrow account.
This dispute arose when a title search revealed a handwritten notation by the Georgetown County Clerk of Court in the grantor index indicating that a 1976 deed in Hiottâ€™s chain of title was of no legal effect.Â  The notation referenced case number 78-CP-22-356, a quiet title action concerning a dispute over ownership of certain property located at Magnolia Beach, a tract of land opposite Pawleys Island.Â  In that action, referred to as the Bultman action, title to the disputed property had been confirmed in plaintiffs W.F. Bultman and Anna Birnie McDonald against defendants Arthur L. Barber, Jr. and James A. Wilder and others.Â  
On April 20, 1999, counsel for the Kellys notified Hiottâ€™s closing attorney of the title issue.Â  The Kellysâ€™ counsel opined that the notations in the index rendered the subject property unmarketable.Â  Hiottâ€™s closing attorney referred the matter to an attorney who had represented Hiott in the past.Â  On April 23, the new attorney wrote to the Kellysâ€™ counsel reassuring them that title was marketable and that he was prepared to issue an ownerâ€™s title insurance on the property.Â  Closing did not occur as scheduled on April 26.Â  On April 27, Hiottâ€™s counsel wrote to the clerk of court requesting she review the Bultman file and remove the notation from the deed in Hiottâ€™s chain of title.Â  The next day, the Kellysâ€™ counsel wrote back, raising a number of title concerns.Â  He noted the clerkâ€™s office had made a decision to not remove the notation from the index.Â  The letter concluded by opining that title to the property was not marketable and the Kellys were unwilling to close.Â  He informed Hiottâ€™s counsel that he would be out of town from April 28 until May 3. 
That same day, Hiottâ€™s counsel responded, again taking the position that title to the property was marketable.Â  In the letter, he stated that he was considering the Kellysâ€™ letter of that date as demonstrating an intent to rescind the contract.Â  He warned that if closing did not occur by May 3, he would advise Hiott to â€œresell the property at the Kellyâ€™s risk.â€ However, he also suggested they â€œexplore some reasonable logical solution to this problem[.]â€
On May 5, the clerk of court told Hiottâ€™s counsel in a telephone conversation that the notations would be removed and followed up with a confirmation letter the next day.Â  Hiottâ€™s counsel immediately notified the Kellysâ€™ counsel.Â  The Kellys, however, refused to close as they were no longer interested in the property.Â  At that time, the Kellys had not obligated themselves to purchase any other property.Â  Hiott subsequently sold the property for $675,000. 
Hiott then brought an action seeking damages for breach of contract.Â  The case was referred by consent order to the master-in-equity.Â  The master issued a decree finding that Hiott had failed to deliver marketable title, that the removal of the notations by the clerk of court was insufficient to make the title marketable, and that, in any case, the problem was not corrected within a reasonable time.Â  Hiott filed a timely motion to alter or amend.Â  After hearing the matter, the master issued an amended decree finding only that the notation on the grantor index made the title unmarketable and thus the Kellys did not breach the contract.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action seeking money damages for breach of a land sale contract is an action at law.Â  Sanders v. Coastal Capital Ventures, Inc., 296 S.C. 132, 134, 370 S.E.2d 903, 905 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In an action at law tried by a master alone, our scope of review is limited to correction of errors of law, and we will affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings unless there is no evidence reasonably supporting them.Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 388, 496 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The primary issue on appeal is whether the master correctly found that title to the property was unmarketable.Â  The question of whether a title is marketable is one of law for the court to determine.Â  77 Am. Jur. 2d Vendor and Purchaser Â§ 137 (2004).Â  â€œIt is axiomatic that a purchaser cannot be required to take a doubtful title.â€Â  Sales Intâ€™l Ltd. v. Black River Farms, Inc., 270 S.C. 391, 398, 242 S.E.2d 432, 435 (1978).Â  However, â€œ[t]o be marketable, a title need not be flawless.â€Â  Gibbs v. G.K.H., Inc., 311 S.C. 103, 105, 427 S.E.2d 701, 702 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Instead, title is marketable if it is â€œfree from encumbrances and any reasonable doubt to its validity.Â  It is a title which a reasonable purchaser, well-informed as to the facts and their legal significance, is ready and willing to accept.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe mere, bare possibility, or remote probabilities, that there may be litigation with respect to the title is not sufficient to render it unmarketable.Â  There must be a reasonable probability of litigation.â€Â  Sales Intâ€™l, 270 S.C. at 398, 242 S.E.2d at 435 (quoting 57 A.L.R. 1253, 1307-08 (1928)).Â  
The Kellys challenge marketability by asserting that the facts of the Bultman case and the notations in the grantorâ€™s index produced a sufficient cloud on Hiottâ€™s title to render it unmarketable.Â  
The Bultman action involved a title dispute over property known as Magnolia Beach.Â  W.F. Bultman, Anna Birnie McDonald, and Bultmanâ€™s father purchased the disputed property at a partition sale.Â  The partition deed, dated May 4, 1960, described the subject property as follows:

ALL that tract or parcel of land situate in Township No. 7, County of Georgetown, State of South Carolina, known as Magnolia Beach, constituting a part of Midway Seashore Plantation, containing twenty (20) acres, more or less, bounded on the Northeast by lands of Dr. Henry Norris; Southeast by the Atlantic Ocean, Southwest by a creek separating said Magnolia Beach from Pawleyâ€™s Island; Northwest by lands of Birnie, Bultman and others; and being more fully shown on a plat made by Lawson Oliver, C.E., dated October 30, 1934, as containing 28.8 acres of property, together with 12.5 acres subject to overflow.Â  

This description identifies property lying east of the inlet, between the inlet and the beach.Â  The complaint in Bultman quoted this description in identifying the property to which the plaintiffs sought to quiet title.Â  The supreme court also quoted this description in its opinion.Â  Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 8, 281 S.E.2d 791, 793 (1981).
James A. Wilder and Arthur L. Barber purchased three tracts of property from Donald McKenzie in 1976.Â  In their answer, Wilder and Barber asserted paramount title by referencing all three transactions.Â  Of these three deeds, only one of them involved the disputed area east of Midway inlet known as Magnolia Beach.Â  Wilder and Barber had subdivided their Magnolia Beach property and conveyed some of the lots to others who were made parties to the Bultman case.Â  The other two properties lay west of the inlet.Â  Those properties had already been conveyed to R.S. Cole and Bernice T. Cole, who were not made parties to the Bultman lawsuit, when the action was commenced.Â  Hiottâ€™s title derives from the Coles.Â  
After the trial court granted a directed verdict in favor of Bultman and the other plaintiffs, the supreme court affirmed, finding that the interests of Wilder and Barberâ€™s predecessors in title had been cut off by the partition sale.Â  Bultman, at 9-10, 281 S.E.2d at 794.Â  Upon remand, the trial court issued an order providing that the â€œplaintiffs herein are the owner of all that portion of Magnolia Beach claimed by defendants herein; and the titles thereto held by defendants are of no legal effect and that the records in the office of the Clerk of Court of Georgetown County shall be adjusted to so indicate.â€Â  Counsel for the Bultman plaintiffs wrote the clerk of court requesting that the notation be made regarding a tract of land recorded in â€œDeed Book 144 at page 136â€ and â€œother deeds to the same land executed by defendants.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  Although this letter referenced only the property recorded in Deed Book 144 at page 136, the clerk of court noted that all three 1976 deeds transferring property from McKenzie to Wilder and Barber were of no legal effect in the grantor index.[1]
There is no question that the Bultman action did not involve Hiottâ€™s property and the notation on the grantor index was made in error.Â  The Kellysâ€™ counsel admitted this fact at oral argument.Â  The complaint in Bultman referenced only property east of the inlet.Â  Moreover, the partition deed on which the entire litigation was based contained the same description.Â  Wilder and Barberâ€™s answer did mention the other deeds they received from McKenzie in 1976, but they did not include a counterclaim to put the validity of those deeds at issue.Â  The supreme courtâ€™s opinion and the trial courtâ€™s subsequent order only mention the Magnolia Beach property.Â  Finally, the letter from counsel for the Bultman plaintiffs to the clerk of court contained no reference to Hiottâ€™s property.Â  That letter requested adjustment of the record to reflect the invalidation of the deed recorded in â€œDeed Book 144 at Page 136,â€ the property east of the inlet. Although the letter also requested similar adjustments pertaining to â€œother deeds to the same land executed by defendants,â€ this language clearly refers to the subsequent purchasers of the Magnolia Beach property, who were made parties to the litigation.Â  Therefore, the notations entered concerning the other deeds executed by McKenzie, who was not a defendant, to Wilder and Barber were clearly erroneous.Â  
Furthermore, Hiottâ€™s chain of title could not have been affected by the Bultman action because at the time the litigation was commenced, Hiottâ€™s property had already been conveyed to the Coles, who were not made parties to that case.Â  
We find that a subsequent, erroneous notation in the index of a properly recorded and indexed deed, without more, is insufficient to render title unmarketable.Â  Where, as here, the purchasers could have determined the notations were erroneous by a careful reading of the property descriptions in the referenced case, and the pertinent facts and documents were called to their attention and discussed prior to the closing, the purchasers should not be able to rescind the contract merely by pointing to a technical defect not created by the seller.Â  Allowing rescission under such circumstances would place an undue hardship on sellers, who would be forced to bring quiet title actions to resolve minor defects.Â  
Furthermore, at the very latest, title to Hiottâ€™s title was marketable when the clerk of court corrected the notation in the index.Â  The Kellys assert that the removal of the notation by the clerk of court did not remove the cloud on Hiottâ€™s title because such removal was unauthorized as it was not done with court approval.Â  The clerk of court originally made the notations at the request of the plaintiffâ€™s attorney in Bultman.Â  The request for removal by Hiottâ€™s attorney Moran did not seek to countermand the order of the court in Bultman.Â  It merely pointed out that the notations did not comply with the courtâ€™s order in that case.Â  After considering that matter, the clerk of court agreed and removed the notations.Â  It was merely the clerk of court correcting a prior mistake by the clerk of court. The clerk of court by statute is granted certain discretion in maintaining the record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-9-30 (Supp. 2004).Â  Thus, there was no need for further court action.Â  
The Kellys further argue that even if the removal of the notation cured the marketability problem, it was not done within a reasonable time.Â  The contract did not provide that time was of the essence.Â  â€œIt is well established in this state that time is not of the essence of a contract to convey land unless made so by its terms expressly or by implication.â€Â  Faulkner v. Millar, 319 S.C. 216, 219, 460 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1995).Â  â€œWhen the contract does not include a provision that â€˜time is of the essence,â€™ the law implies that it is to be done within a reasonable time.â€Â  Id.Â  
Hiottâ€™s counsel clearly made every effort to alleviate the problem with the notation on the index within a reasonable time.Â  Hiott was not informed of the problem until April 20, six days before closing.Â  In the flurry of communications over the next several days, Hiott reassured the Kellys that title was marketable, obtained title insurance for the property, explained that the Bultman case had no bearing on the title, and offered to make all her counselâ€™s title notes available to counsel for the Kellys.Â  When the Kellys refused to close, Hiottâ€™s counsel wrote the clerk of court the next day, requesting that the erroneous notations be removed.Â  Although the clerk of court initially refused to remove the notation, Hiottâ€™s counsel persisted and the notations were removed on May 5.Â  Additionally, counsel for the Kellys was out of town for several days during this period.Â  
The Kellys assert that the letter from Hiottâ€™s counsel dated April 28 made time of the essence by implication.Â  This letter concluded as follows:

I take your letter of today as a clear and unequivocal interest to rescind the contract.Â  Mrs. Hiott stands ready, willing and able to close.Â  Given this, I hereby direct the realtors to withhold the [earnest] money.Â  I suspect that your clients do not consent to a release of this money to Mrs. Hiott.Â  If we do not close by 5:00 pm Monday, I will instruct Mrs. Hiott to resell the property at the [Kellysâ€™] risk.
If we agree, for the sake of argument, that your position is correct and title is not marketable, do you agree with me that the seller is contractually granted the right and obligation to cure the defect within a reasonable time?Â  Considering what we both know, do you disagree that a quiet title action will almost certainly be successful?Â  If the answer to both of the preceding questions is in the affirmative, is there any reason for us to explore some reasonable logical solution to this problem?Â  

Although Hiottâ€™s counsel postured in the letter that he would advise Hiott to resell the house if closing did not occur by a certain date, he also inquired about finding a â€œreasonable solution to this problem[.]â€Â  It is apparent that with the letter Hiott was still negotiating to consummate the sale and did not intend to make time of the essence.Â  Thus, we find that as the correction to the notation was made within a reasonable time of the originally scheduled closing, the Kellys were not justified in refusing to close.Â  
CONCLUSION
We conclude the master erred as a matter of law in holding Hiott failed to deliver marketable title to her property.Â  Thus, the Kellys were in breach of their contract with Hiott when they refused to close.Â  We remand for a determination of damages.[2]Â  
 REVERSED and REMANDED. 
 GOOLSBY, HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] The deeds in Hiottâ€™s chain of title were recorded in Deed Book 142 at page 800 and Deed Book 143 at page 274.
[2] Hiottâ€™s complaint sought damages measured by the contract price minus the resale price, plus moving expenses and prejudgment interest.

title: KBR Development v. YANSY Realty
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
KBR Development, LLC, Respondent,
v.
YANSY Realty, Inc. aka YANSY Realty, Inc., Clemson Hospitality Investments, LLC, the BBQ Company, Steve R. Harvey, Robert S. Arnold and Roy S. Arnold,
Defendants,
of whom Clemson Hospitality Investments, LLC, Robert S. Arnold and Roy S. Arnold are
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-217
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James C. Alexander,Â  of Pickens, for Appellants.
Thomas Elihue Dudley, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Clemson Hospitality Investments, LLC (CHI), Robert S. Arnold, and Roy S. Arnold (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal a jury award of $100 to KBR Development, LLC, for breach of contract and past due rent.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â  
 FACTS
    In October of 1999, KBR, developers of a shopping center in Clemson, South Carolina, entered into a lease agreement with YANSY Reality, Inc. and the BBQ Company, Inc.Â  The BBQ Company issued a franchise to CHI to operate a Redâ€™s Backwoods BBQ restaurant in the leased location.Â  CHI, through its members Steve Harvey, Robert Arnold, and Roy Arnold, also signed a guarantee associated with the lease between YANSY, the BBQ Company, and KBR.Â  In addition, Robert Arnold and Steve Harvey signed personal guarantees.Â  
    Both the lease and the guarantee contained provisions allowing KBR to collect attorneyâ€™s fees in the event of litigation between the parties, contingent upon KBRâ€™s success in the proceedings.Â  Another provision of the lease agreement required KBR to build the structure of the building, while the BBQ Company would finance the upfitting.Â  However, the BBQ Company was unable to meet its responsibility because of financial difficulties.Â  Therefore, KBR made an agreement with CHI to upfit the restaurant, guaranteed with a promissory note by CHI in the amount of $190,000, with monthly payments of $3,500 for ten years.Â  
    On January 4, 2002, KBR notified Appellants in writing that the promissory note and the lease were in default and demanded immediate payment.Â  Thereafter, in a meeting between the parties, CHI, through Robert Arnold, agreed to pay $2,500 per week until the rent and note payments were caught up, whereupon he paid $3,000 on January 16, 2002.Â  However, KBR did not receive the $2,500 from CHI the next week.Â  Pursuant to the default provisions under the lease, KBR took possession of the restaurant on January 27, 2002.Â  Upon repossession, KBR turned the restaurant equipment over to Carolina First Bank, who subsequently auctioned off the equipment to pay the secured debt owed by CHI.Â  
    On February 19, 2002, KBR filed a complaint against CHI and its members, alleging breach of contract in regard to the lease agreement and the promissory note, ejectment, and collection of rent by distraint.[2]Â  Appellants counterclaimed alleging unlawful eviction, conversion, and unfair trade practices.Â  KBR motioned for summary judgment for breach of contract concerning the promissory note and the trial court granted partial summary judgment, amounting to an award of $171,738.84 to KBR.Â  The remaining issues went before a jury.Â  At the jury trial, the trial court found as a matter of law that Appellants were liable on the lease, and it directed a verdict against Appellants on their claim for unfair trade practices.Â  The jury awarded $100 to KBR for breach of the lease agreement and further found for KBR on Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims.Â  The trial court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
    LAW/ANALYSIS 
      I.Â  Partial summary judgment
        Appellants claim the trial court erred in awarding partial summary judgment to KBR on its breach of contract claim based on the promissory note.Â  We disagree.
        When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, we apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â 
        â€œWhen determining if any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Id. at 494, 567 S.E.2d at 860.Â  â€œIf triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.â€Â 
        Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Comâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 4, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004).
        Appellants admit they were in default on the promissory note.Â  Appellants also admit they received written notice of default on January 4, 2002.Â  Although Appellants negotiated with KRB to make weekly payments to bring them up to date, they did not make the first $2,500 payment the week immediately following their agreement.Â Â  While the note requires 30 days notice before repossession action may be taken, Appellants were in default from November 2001 and did not attempt to make any other payments after the January 16, 2002 payment, which only partially covered the debt.[3]Â  KBR did not file a complaint to collect on the promissory note until late February 2002.Â  Therefore, KBR complied with the leaseâ€™s notice requirements.Â  
        Appellantsâ€™ also argue that the value of the upfittings and improvements should be credited against the total amount owed under the note.Â  However, Appellants signed a promissory note for $190,000 and there was nothing contained in the note or the lease giving CHI credit for any of the tenant upfits upon expiration of the lease.Â  Therefore, there was no genuine issue of material fact regarding the promissory note and the trial court did not err when granting partial summary judgment for KBR on the breach of contract claim under the promissory note.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
II. 
Unlawful eviction charge
            Appellants claim the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury on the law of unlawful eviction.Â  We disagree.
            â€œA trial court must charge the current and correct law.â€Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 311, 536 S.E.2d 408, 425 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œWhen reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, an appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIf the charge is reasonably free from error, isolated portions, which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Id.
            There is no question that CHI signed and executed a guarantee agreement for the lease between KBR and YANSY and the BBQ Company.Â  Furthermore, Robert Arnold also personally guaranteed the note.Â  According to the guarantee agreement, when YANSY and the BBQ Company failed to make the lease payments, Appellants became responsible.Â  The lease provided KBR with the self-help option of repossessing the property if lease payments were overdue by fifteen days.Â  Therefore, KBR acted within their legal rights, and the trial court charged the correct law in light of the evidence presented at trial.Â Â Â  
            III.Â  Conversion
            Appellants claim the trial court erred in denying their motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and new trial because they were entitled to an award of damages for conversion of their restaurant equipment.Â  We disagree.
            When reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, we apply the same standard as the trial court by viewing the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id. at 299, 536 S.E.2d at 418.Â  â€œThe trial court must deny the motions when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€Â  Id. at 300, 536 S.E.2d at 418.Â  We reverse the trial court only when there is no evidence to support the ruling below.Â  Id.Â  â€œWhen considering directed verdict and JNOV motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.â€Â  Id. at 300, 536 S.E.2d at 419.
            A judge can grant a motion for JNOV only if no reasonable jury could have reached the challenged verdict.Â  Id.Â  A judge will not overturn a juryâ€™s verdict if any evidence exists that sustains the factual findings implicit in its decision.Â  Id.Â  
            â€œA claim for conversion can be based on an unauthorized detention of property, after demand.â€Â  Oxford Finance Companies, Inc. v. Burgess, 303 S.C. 534, 539, 402 S.E.2d 480, 482 (1991).Â  â€œIn order to prevail in a conversion action, the plaintiff must prove either title or right to possession of the property at the time of the conversion.â€Â  Id.Â  Â 
            KBR was in lawful possession of the restaurant at the time it conveyed the equipment to Carolina First Bank.Â  Furthermore, KBR might have subjected itself to liability had it not recognized the collection rights of the bank.[4]Â  Therefore, there was substantial evidence for the trial court to deny a directed verdict for the Appellantsâ€™ on their counterclaim for conversion and for the jury to reach their verdict for KBR on the conversion claim.
            IV.Â  Attorneyâ€™s fees
            Appellants also claim the trial court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to KBR.Â  We disagree. 
            Generally, the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to be awarded is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â 
            Burton v. York County Sheriffâ€™s Dept., 358 S.C. 339, 357, 594 S.E.2d 888, 897 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, the award of fees must be reasonable and supported by adequate findings.Â  Id.
            The trial court considers six factors when determining an award of attorneyâ€™s fees: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Id. at 358, 594 S.E.2d at 897.Â  If the requested attorneyâ€™s fees are authorized by contract or statute, the trial court should make specific findings of fact on the record for each of these factors.Â  Id.  
            The jury found for KBR for breach of the lease and in respect to all of Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims, making KBR the prevailing party in the litigation.[5]Â  Furthermore, Appellants signed a guarantee of â€œthe lease agreements . . . in case of default by the BBQ Company.â€Â  Also, Robert Arnold executed a personal guarantee of the lease.Â Â Â  
            The provisions of the lease entitled the prevailing party to recover attorneyâ€™s fees and costs associated with the litigation as follows:

            In the event that at any time during the term of this Lease either Landlord or Tenant shall institute any action or proceeding against the other, then, and in that event, the unsuccessful party in such action or proceeding agrees to reimburse the successful party for the reasonable expenses of attorneyâ€™s fees and disbursements incurred therein by the successful party.

            In addition, the promissory note, which the trial court issued summary judgment for, also included a provision providing attorneyâ€™s fees at 15% of the balance due in connection with the collection of the note.Â  Also, KBR requested attorneyâ€™s fees in its complaint.
            The trial court thoroughly discussed the factors to be considered when awarding attorneyâ€™s fees in its order.Â  â€œBased on the pleadings in the record, the Memorandum of Law with attached exhibits submitted by [KBR],â€ which included analysis of these factors, the trial court found that an award of attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $23,972.75 in costs to KBR was reasonable and appropriate.Â  Furthermore, the award was substantially less than 15% of the balance due on the promissory note, which is the amount contracted to by the parties in the event of default on the note.Â  Thus, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to
            KBR.    
             AFFIRMED.
            ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Steve Harvey subsequently filed bankruptcy and was discharged from the action.
[3] KBR repossessed the restaurant on January 27, 2002 because Appellantsâ€™ rent was in default.Â  The lease provided that the Landlord could â€œenter upon and take possession of the Premisesâ€ if failure to pay continued â€œfor a period of fifteen (15) days.â€Â  
[4] See Oxford Finance Companies, Inc. v. Burgess, 303 S.C. 534, 402 S.E.2d 480 (1991) (holding a landlord, who refused to turn over an ejected tenantâ€™s collateral to a secured lender, could be liable to lender for conversion and possible punitive damages).
[5] A prevailing party is â€œone who successfully prosecutes the action or successfully defends against it, prevailing on the main issue, even though not to the extent of the original contention [and] is the one in whose favor the decision or verdict is rendered and judgment entered.â€Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182-83, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990).Â

title: Kirchner v. Kirchner
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Barbara J. Kirchner, Respondent,
v.
Allen W. Kirchner, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion 2005-UP-218
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART,
REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Victoria L. Eslinger and Dennis J. Lynch, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Michael Taylor, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from a grant of divorce to Barbara J. Kirchner (â€œWifeâ€) from Allen W. Kirchner (â€œHusbandâ€).Â  Husband appeals the family courtâ€™s decision apportioning certain portions of the marital estate, awarding alimony in the amount of $3,800 per month, admitting the testimony of Wifeâ€™s rebuttal witness, holding Husband in contempt, and awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]Â  
FACTS
Wife and Husband, a physician, were married in February of 1985.Â  In March of 2000, after years of discord, Wife filed for a divorce based on the ground of adultery.Â  She also sought several restraining orders, alimony, equitable distribution, AIDS testing, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In a temporary agreement reached by the parties and approved by the family court, Husband agreed to pay Wife $4,200 a month.Â  In February 2002, Husband filed a motion to reduce alimony and support obligations because he was no longer an employed member of his practice and no longer received a salary.Â  Wife filed for contempt and a rule to show cause for Husbandâ€™s failure to pay the temporary alimony and the auto insurance agreed upon in the pendente lite order.Â  
Prior to the final hearing, the parties reached a settlement agreement regarding the distribution of all the marital property except for possession of the family dog, Sam.Â  The family court approved the property settlement agreement between the parties.Â  The court also granted Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery, gave possession of Sam to Wife, found Husband in contempt for failing to pay the temporary alimony, and awarded Wife permanent alimony of $3,800 per month and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband appeals.Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Hilton Head condominium distribution
Husband claims the family court erred in equally dividing the contents of the Hilton Head condominium between the parties because the property settlement agreement, approved by the court, awarded 60 percent from the proceeds of the sale of the property to Husband and the remainder to Wife.Â  We agree.[2]
Litigants in this state have consistently been encouraged by our courts to reach extra-judicial agreements on issues arising out of the marital relationship, when possible, to enhance judicial efficiency.Â  Drawdy v. Drawdy, 275 S.C. 76, 78, 268 S.E.2d 30, 31 (1980).Â  Nevertheless, the family court has the duty to determine whether any such agreement was entered into freely and voluntarily and whether it was fair.Â  Funderburk v. Funderburk, 286 S.C. 129, 131, 332 S.E.2d 205, 206 (1985).Â  Further, the family court must only determine whether the agreement is within the bounds of reasonableness from both a procedural and substantive perspective when determining if the agreement is fair.Â  The court should not determine the partiesâ€™ rights as if there had been no agreement.Â  Burnett v. Burnett, 290 S.C. 28, 30, 347 S.E.2d 908, 909 (Ct. App. 1986).
The parties submitted a property settlement agreement disposing of the entirety of their marital property with the exception of the dog, Sam.Â  The parties specifically described the nature of the agreement regarding the distribution of the Hilton Head condominium:

So far as the Hilton Head condominium is concerned, there are four sets of items that are nonmarital property of the husbandâ€™s. . . . Marital property, the husband will get the couch, the Wife will get the six-drawer white chest.Â  The rest of the furniture in the condominium is to be sold in a reasonable manner, probably through Mr. Watts or some other estate service, and the proceeds split 60 percent to the husband, 40 percent to the wife.

The court received the agreement into evidence, questioned the parties extensively about the agreement and its voluntariness, and subsequently approved it.Â  The court also made certain the parties understood that the division of the property pursuant to the settlement agreement would be final.Â  The court specifically noted during the hearing that it recognized the 60/40 division of the Hilton Head condominium.Â Â  
Wifeâ€™s attorney submitted a proposed order.Â  Although the court had previously approved the 60/40 property settlement agreement, the proposed order indicated that the Hilton Head property was to be divided 50/50.Â  Prior to the issuance of the order, Husbandâ€™s attorney wrote to the family court judge and indicated the proposed order did not comport with the settlement agreement of the parties.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney, however, indicated in correspondence that after the final hearing, Husband took everything out of the Hilton Head condominium, instead of the few agreed upon items, and offered to recompense Wife by giving her 50 percent instead of the previously agreed upon 40 percent.Â  The family court approved the proposed order.Â  
Reviewing the evidence in the record, we find the family court erred in ordering an equal division of the Hilton Head condominium.Â  The only agreement before the court was that Husband would take certain specified items from the condominium and the parties would divide the value of it 60/40.Â  Nothing regarding a subsequent agreement was presented to the court.Â  Therefore, the courtâ€™s order regarding the division of the condominium is reversed.Â  We remand this issue for a hearing before the family court to determine whether a subsequent agreement between the parties occurred and to award the proper distribution to the parties. 
II. Alimony
Husband claims the family court erred in awarding $3,800 per month in permanent alimony.Â  He argues the courtâ€™s findings were not supported by the record and failed to consider both partiesâ€™ reasonably anticipated income, the partiesâ€™ health, and Wifeâ€™s needs.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support that is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  However, alimony should not â€œserve as a disincentive for spouses to improve their employment potential or to dissuade them from providing, to the extent possible, for their own support.â€Â  Id.Â  
Factors to be considered in making an alimony award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2004).Â  
Evidence was presented regarding the partiesâ€™ employment and health histories.Â  Wife testified that she met Husband while she was employed full-time as a registered nurse.Â  During the marriage, Wife never worked more than part-time, and she did not work at all after the early 1990â€™s.Â  She testified that she would need some amount of continuing education to go back to nursing.Â  Wife suffered from major depression, high cholesterol, and mitral valve prolapse, which she controlled with medication.Â  She was constantly fatigued and could not concentrate because of depression.Â  In fact, her psychiatrist testified that Wife â€œhad a difficult time sequencing things in order to make reasonable decisions. . . .Â  If we are talking about a high degree of ability to reason and make adequate judgments at times, that is clearly impaired in [his] observations of [Wife].â€Â  Husband submitted the testimony of a vocational expert to show that Wife was potentially employable in the nursing field, though she admittedly did not evaluate Wifeâ€™s personal situation other than contacting the South Carolina Board of Nursing.Â Â  
Prior to their separation, the parties enjoyed a comfortable lifestyle, including living in the $700,000 marital home and taking several vacations a year.Â  After the separation, Wife moved to a small apartment and suffered from depression.Â  Wifeâ€™s financial declaration indicated that she incurred $3,306.54 in monthly expenses.Â  
Husband was a successful physician with Aiken Obstetrics and Gynecology Associates, P.A.Â  After twenty-five years, he retired in September 2002 because a neurological disorder in his hand rendered him unable to perform surgeries.Â  However, his financial situation was strong.Â  He received a tax-free disability stipend of $7,800 per month, considerably more than his $60,000 annual salary as an office gynecologist.Â  He also received a property award in the divorce of approximately $1 million, including the marital home, and had access to an additional $800,000 in non-marital assets.Â  He admitted on cross-examination that despite his neurological deficit, he was still capable of employment as an office gynecologist.Â  Furthermore, he spent upwards of 100 hours per month volunteering as a deputy sheriff, proving he was capable of gainful employment in some capacity.Â Â  
Evidence regarding Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct and ability to maintain his standard of living was also presented.Â  Husband admitted that he began an adulterous relationship with Teresa Ellis seven months before he and Wife separated.Â  He continued this relationship, and Ellis and her son moved into the former marital residence, where Husband provided Ellisâ€™ living expenses, automobile insurance, health and life insurance, and shopping expenses.Â  Ellis was also unemployed and was no longer receiving unemployment checks at the time of the final hearing.Â  After his retirement in September 2002, Husband continued to pay the mooring and the maintenance on his fatherâ€™s boat, transferred property worth $80,000 to his son for no consideration and in violation of the pendente lite order, and purchased Ellis a $1,000 mink coat and a $1,800 diamond bezel for her Rolex watch.Â  
Based on the evidence presented to the family court, we find the family court adequately considered all the statutory factors, including the partiesâ€™ employment histories and Husbandâ€™s misconduct, in determining alimony.Â  Although the evidence indicated that Wife could become employable, the evidence also indicated that her lifestyle was substantially diminished by the divorce while Husbandâ€™s remained unchanged.Â  Despite Husbandâ€™s argument that alimony should be lowered because he was unemployed, the evidence indicated that Husband could substantially improve his financial status by electing to return to practice as an office gynecologist.Â  The evidence also showed that Husband had access to substantial resources and could easily pay the ordered alimony while maintaining his standard of living.Â  See McMurtrey v. McMurtrey, 272 S.C. 118, 121, 249 S.E.2d 503, 505 (1978) (noting that there is â€œno limitation that alimony payments be made solely from current earningsâ€).Â  Because the family court adequately considered the factors, we find no abuse of discretion in awarding alimony to Wife in the amount of $3,800 per month.Â Â  
III. Sam
Husband claims the family court erred in awarding the dog, Sam, to Wife.Â  We disagree.
Family pets are considered personal property.Â  See Richardson v. Florida Cent. & P.R. Co., 55 S.C. 334, 335, 33 S.E. 466, 466 (1899) (â€œThere is no longer any room to doubt that a dog is personal property in this State.â€).Â  The apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bungener v. Bungener, 291 S.C. 247, 251, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Section 20-7-472 lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning a marital estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004); Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  On appeal, this court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment. Â Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that the appellate court would have arrived at a different apportionment.Â  Id.Â Â  
The evidence elicited at the final hearing showed that Wife purchased Sam and named him.Â  She also was the dogâ€™s primary caretaker, including taking him to his veterinary appointments.Â  Wife testified as to her extreme emotional attachment to the dog, and Wifeâ€™s daughter confirmed this testimony.Â  Furthermore, Husband recognized Wifeâ€™s ownership of the dog because he would notify her when he was taking the dog out of town with him.Â  In addition, whereas Wife had ownership of the dog upon separation, Husband seized the dog from the kennel Wife had boarded him at and had not allowed Wife access to the dog since that time.Â  Thus, there was sufficient evidence in the record that showed Sam belonged primarily to Wife.Â  Most importantly, Husband retained approximately $800,000 of non-marital assets and obtained 60 percent of the marital assets from this divorce, including the family home.Â  Therefore, we find no abuse of discretion in awarding the dog to Wife.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
IV. Appropriate rebuttal witness
Husband claims the family court erred in allowing Wifeâ€™s psychiatric expert to testify as a rebuttal witness to Husbandâ€™s vocational expert.Â  We disagree.
We recognize that the admission of reply testimony is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  Vernon v. Provident Life & Accident Ins. Co., 266 S.C. 208, 222, 222 S.E.2d 501, 508 (1976).Â  â€œFurther, the rules of discovery were designed to promote the full examination of all relevant facts and issues and to discourage litigants from surprising one another through the introduction of unexpected testimony.â€Â  Kramer v. Kramer, 323 S.C. 212, 217, 473 S.E.2d 846, 848 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In order to encourage compliance with discovery rules, courts can impose sanctions upon parties who violate them, including the exclusion of witnesses whose identities have been withheld.Â  Id.Â  However, because exclusion of a witness is a severe sanction, it should only be imposed after the court inquires into:Â  â€œ(1) the type of witness involved; (2) the content of the evidence to be presented; (3) the nature of the failure to identify the witness; and (4) the degree of surprise to the other party.â€Â  Id. at 217, 473 S.E.2d at 848-49.
Wife testified regarding her ailments, including a heart condition, depression, anxiety, and fatigue, as well as the hurdles she would have to overcome in order to return to her former employment as a nurse.Â  During the presentation of Husbandâ€™s case, his vocational expert testified as to the employment positions available to Wife based on her educational level, experience, skills, and abilities.Â  However, the expert admitted that she did not take into consideration Wifeâ€™s mental and physical condition, though she reviewed the health records.Â  Following her deposition, the expert, who admittedly â€œhad already formulated her opinionâ€ as to Wifeâ€™s employability, reviewed Wifeâ€™s psychological and psychiatric records.Â  She then stated that â€œif [Wife] was psychologically incapable or psychiatrically incapable of doing the job of a registered nurse,â€ it may affect her employability.Â  Over Husbandâ€™s objection, Wife presented the testimony of her treating psychiatrist as an expert in reply.Â  The expert testified that Wifeâ€™s skills and abilities were limited because of her depression and mitral valve prolapse condition, thereby severely restricting her employment capabilities.Â Â  
Husband argues it was error for the family court to allow Wifeâ€™s expert to testify to matters that should have been presented in her case in chief.Â  We agree that Wife broached the topic of her inability to obtain employment during her presentation of the evidence, and it would have been appropriate for her to present her expert to testify regarding her employment prospects at that time.Â  However, Husbandâ€™s expert testified regarding the general ability of someone with a nursing license to obtain employment.Â  Wife was able to present an expert to reply to this evidence by testifying about Wifeâ€™s specific abilities.Â  Although Wife did not specifically note the expert on her witness list prior to the start of trial, she obtained the expert during the six week break in the trial.Â  Further, because Wifeâ€™s expert responded to Husbandâ€™s expert in reply, we find no prejudice or surprise and, thus, the family court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the reply testimony.Â  
V. Contempt
Husband claims the family court erred in finding him in contempt of the pendente lite order because he was unable to pay.Â  We disagree.
Although a determination of contempt is within the family courtâ€™s discretion, an order holding a party in contempt â€œshould be reversed when the holding is based on a finding that is without evidentiary support or when there is . . . an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Means v. Means, 277 S.C. 428, 431, 288 S.E.2d 811, 812-13 (1982).Â  To sustain a finding of contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to acts or conduct upon which the finding is based.Â  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 918 (1982).
If a valid court order exists, a person who is obligated to pay alimony can be held in contempt of court for not paying the required amount on time.Â  There must be a finding of willful contempt.Â  Id.Â  When the contemnor is unable to pay, he should not be held in contempt.Â  Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 381, 312 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
The temporary order memorialized the partiesâ€™ agreement whereby Husband would provide $4,200 per month in temporary alimony to Wife and pay her automobile insurance until a final order.[3]Â  Husband admitted that despite the pendente lite order, he only paid Wife $3,300 in February of 2002 and thereafter.Â  He also dropped Wife from his automobile insurance policy.Â  Husband claimed he could not afford the alimony payments because he lost his job due to illness.Â  However, Husband had access to approximately $1.8 million worth of both non-marital and marital property after the equitable division.Â  He also received $7,800 per month of nontaxable income from his disability policy.Â  Furthermore, in absolute defiance of the court order, he transferred property worth $80,000 to his son for no consideration.Â  Lastly, Husband was supporting his paramour and her son through lodging, car maintenance, credit card purchases, automobile insurance, and numerous gifts, including a mink coat and a diamond bezel for a Rolex watch.Â  The family court found Husband in contempt for purposefully reducing Wifeâ€™s alimony payments in violation of the court order because Husband â€œhad the means, but not the inclination, to obey the Order of this Court.â€Â  
Husband willfully reduced Wifeâ€™s alimony prior to obtaining a new order reducing the amount of alimony.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in holding Husband in contempt.
VI. Attorneyâ€™s fees Â Â Â Â  
Husband claims the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs because her motion for attorneyâ€™s fees was untimely and there was no other evidence in the record to support the award.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â  
â€œThe award of attorney fees is within the discretion of the court.â€Â  Hardwick v. Hardwick, 303 S.C. 256, 261, 399 S.E.2d 791, 794 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained by their attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 815 (1992).Â  Furthermore, once the court decides to award attorneyâ€™s fees, it must determine a reasonable award.Â  The court should look at several factors, including the difficulty of the case, the time involved, the professional standing of the counsel, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  
Testimony in this case was held on January 31, 2002, February 4, 2002, and March 22, 2002.Â  During trial, Wifeâ€™s attorney asked permission to submit an affidavit for attorneyâ€™s fees at the end of the case â€œso [they could] incorporate the present trial time.â€Â  Husband did not have an objection to this request to hold the record open.Â  Wife also testified as to her attorneyâ€™s retainer of $15,000 and his hourly rate of $200.00.Â  After Wife finished her case-in-chief, there was a six-week period during which she was allowed to depose one of Husbandâ€™s experts.Â  Unfortunately, the clerk of court misplaced some exhibits in the case, and the parties agreed to recreate the record after both sides concluded testimony.Â  Furthermore, the court requested the parties submit briefs addressing Husbandâ€™s request for the reduction of temporary alimony and the rule to show cause.Â Â  
The court requested that Wife draft a final order on April 29, 2002.Â  On May 6, 2002, Wifeâ€™s counsel submitted an affidavit in support of Wifeâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, noting that counsel was very experienced in marital matters and had incurred $32,911.25 in the case.Â  Husband moved to strike the affidavit in support of attorneyâ€™s fees, arguing that:Â  Wife rested her case without presenting any evidence regarding attorneyâ€™s fees; Wife failed to reserve the right to present additional evidence on the matter; and Wife waived any request for fees by not addressing it in the final hearing.Â  It does not appear from the record that a hearing was ever held on Husbandâ€™s motion to strike.Â  Nevertheless, the family court awarded Wife $16,455.62 in attorneyâ€™s fees in the final decree of divorce.Â Â  
Husband complains about the timing of the affidavit in support of the attorneyâ€™s fees.[4]Â  Although the usual practice certainly is to submit affidavits in support of attorneyâ€™s fees during the trial of a matter, we find the affidavit was timely submitted in the present case.Â  Husband agreed to allow Wife to submit her affidavit in support of attorneyâ€™s fees after the case, in order to include time expended on the trial.Â  Wifeâ€™s attorney was required to spend more time after testimony was completed to reconstruct the record and draft responses to various motions.Â  Further, Wifeâ€™s affidavit in support of attorneyâ€™s fees was submitted before a final order was signed and before the case was concluded by resolution of the issues.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in considering the affidavit in support of attorneyâ€™s fees in this case.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because the family court erred in apportioning the condominium contents equally, contrary to the only property settlement agreement presented to the court, we reverse and remand to the family court for a hearing to determine whether a subsequent agreement between the parties occurred and to equitably distribute the condominium proceeds.Â  We affirm the Wifeâ€™s alimony award, the award of the dog to Wife, the admittance of the psychiatric expert as a rebuttal witness, the finding of contempt, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  
For the reasons stated, the family courtâ€™s decision is hereby
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â  
ANDERSON, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2] Wife raises a question regarding whether this issue is preserved for review.Â  Although Husband failed to file a post-judgment motion requesting the family court to address why the final order differed from the approved agreement, the approval of the agreement was raised to and ruled upon by the family court.Â  Accordingly, we address Husbandâ€™s issue on appeal.Â  
[3] The family court is authorized by several statutes to award pendente lite alimony and suit costs.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-120 (Supp. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-140 (Supp. 2004).Â  
[4]Â  Husband does not complain that the affidavit submitted by counsel does not support the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees or that the family court failed to consider the relevant factors in making the award.Â
