title: Ralphs v. Trexler
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Richard J. Ralphs, Respondent,
v.
Terry A. Trexler, d/b/a The Trexler Law Firm; and Edward W. Nordstrom, 
Of Whom Terry A. Trexler is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Â Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-219
Heard March 8, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
L. Henry McKellar, of Columbia, for Appellant.
James B. Richardson, Jr. and Palmer Freeman, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terry A. Trexler, d/b/a The Trexler Law Firm, appeals from orders granting Richard J. Ralphs a default judgment and awarding damages and costs.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Ralphs brought a malpractice suit against Trexler, his former attorney, for among other claims, fraudulently inducing him to sign a deed to his house under the pretense that it was a mortgage securing his attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Trexlerâ€™s attorney, Curtis Murph, filed an answer denying Ralphsâ€™ claims.Â  Ralphs attempted to secure Trexlerâ€™s deposition on three separate occasions.Â  Each time, Ralphsâ€™ attorney and Murph agreed upon the date and time.Â  The final two occasions, Ralphsâ€™ attorney, Ralphs, and a court reporter waited more than two hours to see if Trexler would attend.Â  Murph attended the third scheduled deposition; however, he was unable to locate his client.
When Trexler failed to attend a third deposition, Ralphs moved for sanctions under Rule 37, SCRCP.Â  He presented the affidavit of his attorney indicating the depositions were scheduled at times consented to by Murph, but no one attended.Â  Judge James E. Lockemy orally granted a motion to strike Trexlerâ€™s answer and to find him in default.Â  In the written motion, the court did not specifically strike the answer, but did hold Trexler in default.Â  Judge Lockemy also awarded Ralphs costs associated with preparing for and attending the depositions.
Trexler, after retaining new counsel, filed motions pursuant to Rule 59 and 60, SCRCP.Â  Judge Lockemy denied the motion pursuant to Rule 59, finding it was not timely and was not properly served.Â  The Rule 60 motion was later heard before Master-in-Equity Linwood S. Evans.[1]Â  In his order dated March 10, 2003, Judge Evans found the Rule 60 motion was inappropriate because there was no final judgment and also concluded he could not overrule the decision of another judge.
On March 18, 2003, Judge Evans conducted the damages hearing and issued an order awarding $108,213 in actual damages, $50,000 in punitive damages, and prejudgment interest on the actual damages.Â  Also, Judge Evans noted the award was in addition to the costs awarded by Judge Lockemy at the sanctions hearing.
Trexler then filed a motion asking the court to conduct a Gamble[2] hearing on the punitive damages.Â  Additionally, he filed a motion to reconsider the rulings, including the damages ruling.Â  Trexler filed his Notice of Appeal with this court on April 7, 2003, prior to obtaining a ruling on his outstanding motions.Â  This court stayed his appeal pending final disposition of the motions.
On December 11, 2003, Judge Evans granted Trexlerâ€™s motion to reconsider only as to the award of prejudgment interest and denied all remaining motions.Â  He issued an amended order, which reflected the change regarding prejudgment interest.Â  Trexler never filed an amended notice of appeal after receiving this order.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Sanctions
Trexler asserts it was an abuse of discretion for Judge Lockemy to strike his answer and hold him in default for failing to attend the scheduled depositions.Â  We disagree.
First, this issue is not properly preserved for review on appeal.Â  Judge Lockemy filed the order striking Trexlerâ€™s answer and holding him in default in October of 2000.Â  Trexler filed a motion under Rule 59, seeking to have Judge Lockemy reconsider that order.Â  Judge Lockemy ruled the motion was not timely filed and was not properly served pursuant to Rules 59(b) and (g), SCRCP.Â  Trexler never appealed the order by Judge Lockemy finding the motion untimely.Â  See Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR (requiring appeal to be filed within 30 days).Â  Thus, Trexler has waived his right to directly attack on appeal the findings of the October 2000 order, and the determinations of the court become the law of the case.Â  See Buckner v. Preferred Mut. Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 161, 177 S.E.2d 544, 544 (1970) (stating an unchallenged ruling, â€œright or wrong, is the law of th[e] case and requires affirmanceâ€).
While Trexler made a Rule 60 motion, he needed to appeal the original order and denial of his Rule 59 motion in order to raise the appropriateness of the sanction.Â  The Rule 60 motion collaterally attacked the default by asserting there was excusable neglect due to Trexlerâ€™s original counsel failing to inform him of the dates and times of the depositions.Â  Accordingly, we find in order to preserve his claim that the sanctions were an abuse of discretion, Trexler had to properly appeal from the order awarding sanctions or the denial of his motion pursuant to Rule 59.

On the merits, pursuant to Rule 37(d):Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
  
If a party . . . fails (1) to appear before the officer who is to take his deposition, after being served with a proper notice, . . . the court in which the action is pending on motion may make such orders in regard to the failure as are just, and among others it may take any action authorized under paragraphs (A), (B), and (C) of subdivision (b)(2) of this rule.Â  
  

Rule 37(d), SCRCP; see also Karppi v. Greenville Terrazzo Co., Inc., 327 S.C. 538, 542, 489 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 1997) (explaining Rule 37, SCRCP, â€œexpressly grants the trial court power to order judgment by default for either the violation of a court order or, upon motion, for a partyâ€™s failure to respond to certain discovery requestsâ€).Â  
When a court orders a sanction that results in default or dismissal, â€œthe end result is harsh medicine that should not be administered lightly.â€Â  Griffin Grading & Clearing, Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., Inc., 334 S.C. 193, 198, 511 S.E.2d 716, 718 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The sanction should be aimed at the specific misconduct of the party sanctioned and should be reasonable.Â  Id. at 198, 511 S.E.2d at 719; Karppi, 327 S.C. at 543, 489 S.E.2d at 682.Â  Also, the court should â€œnot go beyond the necessities of the situation to foreclose a decision on the merits of a case.â€Â  Id.Â  Finally, when a sanction â€œwould be tantamount to granting a judgment by default, the moving party must show bad faith, willful disobedience or gross indifference to its rights to justify the sanction.â€Â  Griffin, 334 S.C. at 198-99, 511 S.E.2d at 719.
Ralphsâ€™ attorney attempted to schedule and hold depositions of Trexler on three occasions.[3]Â  Each deposition was scheduled through Murph.Â  Murph even attended the third deposition and was unable to locate Trexler, according to the affidavit of Ralphsâ€™ attorney.Â  As an attorney, Trexler should understand the importance of discovery and the excess work caused by his failure to attend.Â  Accordingly, Judge Lockemyâ€™s determination that Trexlerâ€™s willful failure to attend the depositions warranted the striking of his answer and finding him in default is affirmed.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 60 Motion
Trexler next contends the trial court erred in denying his motion pursuant to Rule 60 to set aside the default judgment.Â  We disagree.
First, the motion appealed from was not timely, as the default judgment had not been entered.Â  Trexler was found in default after the trial judge struck his answer as a sanction for his discovery abuse.Â  In order to set aside the default, a motion pursuant to Rule 55 would have been necessary.Â  See Thynes v. Lloyd, 294 S.C. 152, 154, 363 S.E.2d 122, 123 (Ct. App. 1987) (finding Rule 55(c) allows the Circuit Court to grant relief from the entry of default, whereas Rule 60(b) allows the Circuit Court to grant relief from a final judgment).Â  
Second, Judge Evans correctly determined he did not have the authority to determine whether Judge Lockemy abused his discretion in awarding sanctions under Rule 37(b). Â Â Â Â Â  It is settled that one circuit judge does not have the power to review, modify, affirm or reverse the findings of another circuit judge.Â  Cook v. Taylor, 272 S.C. 536, 538, 252 S.E.2d 923, 924 (1979).
Additionally, this issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  Judge Evans issued his order denying the Rule 60 motion on March 10, 2003.Â  Subsequently, Trexler filed a motion to alter or amend the March 10 order.Â  He then filed his notice of appeal from the March 10 order, along with several other orders.Â  This court stayed his appeal pending the disposition of his outstanding motions, including the Rule 59 motion asking Judge Evans to reconsider, alter or amend his March 10 order.Â  After the Rule 59 motion was denied on December 11, 2003, Trexler failed to file an Amended Notice of Appeal to include the December 11 order in his appeal.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s determinations, including the finding that the March 10 order was appropriate, are the law of the case.Â  See Buckner, 255 S.C. at 161, 177 S.E.2d at 544 (stating an unchallenged ruling, â€œright or wrong, is the law of th[e] case and requires affirmanceâ€).
III.Â Â Â  Punitive Damages
Trexler contends the trial court erred in awarding punitive damages to Ralphs.Â  He maintains Judge Evans improperly considered Trexlerâ€™s subsequent disbarment as a ground for awarding punitive damages and also incorrectly concluded there was a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct when Trexler accepted title to Ralphsâ€™ property to protect his fee.Â  We disagree.
Procedurally, this issue is not properly preserved for several reasons.Â  First, the issue regarding the appropriateness of punitive damages does not appear in the record to have been raised to Judge Evans for consideration.Â  Trexlerâ€™s motion to alter or amend raises various issues related to the actual damages, but does not challenge the punitive damage award.Â  Accordingly, the issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Second, Trexler challenged Judge Evansâ€™ March 23 order by way of a motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  Additionally, he filed his Notice of Appeal to this court prior to receiving an order on his Rule 59 motion.Â  When Trexler received the order dated December 11, 2003, he was required to file an Amended Notice of Appeal to include this order in his appeal.Â  See Rules 203(b)(1) and (d)(2)(B), SCACR.Â  As he failed to appeal from this order, the findings made in the December 11 order are the law of the case.Â  See Buckner, 255 S.C. at 161, 177 S.E.2d at 544 (stating an unchallenged ruling, â€œright or wrong, is the law of th[e] case and requires affirmanceâ€).
Additionally, this issue would fail on the merits.Â  In Austin v. Specialty Transportation Services, Inc., this court explained in great detail the nature of punitive damages and the required findings prior to their award: 

Punitive damages, also known as exemplary damages, are imposed as punishment.Â  Punitive damages are allowed in the interest of society in the nature of punishment and as a warning and example to deter the wrongdoer and others from committing like offenses in the future. 

Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., Inc., 358 S.C. 298, 312, 594 S.E.2d 867, 874 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted).Â  This court continued:

On the issue of punitive damages, the highest burden of proof known to the civil law is applicable. . . . In any civil action where punitive damages are claimed, the plaintiff has the burden of proving such damages by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Punitive damages can only be awarded where the plaintiff proves by clear and convincing evidence the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights. 

Austin, 358 S.C. at 313, 594 S.E.2d at 875 (citations omitted).
While Judge Evans did consider the disciplinary order in his determination of awarding punitive damages, it was but one consideration.Â  He specifically found Trexler placed his own interests above those of Ralphs, whom he represented.Â  Additionally, he noted the fraudulent nature of how Trexler came to take title to Ralphsâ€™ property.Â  Finally, in noting the taking of the property to secure his fee, Judge Evans indicated Trexler likely violated Rule 1.8 of the Rules of Professional Conduct and Rule 407, SCACR, by taking a possessory interest in Ralphsâ€™ property that was adverse to his client.Â  Accordingly, we find clear and convincing evidence to support Judge Evans award of punitive damages.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] The outstanding motion and a damages hearing was apparently referred to Judge Evans.Â  While the Rule 60 motion was filed in December of 2000, it was not heard until December of 2002, partly because Trexler was under an automatic stay from the United States Bankruptcy Court.
[2] Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991).
[3] But cf. Balloon Plantation, Inc. v. Head Balloons, Inc., 303 S.C. 152, 154, 399 S.E.2d 439, 440 (Ct. App. 1990) (determining sanctions were not appropriate because the defendants made the extra effort to send their answers by Express Mail and they were only a few hours late during the afternoon they were due.)

title: In the Interest of Clinton P.
text:
FACTS


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Interest of Clinton P., a Minor Under the Age of Seventeen (17) Years, Respondent,
and,
In the Interest of Demetrius R., a Minor Under the Age of Seventeen (17) Years,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â H. Bruce Williams, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-220
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Karen Newell Fryar, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The State appeals the dismissal of juvenile petitions purportedly charging Clinton P. and Demetrius R. with criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor in the second degree.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 27, 2003, the State filed juvenile petitions against minors Clinton P. and Demetrius R. charging in pertinent part as follows:

[Clinton P.] did in June 2003 and while in the custody of DJJ . . . performed oral sex on [Demetrius R.], also 14 years of age.Â  On or about July 17, 2003, while in his bedroom, [Clinton P.] did masturbate [Demetrius R.]. . . . These being in violation of S.C. Code of Laws 16-3-653 Criminal Sexual Conduct with a Minor, 2nd Degree and Common Law Assault and Battery of a High and Aggravated Nature. . . .
[Demetrius R.] did in June 2003 and while in the custody of DJJ . . . performed oral sex on [Clinton P.], also 14 years of age.Â  On or about July 17, 2003, while in his bedroom, [Demetrius R.] did masturbate [Clinton P.]. . . . These being in violation of S.C. Code of Laws 16-3-653 Criminal Sexual Conduct with a Minor, 2nd Degree and Common Law Assault and Battery of a High and Aggravated Nature. . . .

The petition titles indicated a birth date of October 23, 1988 for Clinton P. on his juvenile petition and a birth date of February 7, 1989 for Demetrius R. on his juvenile petition.Â  
On March 3, 2004, the petitions against both Clinton P. and Demetrius R. were brought before the family court.Â  At that time, the attorney for the two minors moved on behalf of both boys to dismiss the criminal sexual conduct charges.Â  She argued the petitions were deficient because they alleged that the minors were both fourteen years of age, and S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(3) requires an actor be older than the victim for that element of the offense.Â  
The State agreed that the petitions were charging second degree CSC with a minor â€œbased on the age issue.â€Â  However, the State asserted that Clinton P. was older than Demetrius R. by â€œthree months,â€ and therefore should be charged with the offense.Â  The State further argued that no person under the age of sixteen had the â€œcapacity to consent to any kind of sexual activity.â€Â  
After noting both boys were fourteen years of age, the family court judge granted the minorsâ€™ motion to dismiss.Â  The boysâ€™ attorney also moved to dismiss the charge of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature arguing there was no allegation of any kind of battery.Â  The State again argued the two were â€œunder legal age to consent.â€Â  The family court judge noted there was no allegation of any coercion, threat or force, and granted the motion to dismiss these charges as well.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The only issue raised on appeal is whether the family court erred in â€œsummarily dismissing the juvenile petitions charging second degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, where the facts alleged that the defendants, who were 14 years old, engaged in oral sex.â€2
South Carolina Code Ann Â§ 16-3-655, the statute prohibiting CSC with minors, provides as follows:

(1) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim who is less than eleven years of age.
(2) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is fourteen years of age or less but who is at least eleven years of age.
(3) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is at least fourteen years of age but who is less than sixteen years of age and the actor is in a position of familial, custodial, or official authority to coerce the victim to submit or is older than the victim.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655 (2003).
The State contends the family court improperly dismissed the juvenile petitions because the conduct set forth in the petitions constituted a violation of Â§ 16-3-655(2).Â  It further asserts, notwithstanding the applicability of Â§ 16-3-655(2), the petition against Clinton P. properly alleged conduct in violation of Â§ 16-3-655(3) since the petitions showed Clinton P. was more than three months older than Demetrius R.Â  It is clear, however, that in argument before the family court, the State took the position that the juvenile indictments alleged CSC with a minor in the second degree pursuant to Â§ 16-3-655(3), which requires either that the actor be older than the victim or the actor be in a position of familial, custodial, or official authority to coerce the victim.Â  It did not advance an argument that the conduct of the two minors fell under subsection (2) of the statute.Â  Because the State did not argue the allegations were sufficient under Â§ 16-3-655(2), it cannot raise that argument for the first time on appeal.Â  See State v. Rice, 348 S.C. 417, 420, 559 S.E.2d 360, 362 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding an argument not raised to the trial court is not preserved for appellate review).Â  Additionally, while the individual petitions do contain the birth date of the minor charged, the petitions do not also contain the birth date of the alleged victim.Â  Thus, neither petition sets forth facts alleging that either actor is older than the victim.Â  To the contrary, each petition alleges that the actor and victim were both â€œ14 years of age.â€Â  
At any rate, we find the petitions are fatally defective such that the family court properly dismissed them.Â  Our statutory law provides that â€œ[e]very indictment shall be deemed and judged sufficient and good in law which, in addition to allegations as to time and place, as required by law, charges the crime substantially in the language of the common law or of the statute prohibiting the crime or so plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood and, if the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense be alleged to be contrary to the statute in such case made and provided.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003).Â  If an objection to the sufficiency of an indictment is timely made, the trial court â€œshould judge the sufficiency of the indictment by determining whether (1) the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon; and (2) whether it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense that is intended to be charged.â€Â  State v. Gentry, Op. No. 25949 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 7, 2005). Â â€œIn determining whether an indictment meets the sufficiency standard, the court must look at the indictment with a practical eye in view of all the surrounding circumstances.â€  Id.Â  The requirement that a criminal defendant receive sufficient notice of the charges against him to enable him to prepare a defense applies in juvenile matters.Â  In re Corey B., 291 S.C. 108, 109, 352 S.E.2d 470, 470 (1987).Â  
Here, the petitions themselves do not delineate which subsection it is relying on under Â§ 16-3-655 in charging CSC with a minor in the second degree, nor indicate the State is even relying on Â§ 16-3-655.Â  Rather, the petitions, while stating the juveniles are charged with the offense of CSC with a minor in the second degree, both erroneously allege the juvenilesâ€™ conduct is a violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-653, which provides, â€œA person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor uses aggravated coercion to accomplish sexual battery.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-653(1) (2003).Â  Section 16-3-653 does not deal with CSC with a minor and the petitions do not allege any facts of aggravated coercion required under Â§ 16-3-653.Â  Because the petitions specify a violation of Â§ 16-3-653, which is the crime of second degree CSC that involves aggravated force and has no age element, but designate the offense for both Clinton P. and Demetrius R. as CSC with a minor in the second degree, we hold the petitions failed to apprise Clinton P. and Demetrius R. the elements of the offense intended to be charged and therefore failed to provide sufficient notice of the charges against the juveniles.Â  Accordingly, the family court properly dismissed the petitions.
For the foregoing reasons, the order below is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
2 The State does not include in its issues on appeal a challenge to the family courtâ€™s dismissal of the assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) charges.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003); Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (no point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of issues on appeal).Â  Further, the State only devotes one statement to the ABHAN charges in its brief asserting that they should not have been dismissed because a minor under the age of sixteen is not capable of voluntarily consenting to a sexual battery.Â  This argument is so conclusory as to amount to an abandonment of the issue on appeal.Â  See State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 58-59, 543 S.E.2d 541, 546 (2001) (finding argument was so conclusory it was abandoned on appeal).Â  Finally, the State does not challenge the family court judgeâ€™s ruling based on his finding that the petitions failed to allege any aggravating circumstance.Â  See State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 580, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002) (ABHAN is an unlawful act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances of aggravation; circumstances of aggravation is an element of ABHAN).Â

title: Leake v. Ethridge
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David G. Leake and Amanda J. Leake, Respondents,
v.
Mitchell Ethridge, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-221
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 24, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Merriman, of Florence, for Appellant.
R. Wayne Byrd, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mitchell Ethridge, Jr. appeals the trial courtâ€™s order upholding a tax sale of his real property.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ethridge has owned the real property in question since 1988 and was in sole physical possession of the property until the hearing.Â  He failed to pay the 1996 property taxes on the real property.Â  On April 7, 1997, the County mailed a notice of delinquent tax to Ethridge explaining the property could be levied upon and sold at public auction if the taxes remained unpaid beyond August 29, 1997.Â  On May 15, 1997, the County mailed a notice of levy to Ethridge via certified mail, return receipt requested.Â  The notice advised that the property would be sold on October 6, 1997 if the taxes were not paid on or before August 29, 1997.Â  The notice of levy was returned unclaimed on June 12, 1997.Â  On July 16, 1997, the County posted a notice of levy on a tree on Ethridgeâ€™s property.Â  
After advertising the sale of the property for three weeks in two local papers, the County sold the property on October 6, 1997 to William E. Tallevast, Jr.Â  On November 21, 1997, the County mailed Ethridge a notice that the property had been sold.Â  In this letter, the County stated the last date of redemption for the property was October 6, 1998.Â  The County mailed Ethridge an official notice of redemption via certified mail, return receipt requested on August 21, 1998.Â  This notice of redemption listed the last date of redemption as October 6, 1998.Â  The notice was returned to the County unclaimed.Â  The Treasurer of the County issued a tax deed on January 11, 1999 to William D. Tallevast, Jr.Â  Tallevastâ€™s estate subsequently issued a deed of distribution to William D. Tallevast, V and Robert Elliott Tallevast, who immediately sold the property to David G. Leake and Amanda J. Leake.Â  
On July 23, 2002, the Leakes brought a declaratory judgment seeking a declaration they are fee simple owners of the property and requesting an injunction requiring Ethridge to vacate the premises.Â  In a counterclaim, Ethridge asserted the tax deed was void due to the Countyâ€™s failure to follow the statutory requirements for a tax sale.Â  The trial court granted the Leakesâ€™ motion to amend their reply to assert the statute of limitations.Â  The court found the County had complied with the applicable statutory requirements, held the statute of limitations barred Ethridgeâ€™s counterclaim, and declared the Leakes to be the owners of the real property.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Statute of Limitations
We first consider Ethridgeâ€™s argument that his counterclaim to set aside the tax deed is not barred by the provisions of section 12-51-160 of the South Carolina Code.Â  We agree.
Section 12-51-160 of the South Carolina Code (2004) provides, â€œNo action for the recovery of land sold under the provisions of this chapter or for the recovery of the possession may be maintained unless brought within two years from the date of sale.â€Â  The supreme court found the former version of this statute of limitations[2] inapplicable to one in possession of property asserting a claim of ownership in defense of an action brought by the purchaser at a tax sale more than two years after receiving the tax deed.Â  Dibble v. Bryant, 274 S.C. 481, 487, 265 S.E.2d 673, 677 (1980).Â  The court found the â€œstatute was intended to bar a defaulting and ousted taxpayer from maintaining an action to defeat the title of the tax sale purchaser and recover the land if brought more than two years from the date the purchaser came into possession.â€Â  Id.Â  The court explained:

[t]o deny the possessor a claim of rightful ownership would be to deny him any defense, and would enable a purchaser at a tax sale to circumvent the valid legal remedies available to the defendant in possession of the property by merely waiting more than two years to bring his action to oust the defendant.

Id. at 487-88, 265 S.E.2d at 677.
Here, Ethridge remained in possession of the land.Â  As in Dibble, Ethridgeâ€™s efforts to defend the Leakesâ€™ action seeking to confirm title in themselves should not be thwarted by the statute of limitations.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in finding the statute of limitations barred Ethridgeâ€™s defense.Â  
II.              
Redemption Notice  
Ethridge argues the County failed to issue the notice of redemption in compliance with the statutory requirements and the noncompliance requires the tax sale to be set aside.Â  We agree.
The appellate courts of this state have â€œconsistently held the enforcing agencies of government to strict compliance with all the legal requirements surrounding tax sales.â€Â  Dibble v. Bryant, 274 S.C. 481, 483-84, 265 S.E.2d 673, 676 (1980); Rives v. Bulsa, 325 S.C. 287, 292, 478 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1996) (citations omitted).Â  â€œThe sound view is that all requirements of law leading up to tax sales which are intended for the protection of the tax payer against surprise or the sacrifice of his property are to be regarded as mandatory and are to be strictly enforced.â€Â  Rives, 325 S.C. at 292-93, 478 S.E.2d at 881.Â  The failure to give proper notice is a fundamental defect in the tax proceedings which renders the proceedings absolutely void.Â  Donahue v. Ward, 298 S.C. 75, 83, 378 S.E.2d 261, 265 (Ct. App. 1989).
A defaulting taxpayer may redeem the real property â€œwithin twelve months from the date of the delinquent tax sale.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann Â§12-51-90 (Supp. 2004).Â  The statutory requirements mandate that the defaulting taxpayer be given notice of the approaching end of the redemption period, providing the delinquent tax collector shall make the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested â€œ[n]either more than forty-five days nor less than twenty days before the end of the redemption period.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-120 (Supp. 2004).
The County held the tax sale for Ethridgeâ€™s property on October 6, 1997. Â The trial court accepted the Countyâ€™s argument at the hearing that the last day of redemption was actually October 5, 1998.Â  However, the notice of sale sent November 21, 1997 and the notice of redemption sent August 21, 1998 both stated that October 6, 1998 was the last day for redemption.Â  Therefore, we find the County is bound by the date it placed on its notices, rather than the date argued by its attorney at the hearing.Â  With October 6, 1998 as the last day of redemption, the earliest the County could have mailed the notice and remained in compliance with the statutory requirements was August 22, 1998.Â  However, the notice was mailed on August 21, 1998.Â  Thus, the notice was sent one day early.Â  
The County asserts the fact that the notice was sent one day early did not prejudice Etheridge because he never received the notice and never attempted to redeem the property.Â  Although Ethridge did not seek to redeem the property, the County is not excused from the strict compliance mandated by the laws of tax sales.Â  See Donahue, 298 S.C. at 83, 378 S.E.2d at 266 (finding without merit the argument that the defaulting taxpayer was not prejudiced by the tax collectorâ€™s failure to give statutory notice). Â As the County failed to strictly comply with the statutory notice requirements intended to protect the taxpayer against a sacrifice of his property, the tax sale must be set aside.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial court erred in not setting aside the defective tax sale.
Because we reverse the decision of the trial court based on the failed notice of redemption and find that Ethridge was not barred by the statute of limitations, we do not need to address the other issues Ethridge raises on appeal.
 REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The former version of the statute of limitations provided: â€œ[n]o action for . . . recovery . . . shall be maintained unless brought within two years from the date of such [tax] sale.â€Â  Dibble, 274 S.C. at 487, 265 S.E.2d at 677 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-49-570 (1976)).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Eric Andrew Rieb, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-222
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 29, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter III, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Eric Andrew Rieb appeals a murder conviction, arguing the trial court erred in excluding evidence of his prior psychiatric hospitalizations and refusing to present a jury charge on the law of self-defense.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
In March 2000, kitchen manager Joe Award hired Rieb, a college dropout with some professional culinary training and experience, as a line cook at the Outrigger, a local seafood restaurant.Â  During the initial weeks of his employment, Rieb rode back and forth to work with Award, who lived near him.Â  Shortly after being hired, Rieb was demoted to fry cook.Â  In mid-August, Award fired Rieb from the kitchen staff, citing his unreliability and serious drinking problem.Â  Following his termination, Rieb occasionally mentioned to others his professional dissatisfaction and personal dislike for Award.Â  Two weeks after being terminated, Rieb approached daytime manager Janice Smith about the possibility of being re-hired at the restaurant and working for her.Â  With Awardâ€™s approval, Rieb was re-hired on the restaurantâ€™s daytime cleaning staff, where he would rarely be in contact with Award.Â  At the end of October, the Outrigger terminated Award as nighttime manager. 
On Sunday, November 19, Rieb was relaxing at his apartment with co-workers Blake Josephs and Jeremiah Lawson.Â  Around noon, Rieb began receiving phone calls from Award, who wanted Rieb to come over to his place for some drinks.Â  It was known to Rieb and other employees of the Outrigger that Award was homosexual.Â  The phone calls continued all afternoon.Â  Rieb told Award he might stop by, but communicated to Josephs and Lawson that he did not desire to do so.Â  After several calls, Rieb refused to speak with Award.Â  Josephs began answering the calls instead, and repeatedly told Award to stop harassing them; the calls, however, continued.Â  Finally, around 7:30 p.m., Josephs and Lawson suggested that Rieb go over to Awardâ€™s home and see what he wanted.Â  Rieb complied, left the apartment, and walked over a mile in the pouring rain to Awardâ€™s residence.
Approximately forty-five minutes later, Rieb called his apartment from Awardâ€™s home to speak to Josephs.Â  Once Josephs was reached, Rieb told him and Lawson that he had just killed Award and needed help.Â  They told Rieb that they were on their way over to help him, so he should stay where he was, but then called 9-1-1 to report the crime.Â  The police drove to a nearby restaurant to meet Josephs, who directed them to Awardâ€™s home.
Once on the scene, law enforcement officers surrounded the residence and ordered Rieb to exit.Â  He was soon spotted breaking out a window in the rear of the building in an attempt to escape, but fled back into the home when ordered to halt.Â  Rieb eventually exited from the front of the house and peacefully surrendered.Â  After he was handcuffed, officers searched his person incident to the arrest.Â  Stuffed in his waistline near the small of his back, the police found a household steak knife. Â The search also revealed what appeared to be a severed penis in his front-right pocket.Â  Rieb was promptly arrested.
Upon entering the small home, officers quickly discovered Award, badly beaten about the head and body, but still breathing, with his groin area exposed and severely mangled.Â  Emergency medical services were called expeditiously, but Award died soon thereafter.Â  A subsequent autopsy was inconclusive as to which specific injury caused Awardâ€™s death, but determined either the blunt trauma to his head or the bodily injuries could have alone proved fatal.Â  
According to Rieb, he and Award began drinking alcohol together soon after his arrival.Â  In the relatively short time period he spent with Award, Rieb estimates he drank from eight to ten beers, around four shots of Vodka, and about four or five shots of Bourbon.Â  At some point in the evening, Award played a homosexual pornographic video on his large television.Â  Rieb testified that sometime thereafter he lost consciousness for what he believes was about forty-five minutes.Â  He claimed to have awoken to find himself standing in the kitchen.Â  Award was kneeling on the floor in front of him with his genitals exposed and began pleading with Rieb to perform oral sex on him.Â  At this point, Rieb admitted he â€œgot nauseous and . . . like a big bolt of adrenaline . . . got really psychedâ€ and hit Award in the head with a nearby brass chalice.Â  He also vaguely recalls hitting Award several times and stomping on his ribs while Award was â€œjust laying thereâ€ on the floor.Â  Rieb, however, claims no recollection of ever wielding a steak knife or cutting the victim. Â Â 
Rieb was indicted and convicted of petit larceny,[2] mayhem, and murder.Â  The trial court sentenced him to concurrent terms totaling forty years of imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I. Self-defense Charge
Rieb argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the law of self-defense.Â  We disagree.
The law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).Â  In determining whether the evidence required a certain jury charge, we view the facts in a light most favorable to the defendant.Â  State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 321, 474 S.E.2d 430, 431 (1996).Â  Accordingly, if there is any evidence in the record to support self-defense, the issue should be submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 260-261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 302 (2002).Â  
 It is well established in South Carolina that in order to establish a valid claim of self-defense, a defendant must prove: â€œ(1) he was without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) he actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the same belief; and (4) he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.â€Â  State v. Long, 325 S.C. 59, 62, 480 S.E.2d 62, 63 (1997).Â  To warrant a jury instruction on self-defense a defendant must produce evidence (albeit only a minimal amount of evidence, per this courtâ€™s standard of review) that if determined credible by the jury, would tend to establish each element of self-defense.Â  Failure to present evidence on any one element precludes a jury charge on the law of self-defense.Â  See, e.g., State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 345-46, 520 S.E.2d 319, 322 (1999) (finding that defendantâ€™s testimony failed to establish he did not bring on the difficulty; thus, a self-defense charge was not warranted); State v. Bruno, 322 S.C. 534, 536, 473 S.E.2d 450, 452 (1996) (finding that appellant â€œwas not entitled to a self-defense charge, because he presented no evidence that he believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injuryâ€); Goodson, 312 S.C. at 280, 440 S.E.2d at 372 (finding defendant was not entitled to self-defense charge when he presented no evidence showing actual or perceived imminent danger).
In order to satisfy the fourth element of self-defense, the defendant must show that he had no other probable means of escape except to take the life of his aggressor or, stated another way, that: 

  Â . . . he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger of losing his own life or sustaining serious bodily harm than to act as he did in the particular instance; that it is oneâ€™s duty to avoid taking human life where it is possible to prevent it even to the extent of retreating from his adversary unless by doing so the danger of being killed or suffering serious bodily harm is increased or it is reasonably apparent that such danger would be increased. 

State v. Jackson, 227 S.C. 271, 279, 87 S.E.2d 681, 685 (1955).
In the present case, we have serious doubts as to whether Riebâ€™s testimony constituted sufficient evidence as to any element of self-defense to warrant the jury charge, especially when considering that one may only use such force as is reasonably necessary to defend oneself.Â  See Jackson, 227 S.C. at 279, 87 S.E.2d at 685.Â  We base our decision, however, on the fact that Riebâ€™s own version of the events transpiring at Awardâ€™s home utterly fails to explain why Rieb did not just decline Awardâ€™s sexual advances and leave the residence.Â  Although defense counsel sought at trial to establish Riebâ€™s belief that he was locked in the apartment, Rieb acknowledged in no uncertain terms on cross-examination that he did not realize the entrance to the residence was locked until after he had fatally beaten his host.Â  Rieb was not entitled to a self-defense charge at trial because he presented no evidence that he had no other means of avoiding the perceived danger.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
II. Exclusion of Psychiatric Hospitalization Evidence
Rieb argues the trial court erred in excluding evidence of his prior psychiatric hospitalizations. We disagree.
At trial, Rieb expressly declined to pursue an insanity defense.Â  Nevertheless, Rieb sought to establish, through his own testimony and that of others, that he has a history of psychiatric problems stemming from past instances of sexual abuse.Â  Rieb, his mother, and his sister proffered testimony that when he was eight years old, Riebâ€™s cousin molested both he and his sister.Â  This experience resulted in a noticeable change in Riebâ€™s personality and, about a year and half later, his parents were finally told about the abuse.Â  Rieb was then hospitalized for psychiatric treatment, diagnosed with attention deficit disorder, and medicated.Â  This treatment continued intermittently until his early twenties. Â Â 
Rieb also proffered testimony of another incident of sexual abuse.Â  According to Rieb, when he was twenty-two, he was invited to the home of an older male acquaintance.Â  After the consumption of several alcoholic beverages, he â€œblacked outâ€ at the manâ€™s home and awoke to find the man sodomizing him.Â  Rieb fled the home, and was later treated for psychiatric distress relating to the incident.[3] 
After considering the above testimony and counselsâ€™ arguments concerning its admissibility, the trial court decided to allow all testimony relating to the two prior instances of abuse, but excluded all evidence of Riebâ€™s past psychiatric treatment.Â  Although the trial court clearly perceived the relevance of the past abuse in establishing Riebâ€™s actual belief that he was in imminent danger at the time he struck the victim, it concluded that all evidence of past psychiatric treatment would only be relevant to the affirmative defense of insanity, a defense that Rieb expressly declined to raise at trial.Â Â  
On appeal, Rieb argues this exclusion was erroneous because evidence of his medical treatment was critical to corroborating the past sexual abuse.Â  We are not convinced the exclusion of this evidence was reversible error.
â€œEvidence is relevant if it tends to establish or make more or less probable some matter in issue upon which it directly or indirectly bears.â€ State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 380, 401 S.E.2d 146, 148 (1991).Â  Certainly evidence of Riebâ€™s past medical treatment is relevant in the sense asserted by Rieb on appeal, namely because it does, to some degree, corroborate the instances of past sexual abuse.Â  However, even relevant evidence may be excluded â€œif its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the competency of testimony under Rule 403, SCRE, should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances and this court is obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.Â  State v. Slocumb, 336 S.C. 619, 633, 521 S.E.2d 507, 514 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The decision to exclude evidence under Rule 403 should not be reversed simply because an appellate court believes it would have decided the matter otherwise. Id.Â  
In excluding the testimony in the present case, the court was simply accepting the Stateâ€™s argument that such evidence would likely mislead the jury into thinking an insanity or diminished capacity style defense was at issue in the trial.Â  Furthermore, as Rieb, his mother, father, and sister were allowed to testify regarding the occurrences, any corroboration of the past instances of abuse would have been cumulative; thus, the trail court acted within its discretion in excluding the evidence.
Moreover, the psychiatric treatment evidence was introduced merely to corroborate the past sexual abuses and the past sexual abuses introduced to establish an element of self-defense.Â  Because the jury charge on self-defense was properly declined for lack of evidence on other elements, we see no undue prejudice in the testimonyâ€™s exclusion.Â  Â See State v. Mason, 215 S.C. 457, 463, 56 S.E.2d 90, 93 (1949) (affirming the exclusion of evidence that was merely cumulative and â€œof inconsequential probative value for the purpose for which is was offeredâ€).
CONCLUSION
Because we find Rieb was not entitled to a jury charge on the law of self-defense and conclude there was no reversible error in the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of evidence regarding his past psychiatric treatment, Riebâ€™s convictions are hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] At trial, Rieb conceded that following the beating of Award, he took several bottles of beer and liquor from the home and hid them outside with the intention of taking them when his roommate arrived.Â  {R. 411-412}
[3] This treatment occurred months later, when a court ordered Rieb to obtain alcohol dependency treatment after being arrested for DUI.Â  The occurrence was brought up and discussed during this court-ordered treatment.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        Alvin Jermaine Green, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
  Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-223
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed March 31, 2005

AFFIRMED

  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.        
      Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent. 
    
  

 PER CURIAM: Alvin J. Green appeals his convictions for criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor in the first degree and CSC with a minor in the second degree. On appeal, he contends the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over both offenses.
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 156, 526 S.E.2d 228, 231 (2000) (stating issue not preserved if party argues one ground for objection at trial and a different ground on appeal); State v. Gentry, Op. No. 25949 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 7, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 11 at 37) (holding circuit courts have subject matter jurisdiction to try criminal matters and questions of the insufficiency of an indictment not affecting the subject matter jurisdiction of the trial court may not be raised for the first time on appeal).Â  
    AFFIRMED.
    ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Linda Dallas and Frankie Dallas,Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        James Todd, II, and Tammy Todd, Defendants,
        Of whom James Todd, II is the, Appellant,
      
      In Re: James Todd, III, Christian Todd and Mason Todd, (Minors Under the Age of 18).
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-224
Submitted March 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jennifer L. Queen and William R. Hearn, Jr., both of Summerville, for Appellant.
        Russell S. Stemke, of Isle of Palms, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: James Todd, II, (Father) appeals the termination of his parental rights to his three children.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS

In 1998, pursuant to an action by the South Carolina Department of Social Services, the family court granted temporary legal custody of Fatherâ€™s two older children, James Todd, III, and Mason Todd, to Linda Dallas after finding a threat of physical neglect against Father and Tammy Todd, the childrenâ€™s mother (Mother).Â  Dallas is Motherâ€™s aunt.Â  After a judicial review hearing in December 1998, the family court issued an order dated May 17, 1999, granting Dallas and her husband Frankie Dallas permanent legal and physical custody of the children.Â  The May 17, 1999 custody order also prohibited both Mother and Father from having contact with the children except in a therapeutic setting, but allowed them to petition for visitation if they completed psychological counseling and a clarification process regarding the circumstances that led to the childrenâ€™s removal from their care.Â  Christian Todd, a third child born to Mother and Father on January 24, 2001, has lived with the Dallases since a few weeks after he was born. 
In 2002, the Dallases brought the present action seeking to adopt James, Mason, and Christian, and to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights to all three children.Â  Mother, who was also a party to the proceedings, had waived her rights and consented to the adoption.Â  
Following a hearing on September 16 and 17, 2003, the family court issued an order on January 13, 2004, terminating the parental rights of Father and Mother to the children and allowing their adoption by the Dallases.Â  Father appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We disagree with Fatherâ€™s argument that the family court erred in terminating his parental rights for willful failure to visit.Â  
The family court may order a termination of parental rights upon finding thatÂ  (1) a child has lived outside the home of either parent for six months and during that time the parent has willfully failed to visit the child, and (2) termination is in the childâ€™s best interest.[2]
The family court found Father had no contact with any of the children since December 1998.Â  Father does not dispute this finding on appeal.Â  In his brief, however, he argues he left South Carolina for a significant period of time to seek employment, had made several unsuccessful attempts to contact the children by calling the Dallasesâ€™ residence to schedule visits with them during their therapy appointments, and was not aware that under the custody order he could petition for visitation with the children after completing certain steps in a treatment program.Â  
 The arguments that Father advances on appeal do not undermine the family courtâ€™s finding that Father willfully failed to visit the children.Â  Father does not contest the finding in the appealed order that he was â€œconstantly moving his residence from one state to another without providing the [Dallases] or his children with his current whereabouts or with any other information that would provide a means for them to contact him if they desired to, thereby purposely eliminating himself from the lives of his children and all manner of contact with them.â€Â  As to Fatherâ€™s attempt to schedule visits with the children through the Dallases, Linda Dallas denied that Father called her to inquire about the childrenâ€™s therapy appointments.Â  The family court found her testimony to be much more credible than that offered by Father.[3]Â  Finally, we are not persuaded by Fatherâ€™s assertions that he was unaware of the provisions in the custody order under which he could petition for visitation.Â  It is apparent from that order that he was present and represented by counsel at the hearing and there appears to be no dispute that he was aware of another provision in the same order restricting his contact with the children.
2.Â  Similarly, Father contends the Dallases failed to establish by clear and convincing evidence that he willfully failed to support the children so as to warrant termination of his parental rights.Â  On appeal, Father asserts (1) he was disabled and this disability limited his capacity to pursue gainful employment; (2) he attempted to provide health insurance for the children through his employment at Wal-Mart, but was unable to because he did not have their social security numbers; and (3) he provided the children gifts, clothes, toys, Wal-Mart gift cards, and money orders.Â  We find these arguments unavailing.Â  
As noted by the family court, Father provided no corroborating evidence of the injury that led to his alleged disability and Wal-Mart already had the childrenâ€™s social security numbers because the children had previously been insured through Motherâ€™s employment with Wal-Mart.Â  The family court also found that Father failed to provide corroborating evidence that he had sent the children gifts and noted that, even if he were to be given credit for what he claimed to have sent, the full dollar value of all the gifts that Father purportedly sent the children since they began residing with the Dallases was insignificant at best.[4]
3.Â  Finally, Father asserts the family court erred in finding the best interests of the children would be served by termination of his parental rights.Â  Specifically, he contends (1) because he does not object allowing the Dallases to retain custody of the children, the only significant change that would result from their adoption by the Dallases would be that their last name would be changed; and (2) there was a complete lack of evidence as to what was in the best interest of Christian, the youngest child.Â  We reject these arguments.Â  
Statutes authorizing the termination of parental rights â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship. The interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€[5]Â  â€œParental rights do not spring full-blown from the biological connection between parent and child.Â  They require relationships more enduring.â€[6]
Contrary to Fatherâ€™s first argument, the family court found that, based on statements by the counselor for one of the children as well as testimony from Linda Dallas and the guardian ad litem, the children â€œwould suffer severe psychological and emotional harm if they were to ever again to have contact with [Father] in the future, or if they were to ever be separated from each other.â€Â  The family court further determined that the adoption of the children by the Dallases â€œwould benefit them psychologically, socially, and emotionally, and would allow them to enjoy the benefits of belonging to a true family and the ability to call the [Dallases], who they regard as their parents, Mom and Dad.â€Â  
To the extent that Fatherâ€™s argument regarding the youngest child has been preserved for appeal, we agree with the Dallases that the record supports a finding that Father had absolutely no relationship with Christian and expressed no desire to have one.Â  To the contrary, there was undisputed evidence that Father not only attempted to deny that Christian was his biological child but also demanded that Mother â€œsellâ€ the child for $25,000.Â  We therefore hold the family courtâ€™s finding that termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights is in the best interests of all three children.[7]
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3) (1976 & Supp. 2004).
[3]Â  See Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004) (â€œWe are not required to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of the child.â€).
[4]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (1976 & Supp. 2004) (stating that â€œ[f]ailure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s careâ€ and noting â€œ[a] material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s meansâ€).Â  In the present case, the family court noted that â€œwhen totaled the full dollar value of all such gift certificates and other matter did not even exceed $400.00 over the full course of time duringÂ  which [the Dallases] have had custody of the three minor children.â€
[5]Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-1578.
[6]Â  Caban v. Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380, 397 (1979), quoted in South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 259, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999).
[7]Â  Although we affirm the termination of parental rights, we extend our gratitude to Toddâ€™s counsel for the fine representation they have given their court-appointed client during both the trial and this appeal.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
 

  
    
      
Don L. Bundrick and Ann R. Bundrick,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
East Richland County Public Service District,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-225
Submitted February 1, 2005 â€“ Filed March 31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charnell Glenn Peake, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Leslie A. Cotter, Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., S. Elizabeth Brosnan, and Scott Elliott, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Don L. Bundrick and Ann R. Bundrick brought claims against East Richland County Public Service District for improper installation and maintenance of a sewer line and drainage ditch.Â  The trial court found the statute of repose barred their claims.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The District obtained a right of way and easement to construct a sewer line on undeveloped property in 1972.Â  The District contracted with two companies to install the line.Â  The construction of the line on the Bundricksâ€™ future property was completed in October 1972, and construction on the entire line was completed by 1974.Â  During 1972, the flow of a creek on the property was diverted through an aluminum pipe running perpendicular to the line, though the District denied it or its contractors installed the pipe.Â  
The Bundricks purchased the property in 1984, and applied for sewer service from the District in 1986.Â  The Bundricks built a house and moved onto the previously undeveloped land in October 1986.Â  They soon began to experience trouble with soil erosion and noticed their house developed structural distress.Â  They surmised the aluminum pipe running near the sewer line caused the difficulties.Â  The Bundricks sued the District in February 2000.
At trial, the Bundricks asserted their problems were caused by the Districtâ€™s improper placement of the aluminum pipe near the sewer line.Â  They further claimed the District failed to properly maintain the pipe.Â  
The District presented evidence supporting its denial of ownership over the aluminum pipe.Â  It also presented evidence establishing that neither the District nor its contractors installed the aluminum pipe.Â  In its answer, the District asserted the statute of repose barred the Bundricksâ€™ claims and the trial court agreed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an appeal from a master in equity, this court has the same scope of review as if the appeal was from a circuit court sitting without a jury.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990).Â  A suit based on negligence is an action at law.Â  Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 592 S.E.2d 315 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Furthermore, while we may correct errors of law, we must affirm a masterâ€™s factual findings unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  Sims, 357 S.C. at 294-95, 592 S.E.2d at 318.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Bundricks argue the master erred in finding their claims were barred by the statute of repose.Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Statute of Repose
The legislature codified a thirteen-year statute of repose in S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-640 (2005).Â  The statute places a bar on actions based on defective improvements to real property.Â  It reads, in part:

No actions to recover damages based upon or arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property may be brought more than thirteen years after substantial completion of such an improvement.Â  For purposes of this section, an action based upon or arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property includes:
. . .
(2)             an action to recover damages for the negligent construction or repair of an improvement to real property;
(3)            an action to recover damages for personal injury, death, or damage to property;
(4)            an action to recover damages for economic or monetary loss;
(5)             an action in contract or tort or otherwise;
. . .
(8)            an action brought against any current or prior owner of the real property or improvement 
. . .
This section describes an outside limitation of thirteen years after the substantial completion of the improvement, within which normal statutes of limitations continue to run.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-640 (2005).
A statute of repose represents â€œan absolute time limit beyond which liability no longer exists.â€Â  Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 404, 438 S.E.2d 242, 243 (1993) (quoting First United Methodist Church v. United States Gypsum Co., 882 F.2d 862, 865-66 (4th Cir. 1989)).Â  The statute is a societal recognition that at some point in the future liability no longer exists.Â  â€œWhen causes of action are extinguished after such time, society generally may continue its business and personal relationships in peace, without worry that some cause of action may arise to haunt it because of some long-forgotten act or omission.â€Â  Langley, 313 S.C. at 404, 438 S.E.2d at 244 (quoting Kissel v. Rosenbaum, 579 N.E.2d 1322, 1326-28 (Ind. Ct. App. 1991)).Â  
To further that purpose, a statute of repose, unlike a statute of limitations, cannot be defeated by estoppel, waiver, or claims of tolling.Â  G&P Trucking v. Parks Auto Sales Svc. & Salvage, Inc., 357 S.C. 82, 89, 591 S.E.2d 42, 45 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In short, a statute of repose is a substantive defense that prevents a cause of action from coming into being after a pre-determined period of time.Â  See Langley, 313 S.C. at 403-04, 438 S.E.2d at 243-44.
The statute of repose applies to the Bundricksâ€™ action because it is one â€œbased upon or arising out of the defective or unsafe condition of an improvement to real property.â€Â  The Districtâ€™s easement is real property.Â  South Carolina Pipeline Corp. v. Lone Star Steel Co., 345 S.C. 151, 153, 546 S.E.2d 654, 656 (2001) (holding an easement is â€œreal propertyâ€ for S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-640 purposes).Â  Further, the sewer line is an improvement to that property.Â  Id. at 154, 546 S.E.2d at 657.
The Bundricks had thirteen years to bring their suit from the date the sewer was completed.Â  Whether the applicable date to start counting is 1972, when the sewer project was completed on the affected property, or 1974, when the entire project was completed, the Bundricksâ€™ February 2000 lawsuit was clearly filed beyond the thirteen-year deadline and is, therefore, barred by the statute of repose.Â  
B.Â  Ownership Exception
The Bundricks argue the statute of repose is inapplicable because the District is in possession of the improvement complained of.Â  In support of their argument, they cite to S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-670, which codifies the ownership exception as follows:

[The statute of repose] may not be asserted as a defense by any person in actual possession or control, as owner, tenant, or otherwise, of the improvement at the time the defective or unsafe condition constitutes the proximate cause of the injury or death for which it is proposed to bring an action, in the event such person in actual possession or control knows, or reasonably should have known, of the defective or unsafe condition. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-670 (2005).
There is no dispute the District owns the easement, which is real property.Â  The District acknowledges its ownership of the sewer lines.Â  However, the District presented evidence at trial that denied it or its contractors installed or owned the aluminum pipe.Â  
It is the aluminum pipe that is the â€œimprovementâ€ alleged to have caused the Bundricksâ€™ damages.Â  Therefore, it is the ownership of the defective aluminum pipe that would trigger the section 15-3-670 exception.Â  Only if the District owned the aluminum pipe would it be barred from asserting the statute of repose as a defense.Â  
In finding against the Bundricks, the master rejected their argument that the District owned the aluminum pipe, which they allege was the culprit.Â  There is evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s conclusion that the District did not own the defective aluminum pipe.Â  Accordingly, the District is not barred by section 15-3-670 from asserting the statute of repose as a defense.
C.Â  Gross Negligence Exception
Finally, the Bundricks assert the District may not avail itself of the statute of repose because it was grossly negligent.Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. section 15-3-670 prohibits defendants from using the statute of repose if they engaged in grossly negligent conduct.Â  Simple negligence is the â€œfailure to exercise due care, while gross negligence is the failure to exercise slight care.â€Â  Clyburn v. Sumter County Sch. Dist. No. 17, 317 S.C. 50, 53, 451 S.E.2d 885, 887 (1994) (citations omitted).Â  
The exception contained in the statute of repose, by its strict terms, applies to grossly negligent conduct in connection with the construction of the improvement.Â  There is no evidence in the record that the sewer line itself was constructed in a negligent manner.Â  The fact that there was no complaint for a period in excess of fourteen years following the completion of this portion of the line belies an assertion of even simple negligence, much less gross negligence.
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
